34.13: Instead, you must destroy their altars and tear down the sacred poles they use in the worship of the goddess Asherah.
34.14: I demand your complete loyalty--you must not worship any other god!
34.15: Don't make treaties with the people there, or you will soon find yourselves worshiping their gods and taking part in their sacrificial meals.
34.16: Your men will even marry their women and be influenced to worship their gods.
34.17: Don't make metal images of gods.
34.18: Don't fail to observe the Festival of Thin Bread in the month of Abib. Obey me and eat bread without yeast for seven days during Abib, because that is the month you left Egypt.
34.19: The first-born males of your families and of your flocks and herds belong to me.
34.20: You can save the life of a first-born donkey by sacrificing a lamb; if you don't, you must break the donkey's neck. You must save every first-born son. Bring an offering every time you come to worship.
34.21: Work for six days and rest on the seventh day, even during the seasons for plowing and harvesting.
34.22: Celebrate the Harvest Festival each spring when you start harvesting your wheat, and celebrate the Festival of Shelters each autumn when you pick your fruit.
34.23: Your men must come to worship me three times a year, because I am the LORD God of Israel.
34.24: As you advance, I will force the nations out of your land and enlarge your borders. Then no one will try to take your property when you come to worship me these three times each year.
34.25: When you sacrifice an animal on the altar, don't offer bread made with yeast. And don't save any part of the Passover meal for the next day.
34.27: The LORD told Moses to put these laws in writing, as part of his agreement with Israel.
34.28: Moses stayed on the mountain with the LORD for 40 days and nights, without eating or drinking. And he wrote down the Ten Commandments, the most important part of God's agreement with his people.
34.29: Moses came down from Mount Sinai, carrying the Ten Commandments. His face was shining brightly because the LORD had been speaking to him. But Moses did not know at first that his face was shining.
34.30: When Aaron and the others looked at Moses, they saw this, and they were afraid to go near him.
34.31: Moses called out for Aaron and the leaders to come to him, and he spoke with them.
34.32: Then the rest of the people of Israel gathered around Moses, and he gave them the laws that the LORD had given him on Mount Sinai.
34.33: The face of Moses kept shining, and after he had spoken with the people, he covered his face with a veil.
34.34: Moses would always remove the veil when he went into the sacred tent to speak with the LORD. And when he came out, he would tell the people everything the LORD had told him to say.
34.35: They could see that his face was still shining. So after he had spoken with them, he would put the veil back on and leave it on until the next time he went to speak with the LORD.

35.1: Moses called together the people of Israel and told them that the LORD had said:
35.2: You have six days in which to do your work. But the seventh day must be dedicated to me, your LORD, as a day of rest. Whoever works on the Sabbath will be put to death.
35.3: Don't even build a cooking fire at home on the Sabbath.
35.4: Moses told the people of Israel that the LORD had said:
35.5: I will welcome an offering from anyone who wants to give something. You may bring gold, silver, or bronze;
35.6: blue, purple, or red wool; fine linen; goat hair;
35.7: tanned ram skin or fine leather; acacia wood;
35.8: olive oil for the lamp; sweet-smelling spices for the oil of dedication and for the incense; or
35.9: onyx stones or other gems for the sacred vest and breastpiece.
35.10: If you have any skills, you should use them to help make what I have commanded:
35.11: the sacred tent with its covering and hooks, its framework and crossbars, and its post and stands;
35.12: the sacred chest with its carrying poles, its place of mercy, and the curtain in front of it;
35.13: the table with its carrying poles and all that goes on it, including the sacred bread;
35.14: the lamp with its equipment and oil;
35.15: the incense altar with its carrying poles and sweet-smelling incense; the ordination oil; the curtain for the entrance to the sacred tent;
35.16: the altar for sacrifices with its bronze grating, its carrying poles, and its equipment; the large bronze bowl with its stand;
35.17: the curtains with the posts and stands that go around the courtyard and the curtain at the entrance;
35.18: the pegs and ropes for the tent and the courtyard;
35.19: and the finely woven priestly clothes for Aaron and his sons.
35.20: Moses finished speaking, and everyone left.
35.21: Then those who wanted to bring gifts to the LORD, brought them to be used for the sacred tent, the worship services, and the priestly clothes.
35.22: Men and women came willingly and gave all kinds of gold jewelry such as pins, earrings, rings, and necklaces.
35.23: Everyone brought their blue, purple, and red wool, their fine linen, and their cloth made of goat hair, as well as their ram skins dyed red and their fine leather.
35.24: Anyone who had silver or bronze or acacia wood brought it as a gift to the LORD.
35.25: The women who were good at weaving cloth brought the blue, purple, and red wool and the fine linen they had made.
35.26: And the women who knew how to make cloth from goat hair were glad to do so.
35.27: The leaders brought different kinds of jewels to be sewn on the special clothes and the breastpiece for the high priest.
35.28: They also brought sweet-smelling spices to be mixed with the incense and olive oil that were for the lamps and for ordaining the priests.
35.29: Moses had told the people what the LORD wanted them to do, and many of them decided to bring their gifts.
35.30: Moses said to the people of Israel: The LORD has chosen Bezalel of the Judah tribe.
35.34: The LORD is urging him and Oholiab from the tribe of Dan to teach others.
35.35: And he has given them all kinds of artistic skills, including the ability to design and embroider with blue, purple, and red wool and to weave fine linen.

36.1: The LORD has given to Bezalel, Oholiab, and others the skills needed for building a place of worship, and they will follow the LORD's instructions.
36.2: Then Moses brought together these workers who were eager to work,
36.3: and he gave them the gifts that the people of Israel had donated for building the place of worship. In fact, so much was being given each morning,
36.5: and said, "Moses, there is already more than we need for what the LORD has assigned us to do."
36.6: So Moses sent word for the people to stop giving, and they did.
36.7: But there was already more than enough to do what needed to be done.
36.10: and they were sewn together to make two curtains with five panels each.
36.16: These eleven sections were joined to make two panels, one with five and the other with six sections.
36.17: Fifty loops were put along one of the wider sides of each panel,
36.18: and the two panels were fastened at the loops with 50 bronze hooks.
36.19: Two other coverings were made--one with fine leather and the other with ram skins dyed red.
36.20: Acacia wood was used to build the framework for the walls of the sacred tent.
36.21: Each frame was 4 meters high and 66 centimeters wide
36.27: Six frames were used for the back wall along the west side
36.30: Altogether, along the back wall there were eight frames with two silver stands under each of them.
36.34: The frames and crossbars were covered with gold, and gold rings were attached to the frames to run the crossbars through.
36.35: They made the inside curtain of fine linen woven with blue, purple, and red wool, and embroidered with figures of winged creatures.
36.36: They also made four acacia wood posts and covered them with gold. Then gold rings were fastened to the posts, which were set on silver stands.
36.37: For the entrance to the tent, they used a curtain of fine linen woven with blue, purple, and red wool and embroidered with fancy needlework.
36.38: They made five posts, covered them completely with gold, and set each of them on a gold-covered bronze stand. Finally, they attached hooks for the curtain.

37.1: Bezalel built a chest of acacia wood 110 centimeters long, 66 centimeters wide, and 66 centimeters high.
37.2: He covered it inside and out with pure gold and put a gold edging around the top.
37.3: He made four gold rings and attached one of them to each of the four legs of the chest.
37.4: Then he made two poles of acacia wood, covered them with gold,
37.5: and put them through the rings, so the chest could be carried by the poles.
37.6: The entire lid of the chest, which was made of pure gold, was the place of mercy.
37.10: Bezalel built a table of acacia wood 88 centimeters long, 44 centimeters wide, and 66 centimeters high.
37.13: He made four gold rings and attached one to each of the legs
37.14: near the edging. The poles for carrying the table were placed through these rings
37.15: and were made of acacia wood covered with gold.
37.16: Everything that was to be set on the table was made of pure gold--the bowls, plates, jars, and cups for wine offerings.
37.17: Bezalel made a lampstand of pure gold. The whole lampstand, including its decorative flowers, was made from a single piece of hammered gold,
37.18: with three branches on each of its two sides.
37.19: There were three decorative almond blossoms on each branch
37.21: There was also a blossom where each pair of branches came out from the stem.
37.22: The lampstand, including its branches and decorative flowers, was made from a single piece of hammered pure gold.
37.25: For burning incense, Bezalel made an altar of acacia wood. It was 45 centimeters square and 90 centimeters high with each of its four corners sticking up like the horn of a bull.
37.26: He covered it with pure gold and put a gold edging around it.
37.27: Then below the edging on opposite sides he attached two gold rings through which he put the poles for carrying the altar.
37.28: These poles were also made of acacia wood and covered with gold.
37.29: Bezalel mixed the sacred oil for dedication and the pure spices for the sweet-smelling incense.

38.1: Bezalel built an altar of acacia wood for offering sacrifices. It was 2.25 meters square and 1.34 meters high
38.2: with each of its four corners sticking up like the horn of a bull, and it was completely covered with bronze.
38.3: The equipment for the altar was also made of bronze--the pans for the hot ashes, the shovels, the bowls, the meat forks, and the fire pans.
38.4: About halfway up the altar he built a ledge around it and covered the bottom half of the altar with a decorative bronze grating.
38.5: Then he attached a bronze ring beneath the ledge at the four corners to put the poles through.
38.6: He covered two acacia wood poles with bronze and
38.7: put them through the rings for carrying the altar, which was shaped like an open box.
38.8: Bezalel made a large bowl and a stand out of bronze from the mirrors of the women who helped at the entrance to the sacred tent.
38.20: The pegs for the tent and for the curtain around the tent were made of bronze.
38.24: According to the official weights, the amount of gold given was a ton,
38.25: and the silver that was collected when the people were counted came to 3.4 tons.
38.26: Everyone who was counted paid the required amount, and there was a total of 603,550 men who were 20 years old or older.
38.27: Thirty-four kilograms of the silver were used to make each of the 100 stands for the sacred tent and the curtain.
38.28: The remaining 30 kilograms of silver were used for the hooks and rods and for covering the tops of the posts.
38.29: Two thousand four hundred and twenty-five kilograms of bronze were given.
38.30: And it was used to make the stands for the entrance to the tent, the altar and its grating, the equipment for the altar,
38.31: the stands for the posts that surrounded the courtyard, including those at the entrance to the courtyard, and the pegs for the tent and the courtyard.

39.1: Beautiful priestly clothes were made of blue, purple, and red wool for Aaron to wear when he performed his duties in the holy place. This was done exactly as the LORD had commanded Moses.
39.6: Onyx stones were placed in gold settings, and each one was engraved with the name of one of Israel's sons.
39.7: Then these were attached to the shoulder straps of the vest, so the LORD would never forget his people. Everything was done exactly as the LORD had commanded Moses.
39.8: The breastpiece was made with the same materials and designs as the priestly vest.
39.9: It was 22 centimeters square and folded double
39.10: with four rows of three precious stones: A carnelian, a chrysolite, and an emerald were in the first row;
39.11: a turquoise, a sapphire, and a diamond were in the second row;
39.12: a jacinth, an agate, and an amethyst were in the third row;
39.13: and a beryl, an onyx, and a jasper were in the fourth row. They were mounted in a delicate gold setting,
39.14: and on each of them was engraved the name of one of the twelve tribes of Israel.
39.19: Two other gold rings were attached to the lower inside corners next to the vest,
39.20: and two more near the bottom of the shoulder straps right above the sash.
39.21: To keep the breastpiece in place, a blue cord was used to tie the two lower rings on the breastpiece to those on the vest. These things were done exactly as the LORD had commanded Moses.
39.22: The priestly robe was made of blue wool
39.23: with an opening in the center for the head. The material around the collar was bound so as to keep it from wearing out.
39.30: The words "Dedicated to the LORD" were engraved on a narrow strip of pure gold,
39.31: which was fastened to Aaron's turban. These things were done exactly as the LORD had commanded Moses.
39.32: So the people of Israel finished making everything the LORD had told Moses to make.
39.33: Then they brought it all to Moses: the sacred tent and its equipment, including the hooks, the framework and crossbars, and its posts and stands;
39.34: the covering of tanned ram skins and fine leather; the inside curtain;
39.35: the sacred chest with its carrying poles and the place of mercy;
39.36: the table with all that goes on it, including the sacred bread;
39.37: the lampstand of pure gold, together with its equipment and oil;
39.38: the gold-covered incense altar; the ordination oil and the sweet-smelling incense; the curtain for the entrance to the tent;
39.39: the bronze altar for sacrifices with its bronze grating, its carrying poles, and its equipment; the large bronze bowl with its stand;
39.40: the curtain with its posts and cords, and its pegs and stands that go around the courtyard; everything needed for the sacred tent;
39.41: and the finely woven priestly clothes for Aaron and his sons.

40.2: Set up my tent on the first day of the year
40.3: and put the chest with the Ten Commandments behind the inside curtain.
40.4: Bring in the table and set on it those things that are made for it. Also bring in the lampstand and attach the lamps to it.
40.5: Then place the gold altar of incense in front of the sacred chest and hang a curtain at the entrance to the tent.
40.6: Set the altar for burning sacrifices in front of the entrance to my tent.
40.7: Put the large bronze bowl between the tent and the altar and fill the bowl with water.
40.8: Surround the tent and the altar with the wall of curtains and hang the curtain that was made for the entrance.
40.9: Use the sacred olive oil to dedicate to me the tent and everything in it.
40.10: Do the same thing with the altar for offering sacrifices and its equipment
40.11: and with the bowl and its stand.
40.12: Bring Aaron and his sons to the entrance of the tent and tell them to wash themselves.
40.13: Dress Aaron in the priestly clothes, then use the sacred olive oil to ordain him and dedicate him to me as my priest.
40.14: Put the priestly robes on Aaron's sons
40.15: and ordain them in the same way, so they and their descendants will always be my priests.
40.17: And on the first day of the first month of the second year, the sacred tent was set up.
40.18: The posts, stands, and framework were put in place,
40.19: then the two layers of coverings were hung over them.
40.20: The stones with the Ten Commandments written on them were stored in the sacred chest, the place of mercy was put on top of it, and the carrying poles were attached.
40.21: The chest was brought into the tent and set behind the curtain in the most holy place. These things were done exactly as the LORD had commanded Moses.
40.22: The table for the sacred bread was put along the north wall of the holy place,
40.23: after which the bread was set on the table.
40.24: The lampstand was put along the south wall,
40.25: then the lamps were attached to it there in the presence of the LORD.
40.26: The gold incense altar was set up in front of the curtain,
40.27: and sweet-smelling incense was burned on it. These things were done exactly as the LORD had commanded Moses.
40.28: The curtain was hung at the entrance to the sacred tent.
40.29: Then the altar for offering sacrifices was put in front of the tent, and animal sacrifices and gifts of grain were offered there.
40.30: The large bronze bowl was placed between the altar and the entrance to the tent. It was filled with water,
40.31: then Moses and Aaron, together with Aaron's sons, washed their hands and feet.
40.32: In fact, they washed each time before entering the tent or offering sacrifices at the altar. These things were done exactly as the LORD had commanded Moses.
40.33: Finally, Moses had the curtains hung around the courtyard and at the entrance.
40.34: Suddenly the sacred tent was covered by a thick cloud and filled with the glory of the LORD.
40.35: And so, Moses could not enter the tent.
40.36: Whenever the cloud moved from the tent, the people would break camp and follow;
40.37: then they would set up camp and stay there, until it moved again.
40.38: No matter where the people traveled, the LORD was with them. Each day his cloud was over the tent, and each night a fire could be seen in the cloud.

1.4: Lay your hand on its head, and I will accept the animal as a sacrifice for taking away your sins.
1.5: After the bull is killed in my presence, some priests from Aaron's family will offer its blood to me by splattering it against the four sides of the altar.
1.6: Skin the bull and cut it up,
1.7: while the priests pile wood on the altar fire to make it start blazing.
1.10: If you sacrifice a ram or a goat, it must not have anything wrong with it.
1.11: Lead the animal to the north side of the altar, where it is to be killed in my presence. Then some of the priests will splatter its blood against the four sides of the altar.
1.14: If you offer a bird for this kind of sacrifice, it must be a dove or a pigeon.
1.15: A priest will take the bird to the bronze altar, where he will wring its neck and put its head on the fire. Then he will drain out its blood on one side of the altar,
1.16: remove the bird's craw with what is in it, and throw them on the ash heap at the east side of the altar.
1.17: Finally, he will take the bird by its wings, tear it partially open, and send it up in smoke with a smell that pleases me.

2.1: When you offer sacrifices to give thanks to me, you must use only your finest flour. Put it in a dish, sprinkle olive oil and incense on the flour,
2.2: and take it to the priests from Aaron's family. One of them will scoop up the incense together with a handful of the flour and oil. Then, to show that the whole offering belongs to me, the priest will lay this part on the bronze altar and send it up in smoke with a smell that pleases me.
2.3: The rest of this sacrifice is for the priests; it is very holy because it was offered to me.
2.4: If you bake bread in an oven for this sacrifice, use only your finest flour, but without any yeast. You may make the flour into a loaf mixed with olive oil, or you may make it into thin wafers and brush them with oil.
2.5: If you cook bread in a shallow pan for this sacrifice, use only your finest flour. Mix it with olive oil, but do not use any yeast.
2.6: Then break the bread into small pieces and sprinkle them with oil.
2.7: If you cook your bread in a pan with a lid on it, you must also use the finest flour mixed with oil.
2.8: You may prepare sacrifices to give thanks in any of these three ways. Bring your sacrifice to a priest, and he will take it to the bronze altar.
2.9: Then, to show that the whole offering belongs to me, the priest will lay part of it on the altar and send it up in smoke with a smell that pleases me.
2.10: The rest of this sacrifice is for the priests; it is very holy because it was offered to me.
2.11: Yeast and honey must never be burned on the altar, so don't ever mix either of these in a grain sacrifice.
2.12: You may offer either of them separately, when you present the first part of your harvest to me, but they must never be burned on the altar.
2.13: Salt is offered when you make an agreement with me, so sprinkle salt on these sacrifices.
2.14: Freshly cut grain, either roasted or coarsely ground, must be used when you offer the first part of your grain harvest.
2.15: You must mix in some olive oil and put incense on top, because this is a grain sacrifice.
2.16: A priest will sprinkle all of the incense and some of the grain and oil on the altar and send them up in smoke to show that the whole offering belongs to me.

3.1: When you offer sacrifices to ask my blessing, you may offer either a bull or a cow, but there must be nothing wrong with the animal.
3.2: Lead it to the entrance of the sacred tent, lay your hand on its head, and have it killed there. A priest from Aaron's family will splatter its blood against the four sides of the altar.
3.3: Offer all of the fat on the animal's insides,
3.4: as well as the lower part of the liver and the two kidneys with their fat.
3.5: Some of the priests will lay these pieces on the altar and send them up in smoke with a smell that pleases me, together with the sacrifice that is offered to please me.
3.6: Instead of a bull or a cow, you may offer any sheep or goat that has nothing wrong with it.
3.7: If you offer a sheep, you must present it to me at the entrance to the sacred tent.
3.8: Lay your hand on its head and have it killed there. A priest will then splatter its blood against the four sides of the altar.
3.9: Offer the fat on the tail, the tailbone, and the insides,
3.10: as well as the lower part of the liver and the two kidneys with their fat.
3.11: One of the priests will lay these pieces on the altar and send them up in smoke as a food offering for me.
3.12: If you offer a goat, you must also present it to me
3.13: at the entrance to the sacred tent. Lay your hand on its head and have it killed there. A priest will then splatter its blood against the four sides of the altar.
3.14: Offer all of the fat on the animal's insides,
3.15: as well as the lower part of the liver and the two kidneys with their fat.
3.16: One of the priests will put these pieces on the altar and send them up in smoke as a food offering with a smell that pleases me. All fat belongs to me.
3.17: So you and your descendants must never eat any fat or any blood, not even in the privacy of your own homes. This law will never change.

4.1: The LORD told Moses
4.2: to say to the community of Israel: Offer a sacrifice to ask forgiveness when you sin by accidentally doing something I have told you not to do.
4.3: When the high priest sins, he makes everyone else guilty too. And so, he must sacrifice a young bull that has nothing wrong with it.
4.4: The priest will lead the bull to the entrance of the sacred tent, lay his hand on its head, and kill it there.
4.5: He will take a bowl of the blood inside the tent,
4.6: dip a finger in the blood, and sprinkle some of it seven times toward the sacred chest behind the curtain.
4.7: Then, in my presence, he will smear some of the blood on each of the four corners of the incense altar, before pouring out the rest at the foot of the bronze altar near the entrance to the tent.
4.13: When the nation of Israel disobeys me without meaning to, the whole nation is still guilty.
4.14: Once you realize what has happened, you must sacrifice a young bull to ask my forgiveness. Lead the bull to the entrance of the sacred tent,
4.15: where your tribal leaders will lay their hands on its head, before having it killed in my presence.
4.16: The priest will take a bowl of the animal's blood inside the sacred tent,
4.17: dip a finger in the blood, and sprinkle some of it seven times toward the sacred chest behind the curtain.
4.18: Then, in my presence, he must smear some of the blood on each of the four corners of the incense altar, before pouring out the rest at the foot of the bronze altar near the entrance to the tent.
4.22: Any tribal leader who disobeys me without knowing it is still guilty.
4.23: As soon as the leader realizes what has happened, he must sacrifice a goat that has nothing wrong with it.
4.24: This is a sacrifice for sin. So he will lay his hand on the animal's head, before having it killed in my presence at the north side of the bronze altar.
4.25: The priest will dip a finger in the blood, smear some of it on each of the four corners of the altar, and pour out the rest at the foot of the altar.
4.26: Then he must send all of the fat up in smoke, just as he does when a sacrifice is offered to ask my blessing. By this sacrifice the leader's sin will be forgiven.
4.27: When any of you ordinary people disobey me without meaning to, you are still guilty.
4.28: As soon as you realize what you have done, you must sacrifice a female goat that has nothing wrong with it.
4.29: Lead the goat to the north side of the bronze altar and lay your hand on its head, before having it killed.
4.30: Then a priest will dip a finger in the blood; he will smear some of it on each of the four corners of the altar and pour out the rest at the foot of the altar.
4.31: After this, the priest will remove all of the fat, just as he does when an animal is sacrificed to ask my blessing. The priest will then send the fat up in smoke with a smell that pleases me. This animal is sacrificed so that I will forgive you ordinary people when you sin.
4.32: If you offer a lamb instead of a goat as a sacrifice for sin, it must be a female that has nothing wrong with it.
4.33: Lead the lamb to the altar and lay your hand on its head, before having it killed.
4.34: The priest will dip a finger in the blood, smear some of it on each of the four corners of the altar, and pour out the rest at the foot of the altar.
4.35: After this, all of the fat must be removed, just as when an animal is sacrificed to ask my blessing. Then the priest will send it up in smoke to me, together with a food offering, and your sin will be forgiven.

5.1: If you refuse to testify in court about something you saw or know has happened, you have sinned and can be punished.
5.2: You are guilty and unfit to worship me, if you accidentally touch the dead body of any kind of unclean animal.
5.3: You are guilty if you find out that you have accidentally touched anything unclean that comes from a human body.
5.4: You are guilty the moment you realize that you have made a hasty promise to do something good or bad.
5.5: As soon as you discover that you have committed any of these sins, you must confess what you have done.
5.6: Then you must bring a female sheep or goat to me as the price for your sin. A priest will sacrifice the animal, and you will be forgiven.
5.8: Give both birds to the priest, who will offer one as a sacrifice to ask my forgiveness. He will wring its neck without tearing off its head,
5.9: splatter some of its blood on one side of the bronze altar, and drain out the rest at the foot of the altar.
5.10: Then he will follow the proper rules for offering the other bird as a sacrifice to please me. You will be forgiven when the priest offers these sacrifices as the price for your sin.
5.11: If you are so poor that you cannot afford doves or pigeons, you may bring one kilogram of your finest flour. This is a sacrifice to ask my forgiveness, so don't sprinkle olive oil or sweet-smelling incense on it.
5.12: Give the flour to a priest, who will scoop up a handful and send it up in smoke together with the other offerings. This is a reminder that all of the flour belongs to me.
5.13: By offering this sacrifice, the priest pays the price for any of these sins you may have committed. The priest gets to keep the rest of the flour, just as he does with grain sacrifices.
5.16: In addition, you must pay what you owe plus a fine of 20 percent. Then the priest will offer the ram as a sacrifice to make things right, and you will be forgiven.

6.4: When this happens, you must return what doesn't belong to you
6.5: and pay the owner a fine of 20 percent.
6.10: The next morning you will dress in your priestly clothes, including your linen underwear. Then clean away the ashes left by the sacrifices and pile them beside the altar.
6.11: Change into your everyday clothes, take the ashes outside the camp, and pile them in the special place.
6.12: The fire must never go out, so put wood on it each morning. After this, you are to lay an animal on the altar next to the fat that you sacrifice to ask my blessing. Then send it all up in smoke to me.
6.13: The altar fire must always be kept burning--it must never go out.
6.14: When someone offers a sacrifice to give thanks to me, the priests from Aaron's family must bring it to the front of the bronze altar,
6.15: where one of them will scoop up a handful of the flour and oil, together with all the incense on it. Then, to show that the whole offering belongs to me, he will lay all of this on the altar and send it up in smoke with a smell that pleases me.
6.18: Only the men in Aaron's family are allowed to eat this bread, and they must go through a ceremony to be made holy before touching it. This law will never change.
6.19: The LORD spoke to Moses
6.20: and told him what sacrifices the priests must offer on the morning and evening of the day they are ordained: It is the same as the regular morning and evening sacrifices--half a kilogram of flour
6.21: mixed with olive oil and cooked in a shallow pan. The bread must then be crumbled into small pieces and sent up in smoke with a smell that pleases me.
6.25: how the priests from Aaron's family were to offer the sacrifice for sin: This sacrifice is very sacred, and the animal must be killed in my presence at the north side of the bronze altar.
6.26: The priest who offers this sacrifice must eat it in the sacred courtyard of the sacred tent,
6.27: and anyone or anything that touches the meat will be holy. If any of the animal's blood is splattered on the clothes of the priest, they must be washed in a holy place.
6.28: If the meat was cooked in a clay pot, the pot must be destroyed, but if it was cooked in a bronze pot, the pot must be scrubbed and rinsed with water.
6.29: This sacrifice is very holy, and only the priests may have any part of it.
6.30: None of the meat may be eaten from the sacrifices for sin that require blood to be brought into the sacred tent. These sacrifices must be completely burned.

7.1: The sacrifice to make things right is very sacred.
7.2: The animal must be killed in the same place where the sacrifice to please me is killed, and the animal's blood must be splattered against the four sides of the bronze altar.
7.3: Offer all of the animal's fat, including the fat on its tail and on its insides,
7.4: as well as the lower part of the liver and the two kidneys with their fat.
7.5: One of the priests will lay these pieces on the altar and send them up in smoke to me.
7.6: This sacrifice for making things right is very holy. Only the priests may eat it, and they must eat it in a holy place.
7.7: The ceremony for this sacrifice and the one for sin are the same, and the meat may be eaten only by the priest who performs this ceremony of forgiveness.
7.8: In fact, the priest who offers a sacrifice to please me may keep the skin of the animal,
7.9: just as he may eat the bread from a sacrifice to give thanks to me.
7.10: All other grain sacrifices--with or without olive oil in them--are to be divided equally among the priests of Aaron's family.
7.11: Here are the instructions for offering a sacrifice to ask my blessing:
7.12: If you offer it to give thanks, you must offer some bread together with it. Use the finest flour to make three kinds of bread without yeast--two in the form of loaves mixed with olive oil and one in the form of thin wafers brushed with oil.
7.13: You must also make some bread with yeast.
7.14: Give me one loaf or wafer from each of these four kinds of bread, after which they will belong to the priest who splattered the blood against the bronze altar.
7.15: When you offer an animal to ask a blessing from me or to thank me, the meat belongs to you, but it must be eaten the same day.
7.16: It is different with the sacrifices you offer when you make me a promise or voluntarily give me something. The meat from those sacrifices may be kept and eaten the next day,
7.19: Don't eat any of the meat that has touched something unclean. Instead, burn it. The rest of the meat may be eaten by anyone who is clean and acceptable to me.
7.22: The LORD told Moses
7.23: to say to the people: Don't eat the fat of cattle, sheep, or goats.
7.24: If one of your animals dies or is killed by some wild animal, you may do anything with its fat except eat it.
7.25: If you eat the fat of an animal that can be used as a sacrifice to me, you will no longer belong to the community of Israel.
7.26: And no matter where you live, you must not eat the blood of any bird or animal,
7.27: or you will no longer belong to the community of Israel.
7.31: A priest from Aaron's family will then send the fat up in smoke, but the ribs belong to the priests.
7.34: I have decided that the people of Israel must always give the choice ribs and the upper joint of the right hind leg to Aaron's descendants
7.35: who have been ordained as priests to serve me.
7.36: This law will never change. I am the LORD!
7.37: These are the ceremonies for sacrifices to please the LORD, to give him thanks, and to ask for his blessing or his forgiveness, as well as the ceremonies for those sacrifices that demand a payment and for the sacrifices that are offered when priests are ordained.
7.38: While Moses and the people of Israel were in the desert at Mount Sinai, the LORD commanded them to start offering these sacrifices.

8.1: The LORD said to Moses:
8.2: Send for Aaron and his sons, as well as their priestly clothes, the oil for ordination, the bull for the sin offering, the two rams, and a basket of bread made without yeast.

8.4: Moses obeyed the LORD, and when everyone had come together,
8.5: he said, "We are here to follow the LORD's instructions."
8.6: After Moses told Aaron and his sons to step forward, he told them to wash themselves.
8.7: He put the priestly shirt and robe on Aaron and wrapped the sash around his waist. Then he put the sacred vest on Aaron and fastened it with the finely woven belt.
8.8: Next, he put on Aaron the sacred breastpiece that was used in finding out what the LORD wanted his people to do.
8.9: He placed the turban on Aaron's head, and on the front of the turban was the narrow strip of thin gold as a sign of his dedication to the LORD.

8.14: Moses led out the bull that was to be sacrificed for sin, and Aaron and his sons laid their hands on its head.
8.15: After it was killed, Moses dipped a finger in the blood and smeared some of it on each of the four corners of the bronze altar, before pouring out the rest at the foot of the altar. This purified the altar and made it a fit place for offering the sacrifice for sin.
8.16: Moses then took the fat on the bull's insides, as well as the lower part of the liver and the two kidneys with their fat, and sent them up in smoke on the altar fire.
8.17: Finally, he took the skin and the flesh of the bull, together with the food still in its stomach, and burned them outside the camp, just as the LORD had commanded.
8.18: Moses led out the ram for the sacrifice to please the LORD. After Aaron and his sons had laid their hands on its head,
8.19: Moses killed the ram and splattered its blood against the four sides of the altar.
8.22: Moses led out the ram for the ceremony of ordination. Aaron and his sons laid their hands on its head,
8.23: and it was killed. Moses smeared some of its blood on Aaron's right earlobe, some on his right thumb, and some on the big toe of his right foot.

8.25: He took the animal's fat tail, the fat on its insides, and the lower part of the liver and the two kidneys with their fat, and the right hind leg.
8.26: Then he took from a basket some of each of the three kinds of bread that had been made without yeast and had been dedicated to the LORD.
8.27: Moses placed the bread on top of the meat and gave it all to Aaron and his sons, who lifted it up to show that it was dedicated to the LORD.
8.28: After this, Moses placed it on the fires of the altar and sent it up in smoke with a smell that pleased the LORD. This was part of the ordination ceremony.
8.29: Moses lifted up the choice ribs of the ram to show that they were dedicated to the LORD. This was the part that the LORD had said Moses could have.
8.30: Finally, Moses sprinkled the priestly clothes of Aaron and his sons with some of the oil for ordination and with some of the blood from the altar. So Aaron and his sons, together with their priestly clothes, were dedicated to the LORD.
8.33: and stay near the entrance to the sacred tent until the ordination ceremony ends seven days from now.
8.34: We have obeyed the LORD in everything that has been done today, so that your sins may be forgiven.
8.35: The LORD has told me that you must stay near the entrance to the tent for seven days and nights, or else you will die.
8.36: Aaron and his sons obeyed everything that the LORD had told Moses they must do.

9.1: Eight days later Moses called together Aaron, his sons, and Israel's leaders.
9.2: Then he said to Aaron: Find a young bull and a ram that have nothing wrong with them. Offer the bull to the LORD as a sacrifice for sin and the ram as a sacrifice to please him.
9.3: Tell the people of Israel that they must offer sacrifices as well. They must offer a goat as a sacrifice for sin, and a bull and a ram as a sacrifice to please the LORD. The bull and the ram must be a year old and have nothing wrong with them.
9.4: Then the people must offer a bull and a ram as a sacrifice to ask the LORD's blessing and also a grain sacrifice mixed with oil. Do this, because the LORD will appear to you today.
9.5: After the animals and the grain had been brought to the front of the sacred tent, and the people were standing there in the presence of the LORD,
9.6: Moses said: The LORD has ordered you to do this, so that he may appear to you in all of his glory.
9.8: Aaron stepped up to the altar and killed the bull that was to be the sacrifice for his sins.
9.9: His sons brought him the blood. He dipped a finger in it, smeared some on the four corners of the bronze altar, and poured out the rest at its foot.
9.10: But he sent up in smoke the fat, the kidneys, and the lower part of the liver, just as the LORD had commanded Moses.
9.11: Then Aaron burned the skin and the flesh outside the camp.
9.12: After Aaron had killed the ram that was sacrificed to please the LORD, Aaron's sons brought him the blood, and he splattered it against all four sides of the altar.
9.13: They brought him each piece of the animal, including the head, and he burned them all on the altar.
9.14: He washed the insides and the hind legs and also sent them up in smoke.
9.15: Next, Aaron sacrificed the goat for the sins of the people, as he had done with the sacrifice for his own sins.
9.16: And so, he burned this sacrifice on the altar in the proper way.
9.17: He also presented the grain sacrifice and burned a handful of the flour on the altar as part of the morning sacrifice.
9.18: Finally, he killed the bull and the ram as a sacrifice to ask the LORD's blessing on the people. Aaron's sons brought him the blood, and he splattered it against the four sides of the altar.
9.19: His sons placed all the fat, as well as the kidneys and the lower part of the liver
9.20: on top of the choice ribs.
9.21: Then Aaron burned the fat on the altar and lifted up the ribs and the right hind leg to show that these were dedicated to the LORD. This was done just as the LORD had instructed Moses.
9.22: Aaron held out his hand and gave the people his blessing, before coming down from the bronze altar where he had offered the sacrifices.
9.23: He and Moses went into the sacred tent, and when they came out, they gave the people their blessing. Then the LORD appeared to the people in all of his glory.
9.24: The LORD sent fiery flames that burned up everything on the altar, and when everyone saw this, they shouted and fell to their knees to worship the LORD.

10.1: Nadab and Abihu were two of Aaron's sons, but they disobeyed the LORD by burning incense to him on a fire pan, when they were not supposed to.
10.2: Suddenly the LORD sent fiery flames and burned them to death.
10.5: So they dragged the dead men away by their clothes.
10.7: But you are the LORD's chosen priests, and you must not leave the sacred tent, or you will die. Aaron and his two sons obeyed Moses.
10.8: The LORD said to Aaron:
10.9: When you or your sons enter the sacred tent, you must never drink beer or wine. If you do, you will die right there! This law will never change.
10.10: You must learn the difference between what is holy and what isn't holy and between the clean and the unclean.
10.11: You must also teach the people of Israel everything that I commanded Moses to say to them.
10.12: Moses told Aaron and his two sons, Eleazar and Ithamar: The grain sacrifice that was offered to give thanks to the LORD is very holy. So make bread without yeast from the part that wasn't sent up in smoke and eat it beside the altar.
10.13: The LORD has said that this belongs to you and your sons, and that it must be eaten in a holy place.
10.16: When Moses asked around and learned that the ram for the sin sacrifice had already been burned on the altar, he became angry with Eleazar and Ithamar and said,
10.17: "Why didn't you eat the meat from this sacrifice in an acceptable place? It is very holy, and the LORD has given you this sacrifice to remove Israel's sin and guilt.
10.18: Whenever an animal's blood isn't brought into the sacred tent, I commanded you to eat its meat in an acceptable place, but you burned it instead."
10.19: Their father Aaron replied, "Today two of my sons offered the sacrifice for sin and the sacrifice to please the LORD, and look what has happened to me! Would the LORD have approved if I had eaten the sacrifice for sin?"
10.20: Moses was satisfied with Aaron's reply.

11.1: The LORD told Moses and Aaron
11.2: to say to the community of Israel: You may eat
11.3: any animal that has divided hoofs and chews the cud.
11.31: Anyone who touches their dead bodies or anything touched by their dead bodies becomes unclean until evening.
11.32: If something made of wood, cloth, or leather touches one of their dead bodies, it must be washed, but it is still unclean until evening.
11.33: If any of these animals is found dead in a clay pot, the pot must be broken to pieces, and everything in it becomes unclean.
11.34: If you pour water from this pot on any food, that food becomes unclean, and anything drinkable in the pot becomes unclean.
11.35: If the dead body of one of these animals touches anything else, including ovens and stoves, that thing becomes unclean and must be destroyed.
11.36: A spring or a cistern where one of these dead animals is found is still clean, but anyone who touches the animal becomes unclean.
11.37: If the dead body of one of these animals is found lying on seeds that have been set aside for planting, the seeds remain clean.
11.38: But seeds that are soaking in water become unclean, if the dead animal is found in the water.
11.39: If an animal that may be eaten happens to die, and you touch it, you become unclean until evening.
11.40: If you eat any of its meat or carry its body away, you must wash your clothes, but you are still unclean until evening.
11.43: If you eat any of them, you will become just as disgusting and unclean as they are.
11.44: I am the LORD your God, and you must dedicate yourselves to me and be holy, just as I am holy. Don't become disgusting by eating any of these unclean creatures.
11.45: I brought you out of Egypt so that I could be your God. Now you must become holy, because I am holy!

12.1: The LORD told Moses
12.2: to say to the community of Israel: If a woman gives birth to a son, she is unclean for seven days, just as she is during her monthly period.
12.3: Her son must be circumcised on the eighth day,
12.4: but her loss of blood keeps her from being completely clean for another 33 days. During this time she must not touch anything holy or go to the place of worship.
12.5: Any woman who gives birth to a daughter is unclean for two weeks, just as she is during her period. And she won't be completely clean for another 66 days.
12.6: When the mother has completed her time of cleansing, she must come to the front of the sacred tent and bring to the priest a year-old lamb as a sacrifice to please me and a dove or a pigeon as a sacrifice for sin.
12.7: After the priest offers the sacrifices to me, the mother will become completely clean from her loss of blood, whether her child is a boy or a girl.
12.8: If she cannot afford a lamb, she can offer two doves or two pigeons, one as a sacrifice to please me and the other as a sacrifice for sin.

13.1: The LORD told Moses and Aaron to say to the people:
13.2: If sores or boils or a skin rash should break out and start spreading on your body, you must be brought to Aaron or to one of the other priests.
13.3: If the priest discovers that the hair in the infected area has turned white and that the infection seems more than skin deep, he will say, "This is leprosy--you are unclean."
13.4: But if the infected area is white and only skin deep, and if the hair in it hasn't turned white, the priest will order you to stay away from everyone else for seven days.
13.5: If the disease hasn't spread by that time, he will order you to stay away from everyone else for another seven days.
13.6: Then if the disease hasn't become any worse or spread, the priest will say, "You are clean. It is only a sore. After you wash your clothes, you may go home."
13.7: However, if the disease comes back, you must return to the priest.
13.8: If it is discovered that the disease has started spreading, he will say, "This is leprosy--you are unclean."
13.9: Any of you with a skin disease must be brought to a priest.
13.10: If he discovers that the sore spot is white with pus and that the hair around it has also turned white,
13.11: he will say, "This is leprosy. You are unclean and must stay away from everyone else."
13.20: If he discovers that the hair in the infected area has turned white and that the infection seems more than skin deep, he will say, "This is leprosy--you are unclean."
13.21: But if the white area is only on the surface of the skin and hasn't become any worse, and if the hair in it hasn't turned white, he will tell you to stay away from everyone else for seven days.
13.22: If the sore begins spreading during this time, the priest will say, "You are unclean because you have a disease."
13.23: But if it doesn't spread, and only a scar remains, he will say, "You are now clean."
13.24: If you have a burn that gets infected and turns red or reddish-white,
13.25: a priest must examine it. Then if he discovers that the hair in the infected area has turned white and that the infection seems more than skin deep, he will say, "The burn has turned into leprosy, and you are unclean."
13.26: But if the priest finds that the hair in the infected area hasn't turned white and that the sore is only skin deep and it is healing, he will tell you to stay away from everyone else for seven days.
13.27: On the seventh day the priest will examine you again, and if the infection is spreading, he will say, "This is leprosy--you are unclean."
13.28: However, if the infection hasn't spread and has begun to heal, and if only a scar remains, he will say, "Only a scar remains from the burn, and you are clean."
13.29: If you have a sore on your head or chin,
13.30: it must be examined by a priest. If the infection seems more than skin deep, and the hair in it has thinned out and lost its color, he will say, "This is leprosy--you are unclean."
13.31: On the other hand, if he discovers that the itchy spot is only skin deep, but that the hair still isn't healthy, he will order you to stay away from everyone else for seven days.
13.32: By that time, if the itch hasn't spread, if the hair seems healthy, and if the itch is only skin deep,
13.33: you must shave off the hair around the infection, but not those on it. Then the priest will tell you to stay away from everyone else for another seven days.
13.34: By that time, if the itch hasn't spread and seems no more than skin deep, he will say, "You are clean; now you must wash your clothes."
13.37: But if he thinks you are completely well, he will say, "You are clean."
13.38: If white spots break out on your skin,
13.39: but the priest discovers that it is only a rash, he will say, "You are clean."
13.46: As long as you have the disease, you are unclean and must live alone outside the camp.
13.51: and if the mildew has spread in that time, he will say, "This is unclean
13.52: because the mildew has spread." Then he will burn the clothing or the piece of leather.
13.54: he will tell you to wash the clothing or leather and put it aside for another seven days,
13.55: after which he will examine it again. If the spot hasn't spread, but is still greenish or reddish, the clothing or leather is unclean and must be burned.
13.56: But if the spot has faded after being washed, he will tear away the spot.
13.57: Later, if the spot reappears elsewhere on the clothing or the leather, you must burn it.
13.58: Even if the spot completely disappears after being washed, it must be washed again before it is clean.
13.59: These are the rules for deciding if clothing is clean or unclean after a spot appears on it.

14.1: The LORD told Moses to say to the people:
14.4: he will order someone to bring out two live birds that are acceptable for sacrifice, together with a stick of cedar wood, a piece of red yarn, and a branch from a hyssop plant.
14.5: The priest will order someone to kill one of the birds over a clay pot of spring water.
14.6: Then he will dip the other bird, the cedar, the red yarn, and the hyssop in the blood of the dead bird.
14.7: Next, he will sprinkle you seven times with the blood and say, "You are now clean." Finally, he will release the bird and let it fly away.
14.8: After this you must wash your clothes, shave your entire body, and take a bath before you are completely clean. You may move back into camp, but you must not enter your tent for seven days.
14.9: Then you must once again shave your head, face, and eyebrows, as well as the hair on the rest of your body. Finally, wash your clothes and take a bath, and you will be completely clean.
14.10: On the eighth day you must bring to the priest two rams and a year-old female lamb that have nothing wrong with them; also bring 300 milliliters of olive oil and 3 kilograms of your finest flour mixed with oil.
14.11: Then the priest will present you and your offerings to me at the entrance to my sacred tent.
14.12: There he will offer one of the rams, together with the oil, as a sacrifice to make things right. He will also lift them up to show that they are dedicated to me.
14.13: This sacrifice is very holy. It belongs to the priest and must be killed in the same place where animals are killed as sacrifices for sins and as sacrifices to please me.
14.14: The priest will smear some of the blood from this sacrifice on your right ear lobe, some on your right thumb, and some on the big toe of your right foot.
14.15: He will then pour some of the olive oil into the palm of his left hand,
14.16: dip a finger of his right hand into the oil, and sprinkle some of it seven times toward the sacred tent.
14.17: Next, the priest will smear some of the oil on your right ear lobe, some on your right thumb, and some on the big toe of your right foot,
14.21: If you are poor and cannot afford to offer this much, you may offer a ram as a sacrifice to make things right, together with 300 milliliters of olive oil and one kilogram of flour mixed with oil as a grain sacrifice. The priest will then lift these up to dedicate them to me.
14.22: Depending on what you can afford, you must also offer either two doves or two pigeons, one as a sacrifice for sin and the other as a sacrifice to please me.
14.23: The priest will offer these to me in front of the sacred tent on the eighth day.
14.26: The priest will pour some of the olive oil into the palm of his left hand,
14.27: then dip a finger of his right hand in the oil and sprinkle some of it seven times toward the sacred tent.
14.28: He will smear some of the oil on your right ear lobe, some on your right thumb, and some on the big toe of your right foot, just as he did with the blood of the sacrifice to make things right.
14.32: These are the things you must do if you have leprosy and cannot afford the usual sacrifices to make you clean.
14.33: The LORD told Moses and Aaron to say to the people:
14.34: After I have given you the land of Canaan as your permanent possession, here is what you must do, if I ever put mildew on the walls of any of your homes.
14.35: First, you must say to a priest, "I think there is mildew on the wall of my house."
14.36: The priest will reply, "Empty the house before I inspect it, or else everything in it will be unclean."
14.37: If the priest discovers greenish or reddish spots that go deeper than the surface of the walls,
14.38: he will have the house closed for seven days.
14.39: Then he will return and check to see if the mildew has spread.
14.42: Afterwards the wall must be repaired with new stones and fresh plaster.
14.43: If the mildew appears a second time,
14.44: the priest will come and say, "This house is unclean. It's covered with mildew that can't be removed."
14.45: Then he will have the house torn down and every bit of wood, stone, and plaster hauled off to an unclean place outside the town.
14.46: Meanwhile, if any of you entered the house while it was closed, you will be unclean until evening.
14.47: And if you either slept or ate in the house, you must wash your clothes.
14.48: On the other hand, if the priest discovers that mildew hasn't reappeared after the house was newly plastered, he will say, "This house is clean--the mildew has gone."
14.49: Then, to show that the house is now clean, he will get two birds, a stick of cedar wood, a piece of red yarn, and a branch from a hyssop plant and bring them to the house.
14.50: He will kill one of the birds over a clay pot of spring water
14.53: Finally, he will release the bird and let it fly away, ending the ceremony for purifying the house.

15.1: The LORD told Moses and Aaron
15.2: to say to the community of Israel: Any man with an infected penis is unclean,
15.3: whether it is stopped up or keeps dripping.
15.8: If you are spit on by the man, you must wash your clothes and take a bath, but you still remain unclean until evening.
15.11: If the man touches you without first washing his hands, you must wash your clothes and take a bath, but you still remain unclean until evening.
15.12: Any clay pot that he touches must be destroyed, and any wooden bowl that he touches must be washed.
15.13: Seven days after the man gets well, he will be considered clean, if he washes his clothes and takes a bath in spring water.
15.14: On the eighth day he must bring either two doves or two pigeons to the front of my sacred tent and give them to a priest.
15.15: The priest will offer one of the birds as a sacrifice for sin and the other as a sacrifice to please me, then I will consider the man completely clean.
15.16: Any man who has a flow of semen must take a bath, but he still remains unclean until evening.
15.17: If the semen touches anything made of cloth or leather, these must be washed, but they still remain unclean until evening.
15.18: After having sex, both the man and the woman must take a bath, but they still remain unclean until evening.
15.19: When a woman has her monthly period, she remains unclean for seven days, and if you touch her, you must take a bath, but you remain unclean until evening.
15.24: Any man who has sex with her during this time becomes unclean for seven days, and anything he rests on is also unclean.
15.25: Any woman who has a flow of blood outside her regular monthly period is unclean until it stops, just as she is during her monthly period.
15.26: Anything that she rests on or sits on during this time is also unclean, just as it would be during her period.
15.27: If you touch either of these, you must wash your clothes and take a bath, but you still remain unclean until evening.
15.28: Seven days after the woman gets well, she will be considered clean.
15.29: On the eighth day, she must bring either two doves or two pigeons to the front of my sacred tent and give them to a priest.
15.30: He will offer one of the birds as a sacrifice for sin and the other as a sacrifice to please me; then I will consider the woman completely clean.
15.31: When any of you are unclean, you must stay away from the rest of the community of Israel. Otherwise, my sacred tent will become unclean, and the whole nation will die.

16.3: Before entering this most holy place, you must offer a bull as a sacrifice for your sins and a ram as a sacrifice to please me.
16.4: You will take a bath and put on the sacred linen clothes, including the underwear, the robe, the sash, and the turban.
16.5: Then the community of Israel will bring you a ram and two goats, both of them males. The goats are to be used as sacrifices for sin, and the ram is to be used as a sacrifice to please me.
16.6: Aaron, you must offer the bull as a sacrifice of forgiveness for your own sins and for the sins of your family.
16.7: Then you will lead the two goats into my presence at the front of the sacred tent,
16.8: where I will show you which goat will be sacrificed to me and which one will be sent into the desert to the demon Azazel.
16.9: After you offer the first goat as a sacrifice for sin,
16.10: the other one must be presented to me alive, before you send it into the desert to take away the sins of the people.
16.11: You must offer the bull as a sacrifice to ask forgiveness for your own sins and for the sins of your family.
16.12: Then you will take a fire pan of live coals from the bronze altar, together with two handfuls of finely ground incense, into the most holy place.
16.13: There you will present them to me by placing the incense on the coals, so that the place of mercy will be covered with a cloud of smoke. Do this, or you will die right there!
16.14: Next, use a finger to sprinkle some of the blood on the place of mercy, which is on the lid of the sacred chest; then sprinkle blood seven times in front of the chest.
16.15: Aaron, you must next sacrifice the goat for the sins of the people, and you must sprinkle its blood inside the most holy place, just as you did with the blood of the bull.
16.16: By doing this, you will take away the sins that make both the most holy place and the people of Israel unclean. Do the same for the sacred tent, which is here among the people.
16.17: Only you are allowed in the sacred tent from the time you enter until the time you come out.
16.18: After leaving the tent, you will purify the bronze altar by smearing each of its four corners with some of the blood from the bull and from the goat.
16.19: Use a finger to sprinkle the altar seven times with the blood, and it will be completely clean from the sins of the people.
16.20: After you have purified the most holy place, the sacred tent, and the bronze altar, you must bring the live goat to the front of the tent.
16.21: There you will lay your hands on its head, while confessing every sin the people have committed, and you will appoint someone to lead the goat into the desert, so that it can take away their sins.
16.22: Finally, this goat that carries the heavy burden of Israel's sins must be released deep in the desert.
16.25: The fat from these sacrifices for sin must be sent up in smoke on the bronze altar.
16.26: The one who led the goat into the desert and sent it off to the demon Azazel must take a bath and wash his clothes before coming back into camp.
16.27: The remains of the bull and the goat whose blood was taken into the most holy place must be taken outside the camp and burned.
16.28: And whoever does this must take a bath and change clothes before coming back into camp.
16.29: On the tenth day of the seventh month of each year, you must go without eating to show sorrow for your sins, and no one, including foreigners who live among you, is allowed to work.
16.30: This is the day on which the sacrifice for the forgiveness of your sins will be made in my presence,
16.31: and from now on, it must be celebrated each year. Go without eating and make this a day of complete rest just like the Sabbath.
16.32: The high priest must offer the sacrifices for cleansing from sin, while wearing the sacred linen clothes.
16.33: He will offer these sacrifices for the most holy place, the sacred tent, the bronze altar, all the priests, and for the whole community.
16.34: You must celebrate this day each year--it is the Great Day of Forgiveness for all the sins of the people of Israel. Moses did exactly as the LORD had commanded.

17.1: The LORD told Moses
