9.16: I saw how quickly you had sinned and disobeyed the LORD your God. There you were, worshiping the metal idol you had made in the shape of a calf.
9.17: So I threw down the two stones and smashed them before your very eyes.
9.21: It was a sin for you to make that idol, so I threw it into the fire to melt it down. Then I took the lump of gold, ground it into powder, and threw the powder into the stream flowing down the mountain.
9.22: You also made the LORD angry when you were staying at Taberah, at Massah, and at Kibroth-Hattaavah.
9.23: Then at Kadesh-Barnea the LORD said, "I am giving you the land, so go ahead and take it!" But since you didn't trust the LORD, you rebelled and disobeyed his command.
9.24: In fact, you've rebelled against the LORD for as long as he has known you.
9.25: After you had made the idol in the shape of a calf, the LORD said he was going to destroy you. So I lay face down in front of the LORD for 40 days and nights
9.26: and prayed: Our LORD, please don't wipe out your people. You used your great power to rescue them from Egypt and to make them your very own.
9.27: Israel's ancestors Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob obeyed you faithfully. Think about them, and not about Israel's stubbornness, evil, and sin.
9.29: But you, our LORD, chose the people of Israel to be your own, and with your mighty power you rescued them from Egypt.

10.2: He told me that he would write on the new stones the same words he had written on the ones I broke, and that I could put these stones in this sacred chest.
10.3: So I made a chest out of acacia wood, and I chiseled two flat stones like the ones I broke. Then I carried the stones up the mountain,
10.4: where the LORD wrote the Ten Commandments on them, just as he had done the first time. The commandments were exactly what he had announced from the fire, when you were gathered at the mountain. After the LORD returned the stones to me,
10.5: I took them down the mountainside and put them in the chest, just as he had commanded. And they are still there.
10.6: Later we set up camp at the wells belonging to the descendants of Jaakan. Then we moved on and camped at Moserah, where Aaron died and was buried, and his son Eleazar became the priest.
10.7: Next, we camped at Gudgodah and then at Jotbathah, where there are flowing streams.
10.8: After I put the two stones in the sacred chest, the LORD chose the tribe of Levi, not only to carry the chest, but also to serve as his priests at the place of worship and to bless the other tribes in his name. And they still do these things.
10.9: The LORD promised that he would always provide for the tribe of Levi, and that's why he won't give them any land, when he divides it among the other tribes.
10.10: When I had taken the second set of stones up the mountain, I spent 40 days and nights there, just as I had done before. Once again, the LORD answered my prayer and did not destroy you.
10.12: People of Israel, what does the LORD your God want from you? The LORD wants you to respect and follow him, to love and serve him with all your heart and soul,
10.13: and to obey his laws and teachings that I am giving you today. Do this, and all will go well for you.
10.14: Everything belongs to the LORD your God, not only the earth and everything on it, but also the sky and the highest heavens.
10.15: Yet the LORD loved your ancestors and wanted them to belong to him. So he chose them and their descendants rather than any other nation, and today you are still his people.
10.16: Remember your agreement with the LORD and stop being so stubborn.
10.17: The LORD your God is more powerful than all other gods and lords, and his tremendous power is to be feared. His decisions are always fair, and you cannot bribe him to change his mind.
10.18: The LORD defends the rights of orphans and widows. He cares for foreigners and gives them food and clothing.
10.19: And you should also care for them, because you were foreigners in Egypt.
10.20: Respect the LORD your God, be faithful, and serve only him, making promises in his name.
10.21: Offer your praises to him, because you have seen him work such terrifying miracles for you.
10.22: When your ancestors went to live in Egypt, there were only 70 of them. But the LORD has blessed you, and now there are more of you than there are stars in the sky.

11.1: The LORD is your God, so you must always love him and obey his laws and teachings.
11.2: Remember, he corrected you and not your children. You are the ones who saw the LORD use his great power
11.3: when he worked miracles in Egypt, making terrible things happen to the king and all his people.
11.4: And when the Egyptian army chased you in their chariots, you saw the LORD drown them and their horses in the Red Sea. Egypt still suffers from that defeat!
11.5: You saw what the LORD did for you while you were in the desert, right up to the time you arrived here.
11.6: And you saw how the LORD made the ground open up in the middle of our camp underneath the tents of Dathan and Abiram, who were swallowed up along with their families, their animals, and their tents.
11.7: With your own eyes, you saw the LORD's mighty power do all these things.
11.8: Soon you will cross the Jordan River, and if you obey the laws and teachings I'm giving you today, you will be strong enough to conquer the land
11.9: that the LORD promised your ancestors and their descendants. It's rich with milk and honey, and you will live there and enjoy it for a long time.
11.10: It's better land than you had in Egypt, where you had to struggle just to water your crops.
11.11: But the hills and valleys in the promised land are watered by rain from heaven,
11.12: because the LORD your God keeps his eye on this land and takes care of it all year long.
11.13: The LORD your God commands you to love him and to serve him with all your heart and soul. If you obey him,
11.16: But watch out! You will be tempted to turn your backs on the LORD. And if you worship other gods,
11.17: the LORD will become angry and keep the rain from falling. Nothing will grow in your fields, and you will die and disappear from the good land that the LORD is giving you.
11.18: Memorize these laws and think about them. Write down copies and tie them to your wrists and your foreheads to help you obey them.
11.19: Teach them to your children. Talk about them all the time--whether you're at home or walking along the road or going to bed at night, or getting up in the morning.
11.20: Write them on the door frames of your homes and on your town gates.
11.21: Then you and your descendants will live a long time in the land that the LORD promised your ancestors. Your families will live there as long as the sky is above the earth.
11.22: Love the LORD your God faithfully and obey all the laws and teachings I'm giving you today. If you live the way the LORD wants,
11.23: he will help you take the land. And even though the nations there are more powerful than you, the LORD will force them to leave when you attack.
11.24: You will capture the land everywhere you go, from the Southern Desert to the Lebanon Mountains, and from the Euphrates River west to the Mediterranean Sea.
11.25: No one will be able to stand up to you. The LORD will make everyone terrified of you, just as he promised.
11.26: You have a choice--do you want the LORD to bless you, or do you want him to put a curse on you?
11.27: Today I am giving you his laws, and if you obey him, he will bless you.
11.28: But if you disobey him and worship those gods that have never done anything for you, the LORD will put a curse on you.
11.29: After the LORD your God helps you take the land, you must have a ceremony where you announce his blessings from Mount Gerizim and his curses from Mount Ebal.
11.30: You know that these two mountains are west of the Jordan River in land now controlled by the Canaanites living in the Jordan River valley. The mountains are west of the road near the sacred trees of Moreh on the other side of Gilgal.
11.31: Soon you will cross the Jordan River to conquer the land that the LORD your God is giving you. And when you have settled there,
11.32: be careful to obey his laws and teachings that I am giving you today.

12.1: Now I'll tell you the laws and teachings that you have to obey as long as you live. Your ancestors worshiped the LORD, and he is giving you this land.
12.2: But the nations that live there worship other gods. So after you capture the land, you must completely destroy their places of worship--on mountains and hills or in the shade of large trees.
12.3: Wherever these nations worship their gods, you must tear down their altars, break their sacred stones, burn the sacred poles used in worshiping the goddess Asherah, and smash their idols to pieces. Destroy these places of worship so completely that no one will remember they were ever there.
12.4: Don't worship the LORD your God in the way those nations worship their gods.
12.22: It is the same as eating the meat from a deer or a gazelle that you kill when you go hunting. And in this way, anyone who is unclean and unfit for worship can have some of the meat.
12.25: Do you want the LORD to make you successful? Do you want your children to be successful even after you are gone? Then do what pleases the LORD and don't eat blood.
12.28: If you obey these laws, you will be doing what the LORD your God says is right and good. Then he will help you and your descendants be successful.
12.29: Israel, as you go into the land and attack the nations that are there, the LORD will get rid of them, and you can have their land.
12.30: But that's when you must be especially careful not to ask, "How did those nations worship their gods? Shouldn't we worship the LORD in the same way?"
12.31: No, you should not! The LORD hates the disgusting way those nations worship their gods, because they even burn their sons and daughters as sacrifices.
12.32: Obey all the laws and teachings I am giving you. Don't add any, and don't take any away.

13.3: If the prophet says this, don't listen! The LORD your God will be watching to find out whether or not you love him with all your heart and soul.
13.4: You must be completely faithful to the LORD. Worship and obey only the LORD and do this with fear and trembling,
13.5: because he rescued you from slavery in Egypt. If a prophet tells you to disobey the LORD your God and to stop worshiping him, then that prophet is evil and must be put to death.
13.11: And when the rest of Israel hears about it, they will be afraid, and no one else will ever do such an evil thing again.
13.12: After the LORD your God gives you towns to live in, you may hear a rumor about one of the towns.
13.13: You may hear that some worthless people have talked everyone there into worshiping other gods, even though these gods had never done anything for them.
13.14: You must carefully find out if the rumor is true. Then if the people of that town have actually done such a disgusting thing in your own country,
13.15: you must take your swords and kill every one of them, and their livestock too.
13.18: That's why you must do what the LORD your God says is right. I am giving you his laws and teachings today, and you must obey them.

14.1: People of Israel, you are the LORD's children, so when you mourn for the dead, you must not cut yourselves or shave your forehead.
14.2: Out of all the nations on this earth, the LORD your God chose you to be his own. You belong to the LORD, so don't behave like those who worship other gods.
14.3: Don't eat any disgusting animals.
14.6: It is all right to eat meat from any animals that have divided hoofs and also chew the cud.
14.7: But don't eat camels, rabbits, and rock badgers. These animals chew the cud but do not have divided hoofs. You must treat them as unclean.
14.8: And don't eat pork, since pigs have divided hoofs, but they do not chew their cud. Don't even touch a dead pig!
14.9: You can eat any fish that has fins and scales. But there are other creatures that live in the water,
14.10: and if they do not have fins and scales, you must not eat them. Treat them as unclean.
14.11: You can eat any clean bird.
14.19: Swarming insects are unclean, so don't eat them.
14.20: However, you are allowed to eat certain kinds of winged insects.
14.21: You belong to the LORD your God, so if you happen to find a dead animal, don't eat its meat. You may give it to foreigners who live in your town or sell it to foreigners who are visiting your town. Don't boil a young goat in its mother's milk.
14.22: People of Israel, every year you must set aside ten percent of your grain harvest.
14.23: Also set aside ten percent of your wine and olive oil, and the first-born of every cow, sheep, and goat. Take these to the place where the LORD chooses to be worshiped, and eat them there. This will teach you to always respect the LORD your God.
14.24: But suppose you can't carry that ten percent of your harvest to the place where the LORD chooses to be worshiped. If you live too far away, or if the LORD gives you a big harvest,
14.25: then sell this part and take the money there instead.
14.26: When you and your family arrive, spend the money on food for a big celebration. Buy cattle, sheep, goats, wine, beer, and if there are any other kinds of food that you want, buy those too.
14.27: And since people of the Levi tribe won't own any land for growing crops, remember to ask the Levites to celebrate with you.
14.28: Every third year, instead of using the ten percent of your harvest for a big celebration, bring it into town and put it in a community storehouse.
14.29: The Levites have no land of their own, so you must give them food from the storehouse. You must also give food to the poor who live in your town, including orphans, widows, and foreigners. If they have enough to eat, then the LORD your God will be pleased and make you successful in everything you do.

15.3: This law applies only to loans you have made to other Israelites. Foreigners will still have to pay back what you have loaned them.
15.7: After the LORD your God gives land to each of you, there may be poor Israelites in the town where you live. If there are, then don't be mean and selfish with your money.
15.8: Instead, be kind and lend them what they need.
15.9: Be careful! Don't say to yourself, "Soon it will be the seventh year, and then I won't be able to get my money back." It would be horrible for you to think that way and to be so selfish that you refuse to help the poor. They are your relatives, and if you don't help them, they may ask the LORD to decide whether you have done wrong. And he will say that you are guilty.
15.10: You should be happy to give the poor what they need, because then the LORD will make you successful in everything you do.
15.11: There will always be some Israelites who are poor and needy. That's why I am commanding you to be generous with them.
15.12: If any of you buy Israelites as slaves, you must set them free after six years.
15.13: And don't just tell them they are free to leave--
15.14: give them sheep and goats and a good supply of grain and wine. The more the LORD has given you, the more you should give them.
15.15: I am commanding you to obey the LORD as a reminder that you were slaves in Egypt before he set you free.
15.16: But one of your slaves may say, "I love you and your family, and I would be better off staying with you, so please don't make me leave."
15.17: Take the slave to the door of your house and push a sharp metal rod through one earlobe and into the door. Such slaves will belong to you for life, whether they are men or women.
15.18: Don't complain when you have to set a slave free. After all, you got six years of service at half the cost of hiring someone to do the work.
15.19: If the first-born animal of a cow or sheep or goat is a male, it must be given to the LORD. Don't put first-born cattle to work or cut wool from first-born sheep.
15.20: Instead, each year you must take the first-born of these animals to the place where the LORD your God chooses to be worshiped. You and your family will sacrifice them to the LORD and then eat them as part of a sacred meal.
15.21: But if the animal is lame or blind or has something else wrong with it, you must not sacrifice it to the LORD your God.
15.22: You can butcher it where you live, and eat it just like the meat of a deer or gazelle that you kill while hunting. Even those people who are unclean and unfit for worship can have some.
15.23: But you must never eat the blood of an animal--let it drain out on the ground.

16.1: People of Israel, you must celebrate Passover in the month of Abib, because one night in that month years ago, the LORD your God rescued you from Egypt.
16.2: The Passover sacrifice must be a cow, a sheep, or a goat, and you must offer it at the place where the LORD chooses to be worshiped.
16.5: Don't offer the Passover sacrifice in just any town where you happen to live.
16.6: It must be offered at the place where the LORD chooses to be worshiped. Kill the sacrifice at sunset, the time of day when you left Egypt.
16.7: Then cook it and eat it there at the place of worship, returning to your tents the next morning.
16.8: Eat thin bread for the next six days. Then on the seventh day, don't do any work. Instead, come together and worship the LORD.
16.9: Seven weeks after you start your grain harvest,
16.12: Remember that you used to be slaves in Egypt, so obey these laws.
16.16: Each year there are three festivals when all Israelite men must go to the place where the LORD chooses to be worshiped. These are the Festival of Thin Bread, the Harvest Festival, and the Festival of Shelters. And don't forget to take along a gift for the LORD.
16.17: The bigger the harvest the LORD gives you, the bigger your gift should be.
16.20: People of Israel, if you want to enjoy a long and successful life, make sure that everyone is treated with justice in the land the LORD is giving you.
16.21: When you build the altar for offering sacrifices to the LORD your God, don't set up a sacred pole for the worship of the goddess Asherah.
16.22: And don't set up a sacred stone! The LORD hates these things.

17.1: If an ox or a sheep has something wrong with it, don't offer it as a sacrifice to the LORD your God--he will be disgusted!
17.4: So when you hear that someone in your town is committing this disgusting sin, you must carefully find out if that person really is guilty.
17.13: When other Israelites hear about it, they will be afraid and obey the decisions of the court.
17.14: People of Israel, after you capture the land the LORD your God is giving you, and after you settle on it, you will say, "We want a king, just like the nations around us."
17.15: Go ahead and appoint a king, but make sure that he is an Israelite and that he is the one the LORD has chosen.
17.16: The king should not have many horses, especially those from Egypt. The LORD has said never to go back there again.
17.17: And the king must not have a lot of wives--they might tempt him to be unfaithful to the LORD. Finally, the king must not try to get huge amounts of silver and gold.
17.18: The official copy of God's laws will be kept by the priests of the Levi tribe. So, as soon as anyone becomes king, he must go to the priests and write out a copy of these laws while they watch.
17.19: Each day the king must read and obey these laws, so that he will learn to worship the LORD with fear and trembling
17.20: and not think that he's better than everyone else. If the king completely obeys the LORD's commands, he and his descendants will rule Israel for many years.

18.1: The people of the Levi tribe, including the priests, will not receive any land. Instead, they will receive part of the sacrifices that are offered to the LORD,
18.2: because he has promised to provide for them in this way.
18.3: When you sacrifice a bull or sheep, the priests will be given the shoulder, the jaws, and the stomach.
18.4: In addition, they will receive the first part of your grain harvest and part of your first batches of wine and olive oil. You must also give them the first wool that is cut from your sheep each year.
18.5: Give these gifts to the priests, because the LORD has chosen them and their descendants out of all the tribes of Israel to be his special servants at the place of worship.
18.6: Any Levite can leave his hometown, and go to the place where the LORD chooses to be worshiped,
18.7: and then be a special servant of the LORD there, just like all the other Levites.
18.8: Some Levites may have money from selling family possessions, and others may not. But all Levites serving at the place of worship will receive the same amount of food from the sacrifices and gifts brought by the people.
18.9: Soon you will go into the land that the LORD your God is giving you. The nations that live there do things that are disgusting to the LORD, and you must not follow their example.
18.12: The LORD is disgusted with anyone who does these things, and that's why he will help you destroy the nations that are in the land.
18.13: Never be guilty of doing any of these disgusting things!
18.14: You will go in and take the land from nations that practice magic and witchcraft. But the LORD your God won't allow you to do those things.
18.15: Instead, he will choose one of your own people to be a prophet just like me, and you must do what that prophet says.
18.16: You were asking for a prophet the day you were gathered at Mount Sinai and said to the LORD, "Please don't let us hear your voice or see this terrible fire again--if we do, we will die!"
18.17: Then the LORD told me: Moses, they have said the right thing.
18.18: So when I want to speak to them, I will choose one of them to be a prophet like you. I will give my message to that prophet, who will tell the people exactly what I have said.
18.19: Since the message comes from me, anyone who doesn't obey the message will have to answer to me.
18.20: But if I haven't spoken, and a prophet claims to have a message from me, you must kill that prophet, and you must also kill any prophet who claims to have a message from another god.
18.21: You may be asking yourselves, "How can we tell if a prophet's message really comes from the LORD?"
18.22: You will know, because if the LORD says something will happen, it will happen. And if it doesn't, you will know that the prophet was falsely claiming to speak for the LORD. Don't be afraid of any prophet whose message doesn't come from the LORD.

They might even choose one of the men from their family to track you down and kill you. If it is too far to one of the Safe Towns, the victim's relative might be able to catch you and kill you.

19.11: But what if you really do commit murder? Suppose one of you hates a neighbor. So you wait in a deserted place, kill the neighbor, and run to a Safe Town.
19.12: If that happens, the leaders of your town must send messengers to bring you back from the Safe Town. They will hand you over to one of the victim's relatives, who will put you to death.
19.13: Israel, for the good of the whole country, you must kill anyone who murders an innocent person. Never show mercy to a murderer!
19.14: In the land the LORD is giving you, there are already stones set up to mark the property lines between fields. So don't move those stones.
19.15: Before you are convicted of a crime, at least two witnesses must be able to testify that you did it.

20.1: If you have to go to war, you may find yourselves facing an enemy army that is bigger than yours and that has horses and chariots. But don't be afraid! The LORD your God rescued you from Egypt, and he will help you fight.
20.2: Before you march into battle, a priest will go to the front of the army
20.3: and say, "Soldiers of Israel, listen to me! Today when you go into battle, don't be afraid of the enemy, and when you see them, don't panic.
20.4: The LORD your God will fight alongside you and help you win the battle."
20.5: Then the tribal officials will say to the troops: If any of you have built a new house, but haven't yet moved in, you may go home. It isn't right for you to die in battle and for somebody else to live in your new house.
20.6: If any of you have planted a vineyard but haven't had your first grape harvest, you may go home. It isn't right for you to die in battle and for somebody else to enjoy your grapes.
20.7: If any of you are engaged to be married, you may go back home and get married. It isn't right for you to die in battle and for somebody else to marry the woman you are engaged to.
20.8: Finally, if any of you are afraid, you may go home. We don't want you to discourage the other soldiers.
20.9: When the officials are finished giving these orders, they will appoint officers to be in command of the army.
20.16: Whenever you capture towns in the land the LORD your God is giving you, be sure to kill all the people and animals.
20.17: He has commanded you to completely wipe out the Hittites, the Amorites, the Canaanites, the Perizzites, the Hivites, and the Jebusites.
20.18: If you allow them to live, they will persuade you to worship their disgusting gods, and you will be unfaithful to the LORD.
20.19: When you are attacking a town, don't chop down its fruit trees, not even if you have had the town surrounded for a long time. Fruit trees aren't your enemies, and they produce food that you can eat, so don't cut them down.
20.20: You may need wood to make ladders and towers to help you get over the walls and capture the town. But use only trees that you know are not fruit trees.

21.1: Suppose the body of a murder victim is found in a field in the land the LORD your God is giving you, and no one knows who the murderer is.
21.2: The judges and other leaders from the towns around there must find out what town is the closest to where the body was found.
21.3: The leaders from that town will go to their cattle herds and choose a young cow that has never been put to work.
21.6: The town leaders will wash their hands over the body of the dead cow
21.7: and say, "We had no part in this murder, and we don't know who did it.
21.10: From time to time, you men will serve as soldiers and go off to war. The LORD your God will help you defeat your enemies, and you will take many prisoners.
21.14: Later on, if you are not happy with the woman, you can divorce her, and she can go free. But you have slept with her as your wife, so you cannot sell her as a slave or make her into your own slave.
21.18: A father and a mother may have a stubborn and rebellious son who refuses to obey them even after he has been punished.
21.19: If a son is like that, his parents must drag him to the town gate, where the leaders of the town hold their meetings.
21.20: The parents will tell the leaders, "This son of ours is stubborn and never obeys. He spends all his time drinking and partying."
21.21: The men of the town will stone that son to death, because they must get rid of the evil he brought into the community. Everyone in Israel will be afraid when they hear how he was punished.
21.22: If a criminal is put to death, and you hang the dead body on a tree,
21.23: you must not leave it there overnight. Bury it the same day, because the dead body of a criminal hanging on a tree will bring God's curse on the land. The LORD your God is giving this land to you, so don't make it unclean by leaving the bodies of executed criminals on display.

22.1: If you see a cow or sheep wandering around lost, take the animal back to its owner.
22.2: If the owner lives too far away, or if you don't know who the owner is, take the animal home with you and take care of it. The owner will come looking for the animal, and then you can give it back.
22.3: That's what you should do if you find anything that belongs to someone else. Do whatever you can to help, whether you find a cow or sheep or donkey or some clothing.
22.4: Oxen and donkeys that carry heavy loads can stumble and fall, and be unable to get up by themselves. So as you walk along the road, help anyone who is trying to get an ox or donkey back on its feet.
22.5: Women must not pretend to be men, and men must not pretend to be women. The LORD your God is disgusted with people who do that.
22.8: If you build a house, make sure to put a low wall around the edge of the flat roof. Then if someone falls off the roof and is killed, it won't be your fault.
22.9: If you plant a vineyard, don't plant any other fruit tree or crop in it. If you do plant something else there, you must bring to the place of worship everything you harvest from the vineyard.
22.10: Don't hitch an ox and a donkey to your plow at the same time.
22.11: When you weave cloth for clothing, you can use thread made of flax or wool, but not both together.
22.12: And when you make a coat, sew a tassel on each of the four corners.
22.13: Suppose a man starts hating his wife soon after they are married.
22.14: He might tell ugly lies about her, and say, "I married this woman, but when we slept together, I found out she wasn't a virgin."
22.15: If this happens, the bride's father and mother must go to the town gate to show the town leaders the proof that the woman was a virgin.
22.16: Her father will say, "I let my daughter marry this man, but he started hating her
22.17: and accusing her of not being a virgin. But he is wrong, because here is proof that she was a virgin!" Then the bride's parents will show them the bed sheet from the woman's wedding night.
22.18: The town leaders will beat the man with a whip
22.19: because he accused his bride of not being a virgin. He will have to pay her father 100 pieces of silver and will never be allowed to divorce her.
22.20: But if the man was right and there is no proof that his bride was a virgin,
22.21: the men of the town will take the woman to the door of her father's house and stone her to death. This woman brought evil into your community by sleeping with someone before she got married, and you must get rid of that evil by killing her.

26.5: Then, standing there in front of the place of worship, you must pray: My ancestor was homeless, an Aramean who went to live in Egypt. There were only a few in his family then, but they became great and powerful, a nation of many people.
26.6: The Egyptians were cruel and had no pity on us. They mistreated our people and forced us into slavery.
26.7: We called out for help to you, the LORD God of our ancestors. You heard our cries; you knew we were in trouble and abused.
26.8: Then you terrified the Egyptians with your mighty miracles and rescued us from Egypt.
26.9: You brought us here and gave us this land rich with milk and honey.
26.10: Now, LORD, I bring to you the best of the crops that you have given me. After you say these things, place the basket in front of the LORD's altar and bow down to worship him.
26.11: Then you and your family must celebrate by eating a meal at the place of worship to thank the LORD your God for giving you such a good harvest. And remember to invite the Levites and the foreigners who live in your town.
26.12: Every year you are to give ten percent of your harvest to the LORD. But every third year, this ten percent must be given to the poor who live in your town, including Levites, foreigners, orphans, and widows. That way, they will have enough to eat.
26.13: Then you must pray: Our LORD and our God, you have said that ten percent of my harvest is sacred. I have obeyed your command and given this to the poor, including the Levites, foreigners, orphans, and widows.
26.14: I have not eaten any of this sacred food while I was in mourning; in fact, I never touched it when I was unclean. And none of it has been offered as a sacrifice to the spirits of the dead. I have done everything exactly as you commanded.
26.15: Our LORD, look down from your temple in heaven and bless us and our land. You promised our ancestors that you would give us this land rich with milk and honey, and you have kept your promise.
26.16: Today the LORD your God has commanded you to obey these laws and teachings with all your heart and soul.
26.17: In response, you have agreed that the LORD will be your God, that you will obey all his laws and teachings, and that you will listen when he speaks to you.
26.18: Since you have agreed to obey the LORD, he has agreed that you will be his people and that you will belong to him, just as he promised.
26.19: The LORD created all nations, but he will make you more famous than any of them, and you will receive more praise and honor. You will belong only to the LORD your God, just as he promised.

12.1: Before Moses died, he and the people of Israel had defeated two kings east of the Jordan River. These kings had ruled the region from the Arnon River gorge in the south to Mount Hermon in the north, including the eastern side of the Jordan River valley.
12.2: The first king that Moses and the Israelites defeated was an Amorite, King Sihon of Heshbon. The southern border of his kingdom ran down the middle of the Arnon River gorge, taking in the town of Aroer on the northern edge of the gorge. The Jabbok River separated Sihon's kingdom from the Ammonites on the east. Then the Jabbok turned west and became his northern border, so his kingdom included the southern half of the region of Gilead.
12.3: Sihon also controlled the eastern side of the Jordan River valley from Lake Galilee south to Beth-Jeshimoth and the Dead Sea. In addition to these regions, he ruled the town called Slopes of Mount Pisgah and the land south of there at the foot of the hill.
12.4: Next, Moses and the Israelites defeated King Og of Bashan, who lived in the town of Ashtaroth part of each year and in Edrei the rest of the year. Og was one of the last of the Rephaim.
12.5: His kingdom stretched north to Mount Hermon, east to the town of Salecah, and included the land of Bashan as far west as the borders of the kingdoms of Geshur and Maacah. He also ruled the northern half of Gilead.
12.6: Moses, the LORD's servant, had led the people of Israel in defeating Sihon and Og. Then Moses gave their land to the tribes of Reuben, Gad, and East Manasseh.

13.1: Many years later, the LORD told Joshua: Now you are very old, but there is still a lot of land that Israel has not yet taken.
13.8: Moses had already given land east of the Jordan River to the tribes of Reuben, Gad, and half of Manasseh.
13.9: This region stretched north from the town in the middle of the Arnon River valley, and included the town of Aroer on the northern edge of the valley. It covered the flatlands of Medeba north of Dibon,
13.10: and took in the towns that had belonged to Sihon, the Amorite king of Heshbon. Some of these towns were as far east as the Ammonite border.
13.13: However, the Israelites did not force the people of Geshur and Maacah to leave, and they still live there among the Israelites.
13.14: Moses did not give any land to the Levi tribe, because the LORD God of Israel had told them, "Instead of land, you will receive the sacrifices offered at my altar."
13.15: Moses gave land to each of the clans in the Reuben tribe.
13.16: Their land started in the south at the town in the middle of the Arnon River valley, took in the town of Aroer on the northern edge of the valley, and went as far north as the flatlands around Medeba.
13.22: The Israelites also killed Balaam the son of Beor, who had been a fortuneteller.
13.23: This region with its towns and villages was the land for the Reuben tribe, and the Jordan River was its western border.
13.24: Moses also gave land to each of the clans in the Gad tribe.
13.25: It included the town of Jazer, and in the Gilead region their territory took in the land and towns as far east as the town of Aroer just west of Rabbah. This was about half of the land that had once belonged to the Ammonites.
13.26: The land given to Gad stretched from Heshbon in the south to Ramath-Mizpeh and Betonim in the north, and even further north to Mahanaim and Lidebor.
13.27: Gad also received the eastern half of the Jordan River valley, which had been ruled by King Sihon of Heshbon. This territory stretched as far north as Lake Galilee, and included the towns of Beth-Haram, Beth-Nimrah, Succoth, and Zaphon.
13.28: These regions with their towns and villages were given to the Gad tribe.
13.29: Moses gave land east of the Jordan River to half of the clans from the Manasseh tribe.
13.32: That was how Moses divided up the Moab Plains to the east of Jericho on the other side of the Jordan River, so these two and a half tribes would have land of their own.
13.33: But Moses did not give any land to the Levi tribe, because the LORD had promised that he would always provide for them.

14.6: One day while the Israelites were still camped at Gilgal, Caleb the son of Jephunneh went to talk with Joshua. Caleb belonged to the Kenaz clan, and many other people from the Judah tribe went with Caleb. He told Joshua: You know that back in Kadesh-Barnea the LORD talked to his prophet Moses about you and me.
14.7: I was 40 years old at the time Moses sent me from Kadesh-Barnea into Canaan as a spy. When I came back and told him about the land, everything I said was true.
14.8: The other spies said things that made our people afraid, but I completely trusted the LORD God.
14.9: The same day I came back, Moses told me, "Since you were faithful to the LORD God, I promise that the places where you went as a spy will belong to you and your descendants forever."
14.10: Joshua, it was 45 years ago that the LORD told Moses to make that promise, and now I am 85. Even though Israel has moved from place to place in the desert, the LORD has kept me alive all this time as he said he would.
14.11: I'm just as strong today as I was then, and I can still fight as well in battle.
14.12: So I'm asking you for the hill country that the LORD promised me that day. You were there. You heard the other spies talk about that part of the hill country and the large, walled towns where the Anakim live. But maybe the LORD will help me take their land, just as he promised.
14.13: Joshua prayed that God would help Caleb, then he gave Hebron to Caleb and his descendants.
14.14: And Hebron still belongs to Caleb's descendants, because he was faithful to the LORD God of Israel.
14.15: Hebron used to be called Arba's Town, because Arba had been one of the greatest of the Anakim. There was peace in the land.

15.1: The clans of the Judah tribe were given land that went south along the border of Edom, and at its farthest point south it even reached the Zin Desert.
15.2: Judah's southern border started at the south end of the Dead Sea.
15.3: As it went west from there, it ran south of Scorpion Pass to Zin, and then came up from the south to Kadesh-Barnea. It continued past Hezron up to Addar, turned toward Karka,
15.4: and ran along to Azmon. After that, it followed the Egyptian Gorge and ended at the Mediterranean Sea. This was also Israel's southern border.
15.5: Judah's eastern border ran the full length of the Dead Sea. The northern border started at the northern end of the Dead Sea.
15.6: From there it went west up to Beth-Hoglah, continued north of Beth-Arabah, and went up to the Monument of Bohan, who belonged to the Reuben tribe.
15.7: From there, it went to Trouble Valley and Debir, then turned north and went to Gilgal, which is on the north side of the valley across from Adummim Pass. It continued on to Enshemesh, Enrogel,
15.8: and up through Hinnom Valley on the land sloping south from Jerusalem. The city of Jerusalem itself belonged to the Jebusites. Next, the border went up to the top of the mountain on the west side of Hinnom Valley and at the north end of Rephaim Valley.
15.9: At the top of the mountain it turned and went to Nephtoah Spring and then to the ruins on Mount Ephron. From there, it went to Baalah, which is now called Kiriath-Jearim.
15.10: From Baalah the northern border curved west to Mount Seir and then ran along the northern ridge of Mount Jearim, where Chesalon is located. Then it went down to Beth-Shemesh and over to Timnah.
15.11: It continued along to the hillside north of Ekron, curved around to Shikkeron, and then went to Mount Baalah. After going to Jabneel, the border finally ended at the Mediterranean Sea,
15.12: which was Judah's western border. The clans of Judah lived within these borders.
15.13: Joshua gave Caleb some land among the people of Judah, as God had told him to do. Caleb's share was Hebron, which at that time was known as Arba's Town, because Arba was the famous ancestor of the Anakim.
15.14: Caleb attacked Hebron and forced the three Anakim clans of Sheshai, Ahiman, and Talmai to leave.
15.15: Next, Caleb started a war with the town of Debir, which at that time was called Kiriath-Sepher.
15.16: He told his men, "The man who captures Kiriath-Sepher can marry my daughter Achsah."
15.17: Caleb's nephew Othniel captured Kiriath-Sepher, and Caleb let him marry Achsah.
15.18: Right after the wedding, Achsah started telling Othniel that he ought to ask her father for a field. She went to see her father, and while she was getting down from her donkey, Caleb asked her, "What's bothering you?"
15.19: She answered, "I need your help. The land you gave me is in the Southern Desert, so I really need some spring-fed ponds for a water supply." Caleb gave her a couple of small ponds, named Higher Pond and Lower Pond.
15.20: The following is a list of the towns in each region given to the Judah clans:
15.60: The eleventh region was located in the northern part of Judah's hill country, and it had the following two towns with their surrounding villages: Rabbah, and Kiriath-Baal, which is also called Kiriath-Jearim.
15.63: The Jebusites lived in Jerusalem, and the people of the Judah tribe could not capture the city and get rid of them. That's why Jebusites still live in Jerusalem along with the people of Judah.

16.5: The following is a description of the land that was divided among the clans of the Ephraim tribe. Their southern border started at Ataroth-Addar and went west to Upper Beth-Horon
16.9: Ephraim also had some towns and villages that were inside Manasseh's tribal land.
16.10: Ephraim could not force the Canaanites out of Gezer, so there are still some Canaanites who live there among the Israelites. But now these Canaanites have to work as slaves for the Israelites.

17.7: The land of the Manasseh tribe went from its northern border with the Asher tribe south to Michmethath, which is to the east of Shechem. The southern border started there, but curved even farther south to include the people who lived around Tappuah Spring.
17.8: The town of Tappuah was on Manasseh's border with Ephraim. Although the land around Tappuah belonged to Manasseh, the town itself belonged to Ephraim.
17.11: Manasseh was supposed to have the following towns with their surrounding villages inside the borders of Issachar's and Asher's tribal lands: Beth-Shan, Ibleam, Endor, Taanach, Megiddo, and Dor, which is also called Naphath.
17.12: But the people of Manasseh could not capture these towns, so the Canaanites kept on living in them.
17.13: When the Israelites grew stronger, they made the Canaanites in these towns work as their slaves, though they never did force them to leave.
17.14: One day the Joseph tribes came to Joshua and asked, "Why didn't you give us more land? The LORD has always been kind to us, and we have too many people for this small region."
17.15: Joshua replied, "If there's not enough room for you in the hill country of Ephraim, then go into the forest that belonged to the Perizzites and the Rephaim. Clear out the trees and make more room for yourselves there."
17.16: "Even if we do that," they answered, "there still won't be enough land for us in the hill country. And we can't move down into Jezreel Valley, because the Canaanites who live in Beth-Shan and in other parts of the valley have iron chariots."
17.17: "Your tribes do have a lot of people," Joshua admitted. "I'll give you more land. Your tribes are powerful,
17.18: so you can have the rest of the hill country, but it's a forest, and you'll have to cut down the trees and clear the land. You can also have Jezreel Valley. Even though the Canaanites there are strong and have iron chariots, you can force them to leave the valley."

18.1: After Israel had captured the land, they met at Shiloh and set up the sacred tent.
18.2: There were still seven tribes without any land,
18.8: Just before the men left camp, Joshua repeated their orders: "Explore the land and write a description of it. Then come back to Shiloh, and I will find out from the LORD how to divide the land."
18.9: The men left and went across the land, dividing it into seven regions. They wrote down a description of each region, town by town, and returned to Joshua at the camp at Shiloh.
18.10: Joshua found out from the LORD how to divide the land, and he told the tribes what the LORD had decided.
18.11: Benjamin was the first tribe chosen to receive land. The region for its clans lay between the Judah tribe on the south and the Joseph tribes on the north.
18.12: Benjamin's northern border started at the Jordan River and went up the ridge north of Jericho, then on west into the hill country as far as the Beth-Aven Desert.
18.15: Benjamin's southern border started at the edge of Kiriath-Jearim and went east to the ruins and on to Nephtoah Spring.
18.16: From there it went to the bottom of the hill at the northern end of Rephaim Valley. The other side of this hill faces Hinnom Valley, which is on the land that slopes south from Jerusalem. The border went down through Hinnom Valley until it reached Enrogel.
18.17: At Enrogel the border curved north and went to Enshemesh and on east to Geliloth, which is across the valley from Adummim Pass. Then it went down to the Monument of Bohan, who belonged to the Reuben tribe.
18.18: The border ran along the hillside north of Beth-Arabah, then down into the Jordan River valley.
18.19: Inside the valley it went south as far as the northern hillside of Beth-Hoglah. The last section of the border went from there to the northern end of the Dead Sea, at the mouth of the Jordan River.
18.20: The Jordan River itself was Benjamin's eastern border. These were the borders of Benjamin's tribal land, where the clans of Benjamin lived.

19.1: Simeon was the second tribe chosen to receive land, and the region for its clans was inside Judah's borders.
19.7: In another region, Simeon had the following four towns with their surrounding villages: Enrimmon, Tachan, Ether, and Ashan.
19.8: Simeon's land also included all the other towns and villages as far south as Baalath-Beer, which is also called Ramah of the South.
19.9: Simeon's tribal land was actually inside Judah's territory. Judah had received too much land for the number of people in its tribe, so part of Judah's land was given to Simeon.
19.13: and continued north to Gath-Hepher, Ethkazin, and Rimmonah, where it curved toward Neah
19.14: and became the northern border. Then it curved south around Hannathon and went as far west as Iphtahel Valley.
19.15: Zebulun had twelve towns with their surrounding villages. Some of these were Kattath, Nahalal, Shimron, Jiralah, and Bethlehem.
19.16: This is the tribal land, and these are the towns and villages of the Zebulun clans.
19.27: then east to Beth-Dagon. On the southeast, Asher shared a border with Zebulun along the Iphtahel Valley. On the eastern side their border ran north to Beth-Emek, went east of Cabul, and then on to Neiel,
19.28: Abdon, Rehob, Hammon, Kanah, and as far north as the city of Sidon.

20.1: One day the LORD told Joshua:
20.2: When Moses was still alive, I commanded him to tell the Israelites about the Safe Towns. Now you tell them that it is time to set up these towns.
20.5: One of the victim's relatives might come to the town, looking for revenge. But the town leaders must not simply hand over the person accused of murder. After all, the accused and the victim had been neighbors, not enemies.
20.6: The citizens of that Safe Town must come together and hold a trial. They may decide that the victim was killed accidentally and that the accused is not guilty of murder. Everyone found not guilty must still live in the Safe Town until the high priest dies. Then they can go back to their own towns and their homes that they had to leave behind.
20.7: The Israelites decided that the following three towns west of the Jordan River would be Safe Towns: Kedesh in Galilee in Naphtali's hill country, Shechem in Ephraim's hill country, and Kiriath-Arba in Judah's hill country. Kiriath-Arba is now called Hebron.
20.8: The Israelites had already decided on the following three towns east of the Jordan River: Bezer in the desert flatlands of Reuben, Ramoth in Gilead, which was a town that belonged to Gad, and Golan in Bashan, which belonged to Manasseh.
20.9: These Safe Towns were set up, so that if Israelites or even foreigners who lived in Israel accidentally killed someone, they could run to one of these towns. There they would be safe until a trial could be held, even if one of the victim's relatives came looking for revenge.

21.3: Since the LORD had said this, the leaders of the other Israelite tribes agreed to give some of the towns and pastures from their tribal lands to Levi.
21.4: The leaders asked the LORD to show them in what order the clans of Levi would be given towns, and which towns each clan would receive. The Kohath clans were first. The descendants of Aaron, Israel's first priest, were given 13 towns from the tribes of Judah, Simeon, and Benjamin.
21.5: The other members of the Kohath clans received 10 towns from the tribes of Ephraim, Dan, and West Manasseh.
21.6: The clans that were descendants of Gershon were given 13 towns from the tribes of Issachar, Asher, Naphtali, and East Manasseh.
21.7: The clans that were descendants of Merari received 12 towns from the tribes of Reuben, Gad, and Zebulun.
21.8: The LORD had told Moses that he would show the Israelites which towns and pastures to give to the clans of Levi, and he did.
21.43: The LORD gave the Israelites the land he had promised their ancestors, and they captured it and settled in it.
21.44: There still were enemies around Israel, but the LORD kept his promise to let his people live in peace. And whenever the Israelites did have to go to war, no enemy could defeat them. The LORD always helped Israel win.
21.45: The LORD promised to do many good things for Israel, and he kept his promise every time.

22.1: Joshua held a meeting with the men of the tribes of Reuben, Gad, and East Manasseh, and he told them:
22.4: The LORD promised to give peace to your relatives, and that's what he has done. Now it's time for you to go back to your own homes in the land that Moses gave you east of the Jordan River.
22.5: Moses taught you to love the LORD your God, to be faithful to him, and to worship and obey him with your whole heart and with all your strength. So be very careful to do everything Moses commanded.
22.12: the Israelite men met at Shiloh to get ready to attack the two and a half tribes.
22.13: But first they sent a priest, Phinehas the son of Eleazar, to talk with the two and a half tribes.
22.14: Each of the ten tribes at Shiloh sent the leader of one of its families along with Phinehas.
22.15: Phinehas and these leaders went to Gilead and met with the tribes of Reuben, Gad, and East Manasseh. They said:
22.16: All of the LORD's people have gathered together and have sent us to find out why you are unfaithful to our God. You have turned your backs on the LORD by building that altar. Why are you rebelling against him?
22.17: Wasn't our people's sin at Peor terrible enough for you? The LORD punished us by sending a horrible sickness that killed many of us, and we still suffer because of that sin.
22.18: Now you are turning your backs on the LORD again. If you don't stop rebelling against the LORD at once, he will be angry with the whole nation.
22.19: If you don't think your land is a fit place to serve God, then move across the Jordan and live with us in the LORD's own land, where his sacred tent is located. But don't rebel against the LORD our God or against us by building another altar besides the LORD's own altar.
22.20: Don't you remember what happened when Achan was unfaithful and took some of the things that belonged to God? This made God angry with the entire nation. Achan died because he sinned, but he also caused the death of many others.
22.21: The tribes of Reuben, Gad, and East Manasseh answered:
22.22: The LORD is the greatest God! We ask him to be our witness, because he knows whether or not we were rebellious or unfaithful when we built that altar. If we were unfaithful, then we pray that God won't rescue us today. Let us tell you why we built that altar,
22.23: and we ask the LORD to punish us if we are lying. We didn't build it so we could turn our backs on the LORD. We didn't even build it so we could offer animal or grain sacrifices to please the LORD or ask his blessing.
22.26: That's why we decided to build the altar. It isn't for offering sacrifices, not even sacrifices to please the LORD.
22.32: Phinehas and the clan leaders left Gilead and went back to Canaan to tell the Israelites about their meeting with the Reuben and Gad tribes.
22.33: The Israelites were happy and praised God. There was no more talk about going to war and wiping out the tribes of Reuben and Gad.
22.34: The people of Reuben and Gad named the altar "A Reminder to Us All That the LORD Is Our God."

23.1: The LORD let Israel live in peace with its neighbors for a long time, and Joshua lived to a ripe old age.
23.2: One day he called a meeting of the leaders of the tribes of Israel, including the old men, the judges, and the officials. Then he told them: I am now very old.
23.3: You have seen how the LORD your God fought for you and helped you defeat the nations who lived in this land.
23.7: Don't have anything to do with the nations that live around you. Don't worship their gods or pray to their idols or make promises in the names of their gods.
23.8: Be as faithful to the LORD as you have always been.
23.9: When you attacked powerful nations, the LORD made them run away, and no one has ever been able to stand up to you.
23.10: Any one of you can defeat a thousand enemy soldiers, because the LORD God fights for you, just as he promised.
23.11: Be sure to always love the LORD your God.
23.14: I will soon die, as everyone must. But deep in your hearts you know that the LORD has kept every promise he ever made to you. Not one of them has been broken.

24.1: Joshua called the tribes of Israel together for a meeting at Shechem. He asked the leaders, including the old men, the judges, and the officials, to come up and stand near the sacred tent.
24.2: Then Joshua told everyone to listen to this message from the LORD, the God of Israel: Long ago your ancestors lived on the other side of the Euphrates River, and they worshiped other gods. This continued until the time of your ancestor Terah and his two sons, Abraham and Nahor.
24.3: But I brought Abraham across the Euphrates River and led him through the land of Canaan. I blessed him by giving him Isaac, the first in a line of many descendants.
24.4: Then I gave Isaac two sons, Jacob and Esau. I gave Esau the hill country of Mount Seir, but your ancestor Jacob and his children went to live in Egypt.
24.7: Your people cried to me for help, so I put a dark cloud between them and the Egyptians. Then I opened up the sea and let your people walk across on dry ground. But when the Egyptians tried to follow, I commanded the sea to swallow them, and they drowned while you watched. You lived in the desert for a long time,
24.8: then I brought you into the land east of the Jordan River. The Amorites were living there, and they fought you. But with my help, you defeated them, wiped them out, and took their land.
24.9: King Balak decided that his nation Moab would go to war against you, so he asked Balaam to come and put a curse on you.
24.10: But I wouldn't listen to Balaam, and I rescued you by making him bless you instead of curse you.
24.11: You crossed the Jordan River and came to Jericho. The rulers of Jericho fought you, and so did the Amorites, the Perizzites, the Canaanites, the Hittites, the Girgashites, the Hivites, and the Jebusites. I helped you defeat them all.
24.12: Your enemies ran from you, but not because you had swords and bows and arrows. I made your enemies panic and run away, as I had done with the two Amorite kings east of the Jordan River.
24.13: You didn't have to work for this land--I gave it to you. Now you live in towns you didn't build, and you eat grapes and olives from vineyards and trees you didn't plant.
24.14: Then Joshua told the people: Worship the LORD, obey him, and always be faithful. Get rid of the idols your ancestors worshiped when they lived on the other side of the Euphrates River and in Egypt.
24.15: But if you don't want to worship the LORD, then choose here and now! Will you worship the same idols your ancestors did? Or since you're living on land that once belonged to the Amorites, maybe you'll worship their gods. I won't. My family and I are going to worship and obey the LORD!
24.17: The LORD is our God. We were slaves in Egypt as our ancestors had been, but we saw the LORD work miracles to set our people free and to bring us out of Egypt. Even though other nations were all around us, the LORD protected us wherever we went.
24.18: And when we fought the Amorites and the other nations that lived in this land, the LORD made them run away. Yes, we will worship and obey the LORD, because the LORD is our God.
24.19: Joshua said: The LORD is fearsome; he is the one true God, and I don't think you are able to worship and obey him in the ways he demands. You would have to be completely faithful, and if you sin or rebel, he won't let you get away with it.
24.20: If you turn your backs on the LORD and worship the gods of other nations, the LORD will turn against you. He will make terrible things happen to you and wipe you out, even though he had been good to you before.
24.21: But the people shouted, "We won't worship any other gods. We will worship and obey only the LORD!"
24.22: Joshua said, "You have heard yourselves say that you will worship and obey the LORD. Isn't that true?" "Yes, it's true," they answered.
24.23: Joshua said, "But you still have some idols, like those the other nations worship. Get rid of your idols! You must decide once and for all that you really want to obey the LORD God of Israel."
24.24: The people said, "The LORD is our God, and we will worship and obey only him."
24.25: Joshua helped Israel make an agreement with the LORD that day at Shechem. Joshua made laws for Israel
24.26: and wrote them down in The Book of the Law of God. Then he set up a large stone under the oak tree at the place of worship in Shechem
24.27: and told the people, "Look at this stone. It has heard everything that the LORD has said to us. Our God can call this stone as a witness if we ever reject him."
24.28: Joshua sent everyone back to their homes.
24.29: Not long afterwards, the LORD's servant Joshua died at the age of 110.
24.30: The Israelites buried him in his own land at Timnath-Serah, north of Mount Gaash in the hill country of Ephraim.
24.31: As long as Joshua lived, Israel worshiped and obeyed the LORD. There were other leaders old enough to remember everything that the LORD had done for Israel. And for as long as these men lived, Israel continued to worship and obey the LORD.
24.32: When the people of Israel left Egypt, they brought the bones of Joseph along with them. They took the bones to the town of Shechem and buried them in the field that Jacob had bought for 100 pieces of silver from Hamor, the founder of Shechem. The town and the field both became part of the land belonging to the descendants of Joseph.
24.33: When Eleazar the priest died, he was buried in the hill country of Ephraim on a hill that belonged to his son Phinehas.

1.1: After the death of Joshua, the Israelites asked the LORD, "Which of our tribes should attack the Canaanites first?"
1.2: "Judah!" the LORD answered. "I'll help them take the land."
1.6: The king tried to escape, but soldiers from Judah caught him. They cut off his thumbs and big toes,
1.7: and he said, "I've cut off the thumbs and big toes of 70 kings and made those kings crawl around under my table for scraps of food. Now God is paying me back." The army of Judah took the king of Bezek along with them to Jerusalem, where he died.
1.8: They attacked Jerusalem, captured it, killed everyone who lived there, and then burned it to the ground.
1.9: Judah's army fought the Canaanites who lived in the hill country, the Southern Desert, and the foothills to the west.
1.10: After that, they attacked the Canaanites who lived at Hebron, defeating the three clans called Sheshai, Ahiman, and Talmai. At that time, Hebron was called Kiriath-Arba.
1.11: From Hebron, Judah's army went to attack Debir, which at that time was called Kiriath-Sepher.
1.12: Caleb told his troops, "The man who captures Kiriath-Sepher can marry my daughter Achsah."
1.13: Caleb's nephew Othniel captured Kiriath-Sepher, so Caleb let him marry Achsah. Othniel was the son of Caleb's younger brother Kenaz.
1.14: Right after the wedding, Achsah started telling Othniel that he ought to ask her father for a field. She went to see her father, and while she was getting down from her donkey, Caleb asked, "What's bothering you?"
1.15: She answered, "I need your help. The land you gave me is in the Southern Desert, so please give me some spring-fed ponds for a water supply." Caleb gave her a couple of small ponds named Higher Pond and Lower Pond.
1.16: The people who belonged to the Kenite clan were the descendants of the father-in-law of Moses. They left Jericho with the people of Judah and settled near Arad in the Southern Desert of Judah not far from the Amalekites.
1.17: Judah's army helped Simeon's army attack the Canaanites who lived at Zephath. They completely destroyed the town and renamed it Hormah.
1.20: The tribe of Judah gave the town of Hebron to Caleb, as Moses had told them to do. Caleb defeated the three Anakim clans and took over the town.
