6.10: I want them to be able to offer pleasing sacrifices to God and to pray for me and my family.
6.11: If any of you don't obey this order, a wooden beam will be taken from your house and sharpened on one end. Then it will be driven through your body, and your house will be torn down and turned into a garbage dump.
6.12: I ask the God who is worshiped in Jerusalem to destroy any king or nation who tries either to change what I have said or to tear down his temple. I, Darius, give these orders, and I expect them to be followed carefully.
6.13: Governor Tattenai, Shethar Bozenai, and their advisors carefully obeyed King Darius.
6.14: With great success the Jewish leaders continued working on the temple, while Haggai and Zechariah encouraged them by their preaching. And so, the temple was completed at the command of the God of Israel and by the orders of kings Cyrus, Darius, and Artaxerxes of Persia.
6.15: On the third day of the month of Adar in the sixth year of the rule of Darius, the temple was finished.
6.16: The people of Israel, the priests, the Levites, and everyone else who had returned from exile were happy and celebrated as they dedicated God's temple.
6.17: One hundred bulls, two hundred rams, and four hundred lambs were offered as sacrifices at the dedication. Also twelve goats were sacrificed as sin offerings for the twelve tribes of Israel.
6.18: Then the priests and Levites were assigned their duties in God's temple in Jerusalem, according to the instructions Moses had written.
6.19: Everyone who had returned from exile celebrated Passover on the fourteenth day of the first month.
6.20: The priests and Levites had gone through a ceremony to make themselves acceptable to lead in worship. Then some of them killed Passover lambs for those who had returned, including the other priests and themselves.
6.21: The sacrifices were eaten by the Israelites who had returned and by the neighboring people who had given up the sinful customs of other nations in order to worship the LORD God of Israel.
6.22: For seven days they celebrated the Festival of Thin Bread. Everyone was happy because the LORD God of Israel had made sure that the king of Assyria would be kind to them and help them build the temple.

7.7: Other Jews, including priests, Levites, musicians, the temple guards, and servants, came to Jerusalem with Ezra. This happened during the seventh year that Artaxerxes was king.
7.10: Ezra had spent his entire life studying and obeying the Law of the LORD and teaching it to others.
7.11: Ezra was a priest and an expert in the laws and commands that the LORD had given to Israel. One day King Artaxerxes gave Ezra a letter which said:
7.12: Greetings from the great King Artaxerxes to Ezra the priest and expert in the teachings of the God of heaven.
7.15: When you go, take the silver and gold that I and my advisors are freely giving to the God of Israel, whose temple is in Jerusalem.
7.16: Take the silver and gold that you collect from everywhere in Babylonia. Also take the gifts that your own people and priests have so willingly contributed for the temple of your God in Jerusalem.
7.17: Use the money carefully to buy the best bulls, rams, lambs, grain, and wine. Then sacrifice them on the altar at God's temple in Jerusalem.
7.18: If any silver or gold is left, you and your people may use it for whatever pleases your God.
7.19: Give your God the other articles that have been contributed for use in his temple.
7.20: If you need to get anything else for the temple, you may have the money you need from the royal treasury.
7.21: Ezra, you are a priest and an expert in the laws of the God of heaven, and I order all treasurers in Western Province to do their very best to help you.
7.22: They will be allowed to give as much as 3.4 tons of silver, 10 tons of wheat, 2,000 liters of wine, 2,000 liters of olive oil, and all the salt you need.
7.23: They must provide whatever the God of heaven demands for his temple, so that he won't be angry with me and with the kings who rule after me.
7.24: We want you to know that no priests, Levites, musicians, guards, temple servants, or any other temple workers will have to pay any kind of taxes.
7.25: Ezra, use the wisdom God has given you and choose officials and leaders to govern the people of Western Province. These leaders should know God's laws and have them taught to anyone who doesn't know them.
7.26: Everyone who fails to obey God's Law or the king's law will be punished without pity. They will either be executed or put in prison or forced to leave their country, or have all they own taken away.
7.27: Because King Artaxerxes was so kind, Ezra said: Praise the LORD God of our ancestors! He made sure that the king honored the LORD's temple in Jerusalem.
7.28: God has told the king, his advisors, and his powerful officials to treat me with kindness. The LORD God has helped me, and I have been able to bring many Jewish leaders back to Jerusalem.

8.1: Artaxerxes was king of Persia when I led the following chiefs of the family groups from Babylonia to Jerusalem:
8.15: I brought everyone together by the river that flows to the town of Ahava where we camped for three days. Not one Levite could be found among the people and priests.
8.16: So I sent for the leaders Eliezer, Ariel, Shemaiah, Elnathan, Jarib, Elnathan, Nathan, Zechariah, and Meshullam. I also sent for Joiarib and Elnathan, who were very wise counselors.
8.17: Then I sent them to Iddo, the leader at Casiphia, and I told them to ask him and his temple workers to send people to serve in God's temple.
8.18: God was kind to us and caused them to send a skillful man named Sherebiah, who was a Levite from the family of Mahli. Eighteen of his relatives came with him.
8.19: We were also sent Hashabiah and Jeshaiah from the family of Merari along with 20 of their relatives.
8.20: In addition, 220 others came to help the Levites in the temple. The ancestors of these workers had been chosen years ago by King David and his officials, and they were all listed by name.
8.21: Beside the Ahava River, I asked the people to go without eating and to pray. We humbled ourselves and asked God to bring us and our children safely to Jerusalem with all of our possessions.
8.22: I was ashamed to ask the king to send soldiers and cavalry to protect us against enemies along the way. After all, we had told the king that our God takes care of everyone who truly worships him, but that he gets very angry and punishes anyone who refuses to obey.
8.23: So we went without food and asked God himself to protect us, and he answered our prayers.
8.24: I chose twelve of the leading priests--Sherebiah, Hashabiah and ten of their relatives.
8.28: I said to the priests: You belong to the LORD, the God of your ancestors, and these things also belong to him. The silver and gold were willingly given as gifts to the LORD.
8.29: Be sure to guard them and keep them safe until you reach Jerusalem. Then weigh them inside God's temple in the presence of the chief priests, the Levites, and the heads of the Israelite families.
8.30: The priests and Levites then took charge of the gifts that had been weighed, so they could take them to the temple of our God in Jerusalem.
8.31: On the twelfth day of the first month, we left the Ahava River and started for Jerusalem. Our God watched over us, and as we traveled along, he kept our enemies from ambushing us.
8.32: After arriving in Jerusalem, we rested for three days.
8.33: Then on the fourth day we went to God's temple, where the silver, the gold, and the other things were weighed and given to the priest Meremoth son of Uriah. With him were Eleazar son of Phinehas and the two Levites, Jozabad son of Jeshua and Noadiah son of Binnui.
8.34: Everything was counted, weighed, and recorded.
8.35: Those who had returned from exile offered sacrifices on the altar to the God of Israel. Twelve bulls were offered for all Israel. Ninety-six rams and 77 lambs were offered on the altar, and 12 goats were sacrificed for the sins of the people.
8.36: Some of those who had returned took the king's orders to the governors and officials in Western Province. Then the officials did what they could for the people and for the temple of God.

9.1: Later the Jewish leaders came to me and said: Many Israelites, including priests and Levites, are living just like the people around them. They are even guilty of some of the horrible sins of the Canaanites, the Hittites, the Perizzites, the Jebusites, the Ammonites, the Moabites, the Egyptians, and the Amorites.
9.2: Some Israelite men have married foreign women and have let their sons do the same thing. Our own officials and leaders were the first to commit this disgusting sin, and now God's holy people are mixed with foreigners.
9.3: This news made me so angry that I ripped my clothes and tore hair from my head and beard. Then I just sat in shock
9.4: until the time for the evening sacrifice. Many of our people were greatly concerned and gathered around me, because the God of Israel had warned us to stay away from foreigners.
9.5: At the time of the evening sacrifice, I was still sitting there in sorrow with my clothes all torn. So I got down on my knees, then lifted my arms,
9.6: and prayed: I am much too ashamed to face you, LORD God. Our sins and our guilt have swept over us like a flood that reaches up to the heavens.
9.7: Since the time of our ancestors, all of us have sinned. That's why we, our kings, and our priests have often been defeated by other kings. They have killed some of us and made slaves of others; they have taken our possessions and made us ashamed, just as we are today.
9.9: We are slaves, but you have never turned your back on us. You love us, and because of you, the kings of Persia have helped us. It's as though you have given us new life! You let us rebuild your temple and live safely in Judah and Jerusalem.
9.10: Our God, what can we say now? Even after all this, we have disobeyed the commands
9.11: that were given to us by your servants the prophets. They said the land you are giving us is full of sinful and wicked people, who never stop doing disgusting things.
9.12: And we were warned not to let our daughters and sons marry their sons and daughters. Your prophets also told us never to help those foreigners or even let them live in peace. You wanted us to become strong and to enjoy the good things in the land, then someday to leave it to our children forever.
9.13: You punished us because of our terrible sins. But you did not punish us nearly as much as we deserve, and you have brought some of us back home.
9.14: Why should we disobey your commands again by letting our sons and daughters marry these foreigners who do such disgusting things? That would make you angry enough to destroy us all!
9.15: LORD God of Israel, you have been more than fair by letting a few of us survive. But once again, our sins have made us ashamed to face you.

10.1: While Ezra was down on his knees in front of God's temple, praying with tears in his eyes and confessing the sins of the people of Israel, a large number of men, women, and children gathered around him and cried bitterly.
10.2: Shecaniah son of Jehiel from the family of Elam said: Ezra, we have disobeyed God by marrying these foreign women. But there is still hope for the people of Israel,
10.3: if we follow your advice and the advice of others who truly respect the laws of God. We must promise God that we will divorce our foreign wives and send them away, together with their children.
10.4: Ezra, it's up to you to do something! We will support whatever you do. So be brave!
10.5: Ezra stood up and made the chief priests, the Levites, and everyone else in Israel swear that they would follow the advice of Shecaniah.
10.6: Then Ezra left God's temple and went to spend the night in the living quarters of Jehohanan son of Eliashib. He felt sorry because of what the people had done, and he did not eat or drink a thing.
10.9: Three days later, on the twentieth day of the ninth month, everyone from Judah and Benjamin came to Jerusalem and sat in the temple courtyard. It was a serious meeting, and they sat there, trembling in the rain.
10.10: Ezra the priest stood up and said: You have broken God's Law by marrying foreign women, and you have made the whole nation guilty!
10.11: Now you must confess your sins to the LORD God of your ancestors and obey him. Divorce your foreign wives and don't have anything to do with the rest of the foreigners who live around here.
10.12: Everyone in the crowd shouted: You're right! We will do what you say.
10.13: But there are so many of us, and we can't just stay out here in this downpour. A lot of us have sinned by marrying foreign women, and the matter can't be settled in only a day or two.
10.14: Why can't our officials stay on in Jerusalem and take care of this for us? Let everyone who has sinned in this way meet here at a certain time with leaders and judges from their own towns. If we take care of this problem, God will surely stop being so terribly angry with us.
10.15: Jonathan son of Asahel and Jahzeiah son of Tikvah were the only ones who objected, except for the two Levites, Meshullam and Shabbethai.
10.16: Everyone else who had returned from exile agreed with the plan. So Ezra the priest chose men who were heads of the families, and he listed their names. They started looking into the matter on the first day of the tenth month,
10.17: and they did not finish until the first day of the first month of the next year.
10.20: Hanani and Zebadiah from the family of Immer;
10.21: Maaseiah, Elijah, Shemaiah, Jehiel, and Uzziah from the family of Harim;
10.22: Elioenai, Maaseiah, Ishmael, Nethanel, Jozabad, and Elasah from the family of Pashhur.
10.23: Those Levites who had foreign wives were: Jozabad, Shimei, Kelaiah (also known as Kelita), Pethahiah, Judah, and Eliezer.
10.24: Eliashib, the musician, had a foreign wife. These temple guards had foreign wives: Shallum, Telem, and Uri.
10.25: Here is a list of the others from Israel who had foreign wives: Ramiah, Izziah, Malchijah, Mijamin, Eleazar, Hashabiah, and Benaiah from the family of Parosh;
10.26: Mattaniah, Zechariah, Jehiel, Abdi, Jeremoth, and Elijah from the family of Elam;
10.27: Elioenai, Eliashib, Mattaniah, Jeremoth, Zabad, and Aziza from the family of Zattu;
10.28: Jehohanan, Hananiah, Zabbai, and Athlai from the family of Bebai;
10.29: Meshullam, Malluch, Adaiah, Jashub, Sheal, and Jeremoth from the family of Bani;
10.30: Adna, Chelal, Benaiah, Maaseiah, Mattaniah, Bezalel, Binnui, and Manasseh from the family of Pahath Moab;
10.33: Mattenai, Mattattah, Zabad, Eliphelet, Jeremai, Manasseh, and Shimei from the family of Hashum;
10.43: Jeiel, Mattithiah, Zabad, Zebina, Jaddai, Joel, and Benaiah from the family of Nebo.
10.44: These men divorced their foreign wives, then sent them and their children away.

1.1: I am Nehemiah son of Hacaliah, and in this book I tell what I have done. During the month of Chislev in the twentieth year that Artaxerxes ruled Persia, I was in his fortress city of Susa,
1.2: when my brother Hanani came with some men from Judah. So I asked them about the Jews who had escaped from being captives in Babylonia. I also asked them about the city of Jerusalem.
1.3: They told me, "Those captives who have come back are having all kinds of troubles. They are terribly disgraced, Jerusalem's walls are broken down, and its gates have been burned."
1.4: When I heard this, I sat down on the ground and cried. Then for several days, I mourned; I went without eating to show my sorrow, and I prayed:
1.5: LORD God of heaven, you are great and fearsome. And you faithfully keep your promises to everyone who loves you and obeys your commands.
1.6: I am your servant, so please have mercy on me and answer the prayer that I make day and night for these people of Israel who serve you. I, my family, and the rest of your people have sinned
1.7: by choosing to disobey you and the laws and teachings you gave to your servant Moses.
1.8: Please remember the promise you made to Moses. You told him that if we were unfaithful, you would scatter us among foreign nations.
1.9: But you also said that no matter how far away we were, we could turn to you and start obeying your laws. Then you would bring us back to the place where you have chosen to be worshiped.
1.10: Our LORD, I am praying for your servants--those you rescued by your great strength and mighty power.
1.11: Please answer my prayer and the prayer of your other servants who gladly honor your name. When I serve the king his wine today, make him pleased with me and let him do what I ask.

2.1: During the month of Nisan in the twentieth year that Artaxerxes was king, I served him his wine, as I had done before. But this was the first time I had ever looked depressed.
2.2: So the king said, "Why do you look so sad? You're not sick. Something must be bothering you." Even though I was frightened,
2.3: I answered, "Your Majesty, I hope you live forever! I feel sad because the city where my ancestors are buried is in ruins, and its gates have been burned down."
2.4: The king asked, "What do you want me to do?" I prayed to the God who rules from heaven.
2.5: Then I told the king, "Sir, if it's all right with you, please send me back to Judah, so that I can rebuild the city where my ancestors are buried."
2.6: The queen was sitting beside the king when he asked me, "How long will it take, and when will you be back?" The king agreed to let me go, and I told him when I would return.
2.7: Then I asked, "Your Majesty, would you be willing to give me letters to the governors of the provinces west of the Euphrates River, so that I can travel safely to Judah?
2.8: I will need timber to rebuild the gates of the fortress near the temple and more timber to construct the city wall and to build a place for me to live. And so, I would appreciate a letter to Asaph, who is in charge of the royal forest." God was good to me, and the king did everything I asked.
2.9: The king sent some army officers and cavalry troops along with me, and as I traveled through the Western Provinces, I gave the letters to the governors.
2.10: But when Sanballat from Horon and Tobiah the Ammonite official heard about what had happened, they became very angry, because they didn't want anyone to help the people of Israel.
2.11: Three days after arriving in Jerusalem,
2.12: I got up during the night and left my house. I took some men with me, without telling anyone what I thought God wanted me to do for the city. The only animal I took was the donkey I rode on.
2.13: I went through Valley Gate on the west, then south past Dragon Spring, before coming to Garbage Gate. As I rode along, I took a good look at the crumbled walls of the city and the gates that had been torn down and burned.
2.14: On the east side of the city, I headed north to Fountain Gate and King's Pool, but then the trail became too narrow for my donkey.
2.15: So I went down to Kidron Valley and looked at the wall from there. Then before daylight I returned to the city through Valley Gate.
2.16: None of the city officials knew what I had in mind. And I had not even told any of the Jews--not the priests, the leaders, the officials, or any other Jews who would be helping in the work.
2.17: But when I got back, I said to them, "Jerusalem is truly in a mess! The gates have been torn down and burned, and everything is in ruins. We must rebuild the city wall so that we can again take pride in our city."
2.18: Then I told them how kind God had been and what the king had said. Immediately, they replied, "Let's start building now!" So they got everything ready.
2.19: When Sanballat, Tobiah, and Geshem the Arab heard about our plans, they started insulting us and saying, "Just look at you! Do you plan to rebuild the walls of the city and rebel against the king?"
2.20: I answered, "We are servants of the God who rules from heaven, and he will make our work succeed. So we will start rebuilding Jerusalem, but you have no right to any of its property, because you have had no part in its history."

3.1: These are the people who helped rebuild the wall and gates of Jerusalem: The high priest Eliashib and the other priests rebuilt Sheep Gate and hung its doors. Then they dedicated Sheep Gate and the section of the wall as far as Hundred Tower and Hananel Tower.
3.2: The people of Jericho rebuilt the next section of the wall, and Zaccur son of Imri rebuilt the section after that.
3.3: The family of Hassenaah built Fish Gate. They put the beams in place and hung the doors, then they added metal bolts and wooden beams as locks.
3.4: Meremoth, son of Uriah and grandson of Hakkoz, completed the next section of the wall. Meshullam, son of Berechiah and grandson of Meshezabel, rebuilt the next section, and Zadok son of Baana rebuilt the section beside that.
3.5: The next section was to be repaired by the men of Tekoa, but their town leaders refused to do the hard work they were assigned.
3.6: Joiada son of Paseah and Meshullam son of Besodeiah restored Ancient Gate. They put the beams in place, hung the doors, and added metal bolts and wooden beams as locks.
3.7: Melatiah from Gibeon, Jadon from Meronoth, and the men from Gibeon and Mizpah rebuilt the next section of the wall. This section reached as far as the house of the governor of West Euphrates Province.
3.8: Uzziel son of Harhaiah the goldsmith rebuilt the next section. Hananiah the perfume maker rebuilt the section next after that, and it went as far as Broad Wall.
3.9: Rephaiah son of Hur ruled half of the Jerusalem District, and he rebuilt the next section of the wall.
3.10: The section after that was close to the home of Jedaiah son of Harumaph, and he rebuilt it. Hattush son of Hashabneiah constructed the next section of the wall.
3.11: Malchijah son of Harim and Hasshub son of Pahath Moab rebuilt the section after that, and they also built Oven Tower.
3.12: Shallum son of Hallohesh ruled the other half of the Jerusalem District, and he rebuilt the next section of the wall. Shallum's daughters also worked with him.
3.13: Hanun and the people who lived in the town of Zanoah rebuilt Valley Gate. They hung the doors and added metal bolts and wooden beams as locks. They also rebuilt the wall for 440 meters, all the way to Garbage Gate.
3.14: Malchijah son of Rechab ruled the district of Beth-Haccherem, and he rebuilt Garbage Gate. He hung the doors and added metal bolts and wooden beams as locks.
3.15: Shallum son of Colhozeh ruled the district of Mizpah, and he rebuilt Fountain Gate. He put a cover over the gateway, then hung the doors and added metal bolts and wooden beams as locks. He also rebuilt the wall at Shelah Pool. This section was next to the king's garden and went as far as the stairs leading down from David's City.
3.16: Nehemiah son of Azbuk ruled half of the district of Beth-Zur, and he rebuilt the next section of the wall. It went as far as the royal cemetery, the artificial pool, and the army barracks.
3.17: The Levites who worked on the next sections of the wall were Rehum son of Bani; Hashabiah, who ruled half of the district of Keilah and did this work for his district;
3.18: Binnui son of Henadad, who ruled the other half of the district of Keilah;
3.19: Ezer son of Jeshua, who ruled Mizpah, rebuilt the section of the wall that was in front of the armory and reached to the corner of the wall;
3.20: Baruch son of Zabbai eagerly rebuilt the section of the wall that went all the way to the door of the house of Eliashib the high priest;
3.21: Meremoth, son of Uriah and grandson of Hakkoz, built up to the far end of Eliashib's house.
3.22: Here is a list of the priests who worked on the wall: Priests from the region around Jerusalem rebuilt the next section of the wall.
3.23: Benjamin and Hasshub rebuilt the wall in front of their own houses. Azariah, who was the son of Maaseiah and the grandson of Ananiah, rebuilt the section in front of his house.
3.24: Binnui son of Henadad rebuilt the section of the wall from Azariah's house to the corner of the wall.
3.25: Palal son of Uzai rebuilt the next section, which began at the corner of the wall and the tower of the upper palace near the court of the guard. Pedaiah son of Parosh rebuilt the next section of the wall.
3.26: He stopped at a place near the Water Gate on the east and the tower guarding the temple. This was close to a section in the city called Ophel, where the temple workers lived.
3.27: The men from Tekoa rebuilt the next section of the wall, and it was their second section. It started at a place across from the large tower that guarded the Temple, and it went all the way to the wall near Ophel.
3.28: Some priests rebuilt the next section of the wall. They began working north of Horse Gate, and each one worked on a section in front of his own house.
3.29: Zadok son of Immer rebuilt the wall in front of his house. Shemaiah son of Shecaniah, who looked after the East Gate, rebuilt the section after that.
3.30: Hananiah and Hanun rebuilt the next section, which was the second section for them. Meshullam son of Berechiah rebuilt the next section, which happened to be in front of his house.
3.31: Malchijah, a goldsmith, rebuilt the next section, as far as the house used by the temple workers and merchants. This area was across from Gathering Gate, near the room on top of the wall at the northeast corner.
3.32: The goldsmiths and merchants rebuilt the last section of the wall, which went from the corner room all the way to Sheep Gate.

4.1: When Sanballat, the governor of Samaria, heard that we were rebuilding the walls of Jerusalem, he became angry and started insulting our people.
4.2: In front of his friends and the Samaritan army he said, "What is this feeble bunch of Jews trying to do? Are they going to rebuild the wall and offer sacrifices all in one day? Do they think they can make something out of this pile of scorched stones?"
4.3: Tobiah from Ammon was standing beside Sanballat and said, "Look at the wall they are building! Why, even a fox could knock over this pile of stones."
4.4: But I prayed, "Our God, these people hate us and have wished horrible things for us. Please answer our prayers and make their insults fall on them! Let them be the ones to be dragged away as prisoners of war.
4.5: Don't forgive the mean and evil way they have insulted the builders."
4.6: The people worked hard, and we built the walls of Jerusalem halfway up again.
4.7: But Sanballat, Tobiah, the Arabs, the Ammonites, and the people from the city of Ashdod saw the walls going up and the holes being repaired. So they became angry
4.8: and decided to stir up trouble, and to fight against the people of Jerusalem.
4.9: But we kept on praying to our God, and we also stationed guards day and night.
4.10: Meanwhile, the people of Judah were singing a sorrowful song: "So much rubble for us to haul! Worn out and weary, will we ever finish this wall?"
4.11: Our enemies were saying, "Before those Jews know what has happened, we will sneak up and kill them and put an end to their work."
4.12: On at least ten different occasions, the Jews living near our enemies warned us against attacks from every side,
4.13: and so I sent people to guard the wall at its lowest places and where there were still holes in it. I placed them according to families, and they stood guard with swords and spears and with bows and arrows.
4.15: Our enemies found out that we knew about their plot against us, but God kept them from doing what they had planned. So we went back to work on the wall.
4.16: From then on, I let half of the young men work while the other half stood guard. They wore armor and had spears and shields, as well as bows and arrows. The leaders helped the workers
4.17: who were rebuilding the wall. Everyone who hauled building materials kept one hand free to carry a weapon.
4.18: Even the workers who were rebuilding the wall strapped on a sword. The worker who was to blow the signal trumpet stayed with me.
4.19: I told the people and their officials and leaders, "Our work is so spread out, that we are a long way from one another.
4.20: If you hear the sound of the trumpet, come quickly and gather around me. Our God will help us fight."
4.21: Every day from dawn to dark, half of the workers rebuilt the walls, while the rest stood guard with their spears.
4.22: I asked the men in charge and their workers to stay inside Jerusalem and stand guard at night. So they guarded the city at night and worked during the day.
4.23: I even slept in my work clothes at night; my relatives, the workers, and the guards slept in theirs as well. And we always kept our weapons close by.

5.1: Some of the men and their wives complained about the Jews in power
5.2: and said, "We have large families, and it takes a lot of grain merely to keep us alive."
5.3: Others said, "During the famine we even had to mortgage our fields, vineyards, and homes to them in order to buy grain."
5.4: Then others said, "We had to borrow money from those in power to pay the government tax on our fields and vineyards.
5.5: We are Jews just as they are, and our children are as good as theirs. But we still have to sell our children as slaves, and some of our daughters have already been raped. We are completely helpless; our fields and vineyards have even been taken from us."
5.6: When I heard their complaints and their charges, I became very angry.
5.7: So I thought it over and said to the leaders and officials, "How can you charge your own people interest?" Then I called a public meeting and accused the leaders
5.8: by saying, "We have tried to buy back all of our people who were sold into exile. But here you are, selling more of them for us to buy back!" The officials and leaders did not say a word, because they knew this was true.
5.9: I continued, "What you have done is wrong! We must honor our God by the way we live, so the Gentiles can't find fault with us.
5.10: My relatives, my friends, and I are also lending money and grain, but we must no longer demand payment in return.
5.11: Now give back the fields, vineyards, olive orchards, and houses you have taken and also the interest you have been paid."
5.12: The leaders answered, "We will do whatever you say and return their property, without asking to be repaid." So I made the leaders promise in front of the priests to give back the property.
5.14: I was governor of Judah from the twentieth year that Artaxerxes was king until the thirty-second year. And during these entire twelve years, my relatives and I refused to accept the food that I was allowed.
5.15: Each governor before me had been a burden to the people by making them pay for his food and wine and by demanding forty silver coins a day. Even their officials had been a burden to the people. But I respected God, and I didn't think it was right to be so hard on them.
5.16: I spent all my time getting the wall rebuilt and did not buy any property. Everyone working for me did the same thing.
5.17: I usually fed 150 of our own Jewish people and their leaders, as well as foreign visitors from surrounding lands.
5.18: Each day one ox, six of the best sheep, and lots of chickens were prepared. Then every ten days, a large supply of wine was brought in. I knew what a heavy burden this would have been for the people, and so I did not ask for my food allowance as governor.
5.19: I pray that God will bless me for everything I have done for my people.

6.1: Sanballat, Tobiah, Geshem, and our other enemies learned that I had completely rebuilt the wall. All I lacked was hanging the doors in the gates.
6.3: So I sent messengers to tell them, "My work is too important to stop now and go there. I can't afford to slow down the work just to visit with you."
6.4: They invited me four times, but each time I refused to go.
6.5: Finally, Sanballat sent an official to me with an unsealed letter,
6.6: which said: A rumor is going around among the nations that you and the other Jews are rebuilding the wall and planning to rebel, because you want to be their king. And Geshem says it's true!
6.7: You even have prophets in Jerusalem, claiming you are now the king of Judah. You know the Persian king will hear about this, so let's get together and talk it over.
6.8: I sent a message back to Sanballat, saying, "None of this is true! You are making it all up."
6.9: Our enemies were trying to frighten us and to keep us from our work. But I asked God to give me strength.
6.10: One day I went to visit Shemaiah. He wasn't supposed to leave his house, but he said, "Let's hurry to the holy place of the temple and hide there. We will lock the temple doors, because your enemies are planning to kill you tonight."
6.11: I answered, "Why should someone like me have to run and hide in the temple to save my life? I won't go!"
6.12: Suddenly I realized that God had not given Shemaiah this message. But Tobiah and Sanballat had paid him to trick me
6.13: and to frighten me into doing something wrong, because they wanted to ruin my good name.
6.14: Then I asked God to punish Tobiah and Sanballat for what they had done. I prayed that God would punish the prophet Noadiah and the other prophets who, together with her, had tried to frighten me.
6.15: On the twenty-fifth day of the month Elul, the wall was completely rebuilt. It had taken 52 days.
6.16: When our enemies in the surrounding nations learned that the work was finished, they felt helpless, because they knew that our God had helped us rebuild the wall.
6.17: All this time the Jewish leaders and Tobiah had been writing letters back and forth.
6.18: Many people in Judah were loyal to Tobiah for two reasons: Shecaniah son of Arah was his father-in-law, and Tobiah's son Jehohanan had married the daughter of Meshullam son of Berechiah.
6.19: The people would always tell me about the good things Tobiah had done, and then they would tell Tobiah everything I had said. So Tobiah kept sending letters, trying to frighten me.

9.1: On the twenty-fourth day of the seventh month, the people of Israel went without eating, and they dressed in sackcloth and threw dirt on their heads to show their sorrow.
9.2: They refused to let foreigners join them, as they met to confess their sins and the sins of their ancestors.
9.3: For three hours they stood and listened to the Law of the LORD their God, and then for the next three hours they confessed their sins and worshiped the LORD.
9.4: Jeshua, Bani, Kadmiel, Shebaniah, Bunni, Sherebiah, Bani, and Chenani stood on the special platform for the Levites and prayed aloud to the LORD their God.
9.6: You alone are the LORD, Creator of the heavens and all the stars, Creator of the earth and those who live on it, Creator of the ocean and all its creatures. You are the source of life, praised by the stars that fill the heavens.
9.7: You are the LORD our God, the one who chose Abram--you brought him from Ur in Babylonia and named him Abraham.
9.8: Because he was faithful, you made an agreement to give his descendants the land of the Canaanites and Hittites, of the Amorites and Perizzites, and of the Jebusites and Girgashites. Now you have kept your promise, just as you always do.
9.9: When our ancestors were in Egypt, you saw their suffering; when they were at the Red Sea, you heard their cry for help.
9.10: You knew that the King of Egypt and his officials and his nation had mistreated your people. So you worked fearsome miracles against the Egyptians and earned a reputation that still remains.
9.11: You divided the deep sea, and your people walked through on dry land. But you tossed their enemies in, and they sank down like a heavy stone.
9.12: Each day you led your people with a thick cloud, and at night you showed the way with a flaming fire.
9.13: At Sinai you came down from heaven, and you gave your people good laws and teachings that are fair and honest.
9.14: You commanded them to respect your holy Sabbath, and you instructed your servant Moses to teach them your laws.
9.15: When they were hungry, you sent bread from heaven, and when they were thirsty, you let water flow from a rock. Then you commanded them to capture the land that you had solemnly promised. *
9.17: But, our God, you are merciful and quick to forgive; you are loving, kind, and very patient. So you never turned away from them--
9.18: not even when they made an idol shaped like a calf and insulted you by claiming, "This is the god who rescued us from Egypt."
9.19: Because of your great mercy, you never abandoned them in the desert. And you always guided them with a cloud by day and a fire at night.
9.20: Your gentle Spirit instructed them, and you gave them manna to eat and water to drink.
9.21: You took good care of them, and for forty years they never lacked a thing. Their clothes didn't wear out, and their feet were never swollen.
9.22: You let them conquer kings and take their land, including King Sihon of Heshbon and King Og of Bashan.
9.23: You brought them into the land that you had promised their ancestors, and you blessed their nation with people that outnumbered the stars in the sky.
9.24: Then their descendants conquered the land. You helped them defeat the kings and nations and treat their enemies however they wished.
9.25: They captured strong cities and rich farmland; they took furnished houses, as well as cisterns, vineyards, olive orchards, and numerous fruit trees. They ate till they were satisfied, and they celebrated your abundant blessings.
9.27: So you handed them over to their enemies, who treated them terribly. But in their sufferings, they begged you to help. From heaven you listened to their prayers and because of your great mercy, you sent leaders to rescue them.
9.29: You warned them to turn back and discover true life by obeying your laws. But they stubbornly refused and continued to sin.
9.30: For years, you were patient, and your Spirit warned them with messages spoken by your prophets. Still they refused to listen, and you handed them over to their enemies.
9.31: But you are merciful and kind, and so you never forgot them or let them be destroyed.
9.32: Our God, you are powerful, fearsome, and faithful, always true to your word. So please keep in mind the terrible sufferings of our people, kings, leaders, priests, and prophets, from the time Assyria ruled until this very day.
9.33: You have always been fair when you punished us for our sins.
9.34: Our kings and leaders, our priests and ancestors have never obeyed your commands or heeded your warnings.
9.35: You blessed them with a kingdom and with an abundance of rich, fertile land, but they refused to worship you or turn from their evil.
9.37: Its plentiful harvest is taken by kings you placed over us because of our sins. Our suffering is unbearable, because they do as they wish to us and our livestock.
9.38: And so, a firm agreement was made that had the official approval of the leaders, the Levites, and priests.

12.45: when they performed the ceremonies to make people acceptable to worship God. And the singers and the temple guards did their jobs according to the instructions given by David and his son Solomon.

13.1: On that day when the Law of Moses was read aloud to everyone, it was discovered that Ammonites and Moabites were forbidden to belong to the people of God.
13.2: This was because they had refused to give food and water to Israel and had hired Balaam to call down a curse on them. However, our God turned the curse into a blessing.
13.3: Following the reading of the Law of Moses, the people of Israel started sending away anyone who had any foreign ancestors.
13.4: The priest Eliashib was a relative of Tobiah and had earlier been put in charge of the temple storerooms.
13.5: So he let Tobiah live in one of these rooms, where all kinds of things had been stored--the grain offerings, incense, utensils for the temple, as well as the tenth of the grain, wine, and olive oil that had been given for the use of the Levites, singers, and temple guards, and the gifts for the priests.
13.6: This happened in the thirty-second year that Artaxerxes ruled Babylonia. I was away from Jerusalem at the time, because I was visiting him. Later I received permission from the king
13.7: to return to Jerusalem. Only then did I find out that Eliashib had done this terrible thing of letting Tobiah have a room in the temple.
13.8: It upset me so much that I threw out every bit of Tobiah's furniture.
13.9: Then I ordered the room to be cleaned and the temple utensils, the grain offerings, and the incense to be brought back into the room.
13.10: I also found out that the temple singers and several other Levites had returned to work on their farms, because they had not been given their share of the harvest.
13.11: I called the leaders together and angrily asked them, "Why is the temple neglected?" Then I told them to start doing their jobs.
13.12: After this, everyone in Judah brought a tenth of their grain, wine, and olive oil to the temple storeroom.
13.13: Finally, I appointed three men with good reputations to be in charge of what was brought there and to distribute it to the others. They were Shelemiah the priest, Zadok the teacher of the Law, and Pedaiah the Levite. Their assistant was Hanan, the son of Zaccur and the grandson of Mattaniah.
13.14: I pray that my God will remember these good things that I have done for his temple and for those who worship there.
13.15: I also noticed what the people of Judah were doing on the Sabbath. Not only were they trampling grapes to make wine, but they were harvesting their grain, grapes, figs, and other crops, and then loading these on donkeys to sell in Jerusalem. So I warned them not to sell food on the Sabbath.
13.16: People who had moved to Jerusalem from the city of Tyre were bringing in fish and other things to sell there on the Sabbath.
13.17: I got angry and said to the leaders of Judah, "This evil you are doing is an insult to the Sabbath!
13.18: Didn't God punish us and this city because our ancestors did these very same things? And here you are, about to make God furious again by disgracing the Sabbath!"
13.19: I ordered the gates of Jerusalem to be closed on the eve of the Sabbath and not to be opened until after the Sabbath had ended. Then I put some of my own men in charge of the gates to make certain that nothing was brought in on the Sabbath.
13.20: Once or twice some merchants spent the night outside Jerusalem with their goods.
13.21: But I warned them, "If you do this again, I'll have you arrested." From then on, they did not come on the Sabbath.
13.22: I ordered the Levites to make themselves holy and to guard the gates on the Sabbath, so that it would be kept holy. God is truly merciful, and I pray that he will treat me with kindness and bless me for doing this.
13.23: I discovered that some Jewish men had married women from Ashdod, Ammon, and Moab.
13.24: About half of their children could not speak Hebrew--they spoke only the language of Ashdod or some other foreign language.
13.25: So in my anger, I called down curses on those men. I had them beaten and even pulled out the hair of some of them. Then I made them promise: In the name of God we solemnly promise not to let our sons and daughters marry foreigners.
13.26: God dearly loved King Solomon of Israel and made him the greatest king on earth, but Solomon's foreign wives led him into sin.
13.27: So we will obey you and not rebel against our God by marrying foreign women.
13.28: Jehoiada, the son of the high priest Eliashib, had a son who had married a daughter of Sanballat from Horon, and I forced his son to leave.
13.29: I pray that God will punish them for breaking their priestly vows and disgracing the Levi tribe.
13.30: Then I made sure that the people were free from every foreign influence, and I assigned duties for the priests and Levites.
13.31: I also arranged for the people to bring firewood to the altar each day and for them to bring the first part of their harvest to the temple. I pray that God will bless me for the good I have done.

1.3: During the third year of his rule, Xerxes gave a big dinner for all his officials and officers. The governors and leaders of the provinces were also invited, and even the commanders of the Persian and Median armies came.
1.4: For 180 days he showed off his wealth and spent a lot of money to impress his guests with the greatness of his kingdom.
1.5: At the end of this time, King Xerxes gave another dinner and invited everyone in the city of Susa, no matter who they were. The eating and drinking lasted seven days in the beautiful palace gardens.
1.6: The area was decorated with blue and white cotton curtains tied back with purple linen cords that ran through silver rings fastened to marble columns. Couches of gold and silver rested on pavement that had all kinds of designs made from costly bright-colored stones and marble and mother-of-pearl.
1.7: The guests drank from gold cups, and each cup had a different design. The king was generous
1.8: and said to them, "Drink all you want!" Then he told his servants, "Keep their cups full."
1.9: While the men were enjoying themselves, Queen Vashti gave the women a big dinner inside the royal palace.
1.10: By the seventh day, King Xerxes was feeling happy because of so much wine. And he asked his seven personal servants, Mehuman, Biztha, Harbona, Bigtha, Abagtha, Zethar, and Carkas,
1.11: to bring Queen Vashti to him. The king wanted her to wear her crown and let his people and his officials see how beautiful she was.
1.12: The king's servants told Queen Vashti what he had said, but she refused to go to him, and this made him terribly angry.
1.16: Then Memucan told the king and the officials: Your Majesty, Queen Vashti has not only embarrassed you, but she has insulted your officials and everyone else in all the provinces.
1.17: The women in the kingdom will hear about this, and they will refuse to respect their husbands. They will say, "If Queen Vashti doesn't obey her husband, why should we?"
1.18: Before this day is over, the wives of the officials of Persia and Media will find out what Queen Vashti has done, and they will refuse to obey their husbands. They won't respect their husbands, and their husbands will be angry with them.
1.19: Your Majesty, if you agree, you should write for the Medes and Persians a law that can never be changed. This law would keep Queen Vashti from ever seeing you again. Then you could let someone who respects you be queen in her place.

7.18: Why do you test us from sunrise to sunset?
7.19: Won't you look away just long enough for me to swallow?
7.20: Why do you watch us so closely? What's it to you, if I sin? Why am I your target and such a heavy burden?
7.21: Why do you refuse to forgive? Soon you won't find me, because I'll be dead.

8.1: Bildad from Shuah said:
8.2: How long will you talk and keep saying nothing?
8.3: Does God All-Powerful stand in the way of justice?
8.4: He made your children pay for their sins.
8.5: So why don't you turn to him
8.6: and start living right? Then he will decide to rescue and restore you to your place of honor.
8.7: Your future will be brighter by far than your past.
8.8: Our ancestors were wise, so learn from them.
8.9: Our own time has been short, like a fading shadow, and we know very little.
8.10: But they will instruct you with great understanding.
8.11: Papyrus reeds grow healthy only in a swamp,
8.12: and if the water dries up, they die sooner than grass.
8.13: Such is the hopeless future of all who turn from God
8.14: and trust in something as frail as a spider's web--
8.15: they take hold and fall because it's so flimsy.
8.16: Sinful people are like plants with spreading roots and plenty of sun and water.
8.17: They wrap their roots tightly around rocks.
8.18: But once they are pulled up, they have no more place;
8.19: their life slips away, and other plants grow there.
8.20: We know God doesn't reject an innocent person or help a sinner.
8.21: And so, he will make you happy and give you something to smile about.
8.22: But your evil enemies will be put to shame and disappear forever.

9.1: Job said:
9.2: What you say is true. No human is innocent in the sight of God.
9.3: Not once in a thousand times could we win our case if we took him to court.
9.4: God is wise and powerful--who could possibly oppose him and win?
9.5: When God becomes angry, he can move mountains before they even know it.
9.6: God can shake the earth loose from its foundations
9.7: or command the sun and stars to hold back their light.
9.8: God alone stretched out the sky, stepped on the sea,
9.9: and set the stars in place--the Big Dipper and Orion, the Pleiades and the stars in the southern sky.
9.10: Of all the miracles God works, we cannot understand a one.
9.11: God walks right past me, without making a sound.
9.12: And if he grabs something, who can stop him or raise a question?
9.13: When God showed his anger, the servants of the sea monster fell at his feet.
9.14: How, then, could I possibly argue my case with God?
9.15: Even though I am innocent, I can only beg for mercy.
9.16: And if God came into court when I called him, he would not hear my case.
9.17: He would strike me with a storm and increase my injuries for no reason at all.
9.18: Before I could get my breath, my miseries would multiply.
9.19: God is much stronger than I am, and who would call me into court to give me justice?
9.20: Even if I were innocent, God would prove me wrong.
9.21: I am not guilty, but I no longer care what happens to me.
9.22: What difference does it make? God destroys the innocent along with the guilty.
9.23: When a good person dies a sudden death, God sits back and laughs.
9.24: And who else but God blindfolds the judges, then lets the wicked take over the earth?
9.25: My life is speeding by, without a hope of happiness.
9.26: Each day passes swifter than a sailing ship or an eagle swooping down.
9.27: Sometimes I try to be cheerful and to stop complaining,
9.28: but my sufferings frighten me, because I know that God still considers me guilty.
9.29: So what's the use of trying to prove my innocence?
9.30: Even if I washed myself with the strongest soap,
9.31: God would throw me into a pit of stinking slime, leaving me disgusting to my clothes.
9.32: God isn't a mere human like me. I can't put him on trial.
9.33: Who could possibly judge between the two of us?
9.34: Can someone snatch away the stick God carries to frighten me?
9.35: Then I could speak up without fear of him, but for now, I cannot speak.

10.1: I am sick of life! And from my deep despair, I complain to you, my God.
10.3: Why do you take such delight in destroying those you created and in smiling on sinners?
10.4: Do you look at things the way we humans do?
10.5: Is your life as short as ours?
10.6: Is that why you are so quick to find fault with me?
10.7: You know I am innocent, but who can defend me against you?
10.8: Will you now destroy someone you created?
10.9: Remember that you molded me like a piece of clay. So don't turn me back into dust once again.
10.10: As cheese is made from milk, you created my body from a tiny drop.
10.11: Then you tied my bones together with muscles and covered them with flesh and skin.
10.12: You, the source of my life, showered me with kindness and watched over me.
10.13: You have not explained all of your mysteries,
10.14: but you catch and punish me each time I sin.
10.15: Guilty or innocent, I am condemned and ashamed because of my troubles.
10.16: No matter how hard I try, you keep hunting me down like a powerful lion.
10.17: You never stop accusing me; you become furious and attack over and over again.
10.18: Why did you let me be born? I would rather have died before birth
10.19: and been carried to the grave without ever breathing.
10.20: I have only a few days left. Why don't you leave me alone? Let me find some relief, *
10.21: before I travel to the land
10.22: of darkness and despair, the place of no return.

11.1: Zophar from Naamah said:
11.2: So much foolish talk cannot go unanswered.
11.3: Your words have silenced others and made them ashamed; now it is only right for you to be put to shame.
11.4: You claim to be innocent and argue that your beliefs are acceptable to God.
11.5: But I wish God would speak
11.6: and let you know that wisdom has many different sides. You would then discover that God has punished you less than you deserve.
11.8: They are higher than the heavens and deeper than the grave. So what can you do when you know so little,
11.9: and these mysteries outreach the earth and the ocean?
11.10: If God puts you in prison or drags you to court, what can you do?
11.11: God has the wisdom to know when someone is worthless and sinful,
11.12: but it's easier to tame a wild donkey than to make a fool wise.
11.13: Surrender your heart to God, turn to him in prayer,
11.14: and give up your sins--even those you do in secret.
11.15: Then you won't be ashamed; you will be confident and fearless.
11.16: Your troubles will go away like water beneath a bridge,
11.17: and your darkest night will be brighter than noon.
11.18: You will rest safe and secure, filled with hope and emptied of worry.
11.19: You will sleep without fear and be greatly respected.
11.20: But those who are evil will go blind and lose their way. Their only escape is death!

12.1: Job said to his friends:
12.2: You think you are so great, with all the answers.
12.3: But I know as much as you do, and so does everyone else.
12.4: I have always lived right, and God answered my prayers; now friends make fun of me.
12.5: It's easy to condemn those who are suffering, when you have no troubles.
12.6: Robbers and other godless people live safely at home and say, "God is in our hands!"
12.8: the flowers and the fish.
12.9: Any of them can tell you what the LORD has done.
12.10: Every living creature is in the hands of God.
12.11: We hear with our ears, taste with our tongues,
12.12: and gain some wisdom from those who have lived a long time.
12.13: But God is the real source of wisdom and strength.
12.14: No one can rebuild what he destroys, or release those he has imprisoned.
12.15: God can hold back the rain or send a flood,
12.16: just as he rules over liars and those they lie to.
12.17: God shames counselors, turns judges into fools,
12.19: God removes priests and others who have great power--
12.21: puts mighty kings to shame, and takes away their power.
12.23: he makes nations strong, then shatters their strength.
12.24: God strikes their rulers senseless, then leaves them to roam through barren deserts,
12.25: lost in the dark, staggering like someone drunk.

13.1: I know and understand every bit of this.
13.2: None of you are smarter than I am; there's nothing you know that I don't.
13.3: But I prefer to argue my case with God All-Powerful--
13.4: you are merely useless doctors, who treat me with lies.
13.5: The wisest thing you can do is to keep quiet
13.6: and listen to my argument.
13.7: Are you telling lies for God
13.8: and not telling the whole truth when you argue his case?
13.9: If he took you to court, could you fool him, just as you fool others?
13.10: If you were secretly unfair, he would correct you,
13.11: and his glorious splendor would make you terrified.
13.12: Your wisdom and arguments will blow away like dust.
13.13: Be quiet while I speak, and we'll see what happens.
13.14: I will be responsible for what happens to me.
13.15: God may kill me, but still I will trust him and offer my defense.
13.16: This may be what saves me, because no guilty person would come to his court.
13.17: Listen carefully to my words!
13.18: I have prepared my case well, and I am certain to win.
13.19: If you can prove me guilty, I will give up and die.
13.20: I ask only two things of you, my God, and I will no longer hide from you--
13.22: Then speak, and I will reply; or else let me speak, and you reply.
13.23: Please point out my sins, so I will know them.
13.24: Why have you turned your back and count me your enemy?
13.25: Do you really enjoy frightening a fallen leaf?
13.26: Why do you accuse me of horrible crimes and make me pay for sins I did in my youth?
13.27: You have tied my feet down and keep me surrounded;
13.28: I am rotting away like cloth eaten by worms.

14.1: Life is short and sorrowful for every living soul.
14.2: We are flowers that fade and shadows that vanish.
14.3: And so, I ask you, God, why pick on me?
14.4: There's no way a human can be completely pure.
14.5: Our time on earth is brief; the number of our days is already decided by you.
14.6: Why don't you leave us alone and let us find some happiness while we toil and labor?
14.8: Its roots and stump may rot,
14.9: but at the touch of water, it sprouts once again.
14.10: Humans are different--we die, and that's the end.
14.11: We are like streams and lakes after the water has gone;
14.12: we fall into the sleep of death, never to rise again, until the sky disappears.
14.13: Please hide me, God, deep in the ground--and when you are angry no more, remember to rescue me.
14.14: Will we humans live again? I would gladly suffer and wait for my time.
14.15: My Creator, you would want me; you would call out, and I would answer.
14.16: You would take care of me, but not count my sins--
14.17: you would put them in a bag, tie it tight, and toss them away.
14.19: streams wear away stones and wash away soil. And you destroy our hopes!
14.20: You change the way we look, then send us away, wiped out forever.
14.21: We never live to know if our children are praised or disgraced.
14.22: We feel no pain but our own, and when we mourn, it's only for ourselves.

15.1: Eliphaz from Teman said: *
15.2: Job, if you had any sense,
15.3: you would stop spreading all of this hot air.
15.4: Your words are enough to make others turn from God and lead them to doubt.
15.5: And your sinful, scheming mind is the source of all you say.
15.6: I am not here as your judge; your own words are witnesses against you.
15.7: Were you the first human? Are you older than the hills?
15.8: Have you ever been present when God's council meets? Do you alone have wisdom?
15.9: Do you know and understand something we don't?
15.10: We have the benefit of wisdom older than your father.
15.11: And you have been offered comforting words from God. Isn't this enough?
15.12: Your emotions are out of control, making you look fierce;
15.13: that's why you attack God with everything you say.
15.14: No human is pure and innocent,
15.15: and neither are angels--not in the sight of God. If God doesn't trust his angels,
15.16: what chance do humans have? We are so terribly evil that we thirst for sin.
15.17: Just listen to what I know, and you will learn
15.18: wisdom known by others since ancient times.
15.19: Those who gained such insights also gained the land, and they were not influenced by foreign teachings.
15.20: But suffering is in store each day for those who sin.
15.21: Even in times of success, they constantly hear the threat of doom.
15.22: Darkness, despair, and death are their destiny.
15.23: They scrounge around for food, all the while dreading the approaching darkness.
15.24: They are overcome with despair, like frightened soldiers facing a fearsome king in battle.
15.25: This is because they rebelled against God All-Powerful
15.26: and have attacked him with their weapons.
15.27: They may be rich and fat,
15.28: but they will live in the ruins of deserted towns.
15.29: Their property and wealth will shrink and disappear.
15.30: They won't escape the darkness, and the blazing breath of God will set their future aflame. *
15.31: They have put their trust in something worthless; now they will become worthless
15.32: like a date palm tree without a leaf.
15.33: Or like vineyards or orchards whose blossoms and unripe fruit drop to the ground.
15.34: Yes, the godless and the greedy will have nothing but flames feasting on their homes,
15.35: because they are the parents of trouble and vicious lies.

16.1: Job said:
16.2: I have often heard this, and it offers no comfort.
16.3: So why don't you keep quiet? What's bothering you?
16.4: If I were in your place, it would be easy to criticize or to give advice.
16.5: But I would offer hope and comfort instead.
16.6: If I speak, or if I don't, I hurt all the same. My torment continues.
16.7: God has worn me down and destroyed my family;
16.8: my shriveled up skin proves that I am his prisoner.
16.9: God is my hateful enemy, glaring at me and attacking with his sharp teeth.
16.10: Everyone is against me; they sneer and slap my face.
16.11: And God is the one who handed me over to this merciless mob.
16.12: Everything was going well, until God grabbed my neck and shook me to pieces. God set me up as the target
16.13: for his arrows, and without showing mercy, he slashed my stomach open, spilling out my insides.
16.14: God never stops attacking,
16.15: and so, in my sorrow I dress in sackcloth and sit in the dust.
16.16: My face is red with tears, and dark shadows circle my eyes,
16.17: though I am not violent, and my prayers are sincere.
16.18: If I should die, I beg the earth not to cover my cry for justice.
16.19: Even now, God in heaven is both my witness and my protector.
16.20: My friends have rejected me, but God is the one I beg
16.21: to show that I am right, just as a friend should.
16.22: Because in only a few years, I will be dead and gone.

17.1: My hopes have died, my time is up, and the grave is ready.
17.2: All I can see are angry crowds, making fun of me.
17.3: If you, LORD, don't help, who will pay the price for my release?
17.4: My friends won't really listen, all because of you, and so you must be the one to prove them wrong.
17.5: They have condemned me, just to benefit themselves; now blind their children.
17.6: You, God, are the reason I am insulted and spit on.
17.7: I am almost blind with grief; my body is a mere shadow.
17.8: People who are truly good would feel so alarmed, that they would become angry with my worthless friends.
17.9: They would do the right thing and because they did, they would grow stronger.
17.11: My life is drawing to an end; hope has disappeared.
17.12: But all my friends can do is offer empty hopes.
17.13: I could tell the world below to prepare me a bed.
17.14: Then I could greet the grave as my father and say to the worms, "Hello, mother and sisters!"
17.15: But what kind of hope is that?
17.16: Will it keep me company in the world of the dead?

18.1: Bildad from Shuah said:
18.2: How long will you talk? Be sensible! Let us speak.
18.3: Or do you think that we are dumb animals?
18.4: You cut yourself in anger. Will that shake the earth or even move the rocks? *
18.5: The lamps of sinful people soon are snuffed out,
18.6: leaving their tents dark.
18.7: Their powerful legs become weak, and they stumble on schemes of their own doing. *
18.9: they are trapped in a net,
18.11: Terror strikes and pursues from every side.
18.12: Starving, they run, only to meet disaster,
18.13: then afterwards to be eaten alive by death itself.
18.14: Those sinners are dragged from the safety of their tents to die a gruesome death.
18.15: Then their tents and possessions are burned to ashes,
18.16: and they are left like trees, dried up from the roots.
18.17: They are gone and forgotten,
18.18: thrown far from the light into a world of darkness,
18.19: without any children to carry on their name.
18.20: Everyone, from east to west, is overwhelmed with horror.
18.21: Such is the fate of sinners and their families who don't know God.

19.1: Job said:
19.2: How long will you torture me with your words?
19.3: Isn't ten times enough for you to accuse me? Aren't you ashamed?
19.4: Even if I have sinned, you haven't been harmed.
19.5: You boast of your goodness, claiming I am suffering because I am guilty.
19.6: But God is the one at fault for finding fault with me.
19.7: Though I pray to be rescued from this torment, no whisper of justice answers me.
19.8: God has me trapped with a wall of darkness
19.9: and stripped of respect.
19.10: God rips me apart, uproots my hopes,
19.11: and attacks with fierce anger, as though I were his enemy.
19.12: His entire army advances, then surrounds my tent. *
19.13: God has turned relatives and friends against me,
19.14: and I am forgotten.
19.15: My guests and my servants consider me a stranger,
19.16: and when I call my servants, they pay no attention.
19.17: My breath disgusts my wife; everyone in my family turns away.
19.18: Young children can't stand me, and when I come near, they make fun.
19.19: My best friends and loved ones have turned from me.
19.20: I am skin and bones--just barely alive.
19.21: My friends, I beg you for pity! God has made me his target.
19.22: Hasn't he already done enough? Why do you join the attack?
19.23: I wish that my words could be written down
19.25: I know that my Protector lives, and at the end he will stand on this earth.
19.26: My flesh may be destroyed, yet from this body I will see God.
19.27: Yes, I will see him for myself, and I long for that moment.
19.28: My friends, you think up ways to blame and torment me, saying I brought it on myself.
19.29: But watch out for the judgment, when God will punish you!

20.1: Zophar from Naamah said:
20.2: Your words are disturbing; now I must speak.
20.3: You have accused and insulted me, and reason requires a reply.
20.4: Since the time of creation, everyone has known
20.5: that sinful people are happy for only a while.
20.6: Though their pride and power may reach to the sky,
20.7: they will disappear like dust, and those who knew them will wonder what happened.
20.8: They will be forgotten like a dream
20.9: and vanish from the sight of family and friends.
20.10: Their children will have to repay what the parents took from the poor.
20.11: Indeed, the wicked will die and go to their graves in the prime of life.
20.12: Sinners love the taste of sin; they relish every bite
20.14: But their food will turn sour and poison their stomachs.
20.15: Then God will make them lose the wealth they gobbled up.
20.16: They will die from the fangs of poisonous snakes
20.17: and never enjoy rivers flowing with milk and honey.
20.18: Their hard work will result in nothing gained,
20.19: because they cheated the poor and took their homes.
20.20: Greedy people want everything and are never satisfied.
20.21: But when nothing remains for them to grab, they will be nothing.
20.22: Once they have everything, distress and despair will strike them down,
20.23: and God will make them swallow his blazing anger.
20.24: While running from iron spears, they will be killed by arrows of bronze,
20.25: whose shining tips go straight through their bodies. They will be trapped by terror,
20.26: and what they treasure most will be lost in the dark. God will send flames to destroy them in their tents with all their property.
20.27: The heavens and the earth will testify against them,
20.28: and all their possessions will be dragged off when God becomes angry.
20.29: This is what God has decided for those who are evil.

21.1: Job said:
21.2: If you want to offer comfort, then listen to me.
21.3: And when I have finished, you can start your insults all over again.
21.4: My complaint is against God; that's why I am impatient.
21.5: Just looking at me is enough to make you sick,
21.6: and the very thought of myself fills me with disgust.
21.7: Why do evil people live so long and gain such power?
21.8: Why are they allowed to see their children grow up?
21.9: They have no worries at home, and God never punishes them.
21.10: Their cattle have lots of calves without ever losing one;
21.11: their children play and dance safely by themselves.
21.12: These people sing and celebrate to the sound of tambourines, small harps, and flutes,
21.13: and they are successful, without a worry, until the day they die.
21.14: Those who are evil say to God All-Powerful, "Leave us alone! Don't bother us with your teachings.
21.15: What do we gain from praying and worshiping you?
21.16: We succeeded all on our own." And so, I keep away from them and their evil schemes.
21.17: How often does God become angry and send disaster and darkness to punish sinners?
21.18: How often does he strike them like a windstorm that scatters straw?
21.19: You say, "God will punish those sinners' children in place of those sinners." But I say, "Let him punish those sinners themselves until they really feel it.
21.20: Let God All-Powerful force them to drink their own destruction from the cup of his anger.
21.21: Because after they are dead, they won't care what happens to their children."
21.25: while others die in poverty, having known only pain.
21.26: But we all end up dead, beneath a blanket of worms.
21.27: My friends, I know that you are plotting against me.
21.28: You ask, "Where is the home of that important person who does so much evil?"
21.30: that those who do wrong never suffer disaster, when God becomes angry.
21.31: No one points out their sin or punishes them.
21.32: Then at their funerals, they are highly praised;
21.33: the earth welcomes them home, while crowds mourn.
21.34: But empty, meaningless words are the comfort you offer me.

22.3: If you were completely sinless, that would still mean nothing to God All-Powerful.
22.4: Is he correcting you for worshiping him?
22.5: No! It's because of your terrible and endless sins.
22.6: To guarantee payment of a debt, you have taken clothes from innocent people.
22.7: And you refused bread and water to the hungry and thirsty,
22.8: although you were rich, respected, and powerful.
22.9: You have turned away widows and have broken the arms of orphans.
22.10: That's why you were suddenly trapped by terror,
22.11: blinded by darkness, and drowned in a flood.
22.12: God lives in the heavens above the highest stars, where he sees everything.
22.13: Do you think the deep darkness hides you from God?
22.14: Do thick clouds cover his eyes, as he walks around heaven's dome high above the earth?
22.15: Give up those ancient ideas believed by sinners,
22.16: who were swept away without warning.
22.17: They rejected God All-Powerful, feeling he was helpless,
22.18: although he had been kind to their families. The beliefs of these sinners are truly disgusting.
22.19: When God's people see the godless swept away, they celebrate,
22.20: saying, "Our enemies are gone, and fire has destroyed their possessions."
22.21: Surrender to God All-Powerful! You will find peace and prosperity.
22.22: Listen to his teachings and take them to heart.
22.23: If you return to God and turn from sin, all will go well for you.
22.24: So get rid of your finest gold, as though it were sand.
22.25: Let God All-Powerful be your silver and gold,
22.26: and you will find happiness by worshiping him.
22.27: God will answer your prayers, and you will keep the promises you made to him.
22.28: He will do whatever you ask, and life will be bright.
22.29: When others are disgraced, God will clear their names in answer to your prayers.
22.30: Even those who are guilty will be forgiven, because you obey God.

23.3: If I knew where to find God, I would go there
23.5: Then I would discover what he wanted to say.
23.6: Would he overwhelm me with his greatness? No! He would listen
23.7: because I am innocent, and he would say, "I now set you free!"
23.9: to my left or my right. God is always at work, though I never see him.
23.10: But he knows what I am doing, and when he tests me, I will be pure as gold. *
23.11: I have never refused to follow any of his commands,
23.12: and I have always treasured his teachings.
23.14: and he will do exactly what he intends with me. *
23.15: Merely the thought of God All-Powerful
23.17: God has covered me with darkness, but I refuse to be silent.

24.1: Why doesn't God set a time for court? Why don't his people know where he can be found?
24.2: Sinners remove boundary markers and take care of sheep they have stolen.
24.3: They cheat orphans and widows by taking their donkeys and oxen.
24.4: The poor are trampled and forced to hide
24.5: in the desert, where they and their children must live like wild donkeys and search for food.
24.6: If they want grain or grapes, they must go to the property of these sinners.
24.7: They sleep naked in the cold, because they have no cover,
24.8: and during a storm their only shelters are caves among the rocky cliffs.
24.9: Children whose fathers have died are taken from their mothers as payment for a debt.
24.10: Then they are forced to work naked in the grain fields because they have no clothes, and they go hungry.
24.11: They crush olives to make oil and grapes to make wine--but still they go thirsty.
24.12: And along the city streets, the wounded and dying cry out, yet God does nothing.
24.13: Some rebel and refuse to follow the light.
24.14: Soon after sunset they murder the poor and the needy, and at night they steal.
24.15: Others wait for the dark, thinking they won't be seen if they sleep with the wife or husband of someone else.
24.16: Robbers hide during the day, then break in after dark because they reject the light.
24.17: They prefer night to day, since the terrors of the night are their friends.
24.18: Those sinners are filthy foam on the surface of the water. And so, their fields and vineyards will fall under a curse and won't produce.
24.19: Just as the heat of summer swallows the snow, the world of the dead swallows those who sin.
24.20: Forgotten here on earth, and with their power broken, they taste sweet to worms.
24.21: Sinners take advantage of widows and other helpless women.
24.22: But God's mighty strength destroys those in power. Even if they seem successful, they are doomed to fail.
24.23: God may let them feel secure, but they are never out of his sight.
24.24: Great for a while; gone forever! Sinners are mowed down like weeds, then they wither and die.
24.25: If I haven't spoken the truth, then prove me wrong.

42.10: After Job had prayed for his three friends, the LORD made Job twice as rich as he had been before.
42.11: Then Job gave a feast for his brothers and sisters and for his old friends. They expressed their sorrow for the suffering the LORD had brought on him, and they each gave Job some silver and a gold ring.
42.12: The LORD now blessed Job more than ever; he gave him 14,000 sheep, 6,000 camels, 1,000 pair of oxen, and 1,000 donkeys.
42.13: In addition to seven sons, Job had three daughters,
42.14: whose names were Jemimah, Keziah, and Keren Happuch.
42.15: They were the most beautiful women in that part of the world, and Job gave them shares of his property, along with their brothers.
42.16: Job lived for another 140 years--long enough to see his great-grandchildren have children of their own--
42.17: and when he finally died, he was very old.

1.1: God blesses those people who refuse evil advice and won't follow sinners or join in sneering at God.
1.2: Instead, they find happiness in the Teaching of the LORD, and they think about it day and night.
1.3: They are like trees growing beside a stream, trees that produce fruit in season and always have leaves. Those people succeed in everything they do.
1.4: That isn't true of those who are evil--they are like straw blown by the wind.
1.5: Sinners won't have an excuse on the day of judgment, and they won't have a place with the people of God.
1.6: The LORD protects everyone who follows him, but the wicked follow a road that leads to ruin.

2.1: Why do the nations plot, and why do their people make useless plans?
2.2: The kings of this earth have all joined together to turn against the LORD and his chosen king.
2.3: They say, "Let's cut the ropes and set ourselves free!"
2.4: In heaven the LORD laughs as he sits on his throne, making fun of the nations.
2.5: The LORD becomes furious and threatens them. His anger terrifies them as he says,
2.6: "I've put my king on Zion, my sacred hill."
2.7: I will tell the promise that the LORD made to me: "You are my son, because today I have become your father.
2.8: Ask me for the nations, and every nation on earth will belong to you.
2.9: You will smash them with an iron rod and shatter them like dishes of clay."
2.10: Be smart, all you rulers, and pay close attention.
2.11: Serve and honor the LORD; be glad and tremble.
2.12: Show respect to his son because if you don't, the LORD might become furious and suddenly destroy you. But he blesses and protects everyone who runs to him.

3.1: I have a lot of enemies, LORD. Many fight against
3.2: me and say, "God won't rescue you!"
3.3: But you are my shield, and you give me victory and great honor.
3.4: I pray to you, and you answer from your sacred hill.
3.5: I sleep and wake up refreshed because you, LORD, protect me.
3.6: Ten thousand enemies attack from every side, but I am not afraid.
3.7: Come and save me, LORD God! Break my enemies' jaws and shatter their teeth,
3.8: because you protect and bless your people.

4.1: You are my God and protector. Please answer my prayer. I was in terrible distress, but you set me free. Now have pity and listen as I pray.
4.2: How long will you people refuse to respect me? You love foolish things, and you run after what is worthless.
4.3: The LORD has chosen everyone who is faithful to be his very own, and he answers my prayers.
4.4: But each of you had better tremble and turn from your sins. Silently search your heart as you lie in bed.
4.5: Offer the proper sacrifices and trust the LORD.
4.6: There are some who ask, "Who will be good to us?" Let your kindness, LORD, shine brightly on us.
4.7: You brought me more happiness than a rich harvest of grain and grapes.
4.8: I can lie down and sleep soundly because you, LORD, will keep me safe.

5.1: Listen, LORD, as I pray! Pay attention when I groan.
5.2: You are my King and my God. Answer my cry for help because I pray to you.
5.3: Each morning you listen to my prayer, as I bring my requests to you and wait for your reply.
5.4: You are not the kind of God who is pleased with evil. Sinners can't stay with you.
5.5: No one who boasts can stand in your presence, LORD, and you hate evil people.
5.6: You destroy every liar, and you despise violence and deceit.
5.7: Because of your great mercy, I come to your house, LORD, and I am filled with wonder as I bow down to worship at your holy temple.
5.8: You do what is right, and I ask you to guide me. Make your teaching clear because of my enemies.
5.9: Nothing they say is true! They just want to destroy. Their words are deceitful like a hidden pit, and their tongues are good only for telling lies.
5.10: Punish them, God, and let their own plans bring their downfall. Get rid of them! They keep committing crimes and turning against you.
5.11: Let all who run to you for protection always sing joyful songs. Provide shelter for those who truly love you and let them rejoice.
5.12: Our LORD, you bless those who live right, and you shield them with your kindness.

6.1: Don't punish me, LORD, or even correct me when you are angry!
6.2: Have pity on me and heal my feeble body. My bones tremble with fear,
6.3: and I am in deep distress. How long will it be?
6.4: Turn and come to my rescue. Show your wonderful love and save me, LORD.
6.5: If I die, I cannot praise you or even remember you.
6.6: My groaning has worn me out. At night my bed and pillow are soaked with tears.
6.7: Sorrow has made my eyes dim, and my sight has failed because of my enemies.
6.8: You, LORD, heard my crying, and those hateful people had better leave me alone.
6.9: You have answered my prayer and my plea for mercy.
6.10: My enemies will be ashamed and terrified, as they quickly run away in complete disgrace.
