12.4: How long will the ground be dry and the pasturelands parched? The birds and animals are dead and gone. And all of this happened because the people are so sinful. They even brag, "God can't see the sins we commit."
12.5: Jeremiah, if you get tired in a race against people, how can you possibly run against horses? If you fall in open fields, what will happen in the forest along the Jordan River?
12.6: Even your own family has turned against you. They act friendly, but don't trust them. They're out to get you, and so is everyone else.
12.7: I loved my people and chose them as my very own. But now I will reject them and hand them over to their enemies.
12.8: My people have turned against me and roar at me like lions. That's why I hate them.
12.9: My people are like a hawk surrounded and attacked by other hawks. Tell the wild animals to come and eat their fill.
12.10: My beautiful land is ruined like a field or a vineyard trampled by shepherds and stripped bare by their flocks.
12.11: Every field I see lies barren, and no one cares.
12.12: A destroying army marches along desert roads and attacks everywhere. They are my deadly sword; no one is safe from them.
12.13: My people, you planted wheat, but because I was furious, I let only weeds grow. You wore yourselves out and gained only shame!
12.15: But later, I will have pity on these nations and bring them back to their own lands.
12.17: However, if they don't listen to me, I will uproot them from their lands and completely destroy them. I, the LORD, have spoken.

13.1: The LORD told me, "Go and buy a pair of linen shorts. Wear them for a while, but don't wash them."
13.2: So I bought a pair of shorts and put them on.
13.3: Then the LORD said,
13.4: "Take off the shorts. Go to Parah and hide the shorts in a crack between some large rocks."
13.5: And that's what I did.
13.6: Some time later the LORD said, "Go back and get the shorts."
13.7: I went back and dug the shorts out of their hiding place, but the cloth had rotted, and the shorts were ruined.
13.8: Then the LORD said:
13.9: Jeremiah, I will use Babylonia to destroy the pride of the people of Judah and Jerusalem.
13.10: The people of Judah are evil and stubborn. So instead of listening to me, they do whatever they want and even worship other gods. When I am finished with these people, they will be good for nothing, just like this pair of shorts.
13.11: These shorts were tight around your waist, and that's how tightly I held onto the kingdoms of Israel and Judah. I wanted them to be my people. I wanted to make them famous, so that other nations would praise and honor me, but they refused to obey me.
13.13: Then say to them: I am the LORD, and what I'm going to do will make everyone in Judah and Jerusalem appear to be full of wine. And the worst ones will be the kings of David's family and the priests and the prophets.
13.14: Then I will smash them against each other like jars. I will have no pity on the young or the old, and they will all be destroyed. I, the LORD, have spoken.
13.15: People of Judah, don't be too proud to listen to what the LORD has said.
13.16: You hope for light, but God is sending darkness. Evening shadows already deepen in the hills. So return to God and confess your sins to him before you trip and fall.
13.17: If you are too proud to listen, I will weep alone. Tears will stream from my eyes when the LORD's people are taken away as prisoners.
13.18: The LORD told me to tell you that your king and his mother must surrender their thrones and remove their crowns.
13.19: The cities in the Southern Desert are surrounded; no one can get in or out. Everyone in Judah will be taken away.
13.20: Jerusalem, you were so proud of ruling the people of Judah. But where are they now? Look north, and you will see your enemies approaching.
13.21: You once trusted them to help, but now I'll let them rule you. What do you say about that? You will be in pain like a woman giving birth.
13.22: Do you know why your clothes were torn off and you were abused? It was because of your terrible sins.
13.23: Can you ever change and do what's right? Can people change the color of their skin, or can a leopard remove its spots? If so, then maybe you can change and learn to do right.
13.24: I will scatter you, just as the desert wind blows husks from grain tossed in the air.
13.26: You were married to me, but you were unfaithful. You even became a prostitute by worshiping disgusting gods on hilltops and in fields.
13.27: So I'll rip off your clothes and leave you naked and ashamed for everyone to see. You are doomed! Will you ever be worthy to worship me again?

14.1: When there had been no rain for a long time, the LORD told me to say to the people:
14.2: Judah and Jerusalem weep as the land dries up.
14.3: Rulers send their servants to the storage pits for water. But there's none to be found; they return in despair with their jars still empty.
14.4: There has been no rain, and farmers feel sick as they watch cracks appear in the dry ground.
14.5: A deer gives birth in a field, then abandons her newborn fawn and leaves in search of grass.
14.6: Wild donkeys go blind from starvation. So they stand on barren hilltops and sniff the air, hoping to smell green grass.
14.7: We rejected you and did evil, so we deserve to be punished. But if you rescue us, LORD, everyone will see how great you are.
14.8: You're our only hope; you alone can save us now. You help us one day, but you're gone the next.
14.9: Did this disaster take you by surprise? Are you a warrior with your hands tied? You have chosen us, and your temple is here. Don't abandon us!
14.10: My people, you love to wander away; you don't even try to stay close to me. So now I will reject you and punish you for your sins. I, the LORD, have spoken.
14.12: They may even go without eating and offer sacrifices to please me and to give thanks. But when they cry out for my help, I won't listen, and I won't accept their sacrifices. Instead, I'll send war, starvation, and disease to wipe them out."
14.14: The LORD answered: They claim to speak for me, but they're lying! I didn't even speak to them, much less choose them to be my prophets. Their messages come from worthless dreams, useless fortunetelling, and their own imaginations.
14.15: Those lying prophets say there will be peace and plenty of food. But I say that those same prophets will die from war and hunger.
14.16: And everyone who listens to them will be killed, just as they deserve. Their dead bodies will be thrown out into the streets of Jerusalem, because their families will also be dead, and no one will be left to bury them.
14.17: Jeremiah, go and tell the people how you feel about all this. So I told them: "Tears will flood my eyes both day and night, because my nation suffers from a deadly wound.
14.18: In the fields I see the bodies of those killed in battle. And in the towns I see crowds dying of hunger. But the prophets and priests go about their business, without understanding what has happened."
14.19: Have you rejected Judah, LORD? Do you hate Jerusalem? Why did you strike down Judah with a fatal wound? We had hoped for peace and a time of healing, but all we got was terror.
14.20: We and our ancestors are guilty of rebelling against you.
14.21: If you save us, it will show how great you are. Don't let our enemies disgrace your temple, your beautiful throne. Don't forget that you promised to rescue us.
14.22: Idols can't send rain, and showers don't fall by themselves. Only you control the rain, so we put our trust in you, the LORD our God.

15.2: And when they ask where they are going, tell them that I, the LORD, have said: Some of you are going to die of horrible diseases. Others are going to die in war or from starvation. The rest will be led away to a foreign country.
15.3: I will punish you in four different ways: You will be killed in war and your bodies dragged off by dogs, your flesh will be eaten by birds, and your bones will be chewed on by wild animals.
15.4: This punishment will happen because of the horrible things your King Manasseh did. And you will be disgusting to all nations on earth.
15.5: People of Jerusalem, who will feel sorry for you? Will anyone bother to ask if you are well?
15.6: My people, you abandoned me and walked away. I am tired of showing mercy; that's why I'll destroy you
15.7: by scattering you like straw blown by the wind. I will punish you with sorrow and death, because you refuse to change your ways.
15.8: There will be more widows in Judah than grains of sand on a beach. A surprise attack at noon! And the mothers in Jerusalem mourn for their children.
15.9: A mother is in deep despair and struggles for breath. Her daylight has turned to darkness--she has suffered the loss of her seven sons. I will kill anyone who survives. I, the LORD, have spoken.
15.10: I wish I had never been born! I'm always in trouble with everyone in Judah. I never lend or borrow money, but everyone curses me just the same.
15.11: Then the LORD replied, "I promise to protect you, and when disaster comes, even your enemies will beg you for help."
15.13: I will give them everything you own, because you have sinned everywhere in your country.
15.14: My anger is a fire that cannot be put out, so I will make you slaves of your enemies in a foreign land.
15.15: You can see how I suffer insult after insult, all because of you, LORD. Don't be so patient with my enemies; take revenge on them before they kill me.
15.16: When you spoke to me, I was glad to obey, because I belong to you, the LORD All-Powerful.
15.17: I don't go to parties and have a good time. Instead, I keep to myself, because you have filled me with your anger.
15.18: I am badly injured and in constant pain. Are you going to disappoint me, like a stream that goes dry in the heat of summer?
15.19: Then the LORD told me: Stop talking like a fool! If you turn back to me and speak my message, I will let you be my prophet once again. I hope the people of Judah will accept what you say. But you can ignore their threats, *
15.20: because I am making you strong, like a bronze wall. They are evil and violent, but when they attack,
15.21: I will be there to rescue you. I, the LORD, have spoken.

16.1: The LORD said to me:
16.2: Jeremiah, don't get married and have children--Judah is no place to raise a family.
16.3: I'll tell you what's going to happen to children and their parents here.
16.4: They will die of horrible diseases and of war and starvation. No one will give them a funeral or bury them, and their bodies will be food for the birds and wild animals. And what's left will lie on the ground like manure.
16.7: No one will bring food and wine to help comfort those who are mourning the death of their father or mother.
16.8: Don't even set foot in a house where there is eating and drinking and celebrating.
16.9: Warn the people of Judah that I, the LORD All-Powerful, will put an end to all their parties and wedding celebrations.
16.10: They will ask, "Why has the LORD our God threatened us with so many disasters? Have we done something wrong or sinned against him?"
16.12: And you have done even worse! You are stubborn, and instead of obeying me, you do whatever evil comes to your mind.
16.13: So I will throw you into a land that you and your ancestors know nothing about, a place where you will have to worship other gods both day and night. And I won't feel the least bit sorry for you.
16.17: I can see everything you are doing, even if you try to hide your sins from me.
16.18: I will punish you double for your sins, because you have polluted my own land. You have filled it with lifeless idols that remind me of dead bodies.
16.19: Our LORD, you are the one who gives me strength and protects me like a fortress when I am in trouble. People will come to you from distant nations and say, "Our ancestors worshiped false and useless gods,
16.20: worthless idols made by human hands."
16.21: Then the LORD replied, "That's why I will teach them about my power, and they will know that I truly am the LORD."

17.1: People of Judah, your sins cannot be erased. They are written on your hearts like words chiseled in stone or carved on the corners of your altars. *
17.2: One generation after another has set up pagan altars and worshiped the goddess Asherah everywhere in your country--on hills and mountains, and under large trees.
17.3: So I'll take everything you own, including your altars, and give it all to your enemies.
17.4: You will lose the land that I gave you, and I will make you slaves in a foreign country, because you have made my anger blaze up like a fire that won't stop burning.
17.6: They will dry up like a bush in salty desert soil, where nothing can grow.
17.8: They will be like trees growing beside a stream--trees with roots that reach down to the water, and with leaves that are always green. They bear fruit every year and are never worried by a lack of rain.
17.9: You people of Judah are so deceitful that you even fool yourselves, and you can't change.
17.10: But I know your deeds and your thoughts, and I will make sure you get what you deserve.
17.11: You cheated others, but everything you gained will fly away, like birds hatched from stolen eggs. Then you will discover what fools you are.
17.12: Our LORD, your temple is a glorious throne that has stood on a mountain from the beginning.
17.13: You are a spring of water giving Israel life and hope. But if the people reject what you have told me, they will be swept away like words written in dust.
17.14: You, LORD, are the one I praise. So heal me and rescue me! Then I will be completely well and perfectly safe.
17.15: The people of Judah say to me, "Jeremiah, you claimed to tell us what the LORD has said. So why hasn't it come true?"
17.16: Our LORD, you chose me to care for your people, and that's what I have done. You know everything I have said, and I have never once asked you to punish them.
17.17: I trust you for protection in times of trouble, so don't frighten me.
17.18: Keep me from failure and disgrace, but make my enemies fail and be disgraced. Send destruction to make their worst fears come true.
17.25: then Judah and Jerusalem will always be ruled by kings from David's family. The king and his officials will ride through these gates on horses or in chariots, and the people of Judah and Jerusalem will be with them. There will always be people living in Jerusalem,
17.26: and others will come here from the nearby villages, from the towns of Judah and Benjamin, from the hill country and the foothills to the west, and from the Southern Desert. They will bring sacrifices to please me and to give me thanks, as well as offerings of grain and incense.
17.27: But if you keep on carrying things through the city gates on the Sabbath and keep treating it as any other day, I will set fire to these gates and burn down the whole city, including the fortresses.

18.1: The LORD told me,
18.2: "Jeremiah, go to the pottery shop, and when you get there, I will tell you what to say to the people."
18.3: I went there and saw the potter making clay pots on his pottery wheel.
18.4: And whenever the clay would not take the shape he wanted, he would change his mind and form it into some other shape.
18.5: Then the LORD told me to say:
18.7: If I threaten to uproot and shatter an evil nation,
18.8: and that nation turns from its evil, I will change my mind.
18.9: If I promise to make a nation strong,
18.10: but its people start disobeying me and doing evil, then I will change my mind and not help them at all.
18.11: So listen to me, people of Judah and Jerusalem! I have decided to strike you with disaster, and I won't change my mind unless you stop sinning and start living right.
18.12: But I know you won't listen. You might as well answer, "We don't care what you say. We have made plans to sin, and we are going to be stubborn and do as we please!"
18.13: So I, the LORD, command you to ask the nations, and find out if they have ever heard of such a horrible sin as what you have done.
18.14: The snow on Lebanon's mountains never melts away, and the streams there never run dry.
18.15: But you, my people, have turned from me to burn incense to worthless idols. You have left the ancient road to follow an unknown path where you stumble over idols.
18.16: Your land will be ruined, and every passerby will look at it with horror and make insulting remarks.
18.17: When your enemies attack, I will scatter you like dust blown by an eastern wind. Then, on that day of disaster, I will turn my back on you.
18.19: Please, LORD, answer my prayer. Make my enemies stop accusing me of evil.
18.20: I tried to help them, but they are paying me back by digging a pit to trap me. I even begged you not to punish them.
18.21: But now I am asking you to let their children starve or be killed in war. Let women lose their husbands and sons to disease and violence.
18.22: These people have dug pits and set traps for me, LORD. Make them scream in fear when you send enemy troops to attack their homes.
18.23: You know they plan to kill me. So get angry and punish them! Don't ever forgive their terrible crimes.

19.1: The LORD said: Jeremiah, go to the pottery shop and buy a clay jar. Then take along some of the city officials and leading priests
19.2: and go to Hinnom Valley, just outside Potsherd Gate. Tell the people that I have said:
19.3: I am the LORD All-Powerful, the God of Israel, and you kings of Judah and you people of Jerusalem had better pay attention. I am going to bring so much trouble on this valley that everyone who hears about it will be shocked.
19.6: So watch out! Someday this place will no longer be called Topheth or Hinnom Valley. It will be called Slaughter Valley!
19.7: You people of Judah and Jerusalem may have big plans, but here in this valley I'll ruin those plans. I'll let your enemies kill you, and I'll tell the birds and wild animals to eat your dead bodies.
19.8: I will turn Jerusalem into a pile of rubble, and every passerby will be shocked and horrified and will make insulting remarks.
19.9: And while your enemies are trying to break through your city walls to kill you, the food supply will run out. You will become so hungry that you will eat the flesh of your friends and even of your own children.
19.10: Jeremiah, as soon as you have said this, smash the jar while the people are watching.
19.11: Then tell them that I have also said: I am the LORD All-Powerful, and I warn you that I will shatter Judah and Jerusalem just like this jar that is broken beyond repair. You will bury your dead here in Topheth, but so many of you will die that there won't be enough room.
19.14: I went to Topheth, where I told the people what the LORD had said. Then I went to the temple courtyard and shouted to the people,
19.15: "Listen, everyone! Some time ago, the LORD All-Powerful, the God of Israel, warned you that he would bring disaster on Jerusalem and all nearby villages. But you were stubborn and refused to listen. Now the LORD is going to bring the disaster he promised."

20.1: Pashhur son of Immer was a priest and the chief of temple security. He heard what I had said,
20.2: and so he hit me. Then he had me arrested and put in chains at the Benjamin Gate in the LORD's temple.

20.5: He will clean out the royal treasury and take everything else of value from Jerusalem.
20.6: Pashhur, you are guilty of telling lies and claiming they were messages from me. That's why I will let the Babylonians take you, your family, and your friends as prisoners to Babylonia, where you will all die and be buried.
20.7: You tricked me, LORD, and I was really fooled. You are stronger than I am, and you have defeated me. People never stop sneering and insulting me.
20.8: You have let me announce only injustice and death. Your message has brought me nothing but insults and trouble.
20.9: Sometimes I tell myself not to think about you, LORD, or even mention your name. But your message burns in my heart and bones, and I cannot keep silent.
20.10: I heard the crowds whisper, "Everyone is afraid. Now's our chance to accuse Jeremiah!" All of my so-called friends are just waiting for me to make a mistake. They say, "Maybe Jeremiah can be tricked. Then we can overpower him and get even at last."
20.11: But you, LORD, are a mighty soldier, standing at my side. Those troublemakers will fall down and fail--terribly embarrassed, forever ashamed.
20.12: LORD All-Powerful, you test those who do right, and you know every heart and mind. I have told you my complaints, so let me watch you take revenge on my enemies.
20.13: I sing praises to you, LORD. You rescue the oppressed from the wicked.
20.14: Put a curse on the day I was born! Don't bless that day.
20.16: May that man be like the towns you destroyed without pity. Let him hear shouts of alarm in the morning and battle cries at noon.
20.17: He deserves to die for not killing me before I was born. Then my mother's body would have been my grave.
20.18: Why did I have to be born? Was it just to suffer and die in shame?

21.9: The Babylonian army has surrounded Jerusalem, so if you want to live, you must go out and surrender to them. But if you want to die because of hunger, disease, or war, then stay here in the city.

23.1: You leaders of my people are like shepherds that kill and scatter the sheep.
23.2: You were supposed to take care of my people, but instead you chased them away. So now I'll punish you severely and make you pay for your crimes!
23.3: I will bring the rest of my people home from the lands where I have scattered them, and they will grow into a mighty nation.
23.4: I promise to choose leaders who will care for them like real shepherds. All of my people will be there, and they will never again be frightened.
23.5: Someday I will appoint an honest king from the family of David, a king who will be wise and rule with justice.
23.6: As long as he is king, Israel will have peace, and Judah will be safe. The name of this king will be "The LORD Gives Justice."
23.9: When I think of the prophets, I am shocked, and I tremble like someone drunk, because of the LORD and his sacred words.

23.14: And you prophets in Jerusalem are even worse. You're unfaithful in marriage and never tell the truth. You even lead others to sin instead of helping them turn back to me. You and the people of Jerusalem are evil like Sodom and Gomorrah.
23.15: You prophets in Jerusalem have spread evil everywhere. That's why I, the LORD, promise to give you bitter poison to eat and drink.
23.17: These prophets go to people who refuse to respect me and who are stubborn and do whatever they please. The prophets tell them, "The LORD has promised everything will be fine."
23.18: But I, the LORD, tell you that these prophets have never attended a meeting of my council in heaven or heard me speak.

23.20: I won't calm down, until I have finished what I have decided to do. Someday you will understand exactly what I mean.
23.21: I did not send these prophets or speak to them, but they ran to find you and to preach their message.

23.25: These unfaithful prophets claim that I have given them a dream or a vision, and then they tell lies in my name.
23.26: But everything they say comes from their own twisted minds. How long can this go on?
23.27: They tell each other their dreams and try to get my people to reject me, just as their ancestors left me and worshiped Baal.
23.28: Their dreams and my truth are as different as straw and wheat. But when prophets speak for me, they must say only what I have told them.
23.33: Jeremiah, when a prophet or a priest or anyone else comes to you and asks, "Does the LORD have news for us?" tell them, "You people are a nuisance to the LORD, and he will get rid of you."
23.34: If any of you say, "Here is news from the LORD," I will punish you and your families, even if you are a prophet or a priest.

23.37: If you go to a prophet, it's all right to ask, "What answer did the LORD give to my question?" or "What has the LORD said?"
23.39: I will pick you up and throw you far away. And I will abandon this city of Jerusalem that I gave to your ancestors.
23.40: You will never be free from your shame and disgrace.

24.1: The LORD spoke to me in a vision after King Nebuchadnezzar of Babylonia had come to Judah and taken King Jehoiachin, his officials, and all the skilled workers back to Babylonia. In this vision I saw two baskets of figs in front of the LORD's temple.
24.2: One basket was full of very good figs that ripened early, and the other was full of rotten figs that were not fit to eat.
24.4: Then the LORD told me to say:
24.5: People of Judah, the good figs stand for those of you I sent away as exiles to Babylonia,
24.6: where I am watching over them. Then someday I will bring them back to this land. I will plant them, instead of uprooting them, and I will build them up, rather than tearing them down.
24.7: I will give them a desire to know me and to be my people. They will want me to be their God, and they will turn back to me with all their heart.
24.9: I will punish them with a terrible disaster, and everyone on earth will tremble when they hear about it. I will force the people of Judah to go to foreign countries, where they will be cursed and insulted.
24.10: War and hunger and disease will strike them, until they finally disappear from the land that I gave them and their ancestors.

25.4: The LORD has sent prophets to you time after time, but you refused to listen.
25.5: They told you that the LORD had said: Change your ways! If you stop doing evil, I will let you stay forever in this land that I gave your ancestors.
25.6: I don't want to harm you. So don't make me angry by worshiping idols and other gods.
25.10: I will put an end to your parties and wedding celebrations; no one will grind grain or be here to light the lamps at night.
25.11: This country will be as empty as a desert, because I will make all of you the slaves of the king of Babylonia for 70 years.
25.13: My servant Jeremiah has told you what I said I will do to Babylonia and to the other nations, and he wrote it all down in this book. I will do everything I threatened.
25.14: I will pay back the Babylonians for every wrong they have done. Great kings from many other nations will conquer the Babylonians and force them to be slaves.
25.15: The LORD God of Israel showed me a vision in which he said, "Jeremiah, here is a cup filled with the wine of my anger. Take it and make every nation drink some.
25.16: They will vomit and act crazy, because of the war this cup of anger will bring to them."
25.17: I took the cup from the LORD's hand, and I went to the kings of the nations and made each of them drink some.
25.18: I started with Jerusalem and the towns of Judah, and the king and his officials were removed from power in disgrace. Everyone still makes insulting jokes about them and uses their names as curse words.
25.19: The second place I went was Egypt, where everyone had to drink from the cup, including the king and his officials, the other government workers, the rest of the Egyptians,
25.20: and all the foreigners who lived in the country. Next I went to the king of Uz, and then to the four kings of Philistia, who ruled from Ashkelon, Gaza, Ekron, and what was left of Ashdod.
25.21: Then I went to the kings of Edom, Moab, Ammon,
25.22: and to the kings of Tyre, Sidon, and their colonies across the sea.
25.26: and the countries in the north, both near and far. I went to all the countries on earth, one after another, and finally to Babylonia.
25.27: The LORD had said to tell each king, "The LORD All-Powerful, the God of Israel, commands you to drink from this cup that is full of the wine of his anger. It will make you so drunk that you will vomit. And when the LORD sends war against the nations, you will be completely defeated."
25.28: The LORD told me that if any of them refused to drink from the cup, I must tell them that he had said, "I, the LORD All-Powerful, command you to drink.
25.29: Starting with my own city of Jerusalem, everyone on earth will suffer from war. So there is no way I will let you escape unharmed."
25.30: The LORD told me to say: From my sacred temple I will roar like thunder, while I trample my people and everyone else as though they were grapes.
25.31: My voice will be heard everywhere on earth, accusing nations of their crimes and sentencing the guilty to death.
25.32: The LORD All-Powerful says: You can see disaster spreading from far across the earth, from nation to nation like a horrible storm.
25.33: When it strikes, I will kill so many people that their bodies will cover the ground like manure. No one will be left to bury them or to mourn.
25.34: The LORD's people are his flock, and you leaders were the shepherds. But now it's your turn to be butchered like sheep. You'll shatter like fine pottery dropped on the floor. So roll on the ground, crying and mourning.
25.35: You have nowhere to run, nowhere to hide. *
25.38: Like a lion leaving its den, the LORD has abandoned his people to the destruction of war.

26.4: Tell them that I have said: You have refused to listen to me and to obey my laws and teachings.

26.10: The royal officers heard what had happened, and they came from the palace to the new gate of the temple to be the judges at my trial.

26.14: You must decide what to do with me. Just do whatever you think is right.

29.3: I gave the letter to Elasah and Gemariah, two men that King Zedekiah of Judah was sending to Babylon to talk with Nebuchadnezzar. In the letter, I wrote

31.2: In the desert I was kind to those who escaped death. I gave them peace, and when the time is right, I'll do the same for you. I, the LORD, have spoken.
31.3: Some time ago, the LORD appeared to me and told me to say: Israel, I will always love you; that's why I've been so patient and kind.
31.4: You are precious to me, and so I will rebuild your nation. Once again you will dance for joy and play your tambourines.
31.5: You will plant vineyards on the hills of Samaria and enjoy the grapes.
31.7: The LORD says: Celebrate and sing for Israel, the greatest of nations. Offer praises and shout, "Come and rescue your people, LORD! Save what's left of Israel."
31.8: I, the LORD, will bring my people back from Babylonia and everywhere else on earth. The blind and the lame will be there. Expectant mothers and women about to give birth will come and be part of that great crowd.
31.9: They will weep and pray as I bring them home. I will lead them to streams of water. They will walk on a level road and not stumble. I am a father to Israel, my favorite children.
31.10: Listen to me, you nations nearby or across the sea. I scattered the people of Israel, but I will gather them again. I will protect them like a shepherd guarding a flock;
31.11: I will rescue them from enemies who could overpower them.

31.14: I will bless my people with more food than they need, and the priests will enjoy the choice cuts of meat. I, the LORD, have spoken.
31.16: But I, the LORD, say to dry your tears. Someday your children will come home from the enemy's land. Then all you have done for them will be greatly rewarded.
31.17: So don't lose hope. I, the LORD, have spoken.
31.18: The people of Israel moan and say to me, "We were like wild bulls, but you, LORD, broke us, and we learned to obey. You are our God--please let us come home.
31.19: When we were young, we strayed and sinned, but then we realized what we had done. We are ashamed and disgraced and want to return to you."
31.20: People of Israel, you are my own dear children. Don't I love you best of all? Though I often make threats, I want you to be near me, so I will have mercy on you. I, the LORD, have spoken.
31.21: With rock piles and signposts, mark the road well, my dear people. The road by which you left by will now lead you home.
31.22: Will you ever decide to be faithful? I will make sure that someday things will be different, as different as a woman protecting a man.
31.23: The LORD All-Powerful, the God of Israel, said: I promise to set the people of Judah free and to lead them back to their hometowns. And when I do, they will once again say, "We pray that the LORD will bless his home, the sacred hill in Jerusalem where his temple stands."

31.30: When that day comes, only those who eat sour grapes will get the sour taste, and only those who sin will be put to death.

31.32: It will be different from the agreement I made with their ancestors when I led them out of Egypt. Although I was their God, they broke that agreement.
31.33: Here is the new agreement that I, the LORD, will make with the people of Israel: "I will write my laws on their hearts and minds. I will be their God, and they will be my people.
31.35: I am the LORD All-Powerful. I command the sun to give light each day, the moon and stars to shine at night, and ocean waves to roar.
31.36: I will never forget to give those commands, and I will never let Israel stop being a nation. I, the LORD, have spoken.
31.37: Can you measure the heavens? Can you explore the depths of the earth? That's how hard it would be for me to reject Israel forever, even though they have sinned. I, the LORD, have spoken.
31.38: The LORD said: Someday, Jerusalem will truly belong to me. It will be rebuilt with a boundary line running from Hananel Tower to Corner Gate.

44.28: Only a few will escape and return to Judah. Then everyone who went to live in Egypt will know that when I say something will happen, it will--no matter what you say.
44.29: And here is how you will know that I will keep my threats to punish you in Egypt.
44.30: I will hand over King Hophra of Egypt to those who want to kill him, just as I handed Zedekiah over to Nebuchadnezzar, who wanted to kill him.

45.1: In the fourth year that Jehoiakim was king of Judah, Baruch wrote down everything I had told him.
45.2: Then later, the LORD God of Israel told me to say to Baruch:
45.3: You are moaning and blaming me, the LORD, for your troubles and sorrow, and for being so tired that you can't even rest.
45.4: But all over the earth I am tearing down what I built and pulling up what I planted.

46.1: The LORD often told me what to say about the different nations of the world.
46.2: In the fourth year that Jehoiakim was king of Judah, King Nebuchadnezzar of Babylonia defeated King Neco of Egypt in a battle at the city of Carchemish near the Euphrates River. And here is what the LORD told me to say about the Egyptian army:
46.3: It's time to go into battle! So grab your shields,
46.4: saddle your horses, and polish your spears. Put on your helmets and armor, then take your positions.
46.5: I can see the battle now--you are defeated and running away, never once looking back. Terror is all around.
46.6: You are strong and run fast, but you can't escape. You fall in battle near the Euphrates River.
46.7: What nation is this, that rises like the Nile River overflowing its banks?
46.8: It is Egypt, rising with a roar like a raging river and saying, "I'll flood the earth, destroying cities, and killing everyone in them."
46.9: Go ahead, Egypt. Tell your chariots and cavalry to attack and fight hard. Order your troops to march out, with Ethiopians and Libyans carrying shields, and the Lydians armed with bows and arrows.
46.10: But the LORD All-Powerful will win this battle and take revenge on his enemies. His sword will eat them and drink their blood until it is full. They will be killed in the north near the Euphrates River, as a sacrifice to the LORD.
46.11: Egypt, no medicine can heal you, not even the soothing lotion from Gilead.
46.12: All nations have heard you weep; you are disgraced, and they know it. Your troops fall to the ground, stumbling over each other.
46.15: I have struck down your mighty god Apis and chased him away.
46.16: Your soldiers stumble over each other and say, "Get up! The enemy will kill us, unless we can escape to our own land."
46.17: Give the king of Egypt this new name, "Talks-Big-Does-Nothing."
46.19: You will be led away captive, so pack a few things to bring with you. Your capital, Memphis, will lie empty and in ruins.
46.21: The foreign soldiers you hired will turn and run. But they are doomed, like well-fed calves being led to the butcher. *
46.22: The enemy army will go forward like a swarm of locusts. Your troops will feel helpless, like a snake in a forest
46.23: when men with axes start chopping down trees. It can only hiss and try to escape.
46.24: Your people will be disgraced and captured by the enemy from the north.
46.25: I am the LORD All-Powerful, the God of Israel. Soon I will punish the god Amon of Thebes and the other Egyptian gods, the Egyptian kings, the people of Egypt, and everyone who trusts in the Egyptian power.
46.26: I will hand them over to King Nebuchadnezzar and his army. But I also promise that Egypt will someday have people living here again, just as it had before. I, the LORD, have spoken.
46.28: So don't be afraid, even though now you deserve to be punished and have been scattered among other nations. But when I destroy them, I will protect you. I, the LORD, have spoken.

47.1: Before the king of Egypt attacked the town of Gaza, the LORD told me to say to the Philistines:
47.2: I, the LORD, tell you that your land will be flooded with an army from the north. It will destroy your towns and sweep you away, moaning and screaming.
47.3: When you hear the thunder of horses and chariots, your courage will vanish, and parents will even abandon their own children.
47.4: You refugees from Crete, your time has now come, and I will destroy you. None of you will be left to help the cities of Tyre and Sidon.
47.5: The Anakim who survive in Gaza and Ashkelon will mourn for you by shaving their heads and sitting in silence.
47.7: But how can my sword rest, when I have commanded it to attack Ashkelon and the seacoast?

48.1: The LORD All-Powerful, the God of Israel, told me to say to the nation of Moab: The town of Nebo is doomed; Kiriathaim will be captured and disgraced, and even its fortress will be left in ruins.
48.4: Moab will be shattered! Your children will sob
48.5: and cry on their way up to the town of Luhith; on the road to Horonaim they will tell of disasters.

48.9: Spread salt on the ground to kill the crops. Leave its towns in ruins, with no one living there.

48.21: I will punish every town that belongs to Moab, but especially Holon, Jahzah, Mephaath,
48.25: My decision is final--your army will be crushed, and your power broken.

48.28: Now you must leave your towns and live like doves in the shelter of cliffs and canyons.

48.40: Moab, an enemy swoops down like an eagle spreading its wings over your land.

48.42: You are finished as a nation, because you dared oppose me, the LORD.
48.43: Terror, pits, and traps are waiting for you.

48.46: People of Moab, you worshiped Chemosh, your god, but now you are done for, and your children are prisoners in a foreign country.
48.47: Yet someday, I will bring your people back home. I, the LORD, have spoken.

49.1: The LORD has this to say about the nation of Ammon: The people of Israel have plenty of children to inherit their lands. So why have you worshipers of the god Milcom taken over towns and land belonging to the tribe of Gad?

49.3: Cry, people of Heshbon; your town will become a pile of rubble. You will turn here and there, but your path will be blocked. Put on sackcloth and mourn, you citizens of Rabbah, because the idol you worship will be taken to a foreign country, along with its priests and temple officials.
49.4: You rebellious Ammonites trust your wealth and ask, "Who could attack us?" But I warn you not to boast when your strength is fading.
49.6: Yet someday, I will bring your people back home. I, the LORD, have spoken.
49.7: The LORD All-Powerful says about Edom: Wisdom and common sense have vanished from Teman.
49.8: I will send disaster to punish you descendants of Esau, so anyone from Dedan had better turn around and run back home.
49.9: People who harvest grapes leave some for the poor. Thieves who break in at night take only what they want.
49.10: But I will take everything that belongs to you, people of Edom, and I will uncover every place where you try to hide. Then you will die, and so will your children, relatives, and neighbors.
49.11: But I can be trusted to care for your orphans and widows.
49.13: I, the LORD, swear in my own name that your city of Bozrah and all your towns will suffer a horrible fate. They will lie in ruins forever, and people will use the name "Bozrah" as a curse word.
49.14: I have sent a messenger to command the nations to prepare for war against you people of Edom.
49.15: Your nation will be small, yet hated by other nations.
49.16: Pride tricks you into thinking that other nations look at you with fear. You live along the cliffs and high in the mountains like the eagles, but I am the LORD, and I will bring you down.
49.18: as bad as the destruction of Sodom and Gomorrah and towns nearby. The towns of Edom will be empty.
49.19: I, the LORD, will attack you like a lion from the forest, attacking sheep in a meadow along the Jordan. In a moment the flock runs, and the land is empty. Who will I choose to attack you? I will do it myself! No one can force me to fight or chase me away.
49.20: Listen to my plans for you, people of Edom. Your children will be dragged off and your country destroyed.
49.21: The sounds of your destruction will reach the Red Sea and cause the earth to shake.
49.22: An enemy will swoop down to attack you, like an eagle spreading its wings and circling over Bozrah. Your warriors will be as fearful as women giving birth.
49.23: The LORD says about Damascus: The towns of Hamath and Arpad have heard your bad news. They have lost hope, and worries roll over them like ocean waves.
49.24: You people of Damascus have lost your courage, and in panic you turn to run, gripped by fear and pain.
49.25: Once I was pleased with your famous city. But now I warn you, "Escape while you still can!"
49.26: Soon, even your best soldiers will lie dead in your streets. I, the LORD All-Powerful, have spoken.
49.27: I will set fire to your city walls and burn down the fortresses King Benhadad built.
49.29: His fearsome army will surround you, taking your tents and possessions, your sheep and camels.
49.32: Then your camels and large herds will be yours no longer. People of the Arabian Desert, disaster will strike you from every side, and you will be scattered everywhere on earth.
49.33: Only jackals will live where your villages once stood. I, the LORD, have spoken.
49.36: Enemies will attack from all directions, and you will be led captive to every nation on earth.
49.37: Their armies will crush and kill you, and you will face the disaster that my anger brings.
49.38: Your king and his officials will die, and I will rule in their place. I, the LORD, have spoken.
49.39: But I promise that someday I will bring your people back to their land.

50.1: The LORD told me to say: Announce what will happen and don't leave anything out.
50.3: The attack on the Babylonians will come from the north; they and their animals will run, leaving the land empty.
50.4: The LORD said: People of Israel and Judah, when these things happen you will weep, and together you will return to your land and worship me, the LORD your God.
50.5: You will ask the way to Zion and then come and join with me in making an agreement you won't break or forget.
50.6: My people, you are lost sheep abandoned in the mountains by their shepherds. You don't even remember your resting place.
50.7: I am your true pastureland, the one who gave hope to your ancestors. But you abandoned me, so when your enemies found you, they felt no guilt as they gobbled you up.
50.8: Escape from Babylonia, my people. Get out of that country! Don't wait for anyone else.
50.9: In the north I am bringing great nations together. They will attack Babylon and capture it. The arrows they shoot are like the best soldiers, always finding their target.
50.10: Babylonia will be conquered, and its enemies will carry off everything they want.
50.12: The city of Babylon was like a mother to you. But it will be disgraced and become nothing but a barren desert.
50.13: My anger will destroy Babylon, and no one will live there. Everyone who passes by will be shocked to see what has happened.
50.14: Babylon has rebelled against me. Archers, take your places. Shoot all your arrows at Babylon.
50.15: Attack from every side! Babylon surrenders! The enemy tears down its walls and towers. I am taking my revenge by doing to Babylon what it did to other cities.
50.16: There is no one in Babylonia to plant or harvest crops. Even foreigners who lived there have left for their homelands, afraid of the enemy armies.
50.17: Israel is a flock of sheep scattered by hungry lions. The king of Assyria first gobbled Israel up. Then Nebuchadnezzar, king of Babylonia, crunched on Israel's bones.
50.18: I, the LORD All-Powerful, the God of Israel, punished the king of Assyria, and I will also punish the king of Babylonia.
50.19: But I will bring Israel back to its own land. The people will be like sheep eating their fill on Mount Carmel and in Bashan, in the hill country of Ephraim and in Gilead.
50.20: I will rescue a few people from Israel and Judah. I will forgive them so completely that their sin and guilt will disappear, never to be found.
50.22: Sounds of war and the noise of destruction can be heard.
50.23: Babylonia was a hammer pounding every country, but now it lies broken. What a shock to the nations of the world!
50.24: Babylonia challenged me, the LORD God All-Powerful, but that nation doesn't know it is caught in a trap that I set.
50.25: I've brought out my weapons, and with them I will put a curse on Babylonia.
50.26: Come from far away, you enemies of Babylon! Pile up the grain from its storehouses, and destroy it completely, along with everything else.
50.27: Kill the soldiers of Babylonia, because the time has come for them to be punished.
50.28: The Babylonian army destroyed my temple, but soon I will take revenge. Then refugees from Babylon will tell about it in Zion.
50.29: Attack Babylon, enemy archers; set up camp around the city, and don't let anyone escape. It challenged me, the holy God, so do to it what it did to other cities.
50.30: People of Babylon, I, the LORD, promise that even your best soldiers will lie dead in the streets.
50.32: You are proud, but you will stumble and fall, and no one will help you up. I will set your villages on fire, and everything around you will go up in flames.
50.33: You Babylonians were cruel to Israel and Judah. You took them captive, and now you refuse to let them go.
50.34: But I, the LORD All-Powerful, will rescue and protect them. I will bring peace to their land and trouble to yours.
50.36: This war will prove that your prophets are liars and fools. And it will frighten your warriors.
50.37: Then your chariot horses and the foreigners in your army will refuse to go into battle, and the enemy will carry away everything you treasure.
50.38: Your rivers and canals will dry up. All of this will happen, because your land is full of idols, and they have made fools of you.
50.39: Never again will people live in your land--only desert animals, jackals, and unclean birds.
50.40: I destroyed Sodom and Gomorrah and the nearby towns, and I will destroy Babylon just as completely. No one will live there again.
50.41: Far to the north, a nation and its allies have been awakened. They are powerful and ready for war.
50.42: Bows and arrows and swords are in their hands. The soldiers are cruel and show no pity. The hoofbeats of their horses echo like ocean waves crashing against the shore. The army has lined up for battle and is coming to attack you, people of Babylonia!
50.43: Ever since your king heard about this army, he has been weak with fear; he twists and turns in pain like a woman giving birth.
50.44: Babylonia, I will attack you like a lion from the forest, attacking sheep in a meadow along the Jordan. In a moment the flock runs, and the land is empty. Who will I choose to attack you? I will do it myself! No one can force me to fight or chase me away.
50.45: Listen to my plans for you, people of Babylonia. Your children will be dragged off, and your country destroyed.
50.46: The sounds of your destruction will be heard among the nations, and the earth will shake.

51.1: I, the LORD, am sending a wind to destroy the people of Babylonia and Babylon, its capital.
51.2: Foreign soldiers will come from every direction, and when the disaster is over, Babylonia will be empty and worthless.
51.3: I will tell these soldiers, "Attack quickly, before the Babylonians can string their bows or put on their armor. Kill their best soldiers and destroy their army!"
51.4: Their troops will fall wounded in the streets of Babylon.
51.5: Everyone in Israel and Judah is guilty. But I, the LORD All-Powerful, their holy God, have not abandoned them.
51.6: Get out of Babylon! Run for your lives! If you stay, you will be killed when I take revenge on the city and punish it for its sins.
51.7: Babylon was my golden cup, filled with the wine of my anger. The nations of the world got drunk on this wine and went insane.
51.8: But suddenly, Babylon will fall and be destroyed. I, the LORD, told the foreigners who lived there, "Weep for the city! Get medicine for its wounds; maybe they will heal."
51.9: The foreigners answered, "We have already tried to treat Babylon's wounds, but they would not heal. Come on, let's all go home to our own countries. Nothing is left in Babylonia; everything is destroyed."
51.10: The people of Israel said, "Tell everyone in Zion! The LORD has taken revenge for what Babylon did to us."
51.11: I, the LORD, want Babylon destroyed, because its army destroyed my temple. So, you kings of Media, sharpen your arrows and pick up your shields.
51.12: Raise the signal flag and attack the city walls. Post more guards. Have soldiers watch the city and set up ambushes. I have made plans to destroy Babylon, and nothing will stop me.
51.13: People of Babylon, you live along the Euphrates River and are surrounded by canals. You are rich, but now the time has come for you to die.
51.14: I, the LORD All-Powerful, swear by my own life that enemy soldiers will fill your streets like a swarm of locusts. They will shout and celebrate their victory.
51.15: God used his wisdom and power to create the earth and spread out the heavens.
51.16: The waters in the heavens roar at his command. He makes clouds appear; he sends the wind from his storehouse and makes lightning flash in the rain.
51.17: People who make idols are stupid! They will be disappointed, because their false gods cannot breathe.
51.18: Idols are merely a joke, and when the time is right, they will be destroyed.
51.19: But the LORD, Israel's God, is all-powerful. He created everything, and he chose Israel to be his very own.
51.20: Babylonia, you were my hammer; I used you to pound nations and break kingdoms,
51.22: as well as men and women, young and old,
51.23: shepherds and their flocks, farmers and their oxen, and governors and leaders.
51.26: Your stone blocks won't be reused for cornerstones or foundations, and I promise that forever you will be a desert. I, the LORD, have spoken.
51.27: Signal the nations to get ready to attack. Raise a flag and blow a trumpet. Send for the armies of Ararat, Minni, and Ashkenaz. Choose a commander; let the cavalry attack like a swarm of locusts.
51.28: Tell the kings and governors, the leaders and the people of the kingdoms of the Medes to prepare for war!
51.29: The earth twists and turns in torment, because I have decided to make Babylonia a desert where no one can live, and I won't change my mind.
51.30: The Babylonian soldiers have lost their strength and courage. They stay in their fortresses, unable to fight, while the enemy breaks through the city gates, then sets their homes on fire.
51.31: One messenger after another announces to the king, "Babylon has been captured!
51.32: The enemy now controls the river crossings! The marshes are on fire! Your army has panicked!"
51.33: I am the LORD All-Powerful, the God of Israel, and I make this promise--"Soon Babylon will be leveled and packed down like a threshing place at harvest time."
51.34: The people of Jerusalem say, "King Nebuchadnezzar made us panic. That monster stuffed himself with us and our treasures, leaving us empty--he gobbled up what he wanted and spit out the rest.
51.35: The people of Babylonia harmed some of us and killed others. Now, LORD, make them pay!"
51.36: My people, I am on your side, and I will take revenge on Babylon. I will cut off its water supply, and its stream will dry up.
51.37: Babylon will be a pile of rubble where only jackals live, and everyone will be afraid to walk among the ruins.
51.38: The Babylonians roar and growl like young lions.
51.39: And since they are hungry, I will give them a banquet. They will celebrate, get drunk, then fall asleep, never to wake up!
51.40: I will lead them away to die, like sheep, lambs, and goats being led to the butcher.
51.41: All nations now praise Babylon, but when it is captured, those same nations will be horrified.
51.42: Babylon's enemies will rise like ocean waves and flood the city.
51.43: Horrible destruction will strike the nearby towns. The land will become a barren desert, where no one can live or even travel.
51.44: I will punish Marduk, the god of Babylon, and make him vomit out everything he gobbled up. Then nations will no longer bring him gifts, and Babylon's walls will crumble.
51.46: Don't be afraid or lose hope, though year after year there are rumors of leaders fighting for control in the city of Babylon.
51.47: The time will come when I will punish Babylon's false gods. Everyone there will die, and the whole nation will be disgraced,
51.48: when an army attacks from the north and brings destruction. Then the earth and the heavens and everything in them will celebrate.
51.49: Babylon must be overthrown, because it slaughtered the people of Israel and of many other nations.
51.50: My people, you escaped death when Jerusalem fell. Now you live far from home, but you should trust me and think about Jerusalem. Leave Babylon! Don't stay!
51.51: You feel ashamed and disgraced, because foreigners have entered my sacred temple.
51.52: Soon I will send a war to punish Babylon's idols and leave its wounded people moaning everywhere.
51.53: Although Babylon's walls reach to the sky, the army I send will destroy that city. I, the LORD, have spoken.
51.54: Listen to the cries for help coming from Babylon. Everywhere in the country the sounds of destruction can be heard.
51.55: The shouts of the enemy, like crashing ocean waves, will drown out Babylon's cries as I level the city.
51.56: An enemy will attack and destroy Babylon. Its soldiers will be captured and their weapons broken, because I am a God who takes revenge against nations for what they do.
51.57: I, the LORD All-Powerful, the true King, promise that the officials and advisors, the governors and leaders, and the soldiers of Babylon will get drunk, fall asleep, and never wake up.
51.58: The thick walls of that city will be torn down, and its huge gates burned. Everything that nation worked so hard to gain will go up in smoke.
51.59: During Zedekiah's fourth year as king of Judah, he went to Babylon. And Baruch's brother Seraiah went along as the officer in charge of arranging for places to stay overnight.
51.60: Before they left, I wrote on a scroll all the terrible things that would happen to Babylon.
51.61: I gave the scroll to Seraiah and said: When you get to Babylon, read this scroll aloud,
51.62: then pray, "Our LORD, you promised to destroy this place and make it into a desert where no people or animals will ever live."
51.63: When you finish praying, tie the scroll to a rock and throw it in the Euphrates River. Then say,
51.64: "This is how Babylon will sink when the LORD destroys it. Everyone in the city will die, and it won't have the strength to rise again." Jeremiah's writing ends here.

52.1: Zedekiah was 21 years old when he was appointed king of Judah, and he ruled from Jerusalem for eleven years. His mother Hamutal was the daughter of Jeremiah from the town of Libnah.
52.2: Zedekiah disobeyed the LORD, just as Jehoiakim had done,
52.3: and it was Zedekiah who finally rebelled against Nebuchadnezzar. The people of Judah and Jerusalem had made the LORD so angry that he finally turned his back on them. That's why horrible things were happening there.
52.4: In Zedekiah's ninth year as king, on the tenth day of the tenth month, King Nebuchadnezzar of Babylonia led his entire army to attack Jerusalem. The troops set up camp outside the city and built ramps up to the city walls.
52.7: the Babylonian troops broke through the city wall. That same night, Zedekiah and his soldiers tried to escape through the gate near the royal garden, even though they knew the enemy had the city surrounded. They headed toward the Jordan River valley,
52.8: but the Babylonian troops caught up with them near Jericho. The Babylonians arrested Zedekiah, but his soldiers scattered in every direction.
52.9: Zedekiah was taken to Riblah in the land of Hamath, where Nebuchadnezzar put him on trial and found him guilty.
52.10: Zedekiah's sons and the officials of Judah were killed while he watched,
52.11: then his eyes were poked out. He was put in chains, then dragged off to Babylon and kept in prison until he died.
52.12: Jerusalem was captured during Nebuchadnezzar's nineteenth year as king of Babylonia. About a month later, Nebuchadnezzar's officer in charge of the guards arrived in Jerusalem. His name was Nebuzaradan,
52.13: and he burned down the LORD's temple, the king's palace, and every important building in the city, as well as all the houses.
52.14: Then he ordered the Babylonian soldiers to break down the walls around Jerusalem.
52.15: He led away the people left in the city, including everyone who had become loyal to Nebuchadnezzar, the rest of the skilled workers, and even some of the poor people of Judah.
52.16: Only the very poorest were left behind to work the vineyards and the fields.
52.21: For example, the columns were about 8 meters high and 5.5 meters around. They were hollow, but the bronze was about 75 millimeters thick.
52.22: Each column had a bronze cap over 2 meters high that was decorated with bronze designs. Some of these designs were like chains and others were like pomegranates.
52.23: There were 96 pomegranates evenly spaced around each column, and a total of 100 pomegranates were located above the chains.
52.24: Next, Nebuzaradan arrested Seraiah the chief priest, Zephaniah his assistant, and three temple officials.
52.25: Then he arrested one of the army commanders, seven of King Zedekiah's personal advisors, and the officer in charge of gathering the troops for battle. He also found 60 more soldiers who were still in Jerusalem.
52.31: Jehoiachin was a prisoner in Babylon for 37 years. Then Evil Merodach became king of Babylonia, and in the first year of his rule, on the twenty-fifth day of the twelfth month, he let Jehoiachin out of prison.
52.32: Evil Merodach was kind to Jehoiachin and honored him more than any of the other kings held prisoner there.
52.33: Jehoiachin was allowed to wear regular clothes instead of a prison uniform, and he even ate at the king's table every day.
52.34: As long as Jehoiachin lived, he was paid a daily allowance to buy whatever he needed.

1.1: Jerusalem, once so crowded, lies deserted and lonely. This city that was known all over the world is now like a widow. This queen of the nations has been made a slave.
1.2: Each night, bitter tears flood her cheeks. None of her former lovers are there to offer comfort; her friends have betrayed her and are now her enemies.
1.3: The people of Judah are slaves, suffering in a foreign land, with no rest from sorrow. Their enemies captured them and were terribly cruel.
1.4: The roads to Zion mourn because no one travels there to celebrate the festivals. The city gates are deserted; priests are weeping. Young women are raped; Zion is in sorrow!
1.5: Enemies now rule the city and live as they please. The LORD has punished Jerusalem because of her awful sins; he has let her people be dragged away.
1.6: Zion's glory has disappeared. Her leaders are like deer that cannot find pasture; they are hunted down till their strength is gone.
1.7: Her people recall the good life that once was theirs; now they suffer and are scattered. No one was there to protect them from their enemies who sneered when their city was taken.
1.8: Jerusalem's horrible sins have made the city a joke. Those who once admired her now hate her instead--she has been disgraced; she groans and turns away.
1.9: Her sins had made her filthy, but she wasn't worried about what could happen. And when Jerusalem fell, it was so tragic. No one gave her comfort when she cried out, "Help! I'm in trouble, LORD! The enemy has won."
1.10: Zion's treasures were stolen. Jerusalem saw foreigners enter her place of worship, though the LORD had forbidden them to belong to his people.
1.11: Everyone in the city groans while searching for food; they trade their valuables for barely enough scraps to stay alive. Jerusalem shouts to the LORD, "Please look and see how miserable I am!"
1.12: No passerby even cares. Why doesn't someone notice my terrible sufferings? You were fiercely angry, LORD, and you punished me worst of all.
1.14: You have tied my sins around my neck, and they weigh so heavily that my strength is gone. You have put me in the power of enemies too strong for me.
1.15: You, LORD, have turned back my warriors and crushed my young heroes. Judah was a woman untouched, but you let her be trampled like grapes in a wine pit.
1.16: Because of this, I mourn, and tears flood my eyes. No one is here to comfort or to encourage me; we have lost the war--my people are suffering.
1.17: Zion reaches out her hands, but no one offers comfort. The LORD has turned the neighboring nations against Jacob's descendants. Jerusalem is merely a filthy rag to her neighbors.
1.18: The LORD was right, but I refused to obey him. Now I ask all of you to look at my sufferings--even my young people have been dragged away.
1.19: I called out to my lovers, but they betrayed me. My priests and my leaders died while searching the city for scraps of food.
1.20: Won't you look and see how upset I am, our LORD? My stomach is in knots, and my heart is broken because I betrayed you. In the streets and at home, my people are slaughtered.
1.21: Everyone heard my groaning, but no one offered comfort. My enemies know of the trouble that you have brought on me, and it makes them glad. Hurry and punish them, as you have promised.
1.22: Don't let their evil deeds escape your sight. Punish them as much as you have punished me because of my sins. I never stop groaning--I've lost all hope!

2.1: The Lord was angry! So he disgraced Zion though it was Israel's pride and his own place of rest. In his anger he threw Zion down from heaven to earth.
2.2: The LORD had no mercy! He destroyed the homes of Jacob's descendants. In his anger he tore down every walled city in Judah; he toppled the nation together with its leaders, leaving them in shame.
2.3: The Lord was so furiously angry that he wiped out the whole army of Israel by not supporting them when the enemy attacked. He was like a raging fire that swallowed up the descendants of Jacob.
2.4: He attacked like an enemy with a bow and arrows, killing our loved ones. He has burned to the ground the homes on Mount Zion.
2.5: The Lord was like an enemy! He left Israel in ruins with its palaces and fortresses destroyed, and with everyone in Judah moaning and weeping.
2.6: He shattered his temple like a hut in a garden; he completely wiped out his meeting place, and did away with festivals and Sabbaths in the city of Zion. In his fierce anger he rejected our king and priests.
2.7: The Lord abandoned his altar and his temple; he let Zion's enemies capture her fortresses. Noisy shouts were heard from the temple, as if it were a time of celebration.
2.8: The LORD had decided to tear down the walls of Zion stone by stone. So he started destroying and did not stop until walls and fortresses mourned and trembled.
2.9: Zion's gates have fallen facedown on the ground; the bars that locked the gates are smashed to pieces. Her king and royal family are prisoners in foreign lands. Her priests don't teach, and her prophets don't have a message from the LORD.
2.10: Zion's leaders are silent. They just sit on the ground, tossing dirt on their heads and wearing sackcloth. Her young women can do nothing but stare at the ground.
2.11: My eyes are red from crying, my stomach is in knots, and I feel sick all over. My people are being wiped out, and children lie helpless in the streets of the city.
2.12: A child begs its mother for food and drink, then blacks out like a wounded soldier lying in the street. The child slowly dies in its mother's arms.
2.13: Zion, how can I comfort you? How great is your pain? Lovely city of Jerusalem, how can I heal your wounds, gaping as wide as the sea?
2.14: Your prophets deceived you with false visions and lying messages--they should have warned you to leave your sins and be saved from disaster.
2.15: Those who pass by shake their heads and sneer as they make fun and shout, "What a lovely city you were, the happiest on earth, but look at you now!"
2.16: Zion, your enemies curse you and snarl like wild animals, while shouting, "This is the day we've waited for! At last, we've got you!"
2.17: The LORD has done everything that he had planned and threatened long ago. He destroyed you without mercy and let your enemies boast about their powerful forces.
2.18: Zion, deep in your heart you cried out to the Lord. Now let your tears overflow your walls day and night. Don't ever lose hope or let your tears stop.
2.19: Get up and pray for help all through the night. Pour out your feelings to the Lord, as you would pour water out of a jug. Beg him to save your people, who are starving to death at every street crossing.
2.20: Think about it, LORD! Have you ever been this cruel to anyone before? Is it right for mothers to eat their children, or for priests and prophets to be killed in your temple?
2.21: My people, both young and old, lie dead in the streets. Because you were angry, my young men and women were brutally slaughtered.
2.22: When you were angry, LORD, you invited my enemies like guests for a party. No one survived that day; enemies killed my children, my own little ones.

3.1: I have suffered much because God was angry.
3.2: He chased me into a dark place, where no light could enter.
3.3: I am the only one he punishes over and over again, without ever stopping.
3.4: God caused my skin and flesh to waste away, and he crushed my bones.
3.5: He attacked and surrounded me with hardships and trouble;
3.6: he forced me to sit in the dark like someone long dead.
3.7: God built a fence around me that I cannot climb over, and he chained me down.
3.8: Even when I shouted and prayed for help, he refused to listen.
3.9: God put big rocks in my way and made me follow a crooked path.
3.10: God was like a bear or a lion waiting in ambush for me;
3.11: he dragged me from the road, then tore me to shreds.
3.12: God took careful aim and shot his arrows
3.13: straight through my heart.
3.14: I am a joke to everyone--no one ever stops making fun of me.
3.15: God has turned my life sour.
3.16: He made me eat gravel and rubbed me in the dirt.
3.17: I cannot find peace or remember happiness.
3.18: I tell myself, "I am finished! I can't count on the LORD to do anything for me."
3.19: Just thinking of my troubles and my lonely wandering makes me miserable.
3.20: That's all I ever think about, and I am depressed.
3.21: Then I remember something that fills me with hope.
3.22: The LORD's kindness never fails! If he had not been merciful, we would have been destroyed.
3.23: The LORD can always be trusted to show mercy each morning.
3.24: Deep in my heart I say, "The LORD is all I need; I can depend on him!"
3.25: The LORD is kind to everyone who trusts and obeys him.
3.26: It is good to wait patiently for the LORD to save us.
3.27: When we are young, it is good to struggle hard
3.28: and to sit silently alone, if this is what the LORD intends.
3.29: Being rubbed in the dirt can teach us a lesson;
3.30: we can also learn from insults and hard knocks.
3.31: The Lord won't always reject us!
3.32: He causes a lot of suffering, but he also has pity because of his great love.
3.33: The Lord doesn't enjoy sending grief or pain.
3.34: Don't trample prisoners under your feet
3.35: or cheat anyone out of what is rightfully theirs. God Most High sees everything,
3.36: and he knows when you refuse to give someone a fair trial.
3.37: No one can do anything without the Lord's approval.
3.38: Good and bad each happen at the command of God Most High.
3.39: We're still alive! We shouldn't complain when we are being punished for our sins.
3.40: Instead, we should think about the way we are living, and turn back to the LORD.
3.41: When we lift our hands in prayer to God in heaven, we should offer him our hearts and say,
3.42: "We've sinned! We've rebelled against you, and you haven't forgiven us!
3.43: Anger is written all over you, as you pursue and slaughter us without showing pity.
3.44: You are behind a wall of clouds that blocks out our prayers.
3.45: You allowed nations to treat us like garbage;
3.47: We are terrified and trapped, caught and crushed."
3.48: My people are destroyed! Tears flood my eyes,
3.50: until the LORD looks down from heaven and helps.
3.51: I am horrified when I see what enemies have done to the young women of our city.
3.52: No one had reason to hate me, but I was hunted down like a bird.
3.53: Then they tried to kill me by tossing me into a pit and throwing stones at me.
3.54: Water covered my head--I thought I was gone.
3.55: From the bottom of the pit, I prayed to you, LORD.
3.58: You rescued me and saved my life.
3.59: You saw them abuse me, LORD, so make things right.
3.60: You know every plot they have made against me.
3.61: Yes, you know their insults and their evil plans.
3.62: All day long they attack with words and whispers.
3.63: No matter what they are doing, they keep on mocking me.
3.64: Pay them back for everything they have done, LORD!
3.65: Put your curse on them and make them suffer.
3.66: Get angry and go after them until not a trace is left under the heavens.

4.1: The purest gold is ruined and has lost its shine; jewels from the temple lie scattered in the streets.
4.2: These are Zion's people, worth more than purest gold; yet they are counted worthless like dishes of clay.
4.3: Even jackals nurse their young, but my people are like ostriches that abandon their own.
4.4: Babies are so thirsty that their tongues are stuck to the roof of the mouth. Children go begging for food, but no one gives them any.
4.5: All who ate expensive foods lie starving in the streets; those who grew up in luxury now sit on trash heaps.
4.6: My nation was punished worse than the people of Sodom, whose city was destroyed in a flash without the help of human hands.
4.7: The leaders of Jerusalem were purer than snow and whiter than milk; their bodies were healthy and glowed like jewels.
4.8: Now they are blacker than tar, and no one recognizes them; their skin clings to their bones and is drier than firewood.
4.9: Being killed with a sword is better than slowly starving to death.
4.10: Life in the city is so bad that loving mothers have boiled and eaten their own children.
4.11: The LORD was so fiercely angry that he burned the city of Zion to the ground.
4.12: Not a king on this earth or the people of any nation believed enemies could break through her gates.
4.13: Jerusalem was punished because her prophets and her priests had sinned and caused the death of innocent victims.
4.14: Yes, her prophets and priests were covered with blood; no one would come near them, as they wandered from street to street.
4.16: The LORD is the one who sent them scattering, and he has forgotten them. No respect or kindness will be shown to the priests or leaders.
4.17: Our eyes became weary, hopelessly looking for help from a nation that could not save us.
4.18: Enemies hunted us down on every public street. Our time was up; our doom was near.
4.19: They swooped down faster than eagles from the sky. They hunted for us in the hills and set traps to catch us out in the desert.
4.20: The LORD's chosen leader was our hope for survival! We thought he would keep us safe somewhere among the nations, but even he was caught in one of their traps.
4.21: You people of Edom can celebrate now! But your time will come to suffer and stagger around naked.
4.22: The people of Zion have paid for their sins, and the Lord will soon let them return home. But, people of Edom, you will be punished, and your sins exposed.

5.1: Our LORD, don't forget how we have suffered and been disgraced.
5.2: Foreigners and strangers have taken our land and our homes.
5.3: We are like children whose mothers are widows.
5.4: The water we drink and the wood we burn cost far too much.
5.5: We are terribly mistreated; we are worn out and can find no rest.
5.6: We had to surrender to Egypt and Assyria because we were hungry.
5.7: Our ancestors sinned, but they are dead, and we are left to pay for their sins.
5.8: Slaves are now our rulers, and there is no one to set us free.
5.9: We are in danger from brutal desert tribes; we must risk our lives just to bring in our crops.
5.10: Our skin is scorched from fever and hunger.
5.11: On Zion and everywhere in Judah our wives and daughters are being raped.
5.12: Our rulers are strung up by their arms, and our nation's advisors are treated shamefully.
5.13: Young men are forced to do the work of slaves; boys must carry heavy loads of wood.
5.14: Our leaders are not allowed to decide cases in court, and young people no longer play music.
5.15: Our hearts are sad; instead of dancing, we mourn.
5.16: Zion's glory has disappeared! And we are doomed because of our sins.
5.17: We feel sick all over and can't even see straight;
5.18: our city is in ruins, overrun by wild dogs.
5.19: You will rule forever, LORD! You are King for all time.
5.20: Why have you forgotten us for so long?
5.21: Bring us back to you! Give us a fresh start.
5.22: Or do you despise us so much that you don't want us?

1.4: I saw a windstorm blowing in from the north. Lightning flashed from a huge cloud and lit up the whole sky with a dazzling brightness. The fiery center of the cloud was as shiny as polished metal,
1.5: and in that center I saw what looked like four living creatures. They were somewhat like humans,
1.6: except that each one had four faces and four wings.
1.7: Their legs were straight, but their feet looked like the hoofs of calves and sparkled like bronze.
1.8: Under each of their wings, these creatures had a human hand.
1.9: The four creatures were standing back to back with the tips of their wings touching. They moved together in every direction, without turning their bodies.
1.10: Each creature had the face of a human in front, the face of a lion on the right side, the face of a bull on the left, and the face of an eagle in back.
1.11: Two wings of each creature were spread out and touched the wings of the creatures on either side. The other two wings of each creature were folded against its body.
1.12: The four living creatures went wherever the Spirit led them, and they moved together without turning their bodies, because each creature faced straight ahead.
1.13: The creatures were glowing like hot coals, and I saw something like a flaming torch moving back and forth among them. Lightning flashed from the torch every time its flame blazed up.
1.14: The creatures themselves moved as quickly as sparks jumping from a fire.
1.15: I then noticed that on the ground beside each of the four living creatures was a wheel,
1.16: shining like chrysolite. Each wheel was exactly the same and had a second wheel that cut through the middle of it,
1.17: so that they could move in any direction without turning.
1.18: The rims of the wheels were large and frightening, and they had eyes all the way around them.
1.24: Whenever the creatures flew, their wings roared like an ocean or a large army or even the voice of God All-Powerful. And whenever the creatures stopped, they folded their wings against their bodies.
1.25: When the creatures stopped flapping their wings, I heard a sound coming from above the dome.
1.26: I then saw what looked like a throne made of sapphire, and sitting on the throne was a figure in the shape of a human.
1.27: From the waist up, it was glowing like metal in a hot furnace, and from the waist down it looked like the flames of a fire. The figure was surrounded by a bright light,
1.28: as colorful as a rainbow that appears after a storm. I realized I was seeing the brightness of the LORD's glory! So I bowed with my face to the ground, and just then I heard a voice speaking to me.

2.1: The LORD said, "Ezekiel, son of man, I want you to stand up and listen."
2.2: After he said this, his Spirit took control of me and lifted me to my feet. Then the LORD said:
2.3: Ezekiel, I am sending you to the people of Israel. They are just like their ancestors who rebelled against me and refused to stop.
2.4: They are stubborn and hardheaded. But I, the LORD God, have chosen you to tell them what I say.
2.5: Those rebels may not even listen, but at least they will know that a prophet has come to them.
2.6: Don't be afraid of them or of anything they say. You may think you're in the middle of a thorn patch or a bunch of scorpions. But be brave
2.7: and preach my message to them, whether they choose to listen or not.
2.8: Ezekiel, don't rebel against me, as they have done. Instead, listen to everything I tell you. And now, Ezekiel, open your mouth and eat what I am going to give you.
2.9: Just then, I saw a hand stretched out toward me. And in it was a scroll.
2.10: The hand opened the scroll, and both sides of it were filled with words of sadness, mourning, and grief.

3.1: The LORD said, "Ezekiel, son of man, after you eat this scroll, go speak to the people of Israel."
3.4: The LORD said: Ezekiel, I am sending you to your own people.
3.7: But the people of Israel will refuse to listen, because they have refused to listen to me. All of them are stubborn and hardheaded,
3.8: so I will make you as stubborn as they are.
3.9: You will be so determined to speak my message that nothing will stop you. I will make you hard like a diamond, and you'll have no reason to be afraid of those arrogant rebels.
3.10: Listen carefully to everything I say and then think about it.
3.11: Then go to the people who were brought here to Babylonia with you and tell them you have a message from me, the LORD God. Do this, whether they listen to you or not.
3.12: The Spirit lifted me up, and as the glory of the LORD started to leave, I heard a loud, thundering noise behind me.
3.13: It was the sound made by the creatures' wings as they brushed against each other, and by the rumble of the wheels beside them.
3.14: Then the Spirit carried me away. The LORD's power had taken complete control of me, and I was both annoyed and angry.
3.15: When I was back with the others living at Abib Hill near the Chebar River, I sat among them for seven days, shocked at what had happened to me.
