3.16: Seven days after I had seen the brightness of the LORD's glory, the LORD said:
3.17: Ezekiel, son of man, I have appointed you to stand watch for the people of Israel. So listen to what I say, then warn them for me.
3.18: When I tell wicked people they will die because of their sins, you must warn them to turn from their sinful ways so they won't be punished. If you refuse, you are responsible for their death.
3.19: However, if you do warn them, and they keep on sinning, they will die because of their sins, and you will be innocent.
3.21: But if you do warn them, and they listen to you and stop sinning, I will let them live. And you will be innocent.
3.22: The LORD took control of me and said, "Stand up! Go into the valley, and I will talk with you there."
3.23: I immediately went to the valley, where I saw the brightness of the LORD's glory, just as I had seen it near the Chebar River, and I bowed with my face to the ground.
3.24: His Spirit took control of me and lifted me to my feet. Then the LORD said: Go back and lock yourself in your house!
3.25: You will be tied up to keep you inside,
3.26: and I will make you unable to talk or to warn those who have rebelled against me.
3.27: But the time will come, when I will tell you what to say, and you will again be able to speak my message. Some of them will listen; others will be stubborn and refuse to listen.

4.1: Ezekiel, son of man, find a brick and sketch a picture of Jerusalem on it.
4.2: Then prepare to attack the brick as if it were a real city. Build a dirt mound and a ramp up to the top and surround the brick with enemy camps. On every side put large wooden poles as though you were going to break down the gate to the city.
4.3: Set up an iron pan like a wall between you and the brick. All this will be a warning for the people of Israel.
4.6: Then turn over and lie on your right side 40 more days. That will be a sign of Judah's punishment--one day for each year of its suffering.
4.7: The brick stands for Jerusalem, so attack it! Stare at it and shout angry warnings.
4.8: I will tie you up, so you can't leave until your attack has ended.
4.9: Get a large bowl. Then mix together wheat, barley, beans, lentils, and millet, and make some bread. This is what you will eat for the 390 days you are lying down.
4.10: Eat only a small loaf of bread each day
4.11: and drink only two large cups of water.
4.12: Use dried human waste to start a fire, then bake the bread on the coals where everyone can watch you.
4.13: When I scatter the people of Israel among the nations, they will also have to eat food that is unclean, just as you must do.
4.14: I said, "LORD God, please don't make me do that! Never in my life have I eaten food that would make me unacceptable to you. I've never eaten anything that died a natural death or was killed by a wild animal or that you said was unclean."
4.15: The LORD replied, "Instead of human waste, I will let you bake your bread on a fire made from cow manure.
4.16: Ezekiel, the people of Jerusalem will starve. They will have so little food and water that they will be afraid and hopeless.
4.17: Everyone will be shocked at what is happening, and, because of their sins, they will die a slow death."

5.1: Ezekiel, son of man, get a sharp sword and use it to cut off your hair and beard. Weigh the hair and divide it into three equal piles.
5.2: After you attack the brick that stands for Jerusalem, burn one pile of your hair on the brick. Chop up the second pile and let the small pieces of hair fall around the brick. Throw the third pile into the wind, and I will strike it with my own sword.
5.3: Keep a few of the hairs and wrap them in the hem of your clothes.
5.4: Then pull out a few of those hairs and throw them in the fire, so they will also burn. This fire will spread, destroying everyone in Israel.
5.5: I am the LORD God, and I have made Jerusalem the most important place in the world, and all other nations admire it.
5.6: But the people of Jerusalem rebelled and refuse to obey me. They ignored my laws and have become even more sinful than the nations around them.
5.7: So tell the people of Jerusalem: I am the LORD God! You have refused to obey my laws and teachings, and instead you have obeyed the laws of the surrounding nations. You have become more rebellious than any of them!
5.8: Now all those nations will watch as I turn against you and punish you
5.9: for your sins. Your punishment will be more horrible than anything I've ever done or will ever do again.
5.10: Parents will be so desperate for food that they will eat their own children, and children will eat their parents. Those who survive this horror will be scattered in every direction.
5.11: Your sins have disgusted me and made my temple unfit as a place to worship me. So I swear by my own life that I will cut you down and show you no pity.
5.12: A third of you will die here in Jerusalem from disease or starvation. Another third will be killed in war. And I will scatter the last third of you in every direction, then track you down and kill you.
5.13: You will feel my fierce anger until I have finished taking revenge. Then you will know that I, the LORD, was furious because of your disobedience.
5.14: Every passerby will laugh at your destruction. Foreign nations
5.15: will insult you and make fun of you, but they will also be shocked and terrified at what I did in my anger.
5.16: I will destroy your crops until you starve to death, and disasters will strike you like arrows.
5.17: Starvation and wild animals will kill your children. I'll punish you with horrible diseases, and your enemies will strike you down with their swords. I, the LORD, have spoken.

6.1: The LORD God said:
6.2: Ezekiel, son of man, face the hills of Israel and tell them:
6.3: Listen, you mountains and hills, and every valley and gorge! I, the LORD, am about to turn against you and crush all the places where foreign gods are worshiped.
6.4: Every altar will be smashed, and in front of the idols I will put to death the people who worship them.
6.5: Dead bodies and bones will be lying around the idols and the altars.
6.6: Every town in Israel will be destroyed to make sure that each shrine, idol, and altar is smashed--everything the Israelites made will be a pile of ruins.
6.7: All over the country, your people will die. And those who survive will know that I, the LORD, did these things.
6.8: I will let some of the people live through this punishment, but I will scatter them among the nations,
6.9: where they will be prisoners. And when they think of me, they will realize that they disgraced me by rebelling and by worshiping idols. They will hate themselves for the evil things they did,
6.10: and they will know that I am the LORD and that my warnings must be taken seriously.
6.12: Those who live far away will be struck with deadly diseases. Those who live nearby will be killed in war. And the ones who are left will starve to death. I will let loose my anger on them!
6.13: These people used to offer incense to idols at altars built on hills and mountaintops and in the shade of large oak trees. But when they see dead bodies lying around those altars, they will know that I am the LORD.
6.14: I will make their country a barren wasteland, from the Southern Desert to the town of Diblah in the north. Then they will know that I, the LORD, have done these things.

7.1: The LORD God said:
7.3: as punishment for your disgusting sins. I, the LORD, am so angry
7.4: that I will show no pity. I will punish you for the evil you've done, and you will know that I am the LORD.
7.6: And when it comes, your life will be over.
7.7: You people of Israel are doomed! Soon there will be panic on the mountaintops instead of celebration.
7.8: I will let loose my anger and punish you for the evil things you've done. You'll get what you deserve.
7.9: Your sins are so terrible, that you'll get no mercy from me. Then you will know that I, the LORD, have punished you.
7.10: Disaster is near! Injustice and arrogance are everywhere,
7.11: and violent criminals run free. None of you will survive the disaster, and everything you own and value will be shattered.
7.12: The time is coming when everyone will be ruined. Buying and selling will stop,
7.13: and people who sell property will never get it back, because all of you must be punished for your sins. And I won't change my mind!
7.14: A signal has been blown on the trumpet, and weapons are prepared for battle. But no one goes to war, because in my anger I will strike down everyone in Israel.
7.15: War, disease, and starvation are everywhere! People who live in the countryside will be killed in battle, and those who live in towns will die from starvation or deadly diseases.
7.16: Anyone who survives will escape into the hills, like doves who leave the valleys to find safety. All of you will moan because of your sins.
7.17: Your hands will tremble, and your knees go limp.
7.18: You will put on sackcloth to show your sorrow, but terror will overpower you. Shame will be written all over your faces, and you will shave your heads in despair.
7.19: Your silver and gold will be thrown into the streets like garbage, because those are the two things that led you into sin, and now they cannot save you from my anger. They are not even worth enough to buy food.
7.20: You took great pride in using your beautiful jewelry to make disgusting idols of foreign gods. So I will make your jewelry worthless.
7.21: Wicked foreigners will rob and disgrace you.
7.22: They will break into my temple and leave it unfit as a place to worship me, but I will look away and let it happen.
7.23: Your whole country is in confusion! Murder and violence are everywhere in Israel,
7.24: so I will tell the most wicked nations to come and take over your homes. They will put an end to the pride you have in your strong army, and they will make your places of worship unfit to use.
7.25: You will be terrified and will desperately look for peace--but there will be no peace.
7.26: One tragedy will follow another, and you'll hear only bad news. People will beg prophets to give them a message from me. Priests will stop teaching my Law, and wise leaders won't be able to give advice.
7.27: Even your king and his officials will lose hope and cry in despair. Your hands will tremble with fear. I will punish you for your sins and treat you the same way you have treated others. Then you will know that I am the LORD.

8.1: Six years after King Jehoiachin and the rest of us had been led away as prisoners to Babylonia, the leaders of Judah were meeting with me in my house. On the fifth day of the sixth month, the LORD God suddenly took control of me,
8.2: and I saw something in the shape of a human. This figure was like fire from the waist down, and it was bright as polished metal from the waist up.
8.3: It reached out what seemed to be a hand and grabbed my hair. Then in my vision the LORD's Spirit lifted me into the sky and carried me to Jerusalem. The Spirit took me to the north gate of the temple's inner courtyard, where there was an idol that disgusted the LORD and made him furious.
8.4: Then I saw the brightness of the glory of the God of Israel, just as I had seen it near the Chebar River.
8.5: God said to me, "Ezekiel, son of man, look north." And when I did, I saw that repulsive idol by the altar near the gate.
8.6: God then said, "Do you see the terrible sins of the people of Israel? Their sins are making my holy temple unfit as a place to worship me. Yet you will see even worse things than this."
8.7: Next, I was taken to the entrance of the courtyard, where I saw a hole in the wall.
8.8: God said, "Make this hole bigger." And when I did, I realized it was a doorway.
8.9: "Go in," God said, "and see what horrible and evil things the people are doing."
8.10: Inside, I saw that the walls were covered with pictures of reptiles and disgusting, unclean animals, as well as with idols that the Israelites were worshiping.
8.11: Seventy Israelite leaders were standing there, including Jaazaniah son of Shaphan. Each of these leaders was holding an incense burner, and the smell of incense filled the room.
8.12: God said, "Ezekiel, do you see what horrible things Israel's leaders are doing in secret? They have filled their rooms with idols. And they say I can't see them, because they think I have already deserted Israel.
8.13: But I will show you something even worse than this."
8.14: He took me to the north gate of the temple, where I saw women mourning for the god Tammuz.
8.16: I was then led into the temple's inner courtyard, where I saw about 25 men standing near the entrance, between the porch and the altar. Their backs were to the LORD's temple, and they were bowing down to the rising sun.
8.18: So in my fierce anger, I will punish them without mercy and refuse to help them when they cry out to me."

9.2: I saw six men come through the north gate of the temple, each one holding a deadly weapon. A seventh man dressed in a linen robe was with them, and he was carrying things to write with. The men went into the temple and stood by the bronze altar.
9.3: The brightness of God's glory then left its place above the statues of the winged creatures inside the temple and moved to the entrance. The LORD said to the man in the linen robe,
9.4: "Walk through the city of Jerusalem and mark the forehead of anyone who is truly upset and sad about the terrible things that are being done here."
9.9: The LORD answered, "The people of Israel and Judah have done horrible things. Their country is filled with murderers, and Jerusalem itself is filled with violence. They think that I have deserted them, and that I can't see what they are doing.
9.10: And so I will not have pity on them or forgive them. They will be punished for what they have done."
9.11: Just then, the man in the linen robe returned and said, "I have done what you commanded."

10.1: I saw the dome that was above the four winged creatures, and on it was the sapphire throne.
10.2: The LORD said to the man in the linen robe, "Walk among the four wheels beside the creatures and pick up as many hot coals as you can carry. Then scatter them over the city of Jerusalem." I watched him as he followed the LORD's instructions.
10.3: The winged creatures were standing south of the temple when the man walked among them. A cloud filled the inner courtyard,
10.4: and the brightness of the LORD's glory moved from above the creatures and stopped at the entrance of the temple. The entire temple was filled with his glory, and the courtyard was dazzling bright.
10.5: The sound of the creatures' wings was as loud as the voice of God All-Powerful and could even be heard in the outer courtyard.
10.6: The man in the robe was now standing beside a wheel.
10.7: One of the four creatures reached its hand into the fire among them and gave him some of the hot coals. The man took the coals and left.
10.8: I noticed again that each of the four winged creatures had what looked like human hands under their wings,
10.9: and I saw the four wheels near the creatures. These wheels were shining like chrysolite.
10.10: Each wheel was exactly the same and had a second wheel that cut through the middle of it,
10.11: so that they could move in any direction without turning. The wheels moved together whenever the creatures moved.
10.12: I also noticed that the wheels and the creatures' bodies, including their backs, their hands, and their wings, were covered with eyes.
10.13: And I heard a voice calling these "the wheels that spin."
10.14: Each of the winged creatures had four faces: the face of a bull, the face of a human, the face of a lion, and the face of an eagle.
10.18: Then I watched the brightness of the LORD's glory move from the entrance of the temple and stop above the winged creatures.
10.19: They spread their wings and flew into the air with the wheels at their side. They stopped at the east gate of the temple, and the LORD's glory was above them.
10.20: I knew for sure that these were the same creatures I had seen beneath the LORD's glory near the Chebar River.

11.1: The LORD's Spirit lifted me up and took me to the east gate of the temple, where I saw 25 men, including the two leaders, Jaazaniah son of Azzur and Pelatiah son of Benaiah.
11.2: The LORD said, "Ezekiel, son of man, these men are making evil plans and giving dangerous advice to the people of Jerusalem.
11.3: They say things like, 'Let's build more houses. This city is like a cooking pot over a fire, and we are the meat, but at least the pot keeps us from being burned in the fire.'
11.4: So, Ezekiel, condemn them!"
11.5: The LORD's Spirit took control of me and told me to tell these leaders: I, the LORD God, know what you leaders are saying.
11.6: You have murdered so many people that the city is filled with dead bodies!
11.7: This city is indeed a cooking pot, but the bodies of those you killed are the meat. And so I will force you to leave Jerusalem,
11.8: and I'll send armies to attack you, just as you fear.
11.9: Then you will be captured and punished by foreign enemies.
11.10: You will be killed in your own country, but not before you realize that I, the LORD, have done these things.
11.11: You leaders claim to be meat in a cooking pot, but you won't be protected by this city. No, you will die at the border of Israel.
11.12: You will realize that while you were following the laws of nearby nations, you were disobeying my laws and teachings. And I am the LORD!
11.14: The LORD replied:
11.15: Ezekiel, son of man, the people living in Jerusalem claim that you and the other Israelites who were taken to Babylonia are too far away to worship me. They also claim that the land of Israel now belongs only to them.
11.16: But here is what I want you to tell the Israelites in Babylonia: It's true that I, the LORD God, have forced you out of your own country and made you live among foreign nations. But for now, I will be with you wherever you are, so that you can worship me.
11.17: And someday, I will gather you from the nations where you are scattered and let you live in Israel again.
11.18: When that happens, I want you to clear the land of all those idols I hate so much.
11.19: Then I will take away your stubbornness and make you eager to be completely faithful to me. You will want to obey me
11.20: and all my laws and teachings. You will be my people, and I will be your God.
11.21: But those who worship idols will be punished and get what they deserve. I, the LORD God, have spoken.
11.22: After the LORD had finished speaking, the winged creatures spread their wings and flew into the air, and the wheels were beside them. The brightness of the LORD's glory above them
11.23: left Jerusalem and stopped at a hill east of the city.
11.24: Then in my vision, the LORD's Spirit lifted me up and carried me back to the other exiles in Babylonia. The vision faded away,
11.25: and I told them everything the LORD had shown me.

12.1: The LORD said:
12.2: Ezekiel, son of man, you are living among rebellious people. They have eyes, but refuse to see; they have ears, but refuse to listen.
12.3: So before it gets dark, here is what I want you to do. Pack a few things as though you were going to be taken away as a prisoner. Then go outside where everyone can see you and walk around from place to place. Maybe as they watch, they will realize what rebels they are.
12.4: After you have done this, return to your house. Later that evening leave your house as if you were going into exile.
12.5: Dig through the wall of your house and crawl out, carrying the bag with you. Make sure everyone is watching.
12.6: Lift the bag to your shoulders, and with your face covered, take it into the darkness, so that you cannot see the land you are leaving. All this will be a warning for the people of Israel.
12.7: I did everything the LORD had said. I packed a few things. Then as the sun was going down, and while everyone was watching, I dug a hole through one of the walls of my house. I pulled out my bag, then lifted it to my shoulders and left in the darkness.
12.8: The next morning, the LORD
12.9: reminded me that those rebellious people didn't even ask what I was doing.
12.10: So he sent me back to tell them: The LORD God has a message for the leader of Jerusalem and everyone living there!
12.11: I have done these things to show them what will happen when they are taken away as prisoners.
12.12: The leader of Jerusalem will lift his own bag to his shoulders at sunset and leave through a hole that the others have dug in the wall of his house. He will cover his face, so he can't see the land he is leaving.
12.13: The LORD will spread out a net and trap him as he leaves Jerusalem. He will then be led away to the city of Babylon, but will never see that place, even though he will die there.
12.14: His own officials and troops will scatter in every direction, and the LORD will track them down and put them to death.
12.15: The LORD will force the rest of the people in Jerusalem to live in foreign nations, where they will realize that he has done all these things.
12.16: Some of them will survive the war, the starvation, and the deadly diseases. That way, they will be able to tell foreigners how disgusting their sins were, and that it was the LORD who punished them in this way.
12.17: The LORD said:
12.18: Ezekiel, son of man, shake with fear when you eat, and tremble when you drink.
12.19: Tell the people of Israel that I, the LORD, say that someday everyone in Jerusalem will shake when they eat and tremble when they drink. Their country will be destroyed and left empty, because they have been cruel and violent.
12.20: Every town will lie in ruins, and the land will be a barren desert. Then they will know that I am the LORD.
12.22: Ezekiel, son of man, you've heard people in Israel use the saying, "Time passes, and prophets are proved wrong."
12.23: Now tell the people that I, the LORD, am going to prove that saying wrong. No one will ever be able to use it again in Israel, because very soon everything I have said will come true!
12.24: The people will hear no more useless warnings and false messages.
12.25: I will give them my message, and what I say will certainly happen. Warn those rebels that the time has come for them to be punished. I, the LORD, make this promise.
12.28: So tell them that my words will soon come true, just as I have warned. I, the LORD, have spoken.

13.1: The LORD said:
13.2: Ezekiel, son of man, condemn the prophets of Israel who say they speak in my name, but who preach messages that come from their own imagination. Tell them it's time to hear my message.
13.3: I, the LORD God, say those lying prophets are doomed! They don't see visions--they make up their own messages!
13.4: Israel's prophets are no better than jackals that hunt for food among the ruins of a city.
13.5: They don't warn the people about coming trouble or tell them how dangerous it is to sin against me.
13.6: Those prophets lie by claiming they speak for me, but I have not even chosen them to be my prophets. And they still think their words will come true.
13.7: They say they're preaching my messages, but they are full of lies--I did not speak to them!
13.8: So I am going to punish those lying prophets for deceiving the people of Israel with false messages.
13.9: I will turn against them and no longer let them belong to my people. They will not be allowed to call themselves Israelites or even to set foot in Israel. Then they will realize that I am the LORD God.
13.10: Those prophets refuse to be honest. They tell my people there will be peace, even though there's no peace to be found. They are like workers who think they can fix a shaky wall by covering it with paint.
13.11: But when I send rainstorms, hailstones, and strong winds, the wall will surely collapse.
13.12: People will then ask the workers why the paint didn't hold it up.
13.13: That wall is the city of Jerusalem. And I, the LORD God, am so angry that I will send strong winds, rainstorms, and hailstones to destroy it.
13.14: The lying prophets have tried to cover up the evil in Jerusalem, but I will tear down the city, all the way to its foundations. And when it collapses, those prophets will be killed, and everyone will know that I have done these things.
13.15: The city of Jerusalem and its lying prophets will feel my fierce anger. Then I will announce that the city has fallen and that the lying prophets are dead,
13.16: because they promised my people peace, when there was no peace. I, the LORD God, have spoken.
13.17: Ezekiel, son of man, now condemn the women of Israel who preach messages that come from their own imagination.
13.18: Tell them they're doomed! They wear magic charms on their wrists and scarves on their heads, then trick others into believing they can predict the future. They won't get away with telling those lies.
13.19: They charge my people a few handfuls of barley and a couple pieces of bread, and then give messages that are insulting to me. They use lies to sentence the innocent to death and to help the guilty go free. And my people believe them!
13.20: I hate the magic charms they use to trick people into believing their lies. I will rip those charms from their wrists and set free the people they have trapped like birds.
13.21: I will tear the scarves from their heads and rescue my people from their power once and for all. Then they will know that I am the LORD God.
13.22: They do things I would never do. They lie to good people and encourage them to do wrong, and they convince the wicked to ruin their own lives by not turning from sin.
13.23: I will no longer let these women give false messages and use magic, and I will free my people from their control. Then they will know that I, the LORD, have done these things.

14.1: One day, some of Israel's leaders came to me and asked for a message from the LORD.
14.2: While they were there, the LORD said:
14.3: Ezekiel, son of man, these men have started worshiping idols, though they know it will cause them to sin even more. So I refuse to give them a message!
14.4: Tell the people of Israel that if they sin by worshiping idols and then go to a prophet to find out what I say, I will give them the answer their sins deserve.
14.5: When they hear my message, maybe they will see that they need to turn back to me and stop worshiping those idols.
14.6: Now, Ezekiel, tell everyone in Israel: I am the LORD God. Stop worshiping those idols I hate so much and come back to me.
14.7: Suppose one of you Israelites or a foreigner living in Israel rejects me and starts worshiping idols. If you then go to a prophet to find out what I say, I will answer
14.8: by turning against you. I will make you a warning to anyone who might think of doing the same thing, and you will no longer belong to my people. Then you will know that I am the LORD and that you have sinned against me.
14.10: and anyone who goes to that prophet for a message will be punished in the same way.
14.11: I will do this, so that you will come back to me and stop destroying yourselves with these disgusting sins. So turn back to me! Then I will be your God, and you will be my people. I, the LORD God, make this promise.
14.12: The LORD God said:
14.13: Ezekiel, son of man, suppose an entire nation sins against me, and I punish it by destroying the crops and letting its people and livestock starve to death.
14.14: Even if Noah, Daniel, and Job were living in that nation, their faithfulness would not save anyone but themselves.
14.15: Or suppose I punish a nation by sending wild animals to eat people and scare away every passerby, so that the land becomes a barren desert.
14.16: As surely as I live, I promise that even if these three men lived in that nation, their own children would not be spared. The three men would live, but the land would be an empty desert.
14.17: Or suppose I send an enemy to attack a sinful nation and kill its people and livestock.
14.18: If these three men were in that nation when I punished it, not even their children would be spared. Only the three men would live.
14.19: And suppose I am so angry that I send a deadly disease to wipe out the people and livestock of a sinful nation.
14.20: Again, even if Noah, Daniel, and Job were living there, I, the LORD, promise that the children of these faithful men would also die. Only the three of them would be spared.
14.21: I am the LORD God, and I promise to punish Jerusalem severely. I will send war, starvation, wild animals, and deadly disease to slaughter its people and livestock.
14.22: And those who survive will be taken from their country and led here to Babylonia. Ezekiel, when you see how sinful they are, you will know why I did all these things to Jerusalem.
14.23: You will be convinced that I, the LORD God, was right in doing what I did.

15.1: Some time later, the LORD said:
15.2: Ezekiel, son of man, what happens to the wood of a grapevine after the grapes have been picked? It isn't like other trees in the forest,
15.3: because the wood of a grapevine can't be used to make anything, not even a small peg to hang things on.
15.4: It can only be used as firewood. But after its ends are burnt and its middle is charred, it can't be used for anything.
15.5: The wood is useless before it is burned, and afterwards, it is completely worthless.
15.6: I, the LORD God, promise that just as the wood of a grapevine is burned as firewood,
15.7: I will punish the people of Jerusalem with fire. Some of them have escaped one destruction, but soon they will be completely burned. And when that happens, you, Ezekiel, will know that I am the LORD.
15.8: I will make their country an empty wasteland, because they have not been loyal to me. I, the LORD God, have spoken.

16.1: The LORD said:
16.2: Ezekiel, son of man, remind the people of Jerusalem of their disgusting sins
16.3: and tell them that I, the LORD God, am saying: Jerusalem, you were born in the country where Canaanites lived. Your father was an Amorite, and your mother was a Hittite.
16.4: When you were born, no one cut you loose from your mother or washed your body. No one rubbed your skin with salt and olive oil, and wrapped you in warm blankets.
16.5: Not one person loved you enough to do any of these things, and no one even felt sorry for you. You were despised, thrown into a field, and forgotten.
16.6: I saw you lying there, rolling around in your own blood, and I couldn't let you die.
16.7: I took care of you, like someone caring for a tender, young plant. You grew up to be a beautiful young woman with mature breasts and hair, but you were still naked.
16.8: When I saw you again, you were old enough to have sex. So I covered your naked body with my own robe. Then I solemnly promised that you would belong to me and that I, the LORD God, would take care of you.
16.9: I washed the blood off you and rubbed your skin with olive oil.
16.10: I gave you the finest clothes and the most expensive robes, as well as sandals made from the best leather.
16.11: I gave you bracelets, a necklace,
16.12: a ring for your nose, some earrings, and a beautiful crown.
16.13: Your jewelry was gold and silver, and your clothes were made of only the finest material and embroidered linen. Your bread was baked from fine flour, and you ate honey and olive oil. You were as beautiful as a queen,
16.14: and everyone on earth knew it. I, the LORD God, had helped you become a lovely young woman.
16.16: You made shrines for yourself and decorated them with some of your clothes. That's where you took your visitors to have sex with them. These things should never have happened!
16.17: You made idols out of the gold and silver jewelry I gave you, then you sinned by worshiping those idols.
16.18: You dressed them in the clothes you got from me, and you offered them the olive oil and incense I gave you.
16.19: I supplied you with fine flour, olive oil, and honey, but you sacrificed it all as offerings to please those idols. I, the LORD God, watched this happen.
16.20: But you did something even worse than that--you sacrificed your own children to those idols!
16.21: You slaughtered my children, so you could offer them as sacrifices.
16.22: You were so busy sinning and being a prostitute that you refused to think about the days when you were young and were rolling around naked in your own blood.
16.23: Now I, the LORD God, say you are doomed! Not only did you do these evil things,
16.24: but you also built places on every street corner
16.25: where you disgraced yourself by having sex with anyone who walked by. And you did that more and more every day!
16.26: To make me angry, you even offered yourself to Egyptians, who were always ready to sleep with you.
16.27: So I punished you by letting those greedy Philistine enemies take over some of your territory. But even they were offended by your repulsive behavior.
16.28: You couldn't get enough sex, so you chased after Assyrians and slept with them. You still weren't satisfied,
16.29: so you went after Babylonians. But those merchants could not satisfy you either.
16.30: I, the LORD God, say that you were so disgusting that you would have done anything to get what you wanted.
16.31: You had sex on every street corner, and when you finished, you refused to accept money. That's worse than being a prostitute!
16.32: You are nothing but an unfaithful wife who would rather have sex with strangers than with your own husband.
16.33: Prostitutes accept money for having sex, but you bribe men from everywhere to have sex with you.
16.34: You're not like other prostitutes. Men don't ask you for sex--you offer to pay them!
16.35: Jerusalem, you prostitute, listen to me.
16.36: You chased after lovers, then took off your clothes and had sex. You even worshiped disgusting idols and sacrificed your own children as offerings to them.
16.37: So I, the LORD God, will gather every one of your lovers, those you liked and those you hated. They will stand around you, and I will rip off your clothes and let all of those lovers stare at your nakedness.
16.38: I will find you guilty of being an unfaithful wife and a murderer, and in my fierce anger I will sentence you to a violent death!
16.39: Then I will hand you over to your lovers, who will tear down the places where you had sex. They will take your clothes and jewelry, leaving you naked and empty-handed.
16.40: Your lovers and an angry mob will stone you to death; they will cut your dead body into pieces
16.41: and burn down your houses. Other women will watch these terrible things happen to you. I promise to stop you from being a prostitute and paying your lovers for sex.
16.42: Only then will I calm down and stop being angry and jealous.
16.45: You are just like your mother, who hated her husband and her own children. You are also like your sisters, who hated their husbands and children. Your father was an Amorite, and your mother was a Hittite.
16.46: Your older sister was Samaria, that city to your north with her nearby villages. Your younger sister was Sodom, that city to your south with her nearby villages.
16.47: You followed their way of life and their wicked customs, and soon you were more repulsive than they were.
16.48: As surely as I am the living LORD God, the people of Sodom and its nearby villages were never as sinful as you.
16.49: They were arrogant and spoiled; they had everything they needed and still refused to help the poor and needy.
16.50: They thought they were better than everyone else, and they did things I hate. And so I destroyed them.
16.51: You people of Jerusalem have sinned twice as much as the people of Samaria. In fact, your evil ways have made both Sodom and Samaria look innocent.
16.52: So their punishment will seem light compared to yours. You will be disgraced and put to shame because of your disgusting sins.
16.53: Someday I will bless Sodom and Samaria and their nearby villages. I will also bless you, Jerusalem.
16.54: Then you will be ashamed of how you've acted, and Sodom and Samaria will be relieved that they weren't as sinful as you.
16.55: When that day comes, you and Sodom and Samaria will once again be well-off, and all nearby villages will be restored.
16.56: Jerusalem, you were so arrogant that you sneered at Sodom.
16.57: But now everyone has learned how wicked you really are. The countries of Syria and Philistia, as well as your other neighbors, hate you and make insulting remarks.
16.58: You must pay for all the vulgar and disgusting things you have done. I, the LORD, have spoken.
16.59: Jerusalem, you deserve to be punished, because you broke your promises and ignored our agreement.
16.60: But I remember the agreement I made with you when you were young, and so I will make you a promise that will last forever.
16.61: When you think about how you acted, you will be ashamed, especially when I return your sisters to you as daughters, even though this was not part of our agreement.
16.62: I will keep this solemn promise, and you will know that I am the LORD.
16.63: I will forgive you, but you will think about your sins and be too ashamed to say a word. I, the LORD God, have spoken.

17.1: The LORD said:
17.2: Ezekiel, son of man, tell the people of Israel the following story,
17.3: so they will understand what I am saying to them: A large eagle with strong wings and beautiful feathers once flew to Lebanon. It broke the top branch off a cedar tree,
17.4: then carried it to a nation of merchants and left it in one of their cities.
17.5: The eagle also took a seed from Israel and planted it in a fertile field with plenty of water, like a willow tree beside a stream.
17.6: The seed sprouted and grew into a grapevine that spread over the ground. It had lots of leaves and strong, deep roots, and its branches grew upward toward the eagle.
17.8: But the vine was already growing in fertile soil, where there was plenty of water to produce healthy leaves and large grapes.
17.9: Now tell me, Ezekiel, do you think this grapevine will live? Or will the first eagle pull it up by its roots and pluck off the grapes and let its new leaves die? The eagle could easily kill it without the help of a large and powerful army.
17.10: The grapevine is strong and healthy, but as soon as the scorching desert wind blows, it will quickly wither.
17.11: The LORD said:
17.13: He chose someone from the family of Judah's king and signed a treaty with him, then made him swear to be loyal. He also led away other important citizens,
17.14: so that the rest of the people of Judah would obey only him and never gain control of their own country again.
17.15: But this new king of Judah later rebelled against Babylonia and sent officials to Egypt to get horses and troops. Will this king be successful in breaking the treaty with Babylonia? Or will he be punished for what he's done?
17.17: Even the king of Egypt and his powerful army will be useless to Judah when the Babylonians attack and build towers and dirt ramps to destroy the cities of Judah and its people.
17.18: The king of Judah broke his own promises and ignored the treaty with Babylonia. And so he will be punished!
17.20: I will spread out a net to trap him. Then I will drag him to Babylon and see that he is punished for his unfaithfulness to me.
17.21: His best troops will be killed in battle, and the survivors will be scattered in every direction. I, the LORD, have spoken.
17.22: Someday, I, the LORD, will cut a tender twig from the top of a cedar tree, then plant it on the peak of Israel's tallest mountain,
17.23: where it will grow strong branches and produce large fruit. All kinds of birds will find shelter under the tree, and they will rest in the shade of its branches.
17.24: Every tree in the forest will know that I, the LORD, can bring down tall trees and help short ones grow. I dry up green trees and make dry ones green. I, the LORD, have spoken, and I will keep my word.

18.1: The LORD said:
18.2: Ezekiel, I hear the people of Israel using the old saying, "Sour grapes eaten by parents leave a sour taste in the mouths of their children."
18.4: The lives of all people belong to me--parents as well as children. However, only those who sin will be put to death.
18.5: Suppose there is a truly good man who always does what is fair and right.
18.6: He refuses to eat meat sacrificed to foreign gods at local shrines or to worship Israel's idols. He doesn't have sex with someone else's wife or with a woman having her monthly period.
18.7: He never cheats or robs anyone and always returns anything taken as security for a loan; he gives food and clothes to the poor
18.8: and doesn't charge interest when lending money. He refuses to do anything evil; he is fair to everyone
18.9: and faithfully obeys my laws and teachings. This man is good, and I promise he will live.
18.10: But suppose this good man has an evil son who is violent and commits sins
18.11: his father never did. He eats meat at local shrines, has sex with someone else's wife,
18.12: cheats the poor, and robs people. He keeps what is given to him as security for a loan. He worships idols, does disgusting things,
18.13: and charges high interest when lending money. An evil man like that will certainly not live. He is the one who has done these horrible sins, so it's his own fault that he will be put to death.
18.14: But suppose this evil man has a son who sees his father do these things and refuses to act like him.
18.15: He doesn't eat meat at local shrines or worship Israel's idols, and he doesn't have sex with someone else's wife.
18.16: He never cheats or robs anyone and doesn't even demand security for a loan. He gives food and clothes to the poor
18.17: and refuses to do anything evil or to charge interest. And he obeys all my laws and teachings. Such a man will live. His own father sinned, but this good man will not be put to death for the sins of his father.
18.18: It is his father who will die for cheating and robbing and doing evil.
18.19: You may wonder why a son isn't punished for the sins of his father. It is because the son does what is right and obeys my laws.
18.20: Only those who sin will be put to death. Children won't suffer for the sins of their parents, and parents won't suffer for the sins of their children. Good people will be rewarded for what they do, and evil people will be punished for what they do.
18.22: All their sins will be forgiven, and they will live because they did right.
18.23: I, the LORD God, don't like to see wicked people die. I had much rather see them turn back from their sins and live.
18.25: You people of Israel accuse me of being unfair! But listen--I'm not unfair; you are!
18.26: If good people start doing evil, they must be put to death, because they have sinned.
18.27: And if wicked people start doing right, they will save themselves from punishment.
18.28: They will think about what they've done and stop sinning, and so they won't be put to death.
18.29: But you still say that I am unfair. You are the ones who have done wrong and are unfair!
18.30: I will judge each of you for what you've done. So stop sinning, or else you will certainly be punished.
18.31: Give up your evil ways and start thinking pure thoughts. And be faithful to me! Do you really want to be put to death for your sins?
18.32: I, the LORD God, don't want to see that happen to anyone. So stop sinning and live!

19.1: Ezekiel, sing a funeral song for two of Israel's leaders:
19.2: Your mother was a brave lioness who raised her cubs among lions.
19.3: She taught one of them to hunt, and he learned to eat people.
19.4: When the nations heard of him, they trapped him in a pit, then they used hooks to drag him to Egypt.
19.5: His mother waited for him to return. But soon she lost all hope and raised another cub, who also became fierce.
19.6: He hunted with other lions and learned to eat people.
19.7: He destroyed fortresses and ruined towns; his mighty roar terrified everyone.
19.8: Nations plotted to kill him, and people came from all over to spread out a net and catch him in a trap.
19.9: They put him in a cage and took him to Babylonia. The lion was locked away, so that his mighty roar would never again be heard on Israel's hills.
19.10: Your mother was a vine like you, growing near a stream. There was plenty of water, so she was filled with branches and with lots of fruit.
19.11: Her strong branches became symbols of authority, and she was taller than all other trees--everyone could see how strong and healthy she was.
19.12: But in anger, I pulled her up by the roots and threw her to the ground, where the scorching desert wind dried out her fruit. Her strong branches wilted and burned up.
19.13: Then she was planted in a hot, dry desert,
19.14: where her stem caught fire, and flames burned her branches and fruit. Not one strong branch is left; she is stripped bare. This funeral song must be sung with sorrow.

20.1: Seven years after King Jehoiachin and the rest of us had been led away as prisoners to Babylonia, some of Israel's leaders came to me on the tenth day of the fifth month. They sat down and asked for a message from the LORD.
20.2: Just then, the LORD God said:
20.3: Ezekiel, son of man, these leaders have come to find out what I want them to do. As surely as I live, I will not give them an answer of any kind.
20.4: Are you willing to warn them, Ezekiel? Then remind them of the disgusting sins of their ancestors.
20.5: Tell them that long ago I, the LORD God, chose Israel to be my own. I appeared to their ancestors in Egypt and made a solemn promise that I would be their God and the God of their descendants.
20.6: I swore that I would rescue them from Egypt and lead them to a land I had already chosen. This land was rich with milk and honey and was the most splendid land of all.
20.9: But that would have made me look like a liar, because I had already promised in front of everyone that I would lead them out of Egypt.
20.10: So I brought them out and led them into the desert.
20.11: I gave them my laws and teachings, so they would know how to live right.
20.12: And I commanded them to respect the Sabbath as a way of showing that they were holy and belonged to me.
20.13: But the Israelites rebelled against me in the desert. They refused to obey my laws and teachings, and they treated the Sabbath like any other day. Then in my anger, I decided to destroy the Israelites in the desert once and for all.
20.14: But that would have disgraced me, because many other nations had seen me bring the Israelites out of Egypt.
20.15: Instead, I told them in the desert that I would not lead them into the beautiful, fertile land I had promised.
20.16: I said this because they had not only ignored my laws and teachings, but had disgraced my Sabbath and worshiped idols.
20.17: Yet, I felt sorry for them and could not let them die in the desert.
20.19: I reminded them that I was the LORD their God and that they should obey my laws and teachings.
20.20: I told them to respect my Sabbath to show that they were my people and that I was the LORD their God.
20.22: But I did not. That would have disgraced me in front of the nations that had seen me bring the Israelites out of Egypt.
20.23: So I solemnly swore that I would scatter the people of Israel across the nations,
20.24: because they had disobeyed my laws and ignored my teachings; they had disgraced my Sabbath and worshiped the idols their ancestors had made.
20.25: I gave them laws that bring punishment instead of life,
20.26: and I let them offer me unacceptable sacrifices, including their first-born sons. I did this to horrify them and to let them know that I, the LORD, was punishing them.
20.27: Ezekiel, tell the people of Israel that their ancestors also rejected and insulted me
20.28: by offering sacrifices, incense, and wine to gods on every hill and under every large tree. I was very angry, because they did these things in the land I had given them!
20.29: I asked them where they went to worship those gods, and they answered, "At the local shrines." And those places of worship are still called shrines.
20.30: Then ask the Israelites why they are following the example of their wicked ancestors
20.31: by worshiping idols and by sacrificing their own children as offerings. They commit these sins and still think they can ask me for a message. As surely as I am the living LORD God, I will give them no answer.
20.32: They may think they can be like other nations and get away with worshiping idols made of wood and stone. But that will never happen!
20.33: As surely as I am the living LORD God, I will rule over you with my powerful arm. You will feel my fierce anger
20.34: and my power, when I gather you from the places where you are scattered
20.35: and lead you into a desert surrounded by nations. I will meet you there face to face. Then I will pass judgment on you
20.36: and punish you, just as I punished your ancestors in the desert near Egypt.
20.37: I will force each of you to obey the regulations of our solemn agreement.
20.38: I will separate the sinful rebels from the rest of you, and even though I will bring them from the nations where they live in exile, they won't be allowed to return to Israel. Then you will know that I am the LORD.
20.40: When that day comes, everyone in Israel will worship me on Mount Zion, my holy mountain in Jerusalem. I will once again call you my own, and I will accept your sacred offerings and sacrifices.
20.41: When I bring you home from the places where you are now scattered, I will be pleased with you, just as I am pleased with the smell of the smoke from your sacrifices. Every nation on earth will see that I am holy,
20.42: and you will know that I, the LORD, am the one who brought you back to Israel, the land I promised your ancestors.
20.43: Then you will remember your wicked sins, and you will hate yourselves for doing such horrible things. They have made you unacceptable to me,
20.44: so you deserve to be punished. But I will treat you in a way that will bring honor to my name, and you will know that I am the LORD God.
20.46: "Ezekiel, son of man, turn toward the south and warn the forests
20.47: that I, the LORD God, will start a fire that will burn up every tree, whether green or dry. Nothing will be able to put out the blaze of that fire as it spreads to the north and burns everything in its path.
20.48: Everyone will know that I started it, and that it cannot be stopped."
20.49: But I complained, "LORD God, I don't want to do that! People already say I confuse them with my messages."

21.1: The LORD said:
21.2: Ezekiel, son of man, condemn the places in Jerusalem where people worship. Warn everyone in Israel
21.3: that I am about to punish them. I will pull out my sword and have it ready to kill everyone, whether good or evil.
21.4: From south to north, people will die,
21.5: knowing that my sword will never be put away.
21.6: Ezekiel, groan in sorrow and despair so that everyone can hear you.
21.11: My sword has been polished; it's sharp and ready to kill.
21.12: Groan in sorrow, Ezekiel; the sword is drawn against my people and their leaders. They will die! So give up all hope.
21.13: I am testing my people, and they can do nothing to stop me. I, the LORD, have spoken.
21.14: Ezekiel, warn my people, then celebrate my victory by clapping your hands. My vicious sword will attack again and again, killing my people with every stroke.
21.15: They will lose all courage and stumble with fear. My slaughtering sword is waiting at every gate, flashing and ready to kill.
21.16: It will slash right and left, wherever the blade is pointed.
21.17: Then I will stop being angry, and I will clap my hands in victory. I, the LORD, have spoken.
21.19: Ezekiel, son of man, mark two roads for the king of Babylonia to follow when he comes with his sword. The roads will begin at the same place, but be sure to put up a signpost where the two roads separate and go in different directions.
21.20: Clearly mark where the two roads lead. One goes to Rabbah, the capital of Ammon, and the other goes to Jerusalem, the fortified capital of Judah.
21.21: When the Babylonian king stands at that signpost, he will decide which way to go by shaking his arrows, by asking his idols, and by carefully looking at the liver of a sacrificed animal.
21.22: His right hand will pull out the arrow marked "Jerusalem." Then he will immediately give the signal to shout the battle cry, to build dirt ramps up to the top of the city walls, to break down its walls and gates with large wooden poles, and to kill the people.
21.23: Everyone in Jerusalem had promised to be loyal to Babylonia, and so none of them will believe that this could happen to them. But Babylonia's king will remind them of their sinful ways and warn them of their coming captivity.
21.25: And now, you evil and wicked ruler of Israel, your day of final punishment is almost here.
21.26: I, the LORD God, command you to take off your royal turban and your crown, because everything will be different. Those who had no power will be put in charge, and those who now rule will become nobodies.
21.27: I will leave Jerusalem in complete ruins like no one has ever seen until my chosen one comes to punish this city.
21.29: You wicked Ammonites see false visions and believe untrue messages. But your day of punishment is coming soon, and my sword will slaughter you!
21.30: Your days to punish others are over, so put your swords away. You will be punished in the land of your birth.
21.31: My furious anger will scorch you like fire, and I will hand you over to cruel men who are experts in killing.
21.32: You will be burned and will die in your own land. Then you will be forgotten forever. I, the LORD, have spoken.

22.1: Some time later, the LORD said:
22.2: Ezekiel, son of man, are you ready to condemn Jerusalem? That city is filled with murderers, so remind the people of their sins
22.3: and tell them I am saying: Jerusalem, you have murdered many of your own people and have worshiped idols. You will soon be punished!
22.4: Those crimes have made you guilty, and the idols have made you unacceptable to me. So your final punishment is near. Other nations will laugh at you and make insulting remarks,
22.5: and people far and near will make fun of your misery.
22.6: Your own leaders use their power to murder.
22.7: None of you honor your parents, and you cheat foreigners, orphans, and widows.
22.8: You show no respect for my sacred places and treat the Sabbath just like any other day.
22.9: Some of your own people tell lies, so that others will be put to death. Some of you eat meat sacrificed to idols at local shrines, and others never stop doing vulgar things.
22.10: Men have sex with their father's wife or with women who are having their monthly period
22.11: or with someone else's wife. Some men even sleep with their own daughter-in-law or half sister.
22.12: Others of you accept money to murder someone. Your own people charge high interest when making a loan to other Israelites, and they get rich by cheating. Worst of all, you have forgotten me, the LORD God.
22.13: I will shake my fist in anger at your violent crimes.
22.14: When I'm finished with you, your courage will disappear, and you will be so weak that you won't be able to lift your hands. I, the LORD, have spoken and will not change my mind.
22.15: I will scatter you throughout every nation on earth and put a stop to your sinful ways.
22.16: You will be humiliated in the eyes of other nations. Then you will know that I, the LORD God, have done these things.
22.18: Ezekiel, son of man, I consider the people of Israel as worthless as the leftover metal in a furnace after silver has been purified.
22.22: like silver in a furnace. Then they will know that I, the LORD, have punished them in my anger.
22.24: Ezekiel, son of man, tell the people of Israel that their country is full of sin, and that I, the LORD, am furious!
22.25: Their leaders are like roaring lions, tearing apart their victims. They put people to death, then steal everything of value. Husbands are killed, and many women are left as widows.
22.26: The priests of Israel ignore my Law! Not only do they refuse to respect any of my sacred things, but they don't even teach the difference between what is sacred and what is ordinary or between what is clean and what is unclean. They treat my Sabbath like any other day, and so my own people no longer honor me.
22.27: Israel's officials are like ferocious wolves, ripping their victims apart. They make a dishonest living by injuring and killing people.
22.28: And then the prophets in Israel cover up these sins by giving false visions. I have never spoken to them, but they lie and say they have a message from me.
22.29: The people themselves cheat and rob; they abuse the poor and take advantage of foreigners.
22.30: I looked for someone to defend the city and to protect it from my anger, as well as to stop me from destroying it. But I found no one.
22.31: So in my fierce anger, I will punish the Israelites for what they have done, and they will know that I am furious. I, the LORD, have spoken.

23.2: Ezekiel, son of man, listen to this story about two sisters.
23.3: While they were young and living in Egypt, they became prostitutes.
23.4: The older one was named Oholah, which stands for Samaria; the younger one was Oholibah, which stands for Jerusalem. They became my wives and gave birth to my children.
23.5: Even though Oholah was my wife, she continued to be a prostitute and chased after Assyrian lovers.
23.6: She offered herself to soldiers in purple uniforms: handsome, high-ranking officers and cavalry troops.
23.7: She had sex with all the important Assyrian officials and even worshiped their disgusting idols.
23.8: Once she started doing these things in Egypt, she never stopped. Men slept with her, and she was always ready for sex.
23.9: So I gave Oholah to the Assyrian lovers she wanted so badly.
23.10: They ripped off her clothes, then captured her children and killed her. Women everywhere talked about what had happened to Oholah.
23.11: Oholibah saw all this, but she was more sinful and wanted sex more than her sister Oholah ever did.
23.12: Oholibah also chased after good-looking Assyrian officers, uniformed soldiers, and cavalry troops.
23.13: Just like her sister, she did vulgar things.
23.14: But Oholibah behaved worse than her sister. Oholibah saw images of Babylonian men carved into walls and painted red.
23.15: They had belts around their waists and large turbans on their heads, and they reminded her of Babylonian cavalry officers.
23.16: As soon as she looked at them, she wanted to have sex with them. And so, she sent messengers to bring them to her.
23.17: Men from Babylonia came and had sex with her so many times that she got disgusted with them.
23.18: She let everyone see her naked body and didn't care if they knew she was a prostitute. That's why I turned my back on her, just as I had done with her older sister.
23.19: Oholibah didn't stop there, but became even more immoral and acted as she had back in Egypt.
23.20: She eagerly wanted to go to bed with Egyptian men, who were famous for their sexual powers.
23.21: And she longed for the days when she was a young prostitute, when men enjoyed caressing her body.
23.22: The LORD God said: Oholibah, though you no longer want to be around your lovers, they will surround you like enemies, when I turn them against you.
23.23: I will gather all the handsome young officials and the high-ranking cavalry officers from Babylonia and Assyria, as well as from the Chaldean tribes of Pekod, Shoa, and Koa.
23.24: Their large armies will come from the north with chariots and wagons carrying weapons. They will wear shields and helmets and will surround you, and I will let them judge and sentence you according to their own laws.
23.25: I am angry with you, so I will let them be very cruel. They will cut off your nose and ears; they will kill your children and burn alive anyone in your family who survives.
23.26: Your clothes and jewelry will be torn off.
23.27: I will stop your wickedness and the prostitution you started back in Egypt. You will never want to think about those days again.
23.29: They will cruelly take away everything you have worked for and strip you naked. Then everyone will see you for the prostitute you really are. Your own vulgar sins
23.30: have led to this. You were the one determined to have sex with men from other nations and to worship their idols.
23.31: You have turned out no better than your older sister, and now you must drink from the cup filled with my anger.
23.32: I, the LORD God, gave your sister a large, deep cup filled with my anger. And when you drink from that cup, you will be mocked and insulted.
23.33: You will end up drunk and devastated, because that cup is filled with horror and ruin.
23.34: But you must drink every drop! Then smash the cup and chew on its broken pieces. Use them to cut your breasts in sorrow. I, the LORD God, have spoken.
23.36: The LORD said: Ezekiel, son of man, it's time for you to tell Oholah and Oholibah that they are guilty. Remind them of their evil ways!
23.37: They have been unfaithful by worshiping idols, and they have committed murder by sacrificing my own children as offerings to idols.
23.40: They sent messengers to attract men from far away. When those men arrived, the two sisters bathed themselves and put on eye shadow and jewelry.
23.41: They sat on a fancy couch, and in front of them was a table for the olive oil and incense that had belonged to me.
23.42: Their room was always filled with a noisy crowd of drunkards brought in from the desert. These men gave the women bracelets and beautiful crowns,
23.43: and I noticed that the men were eager to have sex with these women, though they were exhausted from being prostitutes.
23.44: In fact, the men had sex over and over with Oholah and Oholibah, the two sinful sisters.
23.45: But honest judges will someday accuse those two of murder and of being unfaithful, because they are certainly guilty.
23.47: They will stone you to death and cut you to pieces; they will kill your children and burn down your houses.
23.48: I will get rid of sinful prostitution in this country, so that women everywhere will be warned not to act as you have.
23.49: You will be punished for becoming prostitutes and for worshiping idols. Then you will know that I am the LORD God.

24.1: Nine years after King Jehoiachin and the rest of us had been led away as prisoners to Babylonia, the LORD spoke to me on the tenth day of the tenth month. He said:
24.2: Ezekiel, son of man, write down today's date, because the king of Babylonia has just begun attacking the city of Jerusalem.
24.3: Then tell my rebellious people: "Pour water in a cooking pot and set it over a fire. *
24.4: Throw in the legs and shoulders of your finest sheep and put in the juicy bones.
24.5: Pile wood underneath the pot, and let the meat and bones boil until they are done."
24.6: These words mean that Jerusalem is doomed! The city is filled with murderers and is like an old, rusty pot. The meat is taken out piece by piece, and no one cares what happens to it.
24.8: But I have seen that blood, and it cries out for me to take revenge.
24.9: I, the LORD God, will punish that city of violence! I will make a huge pile of firewood,
24.10: so bring more wood and light it. Cook the meat and boil away the broth to let the bones scorch.
24.11: Then set the empty pot over the hot coals until it is red-hot. That will clean the pot and burn off the rust.
24.12: I've tried everything else. Now the rust must be burned away.
24.13: Jerusalem is so full of sin and evil that I can't get it clean, even though I have tried. It will stay filthy until I let loose my fierce anger against it.
24.14: That time will certainly come! And when it does, I won't show the people of Jerusalem any pity or change my mind. They must be punished for the evil they have done. I, the LORD God, have spoken.
24.16: "Ezekiel, son of man, I will suddenly take the life of the person you love most. But I don't want you to complain or cry.
24.17: Mourn in silence and don't show that you are grieving. Don't remove your turban or take off your sandals; don't cover your face to show your sorrow, or eat the food that mourners eat."
24.18: One morning, I was talking with the people as usual, and by sunset my wife was dead. The next day I did what the LORD had told me,
24.19: and when people saw me, they asked, "Why aren't you mourning for your wife?"
24.20: I answered: The LORD God says
24.21: he is ready to destroy the temple in which you take such pride and which makes you feel so safe. Your children who now live in Jerusalem will be killed.
24.22: Then you will do the same things I have done. You will leave your face uncovered and refuse to eat the food that mourners usually eat.
24.23: You won't take off your turbans and your sandals. You won't cry or mourn, but all day long you will go around groaning because of your sins.
24.24: I am a warning sign--everything I have done, you will also do. And then you will know the LORD God has made these things happen.
24.25: The LORD said, "Ezekiel, I will soon destroy the temple that makes everyone feel proud and safe, and I will take away their children as well.
24.26: On that same day, someone will escape from the city and come to tell you what has happened.
24.27: Then you will be able to speak again, and the two of you will talk. You will be a warning sign to the people, and they will know that I am the LORD."

25.2: Ezekiel, son of man, condemn the people of Ammon
25.4: Now I am going to let you be conquered by tribes from the eastern desert. They will set up their camps in your land and eat your fruit and drink your milk.
25.5: Your capital city of Rabbah will be nothing but pastureland for camels, and the rest of the country will be pastures for sheep. Then you will know that I am the LORD God.
25.7: And so I will hand you over to enemies who will rob you. I will completely destroy you. There won't be enough of your people left to be a nation ever again, and you will know that I, the LORD, have done these things.
25.9: So I will let Moab's fortress towns along its border be attacked, including Beth-Jeshimoth, Baal-Meon, and Kiriathaim.
25.10: The same eastern desert tribes that invade Ammon will invade Moab, and just as Ammon will be forgotten forever,
25.11: Moab will be punished. Then the people there will know that I am the LORD."
25.13: So I will punish Edom by killing all its people and livestock. It will be an empty wasteland all the way from Teman to Dedan.
25.14: I will send my own people to take revenge on the Edomites by making them feel my fierce anger. And when I punish them, they will know that I am the LORD God."
25.16: Now it's my turn to treat the Philistines as my enemies and to kill everyone living in their towns along the seacoast.
25.17: In my fierce anger, I will take revenge on them. And when I punish them, they will know that I am the LORD."

26.1: Eleven years after King Jehoiachin and the rest of us had been led away as prisoners to Babylonia, the LORD spoke to me on the first day of the month. He said:
26.3: Because the people of Tyre have sung that song, I have the following warning for them: I am the LORD God, and I am now your enemy! I will send nations to attack you, like waves crashing against the shore.
26.4: They will tear down your city walls and defense towers. I will sweep away the ruins until all that's left of you is a bare rock,
26.5: where fishermen can dry their nets along the coast. I promise that you will be robbed
26.6: and that the people who live in your towns along the coast will be killed. Then you will know that I am the LORD.
26.8: First, he will attack your towns along the coast and kill the people who live there. Then he will build dirt ramps up to the top of your city walls and set up rows of shields around you.
26.9: He will command some of his troops to use large wooden poles to beat down your walls, while others use iron rods to knock down your watchtowers.
26.10: He will have so many horses that the dust they stir up will seem like a thick fog. And as his chariots and cavalry approach, even the walls will shake, especially when he proudly enters your ruined city.
26.11: His troops will ride through your streets, killing people left and right, and your strong columns will crumble to the ground.
26.12: The troops will steal your valuable possessions; they will break down your walls, and crush your expensive houses. Then the stones and wood and all the remains will be dumped into the sea.
26.13: You will have no reason to sing or play music on harps,
26.14: because I will turn you into a bare rock where fishermen can dry their nets. And you will never rebuild your city. I, the LORD God, make this promise.
26.15: The people of the nations up and down the coast will shudder when they hear your screams and moans of death.
26.16: The kings will step down from their thrones, then take off their royal robes and fancy clothes, and sit on the ground, trembling. They will be so shocked at the news of your defeat that they will shake in fear
26.17: and sing this funeral song: "The great city beside the sea is destroyed! Its people once ruled the coast and terrified everyone there.
26.18: But now Tyre is in ruins, and the people on the coast stare at it in horror and tremble in fear."
26.19: I, the LORD God, will turn you into a ghost-town. The ocean depths will rise over you
26.20: and carry you down to the world of the dead, where you will join people of ancient times and towns ruined long ago. You will stay there and never again be a city filled with people.
26.21: You will die a horrible death! People will come looking for your city, but it will never be found. I, the LORD, have spoken.

27.2: Ezekiel, son of man, sing a funeral song for Tyre,
27.3: the city that is built along the sea and that trades with nations along the coast. Tell the people of Tyre that the following message is from me: Tyre, you brag about your perfect beauty,
27.4: and your control of the sea. You are a ship built to perfection.
27.5: Builders used cypress trees from Mount Hermon to make your planks and a cedar tree from Lebanon for your tall mast.
27.6: Oak trees from Bashan were shaped into oars; pine trees from Cyprus were cut for your deck, which was then decorated with strips of ivory.
27.7: The builders used fancy linen from Egypt for your sails, so everyone could see you. Blue and purple cloth from Cyprus was used to shade your deck.
27.8: Men from Sidon and Arvad did the rowing, and your own skilled workers were the captains.
27.9: Experienced men from Byblos repaired any damages. Sailors from all over shopped at the stores in your port.
27.10: Brave soldiers from Persia, Lydia, and Libya served in your navy, protecting you with shields and helmets, and making you famous.
27.11: Your guards came from Arvad and Cilicia, and men from Gamad stood watch in your towers. With their weapons hung on your walls, your beauty was complete.
27.12: Merchants from southern Spain traded silver, iron, tin, and lead for your products.
27.13: The people of Greece, Tubal, and Meshech traded slaves and things made of bronze,
27.14: and those from Beth-Togarmah traded work horses, war horses, and mules.
27.15: You also did business with people from Rhodes, and people from nations along the coast gave you ivory and ebony in exchange for your goods.
27.17: Judah and Israel gave you their finest wheat, fancy figs, honey, olive oil, and spices in exchange for your merchandise.
27.19: Vedan and Javan near Uzal traded you iron and spices.
27.22: Merchants from Sheba and Raamah gave you excellent spices, precious stones, and gold in exchange for your products.
27.23: You also did business with merchants from the cities of Haran, Canneh, Eden, Sheba, Asshur, and Chilmad,
27.24: and they gave you expensive clothing, purple and embroidered cloth, brightly colored rugs, and strong rope.
27.25: Large, seagoing ships carried your goods wherever they needed to go. You were like a ship loaded with heavy cargo
27.26: and sailing across the sea, but you were wrecked by strong eastern winds.
27.27: Everything on board was lost--your valuable cargo, your sailors and carpenters, merchants and soldiers.
27.28: The shouts of your drowning crew were heard on the shore.
27.29: Every ship is deserted; rowers and sailors and captains all stand on shore,
27.30: mourning for you. They show their sorrow by putting dust on their heads and rolling in ashes;
27.31: they shave their heads and dress in sackcloth as they cry in despair.
27.32: In their grief they sing a funeral song for you: "Tyre, you were greater than all other cities. But now you lie in silence at the bottom of the sea.
27.33: "Nations that received your merchandise were always pleased; kings everywhere got rich from your costly goods.
27.34: But now you are wrecked in the deep sea, with your cargo and crew scattered everywhere.
27.35: People living along the coast are shocked at the news. Their rulers are horrified, and terror is written across their faces.
27.36: The merchants of the world can't believe what happened. Your death was gruesome, and you are gone forever."

28.2: Ezekiel, son of man, tell the king of Tyre that I am saying: You are so arrogant that you think you're a god and that the city of Tyre is your throne. You may claim to be a god, though you're nothing but a mere human.
28.3: You think you're wiser than Daniel and know everything.
28.4: Your wisdom has certainly made you rich, because you have storehouses filled with gold and silver.
28.5: You're a clever businessman and are extremely wealthy, but your wealth has led to arrogance!
28.7: will make you the victim of cruel enemies. They will destroy all the possessions you've worked so hard to get.
28.8: Your enemies will brutally kill you, and the sea will be your only grave.
28.9: When you face your enemies, will you still claim to be a god? They will attack, and you will suffer like any other human.
28.10: Foreigners will kill you, and you will die the death of those who don't worship me. I, the LORD, have spoken.
28.12: Ezekiel, son of man, sing a funeral song for the king of Tyre and tell him I am saying: At one time, you were perfect, intelligent, and good-looking.
28.13: You lived in the garden of Eden and wore jewelry made of brightly colored gems and precious stones. They were all set in gold and were ready for you on the day you were born.
28.14: I appointed a winged creature to guard your home on my holy mountain, where you walked among gems that dazzled like fire.
28.15: You were truly good from the time of your birth, but later you started doing wicked things.
28.16: You traded with other nations and became more and more cruel and evil. So I forced you to leave my mountain, and the creature that had been your protector now chased you away from the jewels.
28.17: It was your good looks that made you arrogant, and you were so famous that you started acting like a fool. That's why I threw you to the ground and let other kings sneer at you.
28.18: You have cheated so many other merchants that your places of worship are corrupt. So I set your city on fire and burned it down. Now everyone sees only ashes where your city once stood,
28.19: and the people of other nations are shocked. Your punishment was horrible, and you are gone forever.
28.21: Ezekiel, son of man, condemn the city of Sidon
28.22: and tell its people: I, the LORD God, am your enemy! People will praise me when I punish you, and they will see that I am holy.
28.23: I will send deadly diseases to wipe you out, and I will send enemies to invade and surround you. Your people will be killed, and you will know that I am the LORD.
28.24: When that happens, the people of Israel will no longer have cruel neighbors that abuse them and make them feel as though they are in a field of thorns and briers. And the Israelites will know that I, the LORD God, have done these things.
28.25: The LORD God said: Someday I will gather the people of Israel from the nations where they are now scattered, and every nation will see that I am holy. The Israelites will once again live in the land I gave to my servant Jacob.
28.26: They will be safe and will build houses and plant vineyards. They will no longer be in danger, because I will punish their hateful neighbors. Israel will know that I am the LORD their God.

29.1: Ten years after King Jehoiachin and the rest of us had been led away as prisoners to Babylonia, the LORD spoke to me on the twelfth day of the tenth month. He said:
29.2: Ezekiel, son of man, condemn the king of Egypt. Tell him and his people
29.3: that I am saying: King of Egypt, you were like a giant crocodile lying in a river. You acted as though you owned the Nile and made it for yourself. But now I, the LORD God, am your enemy!
29.4: I will put a hook in your jaw and pull you out of the water, and all the fish in your river will stick to your scaly body.
29.5: I'll throw you and the fish into the desert, and your body will fall on the hard ground. You will be left unburied, and wild animals and birds will eat your flesh.
29.6: Then everyone in Egypt will know that I am the LORD. You and your nation refused to help the people of Israel and were nothing more than a broken stick.
29.7: When they reached out to you for support, you broke in half, cutting their arms and making them fall.
29.8: So I, the LORD God, will send troops to attack you, king of Egypt. They will kill your people and livestock,
29.9: until your land is a barren desert. Then you will know that I have done these things. You claimed that you made the Nile River and control it.
29.10: Now I am turning against you and your river. Your nation will be nothing but an empty wasteland all the way from the town of Migdol in the north to Aswan in the south, and as far as the border of Ethiopia.
29.11: No human or animal will even dare travel through Egypt, because no sign of life will be found there for 40 years.
29.12: It will be the most barren place on earth. Every city in Egypt will lie in ruins during those 40 years, and I will scatter your people throughout the nations of the world.
29.14: They will once again live in their homeland in southern Egypt. But they will be a weak kingdom
29.15: and won't ever be strong enough to rule nations, as they did in the past.
29.16: My own people Israel will never again depend on your nation. In fact, when the Israelites remember what happened to you Egyptians, they will realize how wrong they were to turn to you for help. Then the Israelites will know that I, the LORD God, did these things.
29.17: Twenty-seven years after King Jehoiachin and the rest of us had been led away as prisoners to Babylonia, the LORD spoke to me on the first day of the first month. He said:
29.18: King Nebuchadnezzar of Babylonia has attacked the city of Tyre. He forced his soldiers to carry so many heavy loads that their heads were rubbed bald, and their shoulders were red and sore. Nebuchadnezzar and his army still could not capture the city.
29.19: So now I will hand over the nation of Egypt to him. He will take Egypt's valuable treasures and give them to his own troops.
29.20: Egypt will be his reward, because he and his army have been following my orders. I, the LORD God, have spoken.
29.21: Ezekiel, when Egypt is defeated, I will make the people of Israel strong, and I will give you the power to speak to them. Then they will know that I, the LORD, have done these things.
