4.35: To him the nations are far less than nothing; God controls the stars in the sky and everyone on this earth. When God does something, we cannot change it or even ask why."
4.36: At that time my mind was healed, and once again I became the ruler of my glorious kingdom. My advisors and officials returned to me, and I had greater power than ever before.
4.37: That's why I say: "Praise and honor the King who rules from heaven! Everything he does is honest and fair, and he can shatter the power of those who are proud."

5.1: One evening, King Belshazzar gave a great banquet for a thousand of his highest officials, and he drank wine with them.
5.2: He got drunk and ordered his servants to bring in the gold and silver cups his father Nebuchadnezzar had taken from the temple in Jerusalem. Belshazzar wanted the cups, so that he and all his wives and officials could drink from them.
5.5: Suddenly a human hand was seen writing on the plaster wall of the palace. The hand was just behind the lampstand, and the king could see it writing.
5.6: He was so frightened that his face turned pale, his knees started shaking, and his legs became weak.
5.7: The king called in his advisors, who claimed they could talk with the spirits of the dead and understand the meanings found in the stars. He told them, "The man who can read this writing and tell me what it means will become the third most powerful man in my kingdom. He will wear robes of royal purple and a gold chain around his neck."
5.8: All of King Belshazzar's highest officials came in, but not one of them could read the writing or tell what it meant,
5.9: and they were completely puzzled. Now the king was more afraid than ever before, and his face turned white as a ghost.
5.11: In your kingdom there is a man who has been given special powers by the holy gods. When your father Nebuchadnezzar was king, this man was known to be as smart, intelligent, and wise as the gods themselves. Your father put him in charge of all who claimed they could talk with the spirits or understand the meanings in the stars or tell about the future.
5.12: He also changed the man's name from Daniel to Belteshazzar. Not only is he wise and intelligent, but he can explain dreams and riddles and solve difficult problems. Send for Daniel, and he will tell you what the writing means.
5.14: I was told that the gods have given you special powers and that you are intelligent and very wise.
5.15: Neither my advisors nor the men who talk with the spirits of the dead could read this writing or tell me what it means.
5.16: But I have been told that you understand everything and that you can solve difficult problems. Now then, if you can read this writing and tell me what it means, you will become the third most powerful man in my kingdom. You will wear royal purple robes and have a gold chain around your neck.
5.17: Daniel answered: Your Majesty, I will read the writing and tell you what it means. But you may keep your gifts or give them to someone else.
5.18: Sir, the Most High God made your father a great and powerful man and brought him much honor and glory.
5.19: God did such great things for him that people of all nations and races shook with fear. Your father had the power of life or death over everyone, and he could honor or ruin anyone he chose.
5.20: But when he became proud and stubborn, his glorious kingdom was taken from him.
5.21: His mind became like that of an animal, and he was forced to stay away from people and live with wild donkeys. Your father ate grass like an ox, and he slept outside where his body was soaked with dew. He was forced to do this until he learned that the Most High God rules all kingdoms on earth and chooses their kings.
5.22: King Belshazzar, you knew all of this, but you still refused to honor the Lord who rules from heaven.
5.23: Instead, you turned against him and ordered the cups from his temple to be brought here, so that you and your wives and officials could drink wine from them. You praised idols made of silver, gold, bronze, iron, wood, and stone, even though they cannot see or hear or think. You refused to worship the God who gives you breath and controls everything you do.
5.24: That's why he sent the hand to write this message on the wall.
5.29: Belshazzar gave a command for Daniel to be made the third most powerful man in his kingdom and to be given a purple robe and a gold chain.
5.30: That same night, the king was killed.
5.31: Then Darius the Mede, who was 62 years old, took over his kingdom.

6.1: Darius divided his kingdom into 120 states and placed a governor in charge of each one.
6.2: In order to make sure that his government was run properly, Darius put three other officials in charge of the governors. One of these officials was Daniel.
6.3: And he did his work so much better than the other governors and officials that the king decided to let him govern the whole kingdom.
6.4: The other men tried to find something wrong with the way Daniel did his work for the king. But they could not accuse him of anything wrong, because he was honest and faithful and did everything he was supposed to do.
6.5: Finally, they said to one another, "We will never be able to bring any charge against Daniel, unless it has to do with his religion."
6.6: They all went to the king and said: "Your Majesty, we hope you live forever!
6.7: All of your officials, leaders, advisors, and governors agree that you should make a law forbidding anyone to pray to any god or human except you for the next 30 days. Everyone who disobeys this law must be thrown into a pit of lions.
6.8: Order this to be written and then sign it, so it cannot be changed, just as no written law of the Medes and Persians can be changed."
6.9: So King Darius made the law and had it written down.
6.10: Daniel heard about the law, but when he returned home, he went upstairs and prayed in front of the window that faced Jerusalem. In the same way that he had always done, he knelt down in prayer three times a day, giving thanks to God.
6.11: The men who had spoken to the king watched Daniel and saw him praying to his God for help.
6.14: The king was really upset to hear about this, and for the rest of the day he tried to think how he could save Daniel.
6.15: At sunset the men returned and said, "Your Majesty, remember that no written law of the Medes and Persians can be changed, not even by the king."
6.16: So Darius ordered Daniel to be brought out and thrown into a pit of lions. But he said to Daniel, "You have been faithful to your God, and I pray that he will rescue you."
6.17: A stone was rolled over the pit, and it was sealed. Then Darius and his officials stamped the seal to show that no one should let Daniel out.
6.18: All night long the king could not sleep. He did not eat anything, and he would not let anyone come in to entertain him.
6.19: At daybreak the king got up and ran to the pit.
6.21: Daniel answered, "Your Majesty, I hope you live forever!
6.22: My God knew that I was innocent, and he sent an angel to keep the lions from eating me. Your Majesty, I have never done anything to hurt you."
6.23: The king was relieved to hear Daniel's voice, and he gave orders for him to be taken out of the pit. Daniel's faith in his God had kept him from being harmed.
6.24: And the king ordered the men who had brought charges against Daniel to be thrown into the pit, together with their wives and children. But before they even reached the bottom, the lions ripped them to pieces.
6.25: King Darius then sent this message to all people of every nation and race in the world: "Greetings to all of you!
6.26: I command everyone in my kingdom to worship and honor the God of Daniel. He is the living God, the one who lives forever. His power and his kingdom will never end.
6.27: He rescues people and sets them free by working great miracles. Daniel's God has rescued him from the power of the lions."
6.28: All went well for Daniel while Darius was king, and even when Cyrus the Persian ruled.

7.3: when suddenly four powerful beasts came out of the sea. Each beast was different.
7.4: The first was like a lion with the wings of an eagle. As I watched, its wings were pulled off. Then it was lifted to an upright position and made to stand on two feet, just like a human, and it was given a human mind.
7.8: Just as I was thinking about these horns, a smaller horn appeared, and three of the other horns were pulled up by the roots to make room for it. This horn had the eyes of a human and a mouth that spoke with great arrogance.
7.9: Thrones were set up while I was watching, and the Eternal God took his place. His clothing and his hair were white as snow. His throne was a blazing fire with fiery wheels,
7.10: and flames were dashing out from all around him. Countless thousands were standing there to serve him. The time of judgment began, and the books were opened.
7.11: I watched closely to see what would happen to this smaller horn because of the arrogant things it was saying. Then before my very eyes, the fourth beast was killed and its body destroyed by fire.
7.12: The other three beasts had their authority taken from them, but they were allowed to live a while longer.
7.13: As I continued to watch the vision that night, I saw what looked like a son of man coming with the clouds of heaven, and he was presented to the Eternal God.
7.14: He was crowned king and given power and glory, so that all people of every nation and race would serve him. He will rule forever, and his kingdom is eternal, never to be destroyed.
7.15: Daniel wrote: I was terrified by these visions, and I didn't know what to think.
7.16: So I asked one of those standing there, and he explained,
7.17: "The four beasts are four earthly kingdoms.
7.18: But God Most High will give his kingdom to his chosen ones, and it will be theirs forever and ever."
7.19: I wanted to know more about the fourth beast, because it was so different and much more terrifying than the others. What was the meaning of its iron teeth and bronze claws and of its feet that smashed what the teeth and claws had not ground and crushed?
7.20: I also wanted to know more about all ten of those horns on its head. I especially wanted to know more about the one that took the place of three of the others--the horn that had eyes and spoke with arrogance and seemed greater than the others.
7.21: While I was looking, this horn attacked God's chosen ones and was winning the battle.
7.22: Then God Most High, the Eternal God, came and judged in favor of his chosen ones, because the time had arrived for them to be given the kingdom.
7.23: Then I was told by the one standing there: "The fourth beast will be a fourth kingdom to appear on earth. It will be different from all the others--it will trample the earth and crush it to pieces.
7.24: All ten of those horns are kings who will come from this kingdom, and one more will follow. This horn will be different from the others, and it will conquer three other kings.
7.25: "This king will speak evil of God Most High, and he will be cruel to God's chosen ones. He will try to change God's Law and the sacred seasons. And he will be able to do this for a time, two times, and half a time.
7.26: But he will finally be judged, and his kingdom completely destroyed.
7.27: "Then the greatest kingdom of all will be given to the chosen ones of God Most High. His kingdom will be eternal, and all others will serve and obey him."
7.28: That was what I saw and heard. I turned pale with fear and kept it all to myself.

8.1: Daniel wrote: In the third year of King Belshazzar of Babylonia, I had a second vision
8.2: in which I was in Susa, the chief city of Babylonia's Elam Province. I was beside the Ulai River,
8.3: when I looked up and saw a ram standing there with two horns on its head--both of them were long, but the second one was longer than the first.
8.4: The ram went charging toward the west, the north, and the south. No other animals were strong enough to oppose him, and nothing could save them from his power. So he did as he pleased and became even more powerful.
8.5: I kept on watching and saw a goat come from the west and charge across the entire earth, without even touching the ground. Between his eyes was a powerful horn,
8.6: and with tremendous anger the goat started toward the ram that I had seen beside the river.
8.7: The goat was so fierce that its attack broke both horns of the ram, leaving him powerless. Then the goat trampled on the ram, and no one could do anything to help.
8.8: After this, the goat became even more powerful. But at the peak of his power, his mighty horn was broken, and four other mighty horns took its place--one pointing to the north and one to the east, one to the south and one to the west.
8.9: A little horn came from one of these, and its power reached to the south, the east, and even to the holy land.
8.10: It became so strong that it attacked the stars in the sky, which were heaven's army. Then it threw some of them down to the earth and trampled on them.
8.13: Then one of the holy angels asked another, "When will the daily sacrifices be offered again? What about this horrible rebellion? When will the temple and heaven's army no longer be trampled in the dust?"
8.15: Daniel wrote: I was trying to figure out the meaning of the vision, when someone suddenly appeared there beside me.
8.16: And from beside the Ulai River, a voice like that of a human said, "Gabriel, help him understand the vision."
8.17: Gabriel came over, and I fell to the ground in fear. Then he said, "You are merely a human, but you need to understand that this vision is about the end of time."
8.18: While he was speaking, I fell facedown in a deep sleep. But he lifted me to my feet
8.19: and said: Listen, and I will tell you what will happen at the end of time, when God has chosen to show his anger.
8.20: The two horns of the ram are the kings of Media and Persia,
8.21: the goat is the kingdom of Greece, and the powerful horn between his eyes is the first of its kings.
8.22: After this horn is broken, four other kingdoms will appear, but they won't be as strong.
8.23: When these rulers have become as evil as possible, their power will end, and then a king who is dangerous and cannot be trusted will appear.
8.24: He will gain strength, but not on his own, and he will cause terrible destruction. He will wipe out powerful leaders and God's people as well.
8.25: His deceitful lies will make him so successful, that he will think he is really great. Suddenly he will kill many people, and he will even attack God, the Supreme Ruler. But God will crush him!
8.26: This vision about the evenings and mornings is true, but these things won't happen for a long time, so don't tell it to others.
8.27: After this, I was so worn out and weak that it was several days before I could get out of bed and go about my duties for the king. I was disturbed by this vision that made no sense to me.

9.5: But we have sinned terribly by rebelling against you and rejecting your laws and teachings.
9.6: We have ignored the message your servants the prophets spoke to our kings, our leaders, our ancestors, and everyone else.
9.7: Everything you do is right, our Lord. But still we suffer public disgrace because we have been unfaithful and have sinned against you. This includes all of us, both far and near--the people of Judah, Jerusalem, and Israel, as well as those you dragged away to foreign lands,
9.8: and even our kings, our officials, and our ancestors.
9.9: LORD God, you are merciful and forgiving, even though we have rebelled against you
9.10: and rejected your teachings that came to us from your servants the prophets.
9.11: Everyone in Israel has stubbornly refused to obey your laws, and so those curses written by your servant Moses have fallen upon us.
9.12: You warned us and our leaders that Jerusalem would suffer the worst disaster in human history, and you did exactly as you had threatened.
9.13: We have not escaped any of the terrible curses written by Moses, and yet we have refused to beg you for mercy and to remind ourselves of how faithful you have always been.
9.14: And when you finally punished us with this horrible disaster, that was also the right thing to do, because we deserved it so much.
9.15: Our Lord God, with your own mighty arm you rescued us from Egypt and made yourself famous to this very day, but we have sinned terribly.
9.16: In the past, you treated us with such kindness, that we now beg you to stop being so terribly angry with Jerusalem. After all, it is your chosen city built on your holy mountain, even though it has suffered public disgrace because of our sins and those of our ancestors.
9.17: I am your servant, Lord God, and I beg you to answer my prayers and bring honor to yourself by having pity on your temple that lies in ruins.
9.18: Please show mercy to your chosen city, not because we deserve it, but because of your great kindness.
9.19: Forgive us! Hurry and do something, not only for your city and your chosen people, but to bring honor to yourself.
9.20: I was still confessing my sins and those of all Israel to the LORD my God, and I was praying for the good of his holy mountain,
9.21: when Gabriel suddenly came flying in at the time of the evening sacrifice. This was the same Gabriel I had seen in my vision,
9.23: God thinks highly of you, and at the very moment you started praying, I was sent to give you the answer.
9.24: God has decided that for 70 weeks, your people and your holy city must suffer as the price of their sins. Then evil will disappear, and justice will rule forever; the visions and words of the prophets will come true, and a most holy place will be dedicated.
9.25: You need to realize that from the command to rebuild Jerusalem until the coming of the Chosen Leader, it will be 7 weeks and another 62 weeks. Streets will be built in Jerusalem, and a trench will be dug around the city for protection, but these will be difficult times.
9.26: At the end of the 62 weeks, the Chosen Leader will be killed and left with nothing. A foreign ruler and his army will sweep down like a mighty flood, leaving both the city and the temple in ruins, and war and destruction will continue until the end, just as God has decided.
9.27: For one week this foreigner will make a firm agreement with many people, and halfway through this week, he will end all sacrifices and offerings. Then the "Horrible Thing" that causes destruction will be put there. And it will stay there until the time God has decided to destroy this one who destroys.

10.1: In the third year of Cyrus the king of Persia, a message came to Daniel from God, and it was explained in a vision. The message was about a dreadful war, and it was true.
10.2: Daniel wrote: For three weeks I was in sorrow.
10.3: I ate no fancy food or meat, I drank no wine, and I put no olive oil on my face or hair.
10.4: Then, on the twenty-fourth day of the first month, I was standing on the banks of the great Tigris River,
10.5: when I looked up and saw someone dressed in linen and wearing a solid gold belt.
10.6: His body was like a precious stone, his face like lightning, his eyes like flaming fires, his arms and legs like polished bronze, and his voice like the roar of a crowd.
10.7: Although the people who were with me did not see the vision, they became so frightened that they scattered and hid.
10.8: Only I saw this great vision. I became weak and pale,
10.9: and at the sound of his voice, I fell facedown in a deep sleep.
10.10: He raised me to my hands and knees
10.13: But the guardian angel of Persia opposed me for 21 days. Then Michael, who is one of the strongest guardian angels, came to rescue me from the kings of Persia.
10.14: Now I have come here to give you another vision about what will happen to your people in the future.
10.15: While this angel was speaking to me, I stared at the ground, speechless.
10.16: Then he appeared in human form and touched my lips. I said, "Sir, this vision has brought me great pain and has drained my strength.
10.17: I am merely your servant. How can I possibly speak with someone so powerful, when I am almost too weak to get my breath?"
10.21: I will tell you what is written in The Book of Truth. But first, you must realize that no one except Michael, the guardian angel of Israel, is on my side.

11.1: You also need to know that I protected and helped Darius the Mede in his first year as king.
11.2: What I am going to tell you is certain to happen. Four kings will rule Persia, one after the other, but the fourth one will become much richer than the others. In fact, his wealth will make him so powerful that he will turn everyone against the kingdom of Greece.
11.3: Then a mighty king will come to power and will be able to do whatever he pleases.
11.4: But suddenly his kingdom will be crushed and scattered to the four corners of the earth, where four more kingdoms will rise. But these won't be ruled by his descendants or be as powerful as his kingdom.
11.5: The king of the south will grow powerful. Then one of his generals will rebel and will rule an even larger kingdom.
11.6: Years later the southern kingdom and the northern kingdom will make a treaty, and the daughter of the king of the south will marry the king of the north. But she will lose her power. Then she, her husband, their child, and the servants who came with her will all be killed. After this,
11.7: one of her relatives will become the ruler of the southern kingdom. He will attack the army of the northern kingdom and capture its fortresses.
11.8: Then he will carry their idols to Egypt, together with their precious treasures of silver and gold, but it will be a long time before he attacks the northern kingdom again. Some years later
11.9: the king of the north will invade the southern kingdom, but he will be forced back to his own country.
11.10: The sons of the king of the north will gather a huge army that will sweep down like a roaring flood, reaching all the way to the fortress of the southern kingdom.
11.11: But this will make the king of the south angry, and he will defeat this large army from the north.
11.12: The king of the south will feel proud because of the many thousands he has killed. But his victories won't last long,
11.13: because the king of the north will gather a larger and more powerful army than ever before. Then in a few years, he will start invading other countries.
11.14: At this time many of your own people will try to make this vision come true by rebelling against the king of the south, but their rebellion will fail.
11.15: Then the army from the north will surround and capture a fortress in the south, and not even the most experienced troops of the southern kingdom will be able to make them retreat.
11.16: The king who invaded from the north will do as he pleases, and he will even capture and destroy the holy land.
11.17: In fact, he will decide to invade the south with his entire army. Then he will attempt to make peace by giving the king of the south a bride from the northern kingdom, but this won't be successful.
11.18: Afterwards, this proud king of the north will invade and conquer many of the nations along the coast, but a military leader will defeat him and make him lose his pride.
11.19: He will retreat to his fortresses in his own country, but on the way he will be defeated and never again be seen.
11.20: The next king of the north will try to collect taxes for the glory of his kingdom. However, he will come to a sudden end in some mysterious way, instead of in battle or because of someone's anger.
11.21: The successor of this king of the north will be a worthless nobody, who doesn't even come from a royal family. He will suddenly appear and gain control of the kingdom by treachery.
11.22: Then he will destroy armies and remove God's chosen high priest.
11.23: He will make a treaty, but he will be deceitful and break it, even though he has only a few followers.
11.24: Without warning, he will successfully invade a wealthy province, which is something his ancestors never did. Then he will divide among his followers all of its treasures and property. But none of this will last very long.
11.25: He will gather a large and powerful army, and with great courage he will attack the king of the south. The king of the south will meet him with a much stronger army, but he will lose the battle, because he will be betrayed
11.26: by members of the royal court. He will be ruined, and most of his army will be slaughtered.
11.27: The two kings will meet around a table and tell evil lies to each other. But their plans will fail, because God has already decided what will happen.
11.28: Then the king of the north will return to his country with great treasures. But on the way, he will attack the religion of God's people and do whatever else he pleases.
11.30: Ships from the west will come to attack him, and he will be discouraged. Then he will start back to his own country and take out his anger on the religion of God's faithful people, while showing kindness to those who are unfaithful.
11.31: He will send troops to pollute the temple and the fortress, and he will stop the daily sacrifices. Then he will set up that "Horrible Thing" that causes destruction.
11.32: The king will use deceit to win followers from those who are unfaithful to God, but those who remain faithful will do everything possible to oppose him.
11.33: Wise leaders will instruct many of the people. But for a while, some of these leaders will either be killed with swords or burned alive, or else robbed of their possessions and thrown into prison.
11.34: They will receive only a little help in their time of trouble, and many of their followers will be treacherous.
11.35: Some of those who are wise will suffer, so that God will make them pure and acceptable until the end, which will still come at the time he has decided.
11.36: This king will do as he pleases. He will proudly claim to be greater than any god and will insult the only true God. Indeed, he will be successful until God is no longer angry with his people.
11.37: This king will reject the gods his ancestors worshiped and the god preferred by women. In fact, he will put himself above all gods
11.38: and worship only the so-called god of fortresses, who was unknown to his ancestors. And he will honor it with gold, silver, precious stones, and other costly gifts.
11.39: With the help of this foreign god, he will capture the strongest fortresses. Everyone who worships this god will be put in a position of power and rewarded with wealth and land.
11.41: and when they reach the holy land, tens of thousands will be killed. But the countries of Edom and Moab and the ruler of Ammon will escape.
11.42: The king of the north will invade many countries, including Egypt,
11.43: and he will take its rich treasures of gold and silver. He will also conquer Libya and Ethiopia.
11.44: But he will be alarmed by news from the east and the north, and he will become furious and cause great destruction.
11.45: After this, he will set up camp between the Mediterranean Sea and Mount Zion. Then he will be destroyed, and no one will be able to save him.

12.1: Michael, the chief of the angels, is the protector of your people, and he will come at a time of terrible suffering, the worst in all of history. And your people who have their names written in The Book will be protected.
12.2: Many of those who lie dead in the ground will rise from death. Some of them will be given eternal life, and others will receive nothing but eternal shame and disgrace.
12.3: Everyone who has been wise will shine as bright as the sky above, and everyone who has led others to please God will shine forever like the stars.
12.4: Daniel, I now command you to keep the message of this book secret until the end of time, even though many people will go everywhere, searching for the knowledge to be found in it.
12.5: Daniel wrote: I looked around and saw two other people--one on this side of the river and one on the other side.
12.6: The angel who had spoken to me was dressed in linen and was standing upstream from them. So one of the two beside the river asked him, "How long before these amazing things happen?"
12.7: The angel then raised both hands toward heaven and said, "In the name of the God who lives forever, I solemnly promise that it will be a time, two times, and half a time. Everything will be over, when the suffering of God's holy people comes to an end."
12.8: I heard what the angel said, but I didn't understand. So I asked, "Sir, how will it all end?" The angel in my vision then replied:
12.9: Daniel, go about your business, because the meaning of this message will remain secret until the end of time.
12.10: Many people will have their hearts and lives made pure and clean, but those who are evil will keep on being evil and never understand. Only the wise will understand.
12.12: God will bless everyone who patiently waits until 1,335 days have gone by.

1.1: I am Hosea son of Beeri. When Uzziah, Jotham, Ahaz, and Hezekiah were the kings of Judah, and when Jeroboam son of Jehoash was king of Israel, the LORD spoke this message to me.
1.2: The LORD said, "Hosea, Israel has betrayed me like an unfaithful wife. Marry such a woman and have children by her."
1.3: So I married Gomer the daughter of Diblaim, and we had a son.
1.4: Then the LORD said, "Hosea, name your son Jezreel, because I will soon punish the descendants of King Jehu of Israel for the murders he committed in Jezreel Valley. I will destroy his kingdom,
1.5: and in Jezreel Valley I will break the power of Israel."
1.6: Later, Gomer had a daughter, and the LORD said, "Name her Lo-Ruhamah, because I will no longer have mercy and forgive Israel.
1.7: But I am the LORD God of Judah, and I will have mercy and save Judah by my own power--not by wars and arrows or swords and cavalry."
1.8: After Gomer had stopped nursing Lo-Ruhamah, she had another son.
1.9: Then the LORD said, "Name him Lo-Ammi, because these people are not mine, and I am not their God."
1.10: Someday it will be impossible to count the people of Israel, because there will be as many of them as there are grains of sand along the seashore. They are now called "Not My People," but in the future they will be called "Children of the Living God."
1.11: Israel and Judah will unite and choose one leader. Then they will take back their land, and this will be a great day for Jezreel.

2.1: So let your brothers be called "My People" and your sisters be called "Shown Mercy."
2.2: Accuse! Accuse your mother! She is no longer my wife, and now I, the LORD, am not her husband. Beg her to give up prostitution and stop being unfaithful,
2.3: or I will strip her naked like the day she was born. I will make her barren like a desert, and she will die of thirst.
2.4: You children are the result of her unfaithfulness, and I'll show you no pity.
2.5: Your mother was unfaithful. She was disgraceful and said, "I'll run after my lovers. Everything comes from them--my food and drink, my linen and wool, my olive oil and wine."
2.6: I, the LORD, will build a fence of thorns to block her path.
2.7: She will run after her lovers, but not catch them; she will search, but not find them. Then she will say, "I'll return to my first husband. Life was better then."
2.8: She didn't know that her grain, wine, and olive oil were gifts from me, as were the gold and silver she used in worshiping Baal.
2.9: So I'll hold back the harvest of grain and grapes. I'll take back my wool and my linen that cover her body.
2.10: Then I'll strip her naked in the sight of her lovers. No one can rescue her.
2.11: I'll stop Israel's celebrations--no more New Moon Festivals, Sabbaths, or other feasts.
2.12: She said, "My lovers gave me vineyards and fig trees as payment for sex." Now I, the LORD, will ruin her vineyards and fig trees; they will become clumps of weeds eaten by wild animals.
2.13: I'll punish her for the days she worshiped Baal and burned incense to him. I'll punish her for the times she forgot about me and wore jewelry and rings to attract her lovers. I, the LORD, have spoken!
2.14: Israel, I, the LORD, will lure you into the desert and speak gently to you.
2.15: I will return your vineyards, and then Trouble Valley will become Hopeful Valley. You will say "Yes" to me as you did in your youth, when leaving Egypt.
2.16: I promise from that day on, you will call me your husband instead of your master.
2.17: I will no longer even let you mention the names of those pagan gods that you called "Master."
2.18: And I will agree to let you live in peace--you will no longer be attacked by wild animals and birds or by weapons of war.
2.19: I will accept you as my wife forever, and instead of a bride price I will give you justice, fairness, love, kindness,
2.20: and faithfulness. Then you will truly know who I am.
2.21: I will command the sky to send rain on the earth,
2.22: and it will produce grain, grapes, and olives in Jezreel Valley.
2.23: I will scatter the seeds and show mercy to Lo-Ruhamah. I will say to Lo-Ammi, "You are my people," and they will answer, "You are our God."

3.1: Once again the LORD spoke to me. And this time he said, "Hosea, fall in love with an unfaithful woman who has a lover. Do this to show that I love the people of Israel, even though they worship idols and enjoy the offering cakes made with fruit."
3.2: So I paid 15 pieces of silver and about 150 kilograms of grain for such a woman.
3.3: Then I said, "Now you are mine! You will have to remain faithful to me, though it will be a long time before we sleep together."
3.4: It will also be a long time before Israel has a king or before sacrifices are offered at the temple or before there is any way to get guidance from God.
3.5: But later, Israel will turn back to the LORD their God and to David their king. At that time they will come to the LORD with fear and trembling, and he will be good to them.

4.1: Israel, listen as the LORD accuses everyone in the land! No one is faithful or loyal or truly cares about God.
4.2: Cursing, dishonesty, murder, robbery, unfaithfulness--these happen all the time. Violence is everywhere.
4.3: And so your land is a desert. Every living creature is dying--people and wild animals, birds and fish.
4.4: Don't accuse just anyone! Not everyone is at fault. My case is against you, the priests.
4.5: You and the prophets will stumble day and night; I'll silence your mothers.
4.6: You priests have rejected me, and my people are destroyed by refusing to obey. Now I'll reject you and forget your children, because you have forgotten my Law.
4.7: By adding more of you priests, you multiply the number of people who sin. Now I'll change your pride into shame.
4.8: You encourage others to sin, so you can stuff yourselves on their sin offerings.
4.9: That's why I will punish the people for their deeds, just as I will punish you priests.
4.10: Their food won't satisfy, and having sex at pagan shrines won't produce children. My people have rebelled
4.11: and have been unfaithful to me, their LORD. My people, you are foolish because of too much pleasure and too much wine.
4.12: You expect wooden idols and other objects of wood to give you advice. Lusting for sex at pagan shrines has made you unfaithful to me, your God.
4.13: You offer sacrifices on mountaintops and hills, under oak trees, and wherever good shade is found. Your own daughters and daughters-in-law sell themselves for sex.
4.14: But I won't punish them. You men are to blame, because you go to prostitutes and offer sacrifices with them at pagan shrines. Your own foolishness will lead to your ruin.
4.16: You are nothing more than a stubborn cow--so stubborn that I, the LORD, cannot feed you like lambs in an open pasture.
4.17: You people of Israel are charmed by idols. Leave those people alone!
4.18: You get drunk, then sleep with prostitutes; you would rather be vulgar than lead a decent life.
4.19: And so you will be swept away in a whirlwind for sacrificing to idols.

5.1: Listen, you priests! Pay attention, Israel! Listen, you members of the royal family. Justice was your duty. But at Mizpah and Mount Tabor you trapped the people.
5.2: At the place of worship you were a treacherous pit, and I will punish you.
5.3: Israel, I know all about you, and because of your unfaithfulness, I find you unacceptable.
5.4: Your evil deeds are the reason you won't return to me, your LORD God. And your constant craving for sex keeps you from knowing me.
5.5: Israel, your pride testifies to your guilt; it makes you stumble, and Judah stumbles too.
5.6: You offer sheep and cattle as sacrifices to me, but I have turned away and refuse to be found.
5.7: You have been unfaithful to me, your LORD; you have had children by prostitutes. So at the New Moon Festival, you and your crops will be destroyed.
5.8: Give a warning on the trumpet! Let it be heard in Gibeah, Ramah, and sinful Bethel. Benjamin, watch out!
5.9: I, the LORD, will punish and wipe out Israel. This is my solemn promise to every tribe of Israel.
5.10: Judah's leaders are like crooks who move boundary markers; that's why I will flood them with my anger.
5.11: Israel was brutally crushed. They got what they deserved for worshiping useless idols.
5.12: Now I, the LORD, will fill Israel with maggots and make Judah rot.
5.13: When Israel and Judah saw their sickness and wounds, Israel asked help from Assyria and its mighty king. But the king cannot cure them or heal their wounds.
5.14: So I'll become a fierce lion attacking Israel and Judah. I'll snatch and carry off what I want, and no one can stop me.
5.15: Then I'll return to my temple until they confess their guilt and worship me, until they are desperate and beg for my help.

6.2: In two or three days he will heal us and restore our strength that we may live with him.
6.3: Let's do our best to know the LORD. His coming is as certain as the morning sun; he will refresh us like rain renewing the earth in the springtime.
6.4: People of Israel and Judah, what can I do with you? Your love for me disappears more quickly than mist or dew at sunrise.
6.5: That's why I slaughtered you with the words of my prophets. That's why my judgments blazed like the dawning sun.
6.6: I'd rather for you to be faithful and to know me than to offer sacrifices.
6.7: At a place named Adam, you betrayed me by breaking our agreement.
6.8: Everyone in Gilead is evil; your hands are stained with the blood of victims.
6.9: You priests are like a gang of robbers in ambush. On the road to Shechem you murder and commit other horrible crimes.
6.10: I have seen a terrible thing in Israel--you are unfaithful and unfit to worship me.
6.11: People of Judah, your time is coming too. I, the LORD, would like to make my nation prosper again

7.1: and to heal its wounds. But then I see the crimes in Israel and Samaria. Everyone is deceitful; robbers roam the streets.
7.2: No one realizes that I have seen their sins surround them like a flood.
7.3: The king and his officials take great pleasure in their sin and deceit.
7.4: Everyone burns with desire--they are like coals in an oven, ready to burst into flames.
7.5: On the day their king was crowned, his officials got him drunk, and he joined in their foolishness.
7.6: Their anger is a fire that smolders all night, then flares up at dawn.
7.7: They are flames destroying their leaders. And their kings are powerless; none of them trust me.
7.8: The people of Israel have mixed with foreigners; they are a thin piece of bread scorched on one side.
7.9: They don't seem to realize how weak and feeble they are; their hair has turned gray, while foreigners rule.
7.10: I am the LORD, their God, but in all of their troubles their pride keeps them from returning to me.
7.11: Israel is a senseless bird, fluttering back and forth between Egypt and Assyria.
7.12: But I will catch them in a net as hunters trap birds; I threatened to punish them, and indeed I will.
7.13: Trouble and destruction will be their reward for rejecting me. I would have rescued them, but they told me lies.
7.14: They don't really pray to me; they just howl in their beds. They have rejected me for Baal and slashed themselves, in the hope that Baal will bless their crops.
7.15: I taught them what they know, and I made them strong. Now they plot against me
7.16: and refuse to obey. They are more useless than a crooked arrow. Their leaders will die in war for saying foolish things. Egyptians will laugh at them.

8.1: Sound a warning! Israel, you broke our agreement and ignored my teaching. Now an eagle is swooping down to attack my land.
8.2: Israel, you say, "We claim you, the LORD, as our God."
8.3: But your enemies will chase you for rejecting our good agreement.
8.4: You chose kings and leaders without consulting me; you made silver and gold idols that led to your downfall.
8.5: City of Samaria, I'm angry because of your idol in the shape of a calf. When will you ever be innocent again?
8.6: Someone from Israel built that idol for you, but only I am God. And so it will be smashed to pieces.
8.7: If you scatter wind instead of wheat, you will harvest a whirlwind and have no wheat. Even if you harvest grain, enemies will steal it all.
8.8: Israel, you are ruined, and now the nations consider you worthless.
8.9: You are like a wild donkey that goes its own way. You've run off to Assyria and hired them as allies.
8.10: You can bargain with nations, but I'll catch you anyway. Soon you will suffer abuse by kings and rulers.
8.11: Israel, you have built many altars where you offer sacrifices for sin. But these altars have become places for sin.
8.12: My instructions for sacrifices were written in detail, but you ignored them.
8.13: You sacrifice your best animals and eat the sacrificial meals, but I, the LORD, refuse your offerings. I will remember your sins and punish you. Then you will return to Egypt.
8.14: Israel, I created you, but you forgot me. You and Judah built palaces and many strong cities. Now I will send fire to destroy your towns and fortresses.

9.1: Israel, don't celebrate or make noisy shouts like other nations. You have been unfaithful to your God. Wherever grain is threshed, you behave like prostitutes because you enjoy the money you receive.
9.2: But you will run short of grain and wine,
9.3: and you will have to leave the land of the LORD. Some of you will go to Egypt; others will go to Assyria and eat unclean food.
9.4: You won't be able to offer sacrifices of wine to the LORD. None of your sacrifices will please him--they will be unclean like food offered to the dead. Your food will only be used to satisfy your hunger; none of it will be brought to the LORD's temple.
9.5: You will no longer be able to celebrate the festival of the LORD.
9.6: Even if you escape alive, you will end up in Egypt and be buried in Memphis. Your silver treasures will be lost among weeds; thorns will sprout in your tents.
9.7: Israel, the time has come. You will get what you deserve, and you will know it. "Prophets are fools," you say. "And God's messengers are crazy." Your terrible guilt has filled you with hatred.
9.8: Israel, the LORD sent me to look after you. But you trap his prophets and flood his temple with your hatred.
9.9: You are brutal and corrupt, as were the men of Gibeah. But God remembers your sin, and you will be punished.
9.10: Israel, when I, the LORD, found you long ago it was like finding grapes in a barren desert or tender young figs. Then you worshiped Baal Peor, that disgusting idol, and you became as disgusting as the idol you loved.
9.11: And so, Israel, your glory will fly away like birds--your women will no longer be able to give birth.
9.12: Even if you do have children, I will take them all and leave you to mourn. I will turn away, and you will sink down in deep trouble.
9.13: Israel, when I first met you, I thought of you as palm trees growing in fertile ground. Now you lead your people out, only to be slaughtered.
9.14: Our LORD, do just one thing for your people--make their women unable to have children or to nurse their babies.
9.15: Israel, I first began to hate you because you did evil at Gilgal. Now I will chase you out of my house. No longer will I love you; your leaders betrayed me.
9.16: Israel, you are a vine with dried-up roots and fruitless branches. Even if you had more children and loved them dearly, I would slaughter them all.
9.17: Israel, you disobeyed my God. Now he will force you to roam from nation to nation.

10.1: You were a healthy vine covered with grapes. But the more grapes you grew, the more altars you built; the better off you became, the better shrines you set up for pagan gods.
10.2: You are deceitful and disloyal. So you will pay for your sins, because the LORD will destroy your altars and images.
10.3: "We don't have a king," you will say. "We don't fear the LORD. And what good are kings?"
10.4: Israel, you break treaties and don't keep promises; you turn justice into poisonous weeds where healthy plants should grow.
10.5: All who live in Samaria tremble with concern for the idols at sinful Bethel. The idol there was the pride of the priests, but it has been put to shame; now everyone will cry.
10.6: It will be taken to Assyria and given to the great king. Then Israel will be disgraced for worshiping that idol.
10.7: Like a twig in a stream, the king of Samaria will be swept away.
10.9: Israel, you have never stopped sinning since that time at Gibeah. That's why you will be attacked at Gibeah.
10.10: Your sins have doubled, and you are rebellious. Now I have decided to send nations to attack and put you in chains.
10.11: Once you were obedient like a calf that loved to thresh grain. But I will put a harness on your beautiful neck; you and Judah must plow and cultivate the ground.
10.12: Plow your fields, scatter seeds of justice, and harvest faithfulness. Worship me, the LORD, and I will send my saving power down like rain.
10.13: You have planted evil, harvested injustice, and eaten the fruit of your lies. You trusted your own strength and your powerful forces.
10.14: So war will break out, and your fortresses will be destroyed. Your enemies will do to you what Shalman did to the people of Beth-Arbel--mothers and their children will be beaten to death against rocks.
10.15: Bethel, this will be your fate because of your evil. Israel, at dawn your king will be killed.

11.1: When Israel was a child, I loved him, and I called my son out of Egypt.
11.2: But as the saying goes, "The more they were called, the more they rebelled." They never stopped offering incense and sacrifices to the idols of Baal.
11.3: I took Israel by the arm and taught them to walk. But they would not admit that I was the one who had healed them.
11.4: I led them with kindness and with love, not with ropes. I held them close to me; I bent down to feed them.
11.5: But they rejected me, and so must return to Egypt; now Assyria will rule them.
11.6: War will visit their cities, and their plans will fail.
11.7: My people are determined to reject me for a god they think is stronger, but he can't help.
11.8: Israel, I can't let you go. I can't give you up. How could I possibly destroy you as I did the towns of Admah and Zeboiim? I just can't do it. My feelings for you are much too strong.
11.9: Israel, I won't lose my temper and destroy you again. I am the Holy God--not merely some human, and I won't stay angry.
11.10: I, the LORD, will roar like a lion, and my children will return, trembling from the west.
11.11: They will come back, fluttering like birds from Egypt or like doves from Assyria. Then I will bring them back to their homes. I, the LORD, have spoken!
11.12: Israel is deceitful to me, their loyal and holy God; they surround me with lies, and Judah worships other gods.

12.1: All day long Israel chases wind from the desert; deceit and violence are found everywhere. Treaties are made with Assyria; olive oil is taken to Egypt.
12.2: The LORD also brings charges against the people of Judah, the descendants of Jacob. He will punish them for what they have done.
12.3: Even before Jacob was born, he cheated his brother, and when he grew up, he fought against God.
12.4: At Bethel, Jacob wrestled with an angel and won; then with tears in his eyes, he asked for a blessing, and God spoke to us there.
12.5: God's name is the LORD, the LORD God All-Powerful.
12.6: So return to your God. Patiently trust him, and show love and justice.
12.7: Israel, you enjoy cheating and taking advantage of others.
12.8: You say to yourself, "I'm rich! I earned it all on my own, without committing a sin."
12.9: Israel, I, the LORD, am still your God, just as I have been since the time you were in Egypt. Now I will force you to live in tents once again, as you did in the desert.
12.10: I spoke to the prophets--often I spoke in visions. And so, I will send my prophets with messages of doom.
12.11: Gilead is terribly sinful and will end up ruined. Bulls are sacrificed in Gilgal on altars made of stones, but those stones will be scattered in every field.
12.12: Jacob escaped to Syria where he tended sheep to earn himself a wife.
12.13: I sent the prophet Moses to lead Israel from Egypt and to keep them safe.
12.14: Israel, I will make you pay for your violent crimes and for insulting me.

13.1: When your leaders spoke, everyone in Israel trembled and showed great respect. But you sinned by worshiping Baal, and you were destroyed.
13.2: Now you continue to sin by designing and making idols of silver in the shape of calves. You are told to sacrifice to these idols--yes, even to kiss them.
13.3: And so, all of you will vanish like the mist or the dew of early morning, or husks of grain in the wind or smoke from a chimney.
13.4: I, the LORD, have been your God since the time you were in Egypt. I am the only God you know, the only one who can save.
13.5: I took care of you in a thirsty desert.
13.6: I fed you till you were satisfied, then you became proud and forgot about me.
13.7: Now I will attack like a lion, ambush you like a leopard,
13.8: and rip you apart like a bear robbed of her cubs. I will gnaw on your bones, as though I were a lion or some other wild animal.
13.9: Israel, you are done for. Don't expect help from me.
13.10: You wanted a king and rulers. Where is your king now? What cities have rulers?
13.11: In my anger, I gave you a king; in my fury, I took him away.
13.12: Israel, your terrible sins are written down and stored away.
13.13: You are like a senseless child who refuses to be born at the proper time.
13.14: Should I, the LORD, rescue you from death and the grave? No! I call death and the grave to strike you like a plague. I refuse to show mercy.
13.15: No matter if you prosper more than the other tribes, I, the LORD, will wipe you out, just as a scorching desert wind dries up streams of water. I will take away your precious treasures.
13.16: Samaria will be punished for turning against me. It will be destroyed in war--children will be beaten against rocks, and pregnant women will be ripped open.

14.1: Israel, return! Come back to the LORD, your God. Sin has made you fall.
14.3: Assyria can't save us, and chariots can't help. So we will no longer worship the idols we have made. Our LORD, you show mercy to orphans."
14.4: Israel, you have rejected me, but my anger is gone; I will heal you and love you without limit.
14.5: I will be like the dew--then you will blossom like lilies and have roots like a tree.
14.6: Your branches will spread with the beauty of an olive tree and with the aroma of Lebanon Forest.
14.7: You will rest in my shade, and your grain will grow. You will blossom like a vineyard and be famous as the wine from Lebanon.
14.8: Israel, give up your idols! I will answer your prayers and take care of you. I am that glorious tree, the source of your fruit.
14.9: If you are wise, you will know and understand what I mean. I am the LORD, and I lead you along the right path. If you obey me, we will walk together, but if you are wicked, you will stumble.

1.1: I am Joel the son of Pethuel. And this is the message the LORD gave to me.
1.2: Listen, you leaders and everyone else in the land. Has anything like this ever happened before?
1.3: Tell our children! Let it be told to our grandchildren and their children too.
1.4: Swarm after swarm of locusts has attacked our crops, eating everything in sight.
1.5: Sober up, you drunkards! Cry long and loud; your wine supply is gone.
1.6: A powerful nation with countless troops has invaded our land. They have the teeth and jaws of powerful lions.
1.7: Our grapevines and fig trees are stripped bare; only naked branches remain.
1.8: Grieve like a young woman mourning for the man she was to marry.
1.9: Offerings of grain and wine are no longer brought to the LORD's temple. His servants, the priests, are deep in sorrow.
1.10: Barren fields mourn; grain, grapes, and olives are scorched and shriveled.
1.11: Mourn for our farms and our vineyards! There's no wheat or barley growing in our fields.
1.12: Grapevines have dried up and so has every tree--figs and pomegranates, date palms and apples. All happiness has faded away.
1.13: Mourn, you priests who serve at the altar of my God. Spend your days and nights wearing sackcloth. Offerings of grain and wine are no longer brought to the LORD's temple.
1.14: Tell the leaders and people to come together at the temple. Order them to go without eating and to pray sincerely.
1.15: We are in for trouble! Soon the LORD All-Powerful will bring disaster.
1.16: Our food is already gone; there's no more celebrating at the temple of our God.
1.17: Seeds dry up in the ground; no harvest is possible. Our barns are in bad shape, with no grain to store in them.
1.18: Our cattle wander aimlessly, moaning for lack of pasture, and sheep are suffering.
1.19: I cry out to you, LORD. Grasslands and forests are eaten by the scorching heat.
1.20: Wild animals have no water because of you; rivers and streams are dry, and pastures are parched.

2.1: Sound the trumpet on Zion, the LORD's sacred hill. Warn everyone to tremble! The judgment day of the LORD is coming soon.
2.2: It will be dark and gloomy with storm clouds overhead. Troops will cover the mountains like thunderclouds. No army this powerful has ever been gathered before or will be gathered again.
2.3: Fiery flames surround them; no one escapes. Before they invaded, the land was like Eden; now only a desert remains.
2.4: They look like horses and charge like cavalry.
2.5: They roar over mountains like noisy chariots, or a mighty army ready for battle. They are a forest fire that feasts on straw.
2.6: The very sight of them is frightening.
2.7: They climb over walls like warriors; they march in columns and never turn aside.
2.8: They charge straight ahead, without pushing each other; even arrows and spears cannot make them retreat.
2.9: They swarm over city walls and enter our homes; they crawl in through windows, just like thieves.
2.10: They make the earth tremble and the heavens shake; the sun and moon turn dark, and stars stop shining.
2.11: The LORD God leads this army of countless troops, and they obey his commands. The day of his judgment is so terrible that no one can stand it.
2.12: The LORD said: It isn't too late. You can still return to me with all your heart. Start crying and mourning! Go without eating.
2.13: Don't rip your clothes to show your sorrow. Instead, turn back to me with broken hearts. I am merciful, kind, and caring. I don't easily lose my temper, and I don't like to punish.
2.14: I am the LORD your God. Perhaps I will change my mind and treat you with mercy. Then you will be blessed with enough grain and wine for offering sacrifices to me.
2.15: Sound the trumpet on Zion! Call the people together. Show your sorrow by going without food.
2.16: Make sure that everyone is fit to worship me. Bring adults, children, babies, and even bring newlyweds from their festivities.
2.17: Tell my servants, the priests, to cry inside the temple and to offer this prayer near the altar: "Save your people, LORD God! Don't let foreign nations make jokes about us. Don't let them laugh and ask, 'Where is your God?'"
2.18: The LORD was deeply concerned about his land and had pity on his people.
2.19: In answer to their prayers he said, "I will give you enough grain, wine, and olive oil to satisfy your needs. No longer will I let you be insulted by the nations.
2.20: An army attacked from the north, but I will chase it into a scorching desert. There it will rot and stink from the Dead Sea to the Mediterranean." The LORD works wonders
2.21: and does great things. So tell the soil to celebrate
2.22: and wild animals to stop being afraid. Grasslands are green again; fruit trees and fig trees are loaded with fruit. Grapevines are covered with grapes.
2.23: People of Zion, celebrate in honor of the LORD your God! He is generous and has sent the autumn and spring rains in the proper seasons.
2.24: Grain will cover your threshing places; jars will overflow with wine and olive oil.
2.25: I, the LORD your God, will make up for the losses caused by those swarms and swarms of locusts I sent to attack you.
2.26: My people, you will eat until you are satisfied. Then you will praise me for the wonderful things I have done. Never again will you be put to shame.
2.27: Israel, you will know that I stand at your side. I am the LORD your God--there are no other gods. Never again will you be put to shame.
2.28: Later, I will give my Spirit to everyone. Your sons and daughters will prophesy. Your old men will have dreams, and your young men will see visions.
2.29: In those days I will even give my Spirit to my servants, both men and women.
2.30: I will work wonders in the sky above and on the earth below. There will be blood and fire and clouds of smoke.
2.31: The sun will turn dark, and the moon will be as red as blood before that great and terrible day when I appear.
2.32: Then I, the LORD will save everyone who faithfully worships me. I have promised there will be survivors on Mount Zion and in Jerusalem, and among them will be my chosen ones.

3.1: At that time I, the LORD, will make Judah and Jerusalem prosperous again.
3.2: Then in Judgment Valley I will bring together the nations that scattered my people Israel everywhere in the world, and I will bring charges against those nations. They divided up my land
3.3: and gambled to see who would get my people; they sold boys and girls to pay for prostitutes and wine.
3.4: You people of Tyre and Sidon and you Philistines, why are you doing this? Are you trying to get even with me? I'll strike back before you know what's happened.
3.5: You've taken my prized possessions, including my silver and gold, and carried them off to your temples.
3.6: You have dragged the people of Judah and Jerusalem from their land and sold them to the Greeks.
3.7: But I'll make the people of Judah determined to come home, and what happened to them will happen to you.
3.8: I'll hand over your sons and daughters to the people of Judah, and they will sell them to the Sabeans, who live far away. I, the LORD, have spoken!
3.9: Say to the nations: "Get ready for war! Be eager to fight. Line up for battle and prepare to attack.
3.10: Make swords out of plows and spears out of garden tools. Strengthen every weakling."
3.11: Hurry, all you nations! Come quickly. Ask the LORD to bring his warriors along.
3.12: You must come now to Judgment Valley, where the LORD will judge the surrounding nations.
3.13: They are a field of ripe crops. Bring in the harvest! They are grapes piled high. Start trampling them now! If our enemy's sins were wine, every jar would overflow.
3.14: Crowds fill Decision Valley. The judgment day of the LORD will soon be here--
3.15: no light from the sun or moon, and stars no longer shine.
3.16: From the heart of Jerusalem the LORD roars like a lion, shaking the earth and sky. But the LORD is a fortress, a place of safety for his people Israel.
3.17: I am the LORD your God. And you will know I live on Zion, my sacred hill, because Jerusalem will be sacred, untouched by foreign troops.
3.18: On that day, fruitful vineyards will cover the mountains. And your cattle and goats that graze on the hills will produce a lot of milk. Streams in Judah will never run dry; a stream from my house will flow in Acacia Valley.
3.19: Egypt and Edom were cruel and brutal to Judah, without a reason. Now their countries will become a barren desert,
3.20: but Judah and Jerusalem will always have people.
3.21: I, the LORD, live on Mount Zion. I will punish the guilty and defend the innocent.

1.1: I am Amos. And I raised sheep near the town of Tekoa when Uzziah was king of Judah and Jeroboam son of Jehoash was king of Israel. Two years before the earthquake, the LORD gave me several messages about Israel,
1.2: and I said: When the LORD roars from Jerusalem, pasturelands and Mount Carmel dry up and turn brown.
1.4: Now I will burn down the palaces and fortresses of King Hazael and of King Benhadad.
1.5: I will break through the gates of Damascus. I will destroy the people of Wicked Valley and the ruler of Beth-Eden. Then the Syrians will be dragged as prisoners to Kir. I, the LORD, have spoken!
1.7: That's why I will burn down the walls and fortresses of the city of Gaza.
1.8: I will destroy the king of Ashdod and the ruler of Ashkelon. I will strike down Ekron, and that will be the end of the Philistines. I, the LORD, have spoken!
1.10: That's why I will send flames to burn down the city of Tyre along with its fortresses.
1.12: Now I will send fire to wipe out the fortresses of Teman and Bozrah.
1.14: Now I will send fire to destroy the walls and fortresses of Rabbah. Enemies will shout and attack like a whirlwind.
1.15: Ammon's king and leaders will be dragged away. I, the LORD, have spoken!

2.2: Now I will send fire to destroy the fortresses of Kerioth. Battle shouts and trumpet blasts will be heard as I destroy Moab
2.3: with its king and leaders. I, the LORD, have spoken!
2.5: Now I will send fire on Judah and destroy the fortresses of Jerusalem.
2.7: They smear the poor in the dirt and push aside those who are helpless. My holy name is dishonored, because fathers and sons sleep with the same young women.
2.8: They lie down beside altars on clothes taken as security for loans. And they drink wine in my temple, wine bought with the money they received from fines.
2.9: Israel, the Amorites were there when you entered Canaan. They were tall as cedars and strong as oaks. But I wiped them out--I destroyed their branches and their roots.
2.10: I had rescued you from Egypt, and for forty years I had led you through the desert. Then I gave you the land of the Amorites.
2.11: I chose some of you to be prophets and others to be Nazirites. People of Israel, you know this is true. I, the LORD, have spoken!
2.13: And so I will crush you, just as a wagon full of grain crushes the ground.
2.14: No matter how fast you run, you won't escape. No matter how strong you are, you will lose your strength and your life.
2.15: Even if you are an expert with a bow and arrow, you will retreat. And you won't get away alive, not even if you run fast or ride a horse.
2.16: You may be brave and strong, but you will run away, stripped naked. I, the LORD, have spoken!

3.1: People of Israel, I rescued you from Egypt. Now listen to my judgment against you.
3.2: Of all nations on earth, you are the only one I have chosen. That's why I will punish you because of your sins.
3.3: Can two people walk together without agreeing to meet?
3.4: Does a lion roar in the forest unless it has caught a victim? Does it growl in its den unless it is eating?
3.5: How can anyone catch a bird without using a net? Does a trap spring shut unless something is caught?
3.6: Isn't the whole city frightened when the trumpet signals an attack? Isn't the LORD the one who brings disaster on a city?
3.7: Whatever the LORD God plans to do, he tells his servants, the prophets.
3.8: Everyone is terrified when a lion roars--and ordinary people become prophets when the LORD God speaks.
3.10: The LORD has said that they don't even know how to do right. They have become rich from violence and robbery.
3.12: The LORD has promised that only a few from Samaria will escape with their lives and with some broken pieces of their beds and couches. It will be like when a shepherd rescues two leg bones and part of a sheep's ear from the jaws of a lion.
3.13: The LORD God All-Powerful told me to speak this message against Jacob's descendants:
3.14: When I, the LORD, punish Israel for their sins, I will destroy the altars at Bethel. Even the corners of the altar will be left in the dirt.
3.15: I will tear down winter homes and summer homes. Houses decorated with ivory and all other mansions will be gone forever. I, the LORD, have spoken!

4.2: I, the LORD God, have sworn by my own name that your time is coming. Not one of you will be left--you will be taken away by sharp hooks.
4.3: You will be dragged through holes in your city walls, and you will be thrown toward Harmon. I, the LORD, have spoken!
4.4: Come to Bethel and Gilgal. Sin all you want! Offer sacrifices the next morning and bring a tenth of your crops on the third day.
4.5: Bring offerings to show me how thankful you are. Gladly bring more offerings than I have demanded. You really love to do this. I, the LORD God, have spoken!
4.6: I, the LORD, took away the food from every town and village, but still you rejected me.
4.7: Three months before harvest, I kept back the rain. Sometimes I would let it fall on one town or field but not on another, and pastures dried up.
4.8: People from two or three towns would go to a town that still had water, but it wasn't enough. Even then you rejected me. I, the LORD, have spoken!
4.9: I dried up your grain fields; your gardens and vineyards turned brown. Locusts ate your fig trees and olive orchards, but even then you rejected me. I, the LORD, have spoken!
4.10: I did terrible things to you, just as I did to Egypt--I killed your young men in war; I let your horses be stolen, and I made your camp stink with dead bodies. Even then you rejected me. I, the LORD, have spoken!
4.11: I destroyed many of you, just as I did the cities of Sodom and Gomorrah. You were a burning stick I rescued from the fire. But even then you rejected me. I, the LORD, have spoken!
4.12: Now, Israel, I myself will deal with you. Get ready to face your God!
4.13: I created the mountains and the wind. I let humans know what I am thinking. I bring darkness at dawn and step over hills. I am the LORD God All-Powerful!

5.1: Listen, nation of Israel, to my mournful message:
5.2: You, dearest Israel, have fallen, never to rise again--you lie deserted in your own land, with no one to help you up.
5.3: The LORD God has warned, "From every ten soldiers only one will be left; from a thousand troops, only a hundred will survive."
5.4: The LORD keeps saying, "Israel, turn back to me and you will live!
5.5: Don't go to Gilgal or Bethel or even to Beersheba. Gilgal will be dragged away, and Bethel will end up as nothing."
5.6: Turn back to the LORD, you descendants of Joseph, and you will live. If you don't, the LORD will attack like fire. Bethel will burn to the ground, and no one can save it.
5.7: You people are doomed! You twist the truth and trample on justice.
5.8: But the LORD created the stars and put them in place. He turns darkness to dawn and daylight to darkness; he scoops up the ocean and empties it on the earth.
5.9: God destroys mighty soldiers and strong fortresses.
5.10: You people hate judges and honest witnesses;
5.11: you abuse the poor and demand heavy taxes from them. You have built expensive homes, but you won't enjoy them; you have planted vineyards, but you will get no wine.
5.12: I am the LORD, and I know your terrible sins. You cheat honest people and take bribes; you rob the poor of justice.
5.13: Times are so evil that anyone with good sense will keep quiet.
5.14: If you really want to live, you must stop doing wrong and start doing right. I, the LORD God All-Powerful, will then be on your side, just as you claim I am.
5.15: Choose good instead of evil! See that justice is done. Maybe I, the LORD All-Powerful, will be kind to what's left of your people.
5.16: This is what the LORD has sworn: Noisy crying will be heard in every town and street. Even farmers will be told to mourn for the dead, together with those who are paid to mourn.
5.17: Your vineyards will be filled with crying and weeping, because I will punish you. I, the LORD, have spoken!
5.18: You look forward to the day when the LORD comes to judge. But you are in for trouble! It won't be a time of sunshine; all will be darkness.
5.19: You will run from a lion, only to meet a bear. You will escape to your house, rest your hand on the wall, and be bitten by a snake.
5.20: The day when the LORD judges will be dark, very dark, without a ray of light.
5.21: I, the LORD, hate and despise your religious celebrations and your times of worship.
5.22: I won't accept your offerings or animal sacrifices--not even your very best.
5.23: No more of your noisy songs! I won't listen when you play your harps.
5.24: But let justice and fairness flow like a river that never runs dry.
5.26: Now you will have to carry the two idols you made--Sakkuth, the one you call king, and Kaiwan, the one you built in the shape of a star.
5.27: I will force you to march as captives beyond Damascus. I, the LORD God All-Powerful, have spoken!

6.1: Do you rulers in Jerusalem and in the city of Samaria feel safe and at ease? Everyone bows down to you, and you think you are better than any other nation. But you are in for trouble!
6.2: Look what happened to the cities of Calneh, powerful Hamath, and Gath in Philistia. Are you greater than any of those kingdoms?
6.3: You are cruel, and you forget the coming day of judgment.
6.4: You rich people lounge around on beds with ivory posts, while dining on the meat of your lambs and calves.
6.5: You sing foolish songs to the music of harps, and you make up new tunes, just as David used to do.
6.6: You drink all the wine you want and wear expensive perfume, but you don't care about the ruin of your nation.
6.7: So you will be the first to be dragged off as captives; your good times will end.
6.8: The LORD God All-Powerful has sworn by his own name: "You descendants of Jacob make me angry by your pride, and I hate your fortresses. And so I will surrender your city and possessions to your enemies."
6.9: If only ten of you survive by hiding in a house you will still die.
6.10: As you carry out a corpse to prepare it for burial, your relative in the house will ask, "Are there others?" You will answer, "No!" Then your relative will reply, "Be quiet! Don't dare mention the name of the LORD."
6.11: At the LORD's command, houses great and small will be smashed to pieces.
6.12: Horses can't gallop on rocks; oceans can't be plowed. But you have turned justice and fairness into bitter poison.

7.1: The LORD God showed me that he is going to send locusts to attack your crops. It will happen after the king has already been given his share of the grain and before the rest of the grain has been harvested.
7.2: In my vision the locusts ate every crop in the land, and I said to the LORD, "Please forgive your nation. It's so weak. How can it survive?"
7.3: Then the LORD felt sorry and answered, "I won't let it be destroyed."
7.4: The LORD showed me that he is going to send a ball of fire to burn up everything on earth, including the ocean.
7.5: Then I said, "Won't you please stop? How can our weak nation survive?"
7.6: Again the LORD felt sorry and answered, "I won't let it be destroyed."
7.7: The LORD showed me a vision of himself standing beside a wall and holding a string with a weight tied to the end of it. The string and weight had been used to measure the straightness of the wall.
7.9: Their sacred places will be destroyed, and I will send war against the nation of King Jeroboam."
7.11: Here is what he is saying: 'Jeroboam will be put to death, and the people will be taken to a foreign country.'"
7.12: Then Amaziah told me, "Amos, take your visions and get out! Go back to Judah and earn your living there as a prophet.
7.13: Don't do any more preaching at Bethel. The king worships here at our national temple."
7.14: I answered: I'm not a prophet! And I wasn't trained to be a prophet. I am a shepherd, and I take care of fig trees.
7.15: But the LORD told me to leave my herds and preach to the people of Israel.
7.16: And here you are, telling me not to preach!
7.17: Now, listen to what the LORD says about you: Your wife will become a prostitute in the city, your sons and daughters will be killed in war, and your land will be divided among others. You will die in a country of foreigners, and the people of Israel will be dragged from their homeland.

8.1: The LORD God showed me a basket of ripe fruit
8.3: Instead of singing in the temple, they will cry and weep. Dead bodies will be everywhere. So keep silent! I, the LORD, have spoken!"
8.4: You people crush those in need and wipe out the poor.
8.5: You say to yourselves, "How much longer before the end of the New Moon Festival? When will the Sabbath be over? Our wheat is ready, and we want to sell it now. We can't wait to cheat and charge high prices for the grain we sell. We will use dishonest scales
8.6: and mix dust in the grain. Those who are needy and poor don't have any money. We will make them our slaves for the price of a pair of sandals."
8.7: I, the LORD, won't forget any of this, though you take great pride in your ancestor Jacob.
8.8: Your country will tremble, and you will mourn. It will be like the Nile River that rises and overflows, then sinks back down.
8.9: On that day, I, the LORD God, will make the sun go down at noon, and I will turn daylight into darkness.
8.10: Your festivals and joyful singing will turn into sorrow. You will wear sackcloth and shave your heads, as you would at the death of your only son. It will be a horrible day.
8.11: I, the LORD, also promise you a terrible shortage, but not of food and water. You will hunger and thirst to hear my message.
8.12: You will search everywhere--from north to south, from east to west. You will go all over the earth, seeking a message from me, the LORD. But you won't find one.
8.13: Your beautiful young women and your young men will faint from thirst.

9.1: I saw a vision of the LORD standing by the temple altar, and he said, "Shake the columns until the tops fall loose, and the doorposts crumble. Then make the pieces fall on the people below. I will take a sword and kill anyone who escapes.
9.2: "If they dig deep into the earth or climb to the sky, I'll reach out and get them.
9.3: If they escape to the peaks of Mount Carmel, I'll search and find them. And if they hide from me at the bottom of the ocean, I'll command a sea monster to bite them.
9.4: I'll send a sword to kill them, wherever their enemies drag them off as captives. I'm determined to hurt them, not to help them."
9.5: When the LORD God All-Powerful touches the earth, it melts, and its people mourn. God makes the earth rise and then fall, just like the Nile River.
9.6: He built his palace in the heavens and let its foundations rest on the earth. He scoops up the ocean and empties it on the earth. His name is the LORD.
9.8: My eyes have seen what a sinful nation you are, and I'll wipe you out. But I will leave a few of Jacob's descendants. I, the LORD, have spoken!
9.11: In the future, I will rebuild David's fallen kingdom. I will build it from its ruins and set it up again, just as it used to be.
9.12: Then you will capture Edom and the other nations that are mine. I, the LORD, have spoken, and my words will come true.
9.13: You will have such a harvest that you won't be able to bring in all of your wheat before plowing time. You will have grapes left over from season to season; your fruitful vineyards will cover the mountains.
9.14: I'll make Israel prosper again. You will rebuild your towns and live in them. You will drink wine from your own vineyards and eat the fruit you grow.
9.15: I'll plant your roots deep in the land I have given you, and you won't ever be uprooted again. I, the LORD God, have spoken!

1.1: The LORD God gave Obadiah a message about Edom, and this is what we heard: "I, the LORD, have sent a messenger with orders for the nations to attack Edom."
1.2: The LORD said to Edom: I will make you the weakest and most despised nation.
1.3: You live in a mountain fortress, because your pride makes you feel safe from attack, but you are mistaken.
1.4: I will still bring you down, even if you fly higher than an eagle or nest among the stars. I, the LORD, have spoken!
1.5: If thieves break in at night, they steal only what they want. And people who harvest grapes always leave some unpicked. But, Edom, you are doomed!
1.6: Everything you treasure most will be taken from you.
1.7: Your allies can't be trusted. They will force you out of your own country. And your best friends will trick and trap you, even before you know it.
1.8: Edom, when this happens, I, the LORD, will destroy all your marvelous wisdom.
1.9: Warriors from the city of Teman will be terrified, and you descendants of Esau will be wiped out.
1.10: You were cruel to your relatives, the descendants of Jacob. Now you will be destroyed, disgraced forever.
1.11: You stood there and watched as foreigners entered Jerusalem and took what they wanted. In fact, you were no better than those foreigners.
1.12: Why did you celebrate when such a dreadful disaster struck your relatives? Why were you so pleased when everyone in Judah was suffering?
1.13: They are my people, and you were cruel to them. You went through their towns, sneering and stealing whatever was left.
1.14: In their time of torment, you ambushed refugees and handed them over to their attackers.
1.15: The day is coming when I, the LORD, will judge the nations. And, Edom, you will pay in full for what you have done.
1.16: I forced the people of Judah to drink the wine of my anger on my sacred mountain. Soon the neighboring nations must drink their fill--then vanish without a trace.
1.17: The LORD's people who escape will go to Mount Zion, and it will be holy. Then Jacob's descendants will capture the land of those who took their land.
1.18: Israel will be a fire, and Edom will be straw going up in flames. The LORD has spoken!
1.19: The people of Israel who live in the Southern Desert will take the land of Edom. Those who live in the hills will capture Philistia, Ephraim, and Samaria. And the tribe of Benjamin will conquer Gilead.
1.20: Those who return from captivity will control Phoenicia as far as Zarephath. Captives from Jerusalem who were taken to Sepharad will capture the towns of the Southern Desert.
1.21: Those the LORD has saved will live on Mount Zion and rule over Edom. Then the kingdom will belong to the LORD.

1.1: One day the LORD told Jonah, the son of Amittai,
1.2: to go to the great city of Nineveh and say to the people, "The LORD has seen your terrible sins. You are doomed!"
1.3: Instead, Jonah ran from the LORD. He went to the seaport of Joppa and found a ship that was going to Spain. So he paid his fare, then got on the ship and sailed away to escape.
1.4: But the LORD made a strong wind blow, and such a bad storm came up that the ship was about to be broken to pieces.
1.5: The sailors were frightened, and they all started praying to their gods. They even threw the ship's cargo overboard to make the ship lighter. All this time, Jonah was down below deck, sound asleep.
