26.47: Jesus was still speaking, when Judas the betrayer came up. He was one of the twelve disciples, and a large mob armed with swords and clubs was with him. They had been sent by the chief priests and the nation's leaders.
26.48: Judas had told them ahead of time, "Arrest the man I greet with a kiss."
26.49: Judas walked right up to Jesus and said, "Hello, teacher." Then Judas kissed him.
26.51: One of Jesus' followers pulled out a sword. He struck the servant of the high priest and cut off his ear.
26.52: But Jesus told him, "Put your sword away. Anyone who lives by fighting will die by fighting.
26.53: Don't you know that I could ask my Father, and he would at once send me more than twelve armies of angels?
26.54: But then, how could the words of the Scriptures come true, which say this must happen?"
26.55: Jesus said to the mob, "Why do you come with swords and clubs to arrest me like a criminal? Day after day I sat and taught in the temple, and you didn't arrest me.
26.56: But all this happened, so that what the prophets wrote would come true." All Jesus' disciples left him and ran away.
26.57: After Jesus had been arrested, he was led off to the house of Caiaphas the high priest. The nation's leaders and the teachers of the Law of Moses were meeting there.
26.58: But Peter followed along at a distance and came to the courtyard of the high priest's palace. He went in and sat down with the guards to see what was going to happen.
26.59: The chief priests and the whole council wanted to put Jesus to death. So they tried to find some people who would tell lies about him in court.
26.60: But they could not find any, even though many did come and tell lies. At last, two men came forward
26.61: and said, "This man claimed he could tear down God's temple and build it again in three days."
26.63: But Jesus did not answer. So the high priest said, "With the living God looking on, you must tell the truth. Are you the Messiah, the Son of God?"
26.65: The high priest then tore his robe and said, "This man claims to be God! We don't need any more witnesses! You have heard what he said.
26.66: What do you think?" They answered, "He is guilty and deserves to die!"
26.67: Then they spit in his face and hit him with their fists. Others slapped him
26.68: and said, "You think you are the Messiah! So tell us who hit you!"
26.69: While Peter was sitting out in the courtyard, a servant girl came up to him and said, "You were with Jesus from Galilee."
26.70: But in front of everyone Peter said, "That isn't so! I don't know what you are talking about!"
26.71: When Peter had gone out to the gate, another servant girl saw him and said to some people there, "This man was with Jesus from Nazareth."
26.72: Again Peter denied it, and this time he swore, "I don't even know that man!"
26.73: A little while later some people standing there walked over to Peter and said, "We know you are one of them. We can tell it because you talk like someone from Galilee."
26.74: Peter began to curse and swear, "I don't know that man!" Right then a rooster crowed,

27.1: Early the next morning all the chief priests and the nation's leaders met and decided that Jesus should be put to death.
27.2: They tied him up and led him away to Pilate the governor.
27.3: Judas had betrayed Jesus, but when he learned that Jesus had been sentenced to death, he was sorry for what he had done. He returned the 30 silver coins to the chief priests and leaders
27.4: and said, "I have sinned by betraying a man who has never done anything wrong." "So what? That's your problem," they replied.
27.5: Judas threw the money into the temple and then went out and hanged himself.
27.6: The chief priests picked up the money and said, "This money was paid to have a man killed. We can't put it in the temple treasury."
27.7: Then they had a meeting and decided to buy a field that belonged to someone who made clay pots. They wanted to use it as a graveyard for foreigners.
27.8: This is why people still call that place "Field of Blood."
27.9: So the words of the prophet Jeremiah came true, "They took the thirty silver coins, the price of a person among the people of Israel.
27.10: They paid it for a potter's field, as the Lord had commanded me."
27.12: And when the chief priests and leaders brought their charges against him, he did not say a thing.
27.14: But Jesus did not say anything, and the governor was greatly amazed.
27.15: During Passover the governor always freed a prisoner chosen by the people.
27.16: At that time a well-known terrorist named Jesus Barabbas was in jail.
27.17: So when the crowd came together, Pilate asked them, "Which prisoner do you want me to set free? Do you want Jesus Barabbas or Jesus who is called the Messiah?"
27.18: Pilate knew the leaders had brought Jesus to him because they were jealous.
27.19: While Pilate was judging the case, his wife sent him a message. It said, "Don't have anything to do with that innocent man. I have had nightmares because of him."
27.20: But the chief priests and the leaders convinced the crowds to ask for Barabbas to be set free and for Jesus to be killed.
27.24: Pilate saw that there was nothing he could do and that the people were starting to riot. So he took some water and washed his hands in front of them and said, "I won't have anything to do with killing this man. You are the ones doing it!"
27.25: Everyone answered, "We and our own families will take the blame for his death!"
27.26: Pilate set Barabbas free. Then he ordered his soldiers to beat Jesus with a whip and nail him to a cross.
27.27: The governor's soldiers led Jesus into the fortress and brought together the rest of the troops.
27.28: They stripped off Jesus' clothes and put a scarlet robe on him.
27.29: They made a crown out of thorn branches and placed it on his head, and they put a stick in his right hand. The soldiers knelt down and pretended to worship him. They made fun of him and shouted, "Hey, you king of the Jews!"
27.30: Then they spit on him. They took the stick from him and beat him on the head with it.
27.31: When the soldiers had finished making fun of Jesus, they took off the robe. They put his own clothes back on him and led him off to be nailed to a cross.
27.32: On the way they met a man named Simon who was from Cyrene, and they forced him to carry Jesus' cross.
27.33: They came to a place named Golgotha, which means "Place of a Skull."
27.34: There they gave Jesus some wine mixed with a drug to ease the pain. But when Jesus tasted what it was, he refused to drink it.
27.35: The soldiers nailed Jesus to a cross and gambled to see who would get his clothes.
27.36: Then they sat down to guard him.
27.37: Above his head they put a sign that told why he was nailed there. It read, "This is Jesus, the King of the Jews."
27.38: The soldiers also nailed two criminals on crosses, one to the right of Jesus and the other to his left.
27.39: People who passed by said terrible things about Jesus. They shook their heads and
27.40: shouted, "So you're the one who claimed you could tear down the temple and build it again in three days! If you are God's Son, save yourself and come down from the cross!"
27.41: The chief priests, the leaders, and the teachers of the Law of Moses also made fun of Jesus. They said,
27.42: "He saved others, but he can't save himself. If he is the king of Israel, he should come down from the cross! Then we will believe him.
27.43: He trusted God, so let God save him, if he wants to. He even said he was God's Son."
27.44: The two criminals also said cruel things to Jesus.
27.45: At noon the sky turned dark and stayed that way until three o'clock.
27.47: Some of the people standing there heard Jesus and said, "He's calling for Elijah."
27.48: One of them at once ran and grabbed a sponge. He soaked it in wine, then put it on a stick and held it up to Jesus.
27.49: Others said, "Wait! Let's see if Elijah will come and save him."
27.50: Once again Jesus shouted, and then he died.
27.51: At once the curtain in the temple was torn in two from top to bottom. The earth shook, and rocks split apart.
27.52: Graves opened, and many of God's people were raised to life.
27.53: They left their graves, and after Jesus had risen to life, they went into the holy city, where they were seen by many people.
27.54: The officer and the soldiers guarding Jesus felt the earthquake and saw everything else that happened. They were frightened and said, "This man really was God's Son!"
27.55: Many women had come with Jesus from Galilee to be of help to him, and they were there, looking on at a distance.
27.56: Mary Magdalene, Mary the mother of James and Joseph, and the mother of James and John were some of these women.
27.57: That evening a rich disciple named Joseph from the town of Arimathea
27.58: went and asked for Jesus' body. Pilate gave orders for it to be given to Joseph,
27.59: who took the body and wrapped it in a clean linen cloth.
27.60: Then Joseph put the body in his own tomb that had been cut into solid rock and had never been used. He rolled a big stone against the entrance to the tomb and went away.
27.61: All this time Mary Magdalene and the other Mary were sitting across from the tomb.
27.62: On the next day, which was a Sabbath, the chief priests and the Pharisees went together to Pilate.
27.64: So please order the tomb to be carefully guarded for three days. If you don't, his disciples may come and steal his body. They will tell the people he has been raised to life, and this last lie will be worse than the first one."
27.65: Pilate said to them, "All right, take some of your soldiers and guard the tomb as well as you know how."
27.66: So they sealed it tight and placed soldiers there to guard it.

28.1: The Sabbath was over, and it was almost daybreak on Sunday when Mary Magdalene and the other Mary went to see the tomb.
28.2: Suddenly a strong earthquake struck, and the Lord's angel came down from heaven. He rolled away the stone and sat on it.
28.3: The angel looked as bright as lightning, and his clothes were white as snow.
28.4: The guards shook from fear and fell down, as though they were dead.
28.6: He isn't here! God has raised him to life, just as Jesus said he would. Come, see the place where his body was lying.
28.7: Now hurry! Tell his disciples he has been raised to life and is on his way to Galilee. Go there, and you will see him. This is what I came to tell you."
28.8: The women were frightened and yet very happy, as they hurried from the tomb and ran to tell his disciples.
28.9: Suddenly Jesus met them and greeted them. They went near him, held on to his feet, and worshiped him.
28.11: While the women were on their way, some soldiers who had been guarding the tomb went into the city. They told the chief priests everything that had happened.
28.12: So the chief priests met with the leaders and decided to bribe the soldiers with a lot of money.
28.13: They said to the soldiers, "Tell everyone that Jesus' disciples came during the night and stole his body while you were asleep.
28.14: If the governor hears about this, we will talk to him. You won't have anything to worry about."
28.15: The soldiers took the money and did what they were told. The people of Judea still tell each other this story.
28.16: Jesus' eleven disciples went to a mountain in Galilee, where Jesus had told them to meet him.
28.17: They saw him and worshiped him, but some of them doubted.
28.19: Go to the people of all nations and make them my disciples. Baptize them in the name of the Father, the Son, and the Holy Spirit,
28.20: and teach them to do everything I have told you. I will be with you always, even until the end of the world.

1.1: This is the good news about Jesus Christ, the Son of God.
1.2: It began just as God had said in the book written by Isaiah the prophet, "I am sending my messenger to get the way ready for you.
1.3: In the desert someone is shouting, 'Get the road ready for the Lord! Make a straight path for him.'"
1.4: So John the Baptist showed up in the desert and told everyone, "Turn back to God and be baptized! Then your sins will be forgiven."
1.5: From all Judea and Jerusalem crowds of people went to John. They told how sorry they were for their sins, and he baptized them in the Jordan River.
1.6: John wore clothes made of camel's hair. He had a leather strap around his waist and ate grasshoppers and wild honey.
1.8: I baptize you with water, but he will baptize you with the Holy Spirit!"
1.9: About that time Jesus came from Nazareth in Galilee, and John baptized him in the Jordan River.
1.10: As soon as Jesus came out of the water, he saw the sky open and the Holy Spirit coming down to him like a dove.
1.11: A voice from heaven said, "You are my own dear Son, and I am pleased with you."
1.12: At once God's Spirit made Jesus go into the desert.
1.13: He stayed there for 40 days while Satan tested him. Jesus was with the wild animals, but angels took care of him.
1.14: After John was arrested, Jesus went to Galilee and told the good news that comes from God.
1.15: He said, "The time has come! God's kingdom will soon be here. Turn back to God and believe the good news!"
1.16: As Jesus was walking along the shore of Lake Galilee, he saw Simon and his brother Andrew. They were fishermen and were casting their nets into the lake.
1.18: Right then the two brothers dropped their nets and went with him.
1.19: Jesus walked on and soon saw James and John, the sons of Zebedee. They were in a boat, mending their nets.
1.20: At once Jesus asked them to come with him. They left their father in the boat with the hired workers and went with him.
1.21: Jesus and his disciples went to the town of Capernaum. Then on the next Sabbath he went into the synagogue and started teaching.
1.22: Everyone was amazed at his teaching. He taught with authority, and not like the teachers of the Law of Moses.
1.23: Suddenly a man with an evil spirit in him entered the synagogue and yelled,
1.24: "Jesus from Nazareth, what do you want with us? Have you come to destroy us? I know who you are! You are God's Holy One."
1.26: The spirit shook him. Then it gave a loud shout and left.
1.27: Everyone was completely surprised and kept saying to each other, "What is this? It must be some new kind of powerful teaching! Even the evil spirits obey him."
1.28: News about Jesus quickly spread all over Galilee.
1.29: As soon as Jesus left the synagogue with James and John, they went home with Simon and Andrew.
1.30: When they got there, Jesus was told that Simon's mother-in-law was sick in bed with fever.
1.31: Jesus went to her. He took hold of her hand and helped her up. The fever left her, and she served them a meal.
1.32: That evening after sunset, all who were sick or had demons in them were brought to Jesus.
1.33: In fact, the whole town gathered around the door of the house.
1.34: Jesus healed all kinds of terrible diseases and forced out a lot of demons. But the demons knew who he was, and he did not let them speak.
1.35: Very early the next morning before daylight, Jesus got up and went to a place where he could be alone and pray.
1.36: Simon and the others started looking for him.
1.38: Jesus replied, "We must go to the nearby towns, so that I can tell the good news to those people. This is why I have come."
1.39: Then Jesus went to their synagogues everywhere in Galilee, where he preached and forced out demons.
1.40: A man with leprosy came to Jesus and knelt down. He begged, "You have the power to make me well, if only you wanted to."
1.42: At once the man's leprosy disappeared, and he was well.
1.43: After Jesus strictly warned the man, he sent him on his way.
1.44: He said, "Don't tell anyone about this. Just go and show the priest that you are well. Then take a gift to the temple as Moses commanded, and everyone will know that you have been healed."
1.45: The man talked about it so much and told so many people, that Jesus could no longer go openly into a town. He had to stay away from the towns, but people still came to him from everywhere.

2.1: Jesus went back to Capernaum, and a few days later people heard that he was at home.
2.2: Then so many of them came to the house that there wasn't even standing room left in front of the door. Jesus was still teaching
2.3: when four people came up, carrying a man on a mat because he could not walk.
2.4: But because of the crowd, they could not get him to Jesus. So they made a hole in the roof above him and let the man down in front of everyone.
2.5: When Jesus saw how much faith they had, he said to the man, "My friend, your sins are forgiven."
2.6: Some of the teachers of the Law of Moses were sitting there. They started wondering,
2.7: "Why would he say such a thing? He must think he is God! Only God can forgive sins."
2.8: At once, Jesus knew what they were thinking, and he said, "Why are you thinking such things?
2.9: Is it easier for me to tell this man his sins are forgiven or to tell him to get up and pick up his mat and go on home?
2.10: I will show you that the Son of Man has the right to forgive sins here on earth." So Jesus said to the man,
2.11: "Get up! Pick up your mat and go on home."
2.12: The man got right up. He picked up his mat and went out while everyone watched in amazement. They praised God and said, "We have never seen anything like this!"
2.13: Once again, Jesus went to the shore of Lake Galilee. A large crowd gathered around him, and he taught them.
2.15: Later, Jesus and his disciples were having dinner at Levi's house. Many tax collectors and other sinners had become followers of Jesus, and they were also guests at the dinner.
2.16: Some of the teachers of the Law of Moses were Pharisees, and they saw Jesus eating with sinners and tax collectors. So they asked his disciples, "Why does he eat with tax collectors and sinners?"
2.17: Jesus heard them and answered, "Healthy people don't need a doctor, but sick people do. I didn't come to invite good people to be my followers. I came to invite sinners."
2.18: The followers of John the Baptist and the Pharisees often went without eating. Some people came and asked Jesus, "Why do the followers of John and those of the Pharisees often go without eating, while your disciples never do?"
2.19: Jesus answered: The friends of a bridegroom don't go without eating while he is still with them.
2.20: But the time will come when he will be taken from them. Then they will go without eating.
2.21: No one patches old clothes by sewing on a piece of new cloth. The new piece would shrink and tear a bigger hole.
2.22: No one pours new wine into old wineskins. The wine would swell and burst the old skins. Then the wine would be lost, and the skins would be ruined. New wine must be put into new wineskins.
2.23: One Sabbath Jesus and his disciples were walking through some wheat fields. His disciples were picking grains of wheat as they went along.
2.24: Some Pharisees asked Jesus, "Why are your disciples picking grain on the Sabbath? They are not supposed to do that!"
2.25: Jesus answered, "Haven't you read what David did when he and his followers were hungry and in need?
2.26: It was during the time of Abiathar the high priest. David went into the house of God and ate the sacred loaves of bread that only priests are allowed to eat. He also gave some to his followers."
2.27: Jesus finished by saying, "People were not made for the good of the Sabbath. The Sabbath was made for the good of people.
2.28: So the Son of Man is Lord over the Sabbath."

3.1: The next time Jesus went into the synagogue, a man with a paralyzed hand was there.
3.2: The Pharisees wanted to accuse Jesus of doing something wrong, and they kept watching to see if Jesus would heal him on the Sabbath.
3.3: Jesus told the man to stand up where everyone could see him.
3.4: Then he asked, "On the Sabbath should we do good deeds or evil deeds? Should we save someone's life or destroy it?" But no one said a word.
3.5: Jesus was angry as he looked around at the people. Yet he felt sorry for them because they were so stubborn. Then he told the man, "Stretch out your hand." He did, and his bad hand was healed.
3.6: The Pharisees left. And at once they started making plans with Herod's followers to kill Jesus.
3.7: Jesus led his disciples down to the shore of the lake. Large crowds followed him from Galilee, Judea,
3.8: and Jerusalem. People came from Idumea, as well as other places east of the Jordan River. They also came from the region around the towns of Tyre and Sidon. All of these crowds came because they had heard what Jesus was doing.
3.9: He even had to tell his disciples to get a boat ready to keep him from being crushed by the crowds.
3.10: After Jesus had healed many people, the other sick people begged him to let them touch him.
3.11: And whenever any evil spirits saw Jesus, they would fall to the ground and shout, "You are the Son of God!"
3.12: But Jesus warned the spirits not to tell who he was.
3.13: Jesus decided to ask some of his disciples to go up on a mountain with him, and they went.
3.14: Then he chose twelve of them to be his apostles, so they could be with him. He also wanted to send them out to preach
3.15: and to force out demons.
3.16: Simon was one of the twelve, and Jesus named him Peter.
3.17: There were also James and John, the two sons of Zebedee. Jesus called them Boanerges, which means "Thunderbolts."
3.18: Andrew, Philip, Bartholomew, Matthew, Thomas, James son of Alphaeus, and Thaddaeus were also apostles. The others were Simon, known as the Eager One,
3.19: and Judas Iscariot, who later betrayed Jesus.
3.20: Jesus went back home, and once again such a large crowd gathered that there was no chance even to eat.
3.21: When Jesus' family heard what he was doing, they thought he was crazy and went to get him under control.
3.22: Some teachers of the Law of Moses came from Jerusalem and said, "This man is under the power of Beelzebul, the ruler of demons! He is even forcing out demons with the help of Beelzebul."
3.23: Jesus told the people to gather around him. Then he spoke to them in riddles and said: How can Satan force himself out?
3.24: A nation whose people fight each other won't last very long.
3.25: And a family that fights won't last long either.
3.26: So if Satan fights against himself, that will be the end of him.
3.27: How can anyone break into the house of a strong man and steal his things, unless he first ties up the strong man? Then he can take everything.
3.28: I promise you that any of the sinful things you say or do can be forgiven, no matter how terrible those things are.
3.29: But if you speak against the Holy Spirit, you can never be forgiven. That sin will be held against you forever.
3.30: Jesus said this because the people were saying that he had an evil spirit in him.
3.31: Jesus' mother and brothers came and stood outside. Then they sent someone with a message for him to come out to them.
3.32: The crowd sitting around Jesus told him, "Your mother and your brothers and sisters are outside and want to see you."
3.33: Jesus asked, "Who is my mother and who are my brothers?"
3.34: Then he looked at the people sitting around him and said, "Here are my mother and my brothers.
3.35: Anyone who obeys God is my brother or sister or mother."

4.1: The next time Jesus taught beside Lake Galilee, a big crowd gathered. It was so large that he had to sit in a boat out on the lake, while the people stood on the shore.
4.2: He used stories to teach them many things, and this is part of what he taught:
4.3: Now listen! A farmer went out to scatter seed in a field.
4.4: While the farmer was scattering the seed, some of it fell along the road and was eaten by birds.
4.5: Other seeds fell on thin, rocky ground and quickly started growing because the soil wasn't very deep.
4.6: But when the sun came up, the plants were scorched and dried up, because they did not have deep roots.
4.7: Some other seeds fell where thornbushes grew up and choked out the plants. So they did not produce any grain.
4.8: But a few seeds did fall on good ground where the plants grew and produced 30 or 60 or even 100 times as much as was scattered.
4.9: Then Jesus said, "If you have ears, pay attention."
4.10: When Jesus was alone with the twelve apostles and some others, they asked him about these stories.
4.11: He answered: I have explained the secret about God's kingdom to you, but for others I can use only stories.
4.12: The reason is, "These people will look and look, but never see. They will listen and listen, but never understand. If they did, they would turn to God and be forgiven."
4.14: What the farmer is spreading is really the message about the kingdom.
4.15: The seeds that fell along the road are the people who hear the message. But Satan soon comes and snatches it away from them.
4.16: The seeds that fell on rocky ground are the people who gladly hear the message and accept it at once.
4.17: But they don't have roots, and they don't last very long. As soon as life gets hard or the message gets them in trouble, they give up.
4.18: The seeds that fell among the thornbushes are also people who hear the message.
4.19: But they start worrying about the needs of this life. They are fooled by the desire to get rich and to have all kinds of other things. So the message gets choked out, and they never produce anything.
4.20: The seeds that fell on good ground are the people who hear and welcome the message. They produce 30 or 60 or even 100 times as much as was planted.
4.22: There is nothing hidden that will not be made public. There is no secret that will not be well known.
4.23: If you have ears, pay attention!
4.24: Listen carefully to what you hear! The way you treat others will be the way you will be treated--and even worse.
4.25: Everyone who has something will be given more. But people who don't have anything will lose what little they have.
4.26: Again Jesus said: God's kingdom is like what happens when a farmer scatters seed in a field.
4.27: The farmer sleeps at night and is up and around during the day. Yet the seeds keep sprouting and growing, and he doesn't understand how.
4.28: It is the ground that makes the seeds sprout and grow into plants that produce grain.
4.29: Then when harvest season comes and the grain is ripe, the farmer cuts it with a sickle.
4.30: Finally, Jesus said: What is God's kingdom like? What story can I use to explain it?
4.31: It is like what happens when a mustard seed is planted in the ground. It is the smallest seed in all the world.
4.32: But once it is planted, it grows larger than any garden plant. It even puts out branches that are big enough for birds to nest in its shade.
4.33: Jesus used many other stories when he spoke to the people, and he taught them as much as they could understand.
4.34: He did not tell them anything without using stories. But when he was alone with his disciples, he explained everything to them.
4.35: That evening, Jesus said to his disciples, "Let's cross to the east side."
4.36: So they left the crowd, and his disciples started across the lake with him in the boat. Some other boats followed along.
4.37: Suddenly a storm struck the lake. Waves started splashing into the boat, and it was about to sink.
4.38: Jesus was in the back of the boat with his head on a pillow, and he was asleep. His disciples woke him and said, "Teacher, don't you care that we're about to drown?"
4.39: Jesus got up and ordered the wind and the waves to be quiet. The wind stopped, and everything was calm.
4.40: Jesus asked his disciples, "Why were you afraid? Don't you have any faith?"
4.41: Now they were more afraid than ever and said to each other, "Who is this? Even the wind and the waves obey him!"

5.1: Jesus and his disciples crossed Lake Galilee and came to shore near the town of Gerasa.
5.2: When he was getting out of the boat, a man with an evil spirit quickly ran to him
5.3: from the graveyard where he had been living. No one was able to tie the man up anymore, not even with a chain.
5.4: He had often been put in chains and leg irons, but he broke the chains and smashed the leg irons. No one could control him.
5.5: Night and day he was in the graveyard or on the hills, yelling and cutting himself with stones.
5.6: When the man saw Jesus in the distance, he ran up to him and knelt down.
5.7: He shouted, "Jesus, Son of God in heaven, what do you want with me? Promise me in God's name that you won't torture me!"
5.10: He then begged Jesus not to send them away.
5.11: Over on the hillside a large herd of pigs was feeding.
5.12: So the evil spirits begged Jesus, "Send us into those pigs! Let us go into them."
5.13: Jesus let them go, and they went out of the man and into the pigs. The whole herd of about 2,000 pigs rushed down the steep bank into the lake and drowned.
5.14: The men taking care of the pigs ran to the town and the farms to spread the news. Then the people came out to see what had happened.
5.15: When they came to Jesus, they saw the man who had once been full of demons. He was sitting there with his clothes on and in his right mind, and they were terrified.
5.16: Everyone who had seen what had happened told about the man and the pigs.
5.17: Then the people started begging Jesus to leave their part of the country.
5.18: When Jesus was getting into the boat, the man begged to go with him.
5.19: But Jesus would not let him. Instead, he said, "Go home to your family and tell them how much the Lord has done for you and how good he has been to you."
5.20: The man went away into the region near the ten cities known as Decapolis and began telling everyone how much Jesus had done for him. Everyone who heard what had happened was amazed.
5.21: Once again Jesus got into the boat and crossed Lake Galilee. Then as he stood on the shore, a large crowd gathered around him.
5.22: The person in charge of the synagogue was also there. His name was Jairus, and when he saw Jesus, he went over to him. He knelt at Jesus' feet
5.23: and started begging him for help. He said, "My little daughter is about to die! Please come and touch her, so she will get well and live."
5.24: Jesus went with Jairus. Many people followed along and kept crowding around.
5.25: In the crowd was a woman who had been bleeding for twelve years.
5.26: She had gone to many doctors, and they had not done anything except cause her a lot of pain. She had paid them all the money she had. But instead of getting better, she only got worse.
5.27: The woman had heard about Jesus, so she came up behind him in the crowd and barely touched his clothes.
5.28: She had said to herself, "If I can just touch his clothes, I will be healed."
5.29: As soon as she touched them, her bleeding stopped, and she knew she was healed.
5.30: At that moment Jesus felt power go out from him. He turned to the crowd and asked, "Who touched my clothes?"
5.31: His disciples said to him, "Look at all these people crowding around you! How can you ask who touched you?"
5.32: But Jesus turned to see who had touched him.
5.33: The woman knew what had happened to her. So she came trembling with fear and knelt down in front of Jesus. Then she told him the whole story.
5.35: While Jesus was still speaking, some people came from Jairus' home and said, "Your daughter has died! Why bother the teacher anymore?"
5.37: Jesus did not let anyone go with him except Peter and the two brothers, James and John.
5.38: They went home with Jairus and saw the people crying and making a lot of noise.
5.39: Then Jesus went inside and said to them, "Why are you crying and carrying on like this? The child isn't dead. She is just asleep."
5.40: But the people laughed at him. After Jesus had sent them all out of the house, he took the girl's father and mother and his three disciples and went to where she was.
5.43: But Jesus ordered them not to tell anyone what had happened. Then he said, "Give her something to eat."

6.1: Jesus left and returned to his hometown with his disciples.
6.2: The next Sabbath he taught in the synagogue. Many of the people who heard him were amazed and asked, "How can he do all this? Where did he get such wisdom and the power to work these miracles?
6.3: Isn't he the carpenter, the son of Mary? Aren't James, Joseph, Judas, and Simon his brothers? Don't his sisters still live here in our town?" The people were upset because of what he was doing.
6.5: Jesus could not work any miracles there, except to heal a few sick people by placing his hands on them.
6.6: He was surprised that the people did not have any faith. Jesus taught in all the neighboring villages.
6.7: Then he called together his twelve apostles and sent them out two by two with power over evil spirits.
6.8: He told them, "You may take along a walking stick. But don't carry food or a traveling bag or any money.
6.9: It's all right to wear sandals, but don't take along a change of clothes.
6.10: When you are welcomed into a home, stay there until you leave that town.
6.11: If any place won't welcome you or listen to your message, leave and shake the dust from your feet as a warning to them."
6.12: The apostles left and started telling everyone to turn to God.
6.13: They forced out many demons and healed a lot of sick people by putting olive oil on them.
6.14: Jesus became so well-known that Herod the ruler heard about him. Some people thought he was John the Baptist, who had come back to life with the power to work miracles.
6.15: Others thought he was Elijah or some other prophet who had lived long ago.
6.16: But when Herod heard about Jesus, he said, "This must be John! I had his head cut off, and now he has come back to life."
6.19: Herodias had a grudge against John and wanted to kill him. But she could not do it
6.20: because Herod was afraid of John and protected him. He knew that John was a good and holy man. Even though Herod was confused by what John said, he was glad to listen to him. And he often did.
6.21: Finally, Herodias got her chance when Herod gave a great birthday celebration for himself and invited his officials, his army officers, and the leaders of Galilee.
6.23: I swear that I will give you as much as half of my kingdom, if you want it."
6.24: The girl left and asked her mother, "What do you think I should ask for?" Her mother answered, "The head of John the Baptist!"
6.25: The girl hurried back and told Herod, "Here and now on a serving plate I want the head of John the Baptist!"
6.26: Herod was very sorry for what he had said. But he did not want to break the promise he had made in front of his guests.
6.27: At once he ordered a guard to cut off John's head there in prison.
6.28: The guard put the head on a serving plate and took it to the girl. Then she gave it to her mother.
6.29: When John's followers learned that he had been killed, they took his body and put it in a tomb.
6.30: After the apostles returned to Jesus, they told him everything they had done and taught.
6.32: They left in a boat for a place where they could be alone.
6.33: But many people saw them leave and figured out where they were going. So people from every town ran on ahead and got there first.
6.34: When Jesus got out of the boat, he saw the large crowd that was like sheep without a shepherd. He felt sorry for the people and started teaching them many things.
6.35: That evening the disciples came to Jesus and said, "This place is like a desert, and it's already late.
6.36: Let the crowds leave, so they can go to the farms and villages near here and buy something to eat."
6.37: Jesus replied, "You give them something to eat." But they asked him, "Don't you know it would take almost a year's wages to buy all of these people something to eat?"

3.20: Finally, Herod put John in jail, and this was the worst thing he had done.
3.21: While everyone else was being baptized, Jesus himself was baptized. Then as he prayed, the sky opened up,
3.22: and the Holy Spirit came down upon him in the form of a dove. A voice from heaven said, "You are my own dear Son, and I am pleased with you."
3.23: When Jesus began to preach, he was about 30 years old. Everyone thought he was the son of Joseph. But his family went back through Heli,
3.24: Matthat, Levi, Melchi, Jannai, Joseph,
3.33: Amminadab, Admin, Arni, Hezron, Perez, Judah,
3.38: Enosh, and Seth. The family of Jesus went all the way back to Adam and then to God.

4.1: When Jesus returned from the Jordan River, the power of the Holy Spirit was with him, and the Spirit led him into the desert.
4.2: For 40 days Jesus was tested by the devil, and during that time he went without eating. When it was all over, he was hungry.
4.3: The devil said to Jesus, "If you are God's Son, tell this stone to turn into bread."
4.4: Jesus answered, "The Scriptures say, 'No one can live only on food.'"
4.5: Then the devil led Jesus up to a high place and quickly showed him all the nations on earth.
4.6: The devil said, "I will give all this power and glory to you. It has been given to me, and I can give it to anyone I want to.
4.7: Just worship me, and you can have it all."
4.8: Jesus answered, "The Scriptures say: 'Worship the Lord your God and serve only him!'"
4.9: Finally, the devil took Jesus to Jerusalem and had him stand on top of the temple. The devil said, "If you are God's Son, jump off.
4.12: Jesus answered, "The Scriptures also say, 'Don't try to test the Lord your God!'"
4.13: After the devil had finished testing Jesus in every way possible, he left him for a while.
4.14: Jesus returned to Galilee with the power of the Spirit. News about him spread everywhere.
4.15: He taught in the Jewish synagogues, and everyone praised him.
4.16: Jesus went back to Nazareth, where he had been brought up, and as usual he went to the synagogue on the Sabbath. When he stood up to read from the Scriptures,
4.17: he was given the book of Isaiah the prophet. He opened it and read,
4.18: "The Lord's Spirit has come to me, because he has chosen me to tell the good news to the poor. The Lord has sent me to announce freedom for prisoners, to give sight to the blind, to free everyone who suffers,
4.19: and to say, 'This is the year the Lord has chosen.'"
4.20: Jesus closed the book, then handed it back to the man in charge and sat down. Everyone in the synagogue looked straight at Jesus.
4.21: Then Jesus said to them, "What you have just heard me read has come true today."
4.22: All the people started talking about Jesus and were amazed at the wonderful things he said. They kept on asking, "Isn't he Joseph's son?"
4.23: Jesus answered: You will certainly want to tell me this saying, "Doctor, first make yourself well." You will tell me to do the same things here in my own hometown that you heard I did in Capernaum.
4.24: But you can be sure that no prophets are liked by the people of their own hometown.
4.25: Once during the time of Elijah there was no rain for three and a half years, and people everywhere were starving. There were many widows in Israel,
4.26: but Elijah was sent only to a widow in the town of Zarephath near the city of Sidon.
4.27: During the time of the prophet Elisha, many men in Israel had leprosy. But no one was healed, except Naaman who lived in Syria.
4.28: When the people in the synagogue heard Jesus say this, they became so angry
4.29: that they got up and threw him out of town. They dragged him to the edge of the cliff on which the town was built, because they wanted to throw him down from there.
4.30: But Jesus slipped through the crowd and got away.
4.31: Jesus went to the town of Capernaum in Galilee and taught the people on the Sabbath.
4.32: His teaching amazed them because he spoke with power.
4.33: There in the synagogue was a man with an evil spirit. He yelled out,
4.34: "Hey, Jesus of Nazareth, what do you want with us? Are you here to get rid of us? I know who you are! You are God's Holy One."
4.36: They all were amazed and kept saying to each other, "What kind of teaching is this? He has power to order evil spirits out of people!"
4.37: News about Jesus spread all over that part of the country.
4.38: Jesus left the synagogue and went to Simon's home. When Jesus got there, he was told that Simon's mother-in-law was sick with a high fever.
4.39: So Jesus went over to her and ordered the fever to go away. Right then she was able to get up and serve them a meal.
4.40: After the sun had set, people with all kinds of diseases were brought to Jesus. He put his hands on each one of them and healed them.
4.41: Demons went out of many people and shouted, "You are the Son of God!" But Jesus ordered the demons not to speak because they knew he was the Messiah.
4.42: The next morning Jesus went out to a place where he could be alone, and crowds came looking for him. When they found him, they tried to stop him from leaving.
4.43: But Jesus said, "People in other towns must hear the good news about God's kingdom. This is why I was sent."
4.44: So he kept on preaching in the synagogues in Judea.

5.1: Jesus was standing on the shore of Lake Gennesaret, teaching the people as they crowded around him to hear God's message.
5.2: Near the shore he saw two boats left there by some fishermen who had gone to wash their nets.
5.3: Jesus got into the boat that belonged to Simon and asked him to row it out a little way from the shore. Then Jesus sat down in the boat to teach the crowd.
5.4: When Jesus had finished speaking, he told Simon, "Row the boat out into the deep water and let your nets down to catch some fish."
5.5: "Master," Simon answered, "we have worked hard all night long and have not caught a thing. But if you tell me to, I will let the nets down."
5.6: They did this and caught so many fish that their nets began ripping apart.
5.7: Then they signaled for their partners in the other boat to come and help them. The men came, and together they filled the two boats so full that they both began to sink.
5.8: When Simon Peter saw this happen, he knelt down in front of Jesus and said, "Lord, don't come near me! I am a sinner."
5.9: Peter and everyone with him were completely surprised at all the fish they had caught.
5.11: The men pulled their boats up on the shore. Then they left everything and went with Jesus.
5.12: Jesus came to a town where there was a man who had leprosy. When the man saw Jesus, he knelt down to the ground in front of Jesus and begged, "Lord, you have the power to make me well, if only you wanted to."
5.13: Jesus put his hand on him and said, "I want to! Now you are well." At once the man's leprosy disappeared.
5.15: News about Jesus kept spreading. Large crowds came to listen to him teach and to be healed of their diseases.
5.16: But Jesus would often go to some place where he could be alone and pray.
5.17: One day some Pharisees and experts in the Law of Moses sat listening to Jesus teach. They had come from every village in Galilee and Judea and from Jerusalem. God had given Jesus the power to heal the sick,
5.18: and some people came carrying a man on a mat because he could not walk. They tried to take him inside the house and put him in front of Jesus.
5.19: But because of the crowd, they could not get him to Jesus. So they went up on the roof, where they removed some tiles and let the mat down in the middle of the room.
5.21: The Pharisees and the experts began arguing, "Jesus must think he is God! Only God can forgive sins."
5.22: Jesus knew what they were thinking, and he said, "Why are you thinking this?
5.23: Is it easier for me to tell this man that his sins are forgiven or to tell him to get up and walk?
5.24: But now you will see that the Son of Man has the right to forgive sins here on earth." Jesus then said to the man, "Get up! Pick up your mat and walk home."
5.25: At once the man stood up in front of everyone. He picked up his mat and went home, giving thanks to God.
5.26: Everyone was amazed and praised God. What they saw surprised them, and they said, "We have seen a great miracle today!"
5.28: Levi left everything and went with Jesus.
5.29: In his home Levi gave a big dinner for Jesus. Many tax collectors and other guests were also there.
5.30: The Pharisees and some of their teachers of the Law of Moses grumbled to Jesus' disciples, "Why do you eat and drink with these tax collectors and other sinners?"
5.31: Jesus answered, "Healthy people don't need a doctor, but sick people do.
5.32: I didn't come to invite good people to turn to God. I came to invite sinners."
5.33: Some people said to Jesus, "John's followers often pray and go without eating, and so do the followers of the Pharisees. But your disciples never go without eating or drinking."
5.34: Jesus told them, "The friends of a bridegroom don't go without eating while he is still with them.
5.35: But the time will come when he will be taken from them. Then they will go without eating."
5.36: Jesus then told them these sayings: No one uses a new piece of cloth to patch old clothes. The patch would shrink and make the hole even bigger.
5.37: No one pours new wine into old wineskins. The new wine would swell and burst the old skins. Then the wine would be lost, and the skins would be ruined.
5.38: New wine must be put only into new wineskins.
5.39: No one wants new wine after drinking old wine. They say, "The old wine is better."

6.1: One Sabbath when Jesus and his disciples were walking through some wheat fields, the disciples picked some wheat. They rubbed the husks off with their hands and started eating the grain.
6.2: Some Pharisees said, "Why are you picking grain on the Sabbath? You're not supposed to do that!"
6.3: Jesus answered, "You surely have read what David did when he and his followers were hungry.
6.4: He went into the house of God and took the sacred loaves of bread that only priests were supposed to eat. He not only ate some himself, but even gave some to his followers."
6.5: Jesus finished by saying, "The Son of Man is Lord over the Sabbath."
6.6: On another Sabbath Jesus was teaching in a synagogue, and a man with a paralyzed right hand was there.
6.7: Some Pharisees and teachers of the Law of Moses kept watching Jesus to see if he would heal the man. They did this because they wanted to accuse Jesus of doing something wrong.
6.8: Jesus knew what they were thinking, so he told the man to stand up where everyone could see him. And the man stood up.
6.9: Then Jesus asked, "On the Sabbath should we do good deeds or evil deeds? Should we save someone's life or destroy it?"
6.10: After he had looked around at everyone, he told the man, "Stretch out your hand." He did, and his bad hand became completely well.
6.11: The teachers and the Pharisees were furious and started saying to one another, "What can we do about Jesus?"
6.12: About that time Jesus went off to a mountain to pray, and he spent the whole night there.
6.13: The next morning he called his disciples together and chose twelve of them to be his apostles.
6.14: One was Simon, and Jesus named him Peter. Another was Andrew, Peter's brother. There were also James, John, Philip, Bartholomew,
6.15: Matthew, Thomas, and James the son of Alphaeus. The rest of the apostles were Simon, known as the Eager One,
6.16: Jude, who was the son of James, and Judas Iscariot, who later betrayed Jesus.
6.17: Jesus and his apostles went down from the mountain and came to some flat, level ground. Many other disciples were there to meet him. Large crowds of people from all over Judea, Jerusalem, and the coastal towns of Tyre and Sidon were there too.
6.18: These people had come to listen to Jesus and to be healed of their diseases. All who were troubled by evil spirits were also healed.
6.19: Everyone was trying to touch Jesus, because power was going out from him and healing them all.
6.21: God will bless you hungry people. You will have plenty to eat! God will bless you people who are now crying. You will laugh!
6.22: God will bless you when others hate you and won't have anything to do with you. God will bless you when people insult you and say cruel things about you, all because you are a follower of the Son of Man.
6.23: Long ago your own people did these same things to the prophets. So when this happens to you, be happy and jump for joy! You will have a great reward in heaven.
6.25: You well-fed people are in for trouble. You will go hungry! You people who are laughing now are in for trouble. You are going to cry and weep!
6.26: You are in for trouble when everyone says good things about you. That is what your own people said about those prophets who told lies.
6.28: Ask God to bless anyone who curses you, and pray for everyone who is cruel to you.
6.29: If someone slaps you on one cheek, don't stop that person from slapping you on the other cheek. If someone wants to take your coat, don't try to keep back your shirt.
6.30: Give to everyone who asks and don't ask people to return what they have taken from you.
6.31: Treat others just as you want to be treated.
6.32: If you love only someone who loves you, will God praise you for that? Even sinners love people who love them.
6.33: If you are kind only to someone who is kind to you, will God be pleased with you for that? Even sinners are kind to people who are kind to them.
6.34: If you lend money only to someone you think will pay you back, will God be pleased with you for that? Even sinners lend to sinners because they think they will get it all back.
6.35: But love your enemies and be good to them. Lend without expecting to be paid back. Then you will get a great reward, and you will be the true children of God in heaven. He is good even to people who are unthankful and cruel.
6.36: Have pity on others, just as your Father has pity on you.
6.38: If you give to others, you will be given a full amount in return. It will be packed down, shaken together, and spilling over into your lap. The way you treat others is the way you will be treated.
6.40: Are students better than their teacher? But when they are fully trained, they will be like their teacher.
6.41: You can see the speck in your friend's eye, but you don't notice the log in your own eye.
6.44: You can tell what a tree is like by the fruit it produces. You cannot pick figs or grapes from thornbushes.
6.45: Good people do good things because of the good in their hearts, but bad people do bad things because of the evil in their hearts. Your words show what is in your heart.
6.46: Why do you keep on saying that I am your Lord, when you refuse to do what I say?
6.47: Anyone who comes and listens to me and obeys me
6.48: is like someone who dug down deep and built a house on solid rock. When a flood came and the river rushed against the house, it was built so well that it didn't even shake.
6.49: But anyone who hears what I say and doesn't obey me is like someone whose house wasn't built on solid rock. As soon as the river rushed against that house, it was smashed to pieces!

7.1: After Jesus had finished teaching the people, he went to Capernaum.
7.2: In this town an army officer's servant was sick and about to die. The officer liked his servant very much.
7.3: And when he heard about Jesus, he sent some Jewish leaders to ask him to come and heal the servant.
7.4: The leaders went to Jesus and begged him to do something. They said, "This man deserves your help!
7.5: He loves our nation and even built us a synagogue."
7.6: So Jesus went with them. When Jesus wasn't far from the house, the officer sent some friends to tell him, "Lord, don't go to any trouble for me! I am not good enough for you to come into my house.
7.7: And I am certainly not worthy to come to you. Just say the word, and my servant will get well.
7.9: When Jesus heard this, he was so surprised that he turned and said to the crowd following him, "In all of Israel I've never found anyone with this much faith!"
7.10: The officer's friends returned and found the servant well.
7.11: Soon Jesus and his disciples were on their way to the town of Nain, and a big crowd was going along with them.
7.12: As they came near the gate of the town, they saw people carrying out the body of a widow's only son. Many people from the town were walking along with her.
7.14: Jesus went over and touched the stretcher on which the people were carrying the dead boy. They stopped, and Jesus said, "Young man, get up!"
7.15: The boy sat up and began to speak. Jesus then gave him back to his mother.
7.17: News about Jesus spread all over Judea and everywhere else in that part of the country.
7.21: At that time Jesus was healing many people who were sick or in pain or were troubled by evil spirits, and he was giving sight to a lot of blind people.
7.22: Jesus said to the messengers sent by John, "Go and tell John what you have seen and heard. Blind people are now able to see, and the lame can walk. People who have leprosy are being healed, and the deaf can now hear. The dead are raised to life, and the poor are hearing the good news.
7.23: God will bless everyone who doesn't reject me because of what I do."
7.24: After John's messengers had gone, Jesus began speaking to the crowds about John: What kind of person did you go out to the desert to see? Was he like tall grass blown about by the wind?
7.25: What kind of man did you really go out to see? Was he someone dressed in fine clothes? People who wear expensive clothes and live in luxury are in the king's palace.
7.26: What then did you go out to see? Was he a prophet? He certainly was! I tell you that he was more than a prophet.
7.27: In the Scriptures, God calls John his messenger and says, "I am sending my messenger ahead of you to get things ready for you."
7.28: No one ever born on this earth is greater than John. But whoever is least important in God's kingdom is greater than John.
7.29: Everyone had been listening to John. Even the tax collectors had obeyed God and had done what was right by letting John baptize them.
7.30: But the Pharisees and the experts in the Law of Moses refused to obey God and be baptized by John.
7.31: Jesus went on to say: What are you people like? What kind of people are you?
7.32: You are like children sitting in the market and shouting to each other, "We played the flute, but you would not dance! We sang a funeral song, but you would not cry!"
7.33: John the Baptist did not go around eating and drinking, and you said, "John has a demon in him!"
7.34: But because the Son of Man goes around eating and drinking, you say, "Jesus eats and drinks too much! He is even a friend of tax collectors and sinners."
7.35: Yet Wisdom is shown to be right by what its followers do.
7.36: A Pharisee invited Jesus to have dinner with him. So Jesus went to the Pharisee's home and got ready to eat.
7.37: When a sinful woman in that town found out that Jesus was there, she bought an expensive bottle of perfume.
7.38: Then she came and stood behind Jesus. She cried and started washing his feet with her tears and drying them with her hair. The woman kissed his feet and poured the perfume on them.
7.39: The Pharisee who had invited Jesus saw this and said to himself, "If this man really were a prophet, he would know what kind of woman is touching him! He would know that she is a sinner."
7.40: Jesus said to the Pharisee, "Simon, I have something to say to you." "Teacher, what is it?" Simon replied.
7.42: Since neither of them could pay him back, the moneylender said that they didn't have to pay him anything. Which one of them will like him more?"
7.43: Simon answered, "I suppose it would be the one who had owed more and didn't have to pay it back." "You are right," Jesus said.
7.45: You didn't greet me with a kiss, but from the time I came in, she has not stopped kissing my feet.
7.46: You didn't even pour olive oil on my head, but she has poured expensive perfume on my feet.
7.47: So I tell you that all her sins are forgiven, and that is why she has shown great love. But anyone who has been forgiven for only a little will show only a little love."
7.48: Then Jesus said to the woman, "Your sins are forgiven."
7.49: Some other guests started saying to one another, "Who is this who dares to forgive sins?"
7.50: But Jesus told the woman, "Because of your faith, you are now saved. May God give you peace!"

8.1: Soon after this, Jesus was going through towns and villages, telling the good news about God's kingdom. His twelve apostles were with him,
8.2: and so were some women who had been healed of evil spirits and all sorts of diseases. One of the women was Mary Magdalene, who once had seven demons in her.
8.3: Joanna, Susanna, and many others had also used what they owned to help Jesus and his disciples. Joanna's husband Chuza was one of Herod's officials.
8.4: When a large crowd from several towns had gathered around Jesus, he told them this story:
8.6: Other seeds fell on rocky ground and started growing. But the plants did not have enough water and soon dried up.
8.7: Some other seeds fell where thornbushes grew up and choked the plants.
8.8: The rest of the seeds fell on good ground where they grew and produced a hundred times as many seeds. When Jesus had finished speaking, he said, "If you have ears, pay attention!"
8.9: Jesus' disciples asked him what the story meant.
8.10: So he answered: I have explained the secrets about God's kingdom to you. But for others I use stories, so they will look, but not see, and they will hear, but not understand.
8.11: This is what the story means: The seed is God's message,
8.12: and the seeds that fell along the road are the people who hear the message. But the devil comes and snatches the message out of their hearts, so they will not believe and be saved.
8.13: The seeds that fell on rocky ground are the people who gladly hear the message and accept it. But they don't have deep roots, and they believe only for a little while. As soon as life gets hard, they give up.
8.14: The seeds that fell among the thornbushes are also people who hear the message. But they are so eager for riches and pleasures that they never produce anything.
8.15: Those seeds that fell on good ground are the people who listen to the message and keep it in good and honest hearts. They last and produce a harvest.
8.16: No one lights a lamp and puts it under a bowl or under a bed. A lamp is always put on a lampstand, so people who come into a house will see the light.
8.17: There is nothing hidden that will not be found. There is no secret that will not be well known.
8.18: Pay attention to how you listen! Everyone who has something will be given more, but people who have nothing will lose what little they think they have.
8.19: Jesus' mother and brothers went to see him, but because of the crowd they could not get near him.
8.20: Someone told Jesus, "Your mother and brothers are standing outside and want to see you."
8.21: Jesus answered, "My mother and my brothers are those people who hear and obey God's message."
8.22: One day, Jesus and his disciples got into a boat, and he said, "Let's cross the lake." They started out,
8.23: and while they were sailing across, he went to sleep. Suddenly a storm struck the lake, and the boat started sinking. They were in danger.
8.24: So they went to Jesus and woke him up, "Master, Master! We are about to drown!" Jesus got up and ordered the wind and waves to stop. They obeyed, and everything was calm.
8.25: Then Jesus asked the disciples, "Don't you have any faith?" But they were frightened and amazed. They said to each other, "Who is this? He can give orders to the wind and the waves, and they obey him!"
8.26: Jesus and his disciples sailed across Lake Galilee and came to shore near the town of Gerasa.
8.27: As Jesus was getting out of the boat, he was met by a man from this town. The man had demons in him. He had gone naked for a long time and no longer lived in a house, but in the graveyard.
8.28: The man saw Jesus and screamed. He knelt down in front of him and shouted, "Jesus, Son of God Most High, what do you want with me? I beg you not to torture me!"
8.29: He said this because Jesus had already told the evil spirit to go out of him. The man had often been attacked by the demon. And even though he had been bound with chains and leg irons and kept under guard, he smashed whatever bound him. Then the demon would force him out into lonely places.
8.30: Jesus asked the man, "What is your name?" He answered, "My name is Lots." He said this because there were "lots" of demons in him.
8.31: They begged Jesus not to send them to the deep pit, where they would be punished.
8.32: A large herd of pigs was feeding there on the hillside. So the demons begged Jesus to let them go into the pigs, and Jesus let them go.
8.33: Then the demons left the man and went into the pigs. The whole herd rushed down the steep bank into the lake and drowned.
8.34: When the men taking care of the pigs saw this, they ran to spread the news in the town and on the farms.
8.35: The people went out to see what had happened, and when they came to Jesus, they also found the man. The demons had gone out of him, and he was sitting there at the feet of Jesus. He had clothes on and was in his right mind. But the people were terrified.
8.36: Then all who had seen the man healed told about it.
8.37: Everyone from around Gerasa begged Jesus to leave, because they were so frightened. When Jesus got into the boat to start back,
8.38: the man who had been healed begged to go with him. But Jesus sent him off and said,
8.39: "Go back home and tell everyone how much God has done for you." The man then went all over town, telling everything that Jesus had done for him.
8.40: Everyone had been waiting for Jesus, and when he came back, a crowd was there to welcome him.
8.41: Just then the man in charge of the synagogue came and knelt down in front of Jesus. His name was Jairus, and he begged Jesus to come to his home
8.42: because his twelve-year-old child was dying. She was his only daughter. While Jesus was on his way, people were crowding all around him.
8.43: In the crowd was a woman who had been bleeding for twelve years. She had spent everything she had on doctors, but none of them could make her well.
8.44: As soon as she came up behind Jesus and barely touched his clothes, her bleeding stopped.
8.45: "Who touched me?" Jesus asked. While everyone was denying it, Peter said, "Master, people are crowding all around and pushing you from every side."
8.46: But Jesus answered, "Someone touched me, because I felt power going out from me."
8.47: The woman knew that she could not hide, so she came trembling and knelt down in front of Jesus. She told everyone why she had touched him and that she had been healed at once.
8.49: While Jesus was speaking, someone came from Jairus' home and said, "Your daughter has died! Why bother the teacher anymore?"
8.51: Jesus went into the house, but he did not let anyone else go with him, except Peter, John, James, and the girl's father and mother.
8.52: Everyone was crying and weeping for the girl. But Jesus said, "The child isn't dead. She is just asleep."
8.53: The people laughed at him because they knew she was dead.
8.55: She came back to life and got right up. Jesus told them to give her something to eat.
8.56: Her parents were surprised, but Jesus ordered them not to tell anyone what had happened.

9.1: Jesus called together his twelve apostles and gave them complete power over all demons and diseases.
9.2: Then he sent them to tell about God's kingdom and to heal the sick.
9.3: He told them, "Don't take anything with you! Don't take a walking stick or a traveling bag or food or money or even a change of clothes.
9.4: When you are welcomed into a home, stay there until you leave that town.
9.5: If people won't welcome you, leave the town and shake the dust from your feet as a warning to them."
9.6: The apostles left and went from village to village, telling the good news and healing people everywhere.
9.7: Herod the ruler heard about all that was happening, and he was worried. Some people were saying John the Baptist had come back to life.
9.8: Others were saying Elijah had come or one of the prophets from long ago had come back to life.
9.9: But Herod said, "I had John's head cut off! Who is this I hear so much about?" Herod was eager to meet Jesus.
9.10: The apostles came back and told Jesus everything they had done. He then took them with him to the village of Bethsaida, where they could be alone.
9.11: But a lot of people found out about this and followed him. Jesus welcomed them. He spoke about God's kingdom and healed everyone who was sick.
9.12: Late in the afternoon the twelve apostles came to Jesus and said, "Send the crowd to the villages and farms around here. They need to find a place to stay and something to eat. There is nothing in this place. It's like a desert!"
9.13: Jesus answered, "You give them something to eat." But they replied, "We have only five small loaves of bread and two fish. If we are going to feed all these people, we will have to go and buy food."
9.14: There were about 5,000 men in the crowd. Jesus said to his disciples, "Tell the people to sit in groups of 50."
9.15: They did this, and all the people sat down.
9.16: Jesus took the five loaves and the two fish. He looked up toward heaven and blessed the food. Then he broke the bread and fish and handed them to his disciples to give to the people.
9.17: Everyone ate all they wanted. What was left over filled twelve baskets.
9.18: When Jesus was alone praying, his disciples came to him, and he asked them, "What do people say about me?"
9.19: They answered, "Some say you are John the Baptist or Elijah or a prophet from long ago who has come back to life."
9.21: Jesus strictly warned his disciples not to tell anyone about this.
9.22: Jesus told his disciples, "The nation's leaders, the chief priests, and the teachers of the Law of Moses will make the Son of Man suffer terribly. They will reject him and kill him, but three days later he will rise to life."
9.23: Then Jesus said to all the people: If any of you want to be my followers, you must forget about yourself. You must take up your cross every day and follow me.
9.24: If you want to save your life, you will destroy it. But if you give up your life for me, you will save it.

9.35: From the cloud a voice spoke, "This is my chosen Son. Listen to what he says!"

9.37: The next day Jesus and his three disciples came down from the mountain and were met by a large crowd.

9.40: I begged your disciples to force out the demon, but they couldn't do it."
9.41: Jesus said to them, "You people are stubborn and don't have any faith! How much longer must I be with you? Why do I have to put up with you?" Then Jesus said to the man, "Bring your son to me."
9.42: While the boy was being brought, the demon attacked him and made him shake all over. Jesus ordered the demon to stop. Then he healed the boy and gave him back to his father.
9.43: Everyone was amazed at God's great power. While everyone was still amazed at what Jesus was doing, he said to his disciples,
9.44: "Pay close attention to what I am telling you! The Son of Man will be handed over to his enemies."
9.45: But the disciples did not know what he meant. The meaning was hidden from them. They could not understand it, and they were afraid to ask.

9.47: Jesus knew what they were thinking, and he had a child stand there beside him.
9.48: Then he said to his disciples, "When you welcome even a child because of me, you welcome me. And when you welcome me, you welcome the one who sent me. Whichever one of you is the most humble is the greatest."

10.26: Jesus answered, "What is written in the Scriptures? How do you understand them?"

10.31: A priest happened to be going down the same road. But when he saw the man, he walked by on the other side.
10.32: Later a temple helper came to the same place. But when he saw the man who had been beaten up, he also went by on the other side.
10.33: A man from Samaria then came traveling along that road. When he saw the man, he felt sorry for him
10.34: and went over to him. He treated his wounds with olive oil and wine and bandaged them. Then he put him on his own donkey and took him to an inn, where he took care of him.
10.35: The next morning he gave the innkeeper two silver coins and said, "Please take care of the man. If you spend more than this on him, I will pay you when I return."
10.36: Then Jesus asked, "Which one of these three people was a real neighbor to the man who was beaten up by robbers?"
10.37: The expert in the Law of Moses answered, "The one who showed pity." Jesus said, "Go and do the same!"
10.38: The Lord and his disciples were traveling along and came to a village. When they got there, a woman named Martha welcomed him into her home.
10.39: She had a sister named Mary, who sat down in front of the Lord and was listening to what he said.
10.40: Martha was worried about all that had to be done. Finally, she went to Jesus and said, "Lord, doesn't it bother you that my sister has left me to do all the work by myself? Tell her to come and help me!"
10.41: The Lord answered, "Martha, Martha! You are worried and upset about so many things,
10.42: but only one thing is necessary. Mary has chosen what is best, and it will not be taken away from her."

11.1: When Jesus had finished praying, one of his disciples said to him, "Lord, teach us to pray, just as John taught his followers to pray."
11.3: Give us each day the food we need.

11.6: A friend of mine has dropped in, and I don't have a thing for him to eat."
11.8: He may not get up and give you the bread, just because you are his friend. But he will get up and give you as much as you need, simply because you are not ashamed to keep on asking.
11.9: So I tell you to ask and you will receive, search and you will find, knock and the door will be opened for you.
11.10: Everyone who asks will receive, everyone who searches will find, and the door will be opened for everyone who knocks.
11.11: Which one of you fathers would give your hungry child a snake if the child asked for a fish?
11.12: Which one of you would give your child a scorpion if the child asked for an egg?
11.13: As bad as you are, you still know how to give good gifts to your children. But your heavenly Father is even more ready to give the Holy Spirit to anyone who asks.
11.14: Jesus forced a demon out of a man who could not talk. And after the demon had gone out, the man started speaking, and the crowds were amazed.
11.15: But some people said, "He forces out demons by the power of Beelzebul, the ruler of the demons!"
11.16: Others wanted to put Jesus to the test. So they asked him to show them a sign from God.
11.18: If Satan fights against himself, how can his kingdom last? Yet you say that I force out demons by the power of Beelzebul.
11.19: If I use his power to force out demons, whose power do your own followers use to force them out? They are the ones who will judge you.
11.20: But if I use God's power to force out demons, it proves that God's kingdom has already come to you.
11.21: When a strong man arms himself and guards his home, everything he owns is safe.
11.22: But if a stronger man comes and defeats him, he will carry off the weapons in which the strong man trusted. Then he will divide with others what he has taken.
11.23: If you are not on my side, you are against me. If you don't gather in the crop with me, you scatter it.
11.24: When an evil spirit leaves a person, it travels through the desert, looking for a place to rest. But when it doesn't find a place, it says, "I will go back to the home I left."
11.25: When it gets there and finds the place clean and fixed up,
11.26: it goes off and finds seven other evil spirits even worse than itself. They all come and make their home there, and that person ends up in worse shape than before.
11.29: As crowds were gathering around Jesus, he said: You people of today are evil! You keep looking for a sign from God. But what happened to Jonah is the only sign you will be given.
11.30: Just as Jonah was a sign to the people of Nineveh, the Son of Man will be a sign to the people of today.
11.31: When the judgment comes, the Queen of the South will stand there with you and condemn you. She traveled a long way to hear Solomon's wisdom, and yet here is something far greater than Solomon.
11.32: The people of Nineveh will also stand there with you and condemn you. They turned to God when Jonah preached, and yet here is something far greater than Jonah.
11.33: No one lights a lamp and then hides it or puts it under a clay pot. A lamp is put on a lampstand, so everyone who comes into the house can see the light.
11.34: Your eyes are the lamp for your body. When your eyes are good, you have all the light you need. But when your eyes are bad, everything is dark.
11.35: So be sure your light isn't darkness.
11.36: If you have light, and nothing is dark, then light will be everywhere, as when a lamp shines brightly on you.
11.37: When Jesus finished speaking, a Pharisee invited him home for a meal. Jesus went and sat down to eat.
11.38: The Pharisee was surprised that he did not wash his hands before eating.
11.39: So the Lord said to him: You Pharisees clean the outside of cups and dishes, but on the inside you are greedy and evil.
11.40: You fools! Didn't God make both the outside and the inside?
11.41: If you would only give what you have to the poor, everything you do would please God.
11.43: You Pharisees are in for trouble! You love the front seats in the synagogues, and you like to be greeted with honor in the market.
11.44: But you are in for trouble! You are like unmarked graves that people walk on without even knowing it.
11.45: A teacher of the Law of Moses spoke up, "Teacher, you said cruel things about us."
11.46: Jesus replied: You teachers are also in for trouble! You load people down with heavy burdens, but you won't lift a finger to help them carry the loads.
11.47: Yes, you are really in for trouble. You build monuments to honor the prophets your own people murdered long ago.
11.48: You must think that was the right thing for your people to do, or else you would not have built monuments for the prophets they murdered.
11.49: Because of your evil deeds, the Wisdom of God said, "I will send prophets and apostles to you. But you will murder some and mistreat others."
11.50: You people living today will be punished for all the prophets who have been murdered since the beginning of the world.
11.51: This includes every prophet from the time of Abel to the time of Zechariah, who was murdered between the altar and the temple. You people will certainly be punished for all of this.
11.52: You teachers of the Law of Moses are really in for trouble! You carry the keys to the door of knowledge about God. But you never go in, and you keep others from going in.
11.53: Jesus was about to leave, but the teachers and the Pharisees wanted to get even with him. They tried to make him say what he thought about other things,
11.54: so they could catch him saying something wrong.

12.2: Everything that is hidden will be found out, and every secret will be known.

12.4: My friends, don't be afraid of people. They can kill you, but after that, there is nothing else they can do.
12.5: God is the one you must fear. Not only can he take your life, but he can throw you into hell. God is certainly the one you should fear!
12.6: Five sparrows are sold for only a few cents, but God doesn't forget a single one of them.
12.7: Even the hairs on your head are counted. So don't be afraid! You are worth much more than many sparrows.
12.9: But if you reject me, you will be rejected in front of them.

12.11: When you are brought to trial in the synagogues or before rulers or officials, don't worry about how you will defend yourselves or what you will say.
12.12: At that time the Holy Spirit will tell you what to say.

12.14: Jesus answered, "Who gave me the right to settle arguments between you and your brother?"
12.15: Then he said to the crowd, "Don't be greedy! Owning a lot of things won't make your life safe."
12.16: So Jesus told them this story: A rich man's farm produced a big crop,
12.17: and he said to himself, "What can I do? I don't have a place large enough to store everything."
12.18: Later, he said, "Now I know what I'll do. I'll tear down my barns and build bigger ones, where I can store all my grain and other goods.
12.19: Then I'll say to myself, 'You have stored up enough good things to last for years to come. Live it up! Eat, drink, and enjoy yourself.'"
12.21: "This is what happens to people who store up everything for themselves, but are poor in the sight of God."
12.22: Jesus said to his disciples: I tell you not to worry about your life! Don't worry about having something to eat or wear.
12.23: Life is more than food or clothing.
12.24: Look at the crows! They don't plant or harvest, and they don't have storehouses or barns. But God takes care of them. You are much more important than any birds.
12.25: Can worry make you live longer?
12.26: If you don't have power over small things, why worry about everything else?
12.28: God gives such beauty to everything that grows in the fields, even though it is here today and thrown into a fire tomorrow. Won't he do even more for you? You have such little faith!
12.29: Don't keep worrying about having something to eat or drink.
12.30: Only people who don't know God are always worrying about such things. Your Father knows what you need.
12.33: Sell what you have and give the money to the poor. Make yourselves moneybags that never wear out. Make sure your treasure is safe in heaven, where thieves cannot steal it and moths cannot destroy it.
12.34: Your heart will always be where your treasure is.
12.36: just like those servants who wait up for their master to return from a wedding feast. As soon as he comes and knocks, they open the door for him.

12.38: Those servants are really fortunate if their master finds them ready, even though he comes late at night or early in the morning.
12.39: You would surely not let a thief break into your home, if you knew when the thief was coming.

14.4: But they did not say a word. Jesus took hold of the man. Then he healed him and sent him away.

14.11: If you put yourself above others, you will be put down. But if you humble yourself, you will be honored.
