14.30: They will say, "You started building, but could not finish the job."
14.31: What will a king do if he has only 10,000 soldiers to defend himself against a king who is about to attack him with 20,000 soldiers? Before he goes out to battle, won't he first sit down and decide if he can win?
14.32: If he thinks he won't be able to defend himself, he will send messengers and ask for peace while the other king is still a long way off.
14.33: So then, you cannot be my disciple unless you give away everything you own.
14.34: Salt is good, but if it no longer tastes like salt, how can it be made to taste salty again?
14.35: It is no longer good for the soil or even for the manure pile. People simply throw it out. If you have ears, pay attention!

15.1: Tax collectors and sinners were all crowding around to listen to Jesus.
15.2: So the Pharisees and the teachers of the Law of Moses started grumbling, "This man is friendly with sinners. He even eats with them."
15.3: Then Jesus told them this story:
15.4: If any of you has 100 sheep, and one of them gets lost, what will you do? Won't you leave the 99 in the field and go look for the lost sheep until you find it?
15.5: And when you find it, you will be so glad that you will put it on your shoulder
15.6: and carry it home. Then you will call in your friends and neighbors and say, "Let's celebrate! I've found my lost sheep."
15.7: Jesus said, "In the same way there is more happiness in heaven because of one sinner who turns to God than over 99 good people who don't need to."
15.8: Jesus told the people another story: What will a woman do if she has ten silver coins and loses one of them? Won't she light a lamp, sweep the floor, and look carefully until she finds it?
15.9: Then she will call in her friends and neighbors and say, "Let's celebrate! I've found the coin I lost."
15.10: Jesus said, "In the same way God's angels are happy when even one person turns to him."
15.13: Not long after that, the younger son packed up everything he owned and left for a foreign country, where he wasted all his money in wild living.
15.14: He had spent everything, when a bad famine spread through that whole land. Soon he had nothing to eat.
15.15: He went to work for a man in that country, and the man sent him out to take care of his pigs.
15.16: He would have been glad to eat what the pigs were eating, but no one gave him a thing.
15.17: Finally, he came to his senses and said, "My father's workers have plenty to eat, and here I am, starving to death!

11.15: I am glad I wasn't there, because now you will have a chance to put your faith in me. Let's go to him."
11.16: Thomas, whose nickname was "Twin," said to the other disciples, "Come on. Let's go, so we can die with him."
11.17: When Jesus got to Bethany, he found that Lazarus had already been in the tomb four days.
11.18: Bethany was less than three kilometers from Jerusalem,
11.19: and many people had come from the city to comfort Martha and Mary because their brother had died.
11.20: When Martha heard that Jesus had arrived, she went out to meet him, but Mary stayed in the house.
11.21: Martha said to Jesus, "Lord, if you had been here, my brother would not have died.
11.22: Yet even now I know that God will do anything you ask."
11.23: Jesus told her, "Your brother will live again!"
11.24: Martha answered, "I know he will be raised to life on the last day, when all the dead are raised."
11.25: Jesus then said, "I am the one who raises the dead to life! Everyone who has faith in me will live, even if they die.
11.26: And everyone who lives because of faith in me will never really die. Do you believe this?"
11.27: "Yes, Lord!" she replied. "I believe you are the Christ, the Son of God. You are the one we hoped would come into the world."
11.28: After Martha said this, she went and privately said to her sister Mary, "The Teacher is here, and he wants to see you."
11.29: As soon as Mary heard this, she got up and went out to Jesus.
11.30: He was still outside the village where Martha had gone to meet him.
11.31: Many people had come to comfort Mary, and when they saw her quickly leave the house, they thought she was going out to the tomb to cry. So they followed her.
11.32: Mary went to where Jesus was. Then as soon as she saw him, she knelt at his feet and said, "Lord, if you had been here, my brother would not have died."
11.33: When Jesus saw that Mary and the people with her were crying, he was terribly upset
11.36: and the people said, "See how much he loved Lazarus."
11.38: Jesus was still terribly upset. So he went to the tomb, which was a cave with a stone rolled against the entrance.
11.42: I know that you always answer my prayers. But I said this, so the people here would believe you sent me."
11.43: When Jesus had finished praying, he shouted, "Lazarus, come out!"
11.44: The man who had been dead came out. His hands and feet were wrapped with strips of burial cloth, and a cloth covered his face. Jesus then told the people, "Untie him and let him go."
11.45: Many of the people who had come to visit Mary saw the things Jesus did, and they put their faith in him.
11.46: Others went to the Pharisees and told what Jesus had done.
11.47: Then the chief priests and the Pharisees called the council together and said, "What should we do? This man is working a lot of miracles.
11.48: If we don't stop him now, everyone will put their faith in him. Then the Romans will come and destroy our temple and our nation."
11.49: One of the council members was Caiaphas, who was also high priest that year. He spoke up and said, "You people don't have any sense at all!
11.50: Don't you know it is better for one person to die for the people than for the whole nation to be destroyed?"
11.51: Caiaphas did not say this on his own. As high priest that year, he was prophesying that Jesus would die for the nation.
11.52: Yet Jesus would not die just for the Jewish nation. He would die to bring together all of God's scattered people.
11.53: From that day on, the council started making plans to put Jesus to death.
11.54: Because of this plot against him, Jesus stopped going around in public. He went to the town of Ephraim, which was near the desert, and he stayed there with his disciples.
11.55: It was almost time for Passover. Many of the Jewish people who lived out in the country had come to Jerusalem to get themselves ready for the festival.
11.56: They looked around for Jesus. Then when they were in the temple, they asked each other, "You don't think he will come here for Passover, do you?"
11.57: The chief priests and the Pharisees told the people to let them know if any of them saw Jesus. This is how they hoped to arrest him.

12.1: Six days before Passover Jesus went back to Bethany, where he had raised Lazarus from death.
12.2: A meal had been prepared for Jesus. Martha was doing the serving, and Lazarus himself was there.
12.3: Mary took a very expensive bottle of perfume and poured it on Jesus' feet. She wiped them with her hair, and the sweet smell of the perfume filled the house.
12.4: A disciple named Judas Iscariot was there. He was the one who was going to betray Jesus, and he asked,
12.5: "Why wasn't this perfume sold for 300 silver coins and the money given to the poor?"
12.6: Judas did not really care about the poor. He asked this because he carried the moneybag and sometimes would steal from it.
12.7: Jesus replied, "Leave her alone! She has kept this perfume for the day of my burial.
12.8: You will always have the poor with you, but you won't always have me."
12.9: A lot of people came when they heard that Jesus was there. They also wanted to see Lazarus, because Jesus had raised him from death.
12.10: So the chief priests made plans to kill Lazarus.
12.11: He was the reason that many of the people were turning from them and putting their faith in Jesus.
12.12: The next day a large crowd was in Jerusalem for Passover. When they heard that Jesus was coming for the festival,
12.14: Jesus found a donkey and rode on it, just as the Scriptures say,
12.16: At first, Jesus' disciples did not understand. But after he had been given his glory, they remembered all this. Everything had happened exactly as the Scriptures said it would.
12.19: But the Pharisees said to each other, "There is nothing we can do! Everyone in the world is following Jesus."
12.20: Some Greeks had gone to Jerusalem to worship during Passover.
12.21: Philip from Bethsaida in Galilee was there too. So they went to him and said, "Sir, we would like to meet Jesus."
12.22: Philip told Andrew. Then the two of them went to Jesus and told him.
12.23: Jesus said: The time has come for the Son of Man to be given his glory.
12.24: I tell you for certain that a grain of wheat that falls on the ground will never be more than one grain unless it dies. But if it dies, it will produce lots of wheat.
12.25: If you love your life, you will lose it. If you give it up in this world, you will be given eternal life.
12.26: If you serve me, you must go with me. My servants will be with me wherever I am. If you serve me, my Father will honor you.
12.28: So Father, bring glory to yourself. A voice from heaven then said, "I have already brought glory to myself, and I will do it again!"
12.29: When the crowd heard the voice, some of them thought it was thunder. Others thought an angel had spoken to Jesus.
12.30: Then Jesus told the crowd, "That voice spoke to help you, not me.
12.31: This world's people are now being judged, and the ruler of this world is already being thrown out!
12.32: If I am lifted up above the earth, I will make everyone want to come to me."
12.33: Jesus was talking about the way he would be put to death.
12.34: The crowd said to Jesus, "The Scriptures teach that the Messiah will live forever. How can you say that the Son of Man must be lifted up? Who is this Son of Man?"
12.35: Jesus answered, "The light will be with you for only a little longer. Walk in the light while you can. Then you won't be caught walking blindly in the dark.
12.36: Have faith in the light while it is with you, and you will be children of the light." After Jesus had said these things, he left and went into hiding.
12.37: He had worked a lot of miracles among the people, but they were still not willing to have faith in him.
12.38: This happened so that what the prophet Isaiah had said would come true, "Lord, who has believed our message? And who has seen your mighty strength?"
12.39: The people could not have faith in Jesus, because Isaiah had also said,
12.40: "The Lord has blinded the eyes of the people, and he has made the people stubborn. He did this so that they could not see or understand, and so that they would not turn to the Lord and be healed."
12.41: Isaiah said this, because he saw the glory of Jesus and spoke about him.
12.42: Even then, many of the leaders put their faith in Jesus, but they did not tell anyone about it. The Pharisees had already given orders for the people not to have anything to do with anyone who had faith in Jesus.
12.43: And besides, the leaders liked praise from others more than they liked praise from God.
12.44: In a loud voice Jesus said: Everyone who has faith in me also has faith in the one who sent me.
12.45: And everyone who has seen me has seen the one who sent me.
12.46: I am the light that has come into the world. No one who has faith in me will stay in the dark.
12.47: I am not the one who will judge those who refuse to obey my teachings. I came to save the people of this world, not to be their judge.
12.48: But everyone who rejects me and my teachings will be judged on the last day by what I have said.
12.49: I don't speak on my own. I say only what the Father who sent me has told me to say.
12.50: I know that his commands will bring eternal life. This is why I tell you exactly what the Father has told me.

13.1: It was before Passover, and Jesus knew that the time had come for him to leave this world and to return to the Father. He had always loved his followers in this world, and he loved them to the very end.
13.2: Even before the evening meal started, the devil had made Judas, the son of Simon Iscariot, decide to betray Jesus.
13.3: Jesus knew he had come from God and would go back to God. He also knew that the Father had given him complete power.
13.4: So during the meal Jesus got up, removed his outer garment, and wrapped a towel around his waist.
13.5: He put some water into a large bowl. Then he began washing his disciples' feet and drying them with the towel he was wearing.
13.6: But when he came to Simon Peter, this disciple asked, "Lord, are you going to wash my feet?"
13.7: Jesus answered, "You don't really know what I am doing, but later you will understand."
13.8: "You will never wash my feet!" Peter replied. "If I don't wash you," Jesus told him, "you don't really belong to me."
13.9: Peter said, "Lord, don't wash just my feet. Wash my hands and my head."
13.10: Jesus answered, "People who have bathed and are clean all over need to wash just their feet. And you, my disciples, are clean, except for one of you."
13.11: Jesus knew who would betray him. That is why he said, "except for one of you."
13.13: You call me your teacher and Lord, and you should, because that is who I am.
13.14: And if your Lord and teacher has washed your feet, you should do the same for each other.
13.15: I have set the example, and you should do for each other exactly what I have done for you.
13.16: I tell you for certain that servants are not greater than their master, and messengers are not greater than the one who sent them.
13.17: You know these things, and God will bless you, if you do them.
13.18: I am not talking about all of you. I know the ones I have chosen. But what the Scriptures say must come true. And they say, "The man who ate with me has turned against me!"
13.19: I am telling you this before it all happens. Then when it does happen, you will believe who I am.
13.20: I tell you for certain that anyone who welcomes my messengers also welcomes me, and anyone who welcomes me welcomes the one who sent me.
13.21: After Jesus had said these things, he was deeply troubled and told his disciples, "I tell you for certain that one of you will betray me."
13.22: They were confused about what he meant. And they just stared at each other.
13.23: Jesus' favorite disciple was sitting next to him at the meal,
13.24: and Simon motioned for this disciple to find out which one Jesus meant.
13.25: So the disciple leaned toward Jesus and asked, "Lord, which one of us are you talking about?"
13.26: Jesus answered, "I will dip this piece of bread in the sauce and give it to the one I was talking about." Then Jesus dipped the bread and gave it to Judas, the son of Simon Iscariot.
13.27: Right then Satan took control of Judas. Jesus said, "Judas, go quickly and do what you have to do."
13.28: No one at the meal understood what Jesus meant.
13.30: Judas took the piece of bread and went out. It was already night.
13.31: After Judas had gone, Jesus said: Now the Son of Man will be given glory, and he will bring glory to God.
13.32: Then, after God is given glory because of him, God will bring glory to him, and God will do it very soon.
13.33: My children, I will be with you for only a little while longer. Then you will look for me, but you won't find me. I tell you just as I told the people, "You cannot go where I am going."
13.35: If you love each other, everyone will know that you are my disciples.
13.36: Simon Peter asked, "Lord, where are you going?" Jesus answered, "You can't go with me now, but later on you will."
13.37: Peter asked, "Lord, why can't I go with you now? I would die for you!"
13.38: "Would you really die for me?" Jesus asked. "I tell you for certain before a rooster crows, you will say three times that you don't even know me."

14.2: There are many rooms in my Father's house. I wouldn't tell you this, unless it was true. I am going there to prepare a place for each of you.
14.3: After I have done this, I will come back and take you with me. Then we will be together.
14.4: You know the way to where I am going."
14.5: Thomas said, "Lord, we don't even know where you are going! How can we know the way?"
14.6: "I am the way, the truth, and the life!" Jesus answered. "Without me, no one can go to the Father.
14.7: If you had really known me, you would have known the Father. But from now on, you do know him, and you have seen him."
14.8: Philip said, "Lord, show us the Father. That is all we need."
14.9: Jesus replied: Philip, I have been with you for a long time. Don't you know who I am? If you have seen me, you have seen the Father. How can you ask me to show you the Father?
14.10: Don't you believe that I am one with the Father and that the Father is one with me? What I say isn't said on my own. The Father who lives in me does these things.
14.11: Have faith in me when I say that the Father is one with me and that I am one with the Father. Or else have faith in me simply because of the things I do.
14.12: I tell you for certain that if you have faith in me, you will do the same things I am doing. You will do even greater things, now that I am going back to the Father.
14.13: Ask me, and I will do whatever you ask. This way the Son will bring honor to the Father.
14.14: I will do whatever you ask me to do.
14.15: Jesus said to his disciples: If you love me, you will do as I command.
14.16: Then I will ask the Father to send you the Holy Spirit who will help you and always be with you.
14.17: The Spirit will show you what is true. The people of this world cannot accept the Spirit, because they don't see or know him. But you know the Spirit, who is with you and will keep on living in you.
14.18: I won't leave you like orphans. I will come back to you.
14.19: In a little while the people of this world won't be able to see me, but you will see me. And because I live, you will live.
14.20: Then you will know I am one with the Father. You will know you are one with me, and I am one with you.
14.21: If you love me, you will do what I have said, and my Father will love you. I will also love you and show you what I am like.
14.22: The other Judas, not Judas Iscariot, then spoke up and asked, "Lord, what do you mean by saying that you will show us what you are like, but you will not show the people of this world?"
14.23: Jesus replied: If anyone loves me, they will obey me. Then my Father will love them, and we will come to them and live in them.
14.24: But anyone who doesn't love me, won't obey me. What they have heard me say doesn't really come from me, but from the Father who sent me.
14.25: I have told you these things while I am still with you.
14.26: But the Holy Spirit will come and help you, because the Father will send the Spirit to take my place. The Spirit will teach you everything and will remind you of what I said while I was with you.
14.27: I give you peace, the kind of peace only I can give. It isn't like the peace this world can give. So don't be worried or afraid.
14.28: You have already heard me say I am going and I will also come back to you. If you really love me, you should be glad I am going back to the Father, because he is greater than I am.
14.29: I am telling you this before I leave, so when it does happen, you will have faith in me.
14.30: I cannot speak with you much longer, because the ruler of this world is coming. But he has no power over me.
14.31: I obey my Father, so everyone in the world might know that I love him. It is time for us to go now.

15.1: Jesus said to his disciples: I am the true vine, and my Father is the gardener.
15.2: He cuts away every branch of mine that doesn't produce fruit. But he trims clean every branch that does produce fruit, so that it will produce even more fruit.
15.3: You are already clean because of what I have said to you.
15.4: Stay joined to me, and I will stay joined to you. Just as a branch cannot produce fruit unless it stays joined to the vine, you cannot produce fruit unless you stay joined to me.
15.5: I am the vine, and you are the branches. If you stay joined to me, and I stay joined to you, then you will produce lots of fruit. But you cannot do anything without me.
15.6: If you don't stay joined to me, you will be thrown away. You will be like dry branches that are gathered up and burned in a fire.
15.7: Stay joined to me and let my teachings become part of you. Then you can pray for whatever you want, and your prayer will be answered.
15.8: When you become fruitful disciples of mine, my Father will be honored.
15.10: If you obey me, I will keep loving you, just as my Father keeps loving me, because I have obeyed him.
15.11: I have told you this to make you as completely happy as I am.
15.12: Now I tell you to love each other, as I have loved you.
15.13: The greatest way to show love for friends is to die for them.
15.14: And you are my friends, if you obey me.
15.15: Servants don't know what their master is doing, and so I don't speak to you as my servants. I speak to you as my friends, and I have told you everything my Father has told me.
15.16: You did not choose me. I chose you and sent you out to produce fruit, the kind of fruit that will last. Then my Father will give you whatever you ask for in my name.
15.17: So I command you to love each other.
15.18: If the people of this world hate you, just remember that they hated me first.
15.19: If you belonged to the world, its people would love you. But you don't belong to the world. I have chosen you to leave the world behind, and this is why its people hate you.
15.21: People will do to you exactly what they did to me. They will do it because you belong to me, and they don't know the one who sent me.
15.22: If I had not come and spoken to them, they would not be guilty of sin. But now they have no excuse for their sin.
15.23: Everyone who hates me also hates my Father.
15.24: I have done things no one else has ever done. If they had not seen me do these things, they would not be guilty. But they did see me do these things, and they still hate me and my Father too.
15.25: This is why the Scriptures are true when they say, "People hated me for no reason."
15.26: I will send you the Spirit who comes from the Father and shows what is true. The Spirit will help you and will tell you about me.
15.27: Then you will also tell others about me, because you have been with me from the beginning.

16.1: I am telling you these things, so that you will not turn away.
16.2: You will be chased out of the synagogues. And the time will come when people will kill you and think they are doing God a favor.
16.3: They will do these things because they don't know either the Father or me.
16.4: I am saying this to you now, so that when the time comes, you will remember what I have said. I was with you at the first, and so I didn't tell you these things.
16.6: You are very sad from hearing all of this.
16.7: But I tell you I am going to do what is best for you. This is why I am going away. The Holy Spirit cannot come to help you until I leave. But after I am gone, I will send the Spirit to you.
16.8: The Spirit will come and show the people of this world the truth about sin and God's justice and the judgment.
16.9: The Spirit will show them that they are wrong about sin, because they didn't have faith in me.
16.10: They are wrong about God's justice, because I am going to the Father, and you won't see me again.
16.11: And they are wrong about the judgment, because God has already judged the ruler of this world.
16.12: I have much more to say to you, but right now it would be more than you could understand.
16.13: The Spirit shows what is true and will come and guide you into the full truth. The Spirit doesn't speak on his own. He will tell you only what he has heard from me, and he will let you know what is going to happen.
16.14: The Spirit will bring glory to me by taking my message and telling it to you.
16.15: Everything the Father has is mine. This is why I have said that the Spirit takes my message and tells it to you.
16.20: I tell you for certain that you will cry and be sad, but the world will be happy. You will be sad, but later you will be happy.
16.21: When a woman is about to give birth, she is in great pain. But after it is all over, she forgets the pain and is happy, because she has brought a child into the world.
16.22: You are now very sad. But later I will see you, and you will be so happy that no one will be able to change the way you feel.
16.23: When that time comes, you won't have to ask me about anything. I tell you for certain the Father will give you whatever you ask for in my name.
16.24: You have not asked for anything in this way before, but now you must ask in my name. Then it will be given to you, so you will be completely happy.
16.25: I have used examples to explain to you what I have been talking about. But the time will come when I will speak to you plainly about the Father and will no longer use examples like these.
16.26: You will ask the Father in my name, and I won't have to ask him for you.
16.27: God the Father loves you because you love me, and you believe I have come from him.
16.28: I came from the Father into the world, but I am leaving the world and returning to the Father.
16.29: The disciples said, "Now you are speaking plainly to us! You are not using examples.
16.30: At last we know that you understand everything, and we don't have any more questions. Now we believe you truly have come from God."
16.33: I have told you this, so that you might have peace in your hearts because of me. While you are in the world, you will have to suffer. But cheer up! I have defeated the world.

17.2: And you gave him power over all people, so he would give eternal life to everyone you give him.
17.3: Eternal life is to know you, the only true God, and to know Jesus Christ, the one you sent.
17.4: I have brought glory to you here on earth by doing everything you gave me to do.
17.5: Now, Father, give me back the glory I had with you before the world was created.
17.6: You have given me some followers from this world, and I have shown them what you are like. They were yours, but you gave them to me, and they have obeyed you.
17.7: They know that you gave me everything I have.
17.8: I told my followers what you told me, and they accepted it. They know I came from you, and they believe you are the one who sent me.
17.9: I am praying for them, but not for those who belong to this world. My followers belong to you, and I am praying for them.
17.10: All I have is yours, and all you have is mine, and they will bring glory to me.
17.11: Holy Father, I am no longer in the world. I am coming to you, but my followers are still in the world. So keep them safe by the power of the name you have given me. Then they will be one with each other, just as you and I are one.
17.12: While I was with them, I kept them safe by the power you have given me. I guarded them, and not one of them was lost, except the one who had to be lost. This happened so that what the Scriptures say would come true.
17.13: I am on my way to you. But I say these things while I am still in the world, so my followers will have the same complete joy that I do.
17.14: I have told them your message. But the people of this world hate them, because they don't belong to this world, just as I don't.
17.15: Father, I don't ask you to take my followers out of the world, but keep them safe from the evil one.
17.16: They don't belong to this world, and neither do I.
17.17: Your word is the truth. So let this truth make them completely yours.
17.18: I am sending them into the world, just as you sent me.
17.19: I have given myself completely for their sake, so they may belong completely to the truth.
17.20: I am not praying just for these followers. I am also praying for everyone else who will have faith because of what my followers will say about me.
17.21: I want all of them to be one with each other, just as I am one with you and you are one with me. I also want them to be one with us. Then the people of this world will believe that you sent me.
17.22: I have honored my followers in the same way you honored me, in order that they may be one with each other, just as we are one.
17.23: I am one with them, and you are one with me, so they may become completely one. Then this world's people will know that you sent me. They will know that you love my followers as much as you love me.
17.25: Good Father, the people of this world don't know you. But I know you, and my followers know that you sent me.
17.26: I told them what you are like, and I will tell them even more. Then the love you have for me will become part of them, and I will be one with them.

18.1: When Jesus had finished praying, he and his disciples crossed the Kidron Valley and went into a garden.
18.2: Jesus had often met there with his disciples, and Judas knew where the place was.
18.6: At once they all backed away and fell to the ground.
18.7: Jesus again asked, "Who are you looking for?" "We are looking for Jesus from Nazareth," they answered.
18.8: This time Jesus replied, "I have already told you that I am Jesus. If I am the one you are looking for, let these others go.
18.9: Then everything will happen, just as I said, 'I did not lose anyone you gave me.'"
18.10: Simon Peter had brought along a sword. He pulled it out and struck at Malchus, the servant of the high priest, cutting off his right ear.
18.11: Jesus told Peter, "Put your sword away. I must drink from the cup that the Father has given me."
18.12: The Roman officer and his men, together with the temple police, arrested Jesus and tied him up.
18.13: They took him first to Annas, who was the father-in-law of Caiaphas, the high priest that year.
18.14: This was the same Caiaphas who had told the Jewish leaders, "It is better if one person dies for the people."
18.15: Simon Peter and another disciple followed Jesus. That disciple knew the high priest, and he followed Jesus into the courtyard of the high priest's house.
18.16: Peter stayed outside near the gate. But the other disciple came back out and spoke to the girl at the gate. She let Peter go in,
18.17: but asked him, "Aren't you one of that man's followers?" "No, I am not!" Peter answered.
18.18: It was cold, and the servants and temple police had made a charcoal fire. They were warming themselves around it, when Peter went over and stood near the fire to warm himself.
18.19: The high priest questioned Jesus about his followers and his teaching.
18.20: But Jesus told him, "I have spoken freely in front of everyone. And I have always taught in our synagogues and in the temple, where all of our people come together. I have not said anything in secret.
18.21: Why are you questioning me? Why don't you ask the people who heard me? They know what I have said."
18.22: As soon as Jesus said this, one of the temple police hit him and said, "That's no way to talk to the high priest!"
18.23: Jesus answered, "If I have done something wrong, say so. But if not, why did you hit me?"
18.24: Jesus was still tied up, and Annas sent him to Caiaphas the high priest.
18.25: While Simon Peter was standing there warming himself, someone asked him, "Aren't you one of Jesus' followers?" Again Peter denied it and said, "No, I am not!"
18.27: Once more Peter denied it, and right then a rooster crowed.
18.28: It was early in the morning when Jesus was taken from Caiaphas to the building where the Roman governor stayed. But the crowd waited outside. Any of them who had gone inside would have become unclean and would not be allowed to eat the Passover meal.
18.29: Pilate came out and asked, "What charges are you bringing against this man?"
18.30: They answered, "He is a criminal! That's why we brought him to you."
18.31: Pilate told them, "Take him and judge him by your own laws." The crowd replied, "We are not allowed to put anyone to death."
18.32: And so what Jesus said about his death would soon come true.
18.35: "You know I'm not a Jew!" Pilate said. "Your own people and the chief priests brought you to me. What have you done?"
18.36: Jesus answered, "My kingdom doesn't belong to this world. If it did, my followers would have fought to keep me from being handed over to our leaders. No, my kingdom doesn't belong to this world."
18.37: "So you are a king," Pilate replied. "You are saying that I am a king," Jesus told him. "I was born into this world to tell about the truth. And everyone who belongs to the truth knows my voice."
18.38: Pilate asked Jesus, "What is truth?" Pilate went back out and said, "I don't find this man guilty of anything!
18.39: And since I usually set a prisoner free for you at Passover, would you like for me to set free the king of the Jews?"
18.40: They shouted, "No, not him! We want Barabbas." Now Barabbas was a terrorist.

19.1: Pilate gave orders for Jesus to be beaten with a whip.
19.2: The soldiers made a crown out of thorn branches and put it on Jesus. Then they put a purple robe on him.
19.3: They came up to him and said, "Hey, you king of the Jews!" They also hit him with their fists.
19.4: Once again Pilate went out. This time he said, "I will have Jesus brought out to you again. Then you can see for yourselves that I have not found him guilty."
19.5: Jesus came out, wearing the crown of thorns and the purple robe. Pilate said, "Here is the man!"
19.7: The crowd replied, "He claimed to be the Son of God! Our law says that he must be put to death."
19.8: When Pilate heard this, he was terrified.
19.9: He went back inside and asked Jesus, "Where are you from?" But Jesus did not answer.
19.11: Jesus replied, "If God had not given you the power, you couldn't do anything at all to me. But the one who handed me over to you did something even worse."
19.12: Then Pilate wanted to set Jesus free. But the crowd again yelled, "If you set this man free, you are no friend of the Emperor! Anyone who claims to be a king is an enemy of the Emperor."
19.13: When Pilate heard this, he brought Jesus out. Then he sat down on the judge's bench at the place known as "The Stone Pavement." In Aramaic this pavement is called "Gabbatha."
19.14: It was about noon on the day before Passover, and Pilate said to the crowd, "Look at your king!"
19.15: "Kill him! Kill him!" they yelled. "Nail him to a cross!" "So you want me to nail your king to a cross?" Pilate asked. The chief priests replied, "The Emperor is our king!"
19.16: Then Pilate handed Jesus over to be nailed to a cross. Jesus was taken away,
19.17: and he carried his cross to a place known as "The Skull." In Aramaic this place is called "Golgotha."
19.18: There Jesus was nailed to the cross, and on each side of him a man was also nailed to a cross.
19.19: Pilate ordered the charge against Jesus to be written on a board and put above the cross. It read, "Jesus of Nazareth, King of the Jews."
19.20: The words were written in Hebrew, Latin, and Greek. The place where Jesus was taken wasn't far from the city, and many of the people read the charge against him.
19.22: But Pilate told them, "What is written will not be changed!"
19.23: After the soldiers had nailed Jesus to the cross, they divided up his clothes into four parts, one for each of them. But his outer garment was made from a single piece of cloth, and it did not have any seams.
19.24: The soldiers said to each other, "Let's not rip it apart. We will gamble to see who gets it." This happened so the Scriptures would come true, which say, "They divided up my clothes and gambled for my garments." The soldiers then did what they had decided.
19.25: Jesus' mother stood beside his cross with her sister and Mary the wife of Clopas. Mary Magdalene was standing there too.
19.26: When Jesus saw his mother and his favorite disciple with her, he said to his mother, "This man is now your son."
19.27: Then he said to the disciple, "She is now your mother." From then on, that disciple took her into his own home.
19.28: Jesus knew that he had now finished his work. And in order to make the Scriptures come true, he said, "I am thirsty!"
19.29: A jar of cheap wine was there. Someone then soaked a sponge with the wine and held it up to Jesus' mouth on the stem of a hyssop plant.
19.30: After Jesus drank the wine, he said, "Everything is done!" He bowed his head and died.
19.31: The next day would be both a Sabbath and the Passover. It was a special day for the Jewish people, and they did not want the bodies to stay on the crosses during this day. So they asked Pilate to break the men's legs and take their bodies down.
19.32: The soldiers first broke the legs of the other two men who were nailed there.
19.33: But when they came to Jesus, they saw he was already dead, and they did not break his legs.
19.34: One of the soldiers stuck his spear into Jesus' side, and blood and water came out.
19.35: We know this is true, because it was told by someone who saw it happen. Now you can have faith too.
19.36: All this happened so that the Scriptures would come true, which say, "No bone of his body will be broken"
19.37: and "They will see the one in whose side they stuck a spear."
19.38: Joseph from Arimathea was one of Jesus' disciples. He had kept it secret though, because he was afraid of the Jewish leaders. But now he asked Pilate to let him have Jesus' body. Pilate gave him permission, and Joseph took it down from the cross.
19.39: Nicodemus also came with about 30 kilograms of spices made from myrrh and aloes. This was the same Nicodemus who had visited Jesus one night.
19.40: The two men wrapped the body in a linen cloth, together with the spices, which was how the Jewish people buried their dead.
19.41: In the place where Jesus had been nailed to a cross, there was a garden with a tomb that had never been used.
19.42: The tomb was nearby, and since it was the time to prepare for the Sabbath, they were in a hurry to put Jesus' body there.

20.1: On Sunday morning while it was still dark, Mary Magdalene went to the tomb and saw that the stone had been rolled away from the entrance.
20.2: She ran to Simon Peter and to Jesus' favorite disciple and said, "They have taken the Lord from the tomb! We don't know where they have put him."
20.3: Peter and the other disciple started for the tomb.
20.4: They ran side by side, until the other disciple ran faster than Peter and got there first.
20.5: He bent over and saw the strips of linen cloth lying inside the tomb, but he did not go in.
20.6: When Simon Peter got there, he went into the tomb and saw the strips of cloth.
20.7: He also saw the piece of cloth that had been used to cover Jesus' face. It was rolled up and in a place by itself.
20.8: The disciple who got there first then went into the tomb, and when he saw it, he believed.
20.9: At that time Peter and the other disciple did not know that the Scriptures said Jesus would rise to life.
20.10: So the two of them went back to the other disciples.
20.11: Mary Magdalene stood crying outside the tomb. She was still weeping, when she stooped down
20.12: and saw two angels inside. They were dressed in white and were sitting where Jesus' body had been. One was at the head and the other was at the foot.
20.14: As soon as Mary said this, she turned around and saw Jesus standing there. But she did not know who he was.
20.15: Jesus asked her, "Why are you crying? Who are you looking for?" She thought he was the gardener and said, "Sir, if you have taken his body away, please tell me, so I can go and get him."
20.16: Then Jesus said to her, "Mary!" She turned and said to him, "Rabboni." The Aramaic word "Rabboni" means "Teacher."
20.18: Mary Magdalene then went and told the disciples she had seen the Lord. She also told them what he had said to her.
20.19: The disciples were afraid of the Jewish leaders, and on the evening of that same Sunday they locked themselves in a room. Suddenly, Jesus appeared in the middle of the group. He greeted them
20.20: and showed them his hands and his side. When the disciples saw the Lord, they became very happy.
20.21: After Jesus had greeted them again, he said, "I am sending you, just as the Father has sent me."
20.22: Then he breathed on them and said, "Receive the Holy Spirit.
20.23: If you forgive anyone's sins, they will be forgiven. But if you don't forgive their sins, they will not be forgiven."
20.24: Although Thomas the Twin was one of the twelve disciples, he wasn't with the others when Jesus appeared to them.
20.25: So they told him, "We have seen the Lord!" But Thomas said, "First, I must see the nail scars in his hands and touch them with my finger. I must put my hand where the spear went into his side. I won't believe unless I do this!"
20.26: A week later the disciples were together again. This time, Thomas was with them. Jesus came in while the doors were still locked and stood in the middle of the group. He greeted his disciples
20.27: and said to Thomas, "Put your finger here and look at my hands! Put your hand into my side. Stop doubting and have faith!"
20.28: Thomas replied, "You are my Lord and my God!"
20.30: Jesus worked many other miracles for his disciples, and not all of them are written in this book.
20.31: But these are written so that you will put your faith in Jesus as the Messiah and the Son of God. If you have faith in him, you will have true life.

21.1: Jesus later appeared to his disciples along the shore of Lake Tiberias.
21.2: Simon Peter, Thomas the Twin, Nathanael from Cana in Galilee, and the brothers James and John, were there, together with two other disciples.
21.3: Simon Peter said, "I'm going fishing!" The others said, "We will go with you." They went out in their boat. But they didn't catch a thing that night.
21.4: Early the next morning Jesus stood on the shore, but the disciples did not realize who he was.
21.7: Jesus' favorite disciple told Peter, "It's the Lord!" When Simon heard it was the Lord, he put on the clothes he had taken off while he was working. Then he jumped into the water.
21.8: The boat was only about 100 meters from shore. So the other disciples stayed in the boat and dragged in the net full of fish.
21.9: When the disciples got out of the boat, they saw some bread and a charcoal fire with fish on it.
21.11: Simon Peter got back into the boat and dragged the net to shore. In it were 153 large fish, but still the net did not rip.
21.13: Jesus took the bread in his hands and gave some of it to his disciples. He did the same with the fish.
21.14: This was the third time Jesus appeared to his disciples after he was raised from death.
21.16: Jesus asked a second time, "Simon son of John, do you love me?" Peter answered, "Yes, Lord, you know I love you!" "Then take care of my sheep," Jesus told him.
21.18: I tell you for certain that when you were a young man, you dressed yourself and went wherever you wanted to go. But when you are old, you will hold out your hands. Then others will wrap your belt around you and lead you where you don't want to go."
21.20: Peter turned and saw Jesus' favorite disciple following them. He was the same one who had sat next to Jesus at the meal and had asked, "Lord, who is going to betray you?"
21.21: When Peter saw this disciple, he asked Jesus, "Lord, what about him?"
21.22: Jesus answered, "What is it to you, if I want him to live until I return? You must follow me."
21.23: So the rumor spread among the other disciples that this disciple would not die. But Jesus did not say he would not die. He simply said, "What is it to you, if I want him to live until I return?"
21.24: This disciple is the one who told all of this. He wrote it, and we know he is telling the truth.
21.25: Jesus did many other things. If they were all written in books, I don't suppose there would be room enough in the whole world for all the books.

1.1: Theophilus, I first wrote to you about all that Jesus did and taught from the very first
1.2: until he was taken up to heaven. But before he was taken up, he gave orders to the apostles he had chosen with the help of the Holy Spirit.
1.3: For 40 days after Jesus had suffered and died, he proved in many ways that he had been raised from death. He appeared to his apostles and spoke to them about God's kingdom.
1.4: While he was still with them, he said: Don't leave Jerusalem yet. Wait here for the Father to give you the Holy Spirit, just as I told you he has promised to do.
1.5: John baptized with water, but in a few days you will be baptized with the Holy Spirit.
1.6: While the apostles were still with Jesus, they asked him, "Lord, are you now going to give Israel its own king again?"
1.7: Jesus said to them, "You don't need to know the time of those events that only the Father controls.
1.8: But the Holy Spirit will come upon you and give you power. Then you will tell everyone about me in Jerusalem, in all Judea, in Samaria, and everywhere in the world."
1.9: After Jesus had said this and while they were watching, he was taken up into a cloud. They could not see him,
1.10: but as he went up, they kept looking up into the sky. Suddenly two men dressed in white clothes were standing there beside them.
1.11: They said, "Why are you men from Galilee standing here and looking up into the sky? Jesus has been taken to heaven. But he will come back in the same way you have seen him go."
1.14: The apostles often met together and prayed with a single purpose in mind. The women and Mary the mother of Jesus would meet with them, and so would his brothers.
1.15: One day there were about 120 of the Lord's followers meeting together, and Peter stood up to speak to them.
1.18: Then Judas bought some land with the money he was given for doing that evil thing. He fell headfirst into the field. His body burst open, and all his insides came out.
1.19: When the people of Jerusalem found out about this, they called the place Akeldama, which in the local language means "Field of Blood."
1.23: Two men were suggested: One of them was Joseph Barsabbas, known as Justus, and the other was Matthias.
1.24: Then they all prayed, "Lord, you know what everyone is like! Show us the one you have chosen
1.25: to be an apostle and to serve in place of Judas, who got what he deserved."
1.26: They drew names, and Matthias was chosen to join the group of the eleven apostles.

2.1: On the day of Pentecost all the Lord's followers were together in one place.
2.2: Suddenly there was a noise from heaven like the sound of a mighty wind! It filled the house where they were meeting.
2.3: Then they saw what looked like fiery tongues moving in all directions, and a tongue came and settled on each person there.
2.4: The Holy Spirit took control of everyone, and they began speaking whatever languages the Spirit let them speak.
2.5: Many religious Jews from every country in the world were living in Jerusalem.
2.6: And when they heard this noise, a crowd gathered. But they were surprised, because they were hearing everything in their own languages.
2.7: They were excited and amazed, and said: Don't all these who are speaking come from Galilee?
2.8: Then why do we hear them speaking our very own languages?
2.9: Some of us are from Parthia, Media, and Elam. Others are from Mesopotamia, Judea, Cappadocia, Pontus, Asia,
2.10: Phrygia, Pamphylia, Egypt, parts of Libya near Cyrene, Rome,
2.11: Crete, and Arabia. Some of us were born Jews, and others of us have chosen to be Jews. Yet we all hear them using our own languages to tell the wonderful things God has done.
2.12: Everyone was excited and confused. Some of them even kept asking each other, "What does all this mean?"
2.13: Others made fun of the Lord's followers and said, "They are drunk."
2.14: Peter stood with the eleven apostles and spoke in a loud and clear voice to the crowd: Friends and everyone else living in Jerusalem, listen carefully to what I have to say!
2.15: You are wrong to think that these people are drunk. After all, it is only nine o'clock in the morning.
2.16: But this is what God told the prophet Joel to say,
2.17: "When the last days come, I will give my Spirit to everyone. Your sons and daughters will prophesy. Your young men will see visions, and your old men will have dreams.
2.18: In those days I will give my Spirit to my servants, both men and women, and they will prophesy.
2.19: "I will work miracles in the sky above and wonders on the earth below. There will be blood and fire and clouds of smoke.
2.20: The sun will turn dark, and the moon will be as red as blood before the great and wonderful day of the Lord appears.
2.21: Then the Lord will save everyone who asks for his help."
2.22: Now, listen to what I have to say about Jesus from Nazareth. God proved he sent Jesus to you by having him work miracles, wonders, and signs. All of you know this.
2.23: God had already planned and decided that Jesus would be handed over to you. So you took him and had evil men put him to death on a cross.
2.24: But God set him free from death and raised him to life. Death could not hold him in its power.
2.25: What David said are really the words of Jesus, "I always see the Lord near me, and I will not be afraid with him at my right side.
2.26: Because of this, my heart will be glad, my words will be joyful, and I will live in hope.
2.27: The Lord won't leave me in the grave. I am his holy one, and he won't let my body decay.
2.28: He has shown me the path to life, and he makes me glad by being near me."
2.30: But David was a prophet, and he knew that God had made a promise he would not break. He had told David someone from his own family would someday be king.
2.31: David knew this would happen, and so he told us Christ would be raised to life. He said God would not leave him in the grave or let his body decay.
2.32: All of us can tell you that God has raised Jesus to life!
2.33: Jesus was taken up to sit at the right side of God, and he was given the Holy Spirit, just as the Father had promised. Jesus is also the one who has given the Spirit to us, and this is what you are now seeing and hearing.
2.34: David didn't go up to heaven. So he wasn't talking about himself when he said, "The Lord told my Lord to sit at his right side,
2.35: until he made my Lord's enemies into a footstool for him."
2.36: Everyone in Israel should then know for certain that God has made Jesus both Lord and Christ, even though you put him to death on a cross.
2.38: Peter said to them, "Turn to God and be baptized, every one of you, in the name of Jesus Christ for the forgiveness of your sins, and you will receive the gift of the Holy Spirit.
2.39: This promise is for you and your children. It is for everyone our Lord God will choose, no matter where they live."
2.41: On that day about 3,000 believed his message and were baptized.
2.42: They spent their time learning from the apostles, and they were like family to each other. They also broke bread and prayed together.
2.43: Everyone was amazed by the many miracles and wonders that the apostles worked.
2.44: All the Lord's followers often met together, and they shared everything they had.
2.45: They would sell their property and possessions and give the money to whoever was in need.
2.46: Day after day they met together in the temple. They broke bread together in different homes and shared their food happily and freely,
2.47: while praising God. Everyone liked them, and each day the Lord added to their group others who were being saved.

3.1: The time of prayer was about three o'clock in the afternoon, and Peter and John were going into the temple.
3.2: A man who had been born lame was being carried to the temple door. Each day he was placed beside this door, known as the Beautiful Gate. He sat there and begged from the people who were going in.
3.3: The man saw Peter and John entering the temple, and he asked them for money.
3.4: But they looked straight at him and said, "Look up at us!"
3.5: The man stared at them and thought he was going to get something.
3.6: But Peter said, "I don't have any silver or gold! But I will give you what I do have. In the name of Jesus Christ from Nazareth, get up and start walking."
3.7: Peter then took him by the right hand and helped him up. At once the man's feet and ankles became strong,
3.8: and he jumped up and started walking. He went with Peter and John into the temple, walking and jumping and praising God.
3.9: Everyone saw him walking around and praising God.
3.10: They knew he was the beggar who had been lying beside the Beautiful Gate, and they were completely surprised. They could not imagine what had happened to the man.
3.11: While the man kept holding on to Peter and John, the whole crowd ran to them in amazement at the place known as Solomon's Porch.
3.12: Peter saw that a crowd had gathered, and he said: Friends, why are you surprised at what has happened? Why are you staring at us? Do you think we have some power of our own? Do you think we were able to make this man walk because we are so religious?
3.13: The God that Abraham, Isaac, Jacob, and our other ancestors worshiped has brought honor to his Servant Jesus. He is the one you betrayed. You turned against him when he was being tried by Pilate, even though Pilate wanted to set him free.
3.14: You rejected Jesus, who was holy and good. You asked for a murderer to be set free,
3.15: and you killed the one who leads people to life. But God raised him from death, and all of us can tell you what he has done.
3.16: You see this man, and you know him. He put his faith in the name of Jesus and was made strong. Faith in Jesus made this man completely well while everyone was watching.
3.17: My friends, I am sure you and your leaders didn't know what you were doing.
3.18: But God had his prophets tell that his Messiah would suffer, and now he has kept this promise.
3.19: So turn to God! Give up your sins, and you will be forgiven.
3.20: Then the time will come when the Lord will give you fresh strength. He will send you Jesus, his chosen Messiah.
3.21: But Jesus must stay in heaven until God makes all things new, just as his holy prophets promised long ago.
3.22: Moses said, "The Lord your God will choose one of your own people to be a prophet, just as he chose me. Listen to everything he tells you.
3.23: No one who disobeys this prophet will be one of God's people any longer."
3.24: Samuel and all the other prophets who came later also spoke about what is now happening.
3.25: You are really the ones God told his prophets to speak to. And you were given the promise God made to your ancestors. He said to Abraham, "All nations on earth will be blessed because of someone from your family."
3.26: God sent his chosen Son to you first, because God wanted to bless you and make each one of you turn away from your sins.

4.1: The apostles were still talking to the people, when some priests, the captain of the temple guard, and some Sadducees arrived.
4.2: These men were angry because the apostles were teaching the people that the dead would be raised from death, just as Jesus had been raised from death.
4.3: It was already late in the afternoon, and they arrested Peter and John and put them in jail for the night.
4.4: But a lot of people who had heard the message believed it. So by now there were about 5,000 followers of the Lord.
4.5: The next morning the leaders, the elders, and the teachers of the Law of Moses met in Jerusalem.
4.6: The high priest Annas was there, as well as Caiaphas, John, Alexander, and other members of the high priest's family.
4.8: Peter was filled with the Holy Spirit and told the nation's leaders and the elders:
4.9: You are questioning us today about a kind deed in which a man who could not walk was healed.
4.10: But there is something we must tell you and everyone else in Israel. This man is standing here completely well because of the power of Jesus Christ from Nazareth. You put Jesus to death on a cross, but God raised him to life.
4.11: He is the stone you builders thought was worthless, and now he is the most important stone of all.
4.12: Only Jesus has the power to save! His name is the only one in all the world that can save anyone.
4.13: The officials were amazed to see how brave Peter and John were, and they knew that these two apostles were only ordinary men and not well educated. The officials were certain these men had been with Jesus.
4.14: But they could not deny what had happened. The man who had been healed was standing there with the apostles.
4.15: The officials commanded them to leave the council room. Then the officials said to each other,
4.16: "What can we do with these men? Everyone in Jerusalem knows about this miracle, and we cannot say it didn't happen.
4.17: But to keep this thing from spreading, we will warn them never again to speak to anyone about the name of Jesus."
4.18: So they called the two apostles back in and told them they must never, for any reason, teach anything about the name of Jesus.
4.19: Peter and John answered, "Do you think God wants us to obey you or to obey him?
4.20: We cannot keep quiet about what we have seen and heard."
4.23: As soon as Peter and John had been set free, they went back and told the others everything the chief priests and the leaders had said to them.
4.24: When the rest of the Lord's followers heard this, they prayed together and said: Master, you created heaven and earth, the sea, and everything in them.
4.25: And by the Holy Spirit you spoke to our ancestor David. He was your servant, and you told him to say: "Why are all the Gentiles so furious? Why do people make foolish plans?
4.26: The kings of earth prepare for war, and the rulers join together against the Lord and his Messiah."
4.27: Here in Jerusalem, Herod and Pontius Pilate got together with the Gentiles and the people of Israel. Then they turned against your holy Servant Jesus, your chosen Messiah.
4.28: They did what you in your power and wisdom had already decided would happen.
4.29: Lord, listen to their threats! We are your servants. So make us brave enough to speak your message.
4.30: Show your mighty power, as we heal people and work miracles and wonders in the name of your holy Servant Jesus.
4.31: After they had prayed, the meeting place shook. They were all filled with the Holy Spirit and bravely spoke God's message.
4.32: The group of followers all felt the same way about everything. None of them claimed that their possessions were their own, and they shared everything they had with each other.
4.33: In a powerful way the apostles told everyone that the Lord Jesus was now alive. God greatly blessed his followers,
4.34: and no one went in need of anything. Everyone who owned land or houses would sell them and bring the money
4.35: to the apostles. Then they would give the money to anyone in need.

5.1: Ananias and his wife Sapphira also sold a piece of property.
5.2: But they agreed to cheat and keep some of the money for themselves. So when Ananias took the rest of the money to the apostles,
5.4: The property was yours before you sold it, and even after you sold it, the money was still yours. What made you do such a thing? You didn't lie to people. You lied to God!"
5.5: As soon as Ananias heard this, he dropped dead, and everyone who heard about it was frightened.
5.6: Some young men came in and wrapped up his body. Then they took it out and buried it.
5.7: Three hours later Sapphira came in, but she did not know what had happened to her husband.
5.9: Then Peter said, "Why did the two of you agree to test the Lord's Spirit? The men who buried Ananias are by the door, and they will carry you out!"
5.10: At once she fell at Peter's feet and died. When the young men came back in, they found Sapphira lying there dead. So they carried her out and buried her beside her husband.
5.11: The church members were afraid, and so was everyone else who heard what had happened.
5.12: The apostles worked many miracles and wonders among the people. All of the Lord's followers often met in the part of the temple known as Solomon's Porch.
5.13: No one outside their group dared join them, even though everyone liked them very much.
5.14: Many men and women started having faith in the Lord.
5.15: Then sick people were brought out to the road and placed on mats. It was hoped that Peter would walk by, and his shadow would fall on them and heal them.
5.16: A lot of people living in the towns near Jerusalem brought those who were sick or troubled by evil spirits, and they were all healed.
5.17: The high priest and all the other Sadducees who were with him became jealous.
5.18: They arrested the apostles and put them in the city jail.
5.19: But that night an angel from the Lord opened the doors of the jail and led the apostles out. The angel said,
5.20: "Go to the temple and tell the people everything about this new life."
5.21: So they went into the temple before sunrise and started teaching. The high priest and his men called together their council, which included all of Israel's leaders. Then they ordered the apostles to be brought to them from the jail.
5.22: The temple police who were sent to the jail did not find the apostles. They returned and said,
5.23: "We found the jail locked tight and the guards standing at the doors. But when we opened the doors and went in, we didn't find anyone there."
5.24: The captain of the temple police and the chief priests listened to their report, but they did not know what to think about it.
5.25: Just then someone came in and said, "Now those men you put in jail are in the temple, teaching the people!"
5.26: The captain went with some of the temple police and brought the apostles back. But they did not use force. They were afraid that the people might start throwing stones at them.
5.27: When the apostles were brought before the council, the high priest said to them,
5.28: "We told you plainly not to teach in the name of Jesus. But look what you have done! You have been teaching all over Jerusalem, and you are trying to blame us for his death."
5.29: Peter and the apostles replied: We don't obey people. We obey God.
5.30: You killed Jesus by nailing him to a cross. But the God our ancestors worshiped raised him to life
5.31: and made him our Leader and Savior. Then God gave him a place at his right side, so that the people of Israel would turn back to him and be forgiven.
5.32: We are here to tell you about all this, and so is the Holy Spirit, who is God's gift to everyone who obeys God.
5.33: When the council members heard this, they became so angry they wanted to kill the apostles.
5.34: But one of the members was the Pharisee Gamaliel, a highly respected teacher. He ordered the apostles to be taken out of the room for a little while.
5.35: Then he said to the council: Men of Israel, be careful what you do with these men.
5.36: Not long ago Theudas claimed to be someone important, and about 400 men joined him. But he was killed, and all his followers were scattered. That was the end of that.
5.37: Later, when the people of our nation were being counted, Judas from Galilee showed up. A lot of people followed him, but he was killed, and all his followers were scattered.
5.38: So I advise you to stay away from these men. Leave them alone. If what they are planning is something of their own doing, it will fail.
5.39: But if God is behind it, you cannot stop it anyway, unless you want to fight against God. The council members agreed with what he said,
5.40: and they called the apostles back in. They had them beaten with a whip and warned them not to speak in the name of Jesus. Then they let them go.
5.41: The apostles left the council and were happy, because God had considered them worthy to suffer for the sake of Jesus.
5.42: Every day they spent time in the temple and in one home after another. They never stopped teaching and telling the good news that Jesus is the Messiah.

6.1: A lot of people were now becoming followers of the Lord. But some of the ones who spoke Greek started complaining about the ones who spoke Aramaic. They complained that the Greek-speaking widows were not given their share when the food supplies were handed out each day.
6.2: The twelve apostles called the whole group of followers together and said, "We should not give up preaching God's message in order to serve at tables.
6.3: My friends, choose seven men who are respected and wise and filled with God's Spirit. We will put them in charge of these things.
6.4: We can spend our time praying and serving God by preaching."
6.5: This suggestion pleased everyone, and they began by choosing Stephen. He had great faith and was filled with the Holy Spirit. Then they chose Philip, Prochorus, Nicanor, Timon, Parmenas, and also Nicolaus, who worshiped with the Jewish people in Antioch.
6.6: These men were brought to the apostles. Then the apostles prayed and placed their hands on the men to show they had been chosen to do this work.
6.7: God's message spread, and many more people in Jerusalem became followers. Even a large number of priests put their faith in the Lord.
6.8: God gave Stephen the power to work great miracles and wonders among the people.
6.9: But some men from Cyrene and Alexandria were members of a group who called themselves "Free Men." They started arguing with Stephen. Some others from Cilicia and Asia also argued with him.
6.10: But they were no match for Stephen, who spoke with the great wisdom that the Spirit gave him.
6.11: So they talked some men into saying, "We heard Stephen say terrible things against Moses and God!"
6.12: They turned the people and their leaders and the teachers of the Law of Moses against Stephen. Then they all grabbed him and dragged him in front of the council.
6.13: Some men agreed to tell lies about Stephen, and they said, "This man keeps on saying terrible things about this holy temple and the Law of Moses.
6.14: We have heard him claim that Jesus from Nazareth will destroy this place and change the customs Moses gave us."
6.15: Then all the council members stared at Stephen. They saw that his face looked like the face of an angel.

7.2: Stephen answered: Friends, listen to me. Our glorious God appeared to our ancestor Abraham while he was still in Mesopotamia, before he had moved to Haran.
7.3: God told him, "Leave your country and your relatives and go to a land that I will show you."
7.4: Then Abraham left the land of the Chaldeans and settled in Haran. After his father died, Abraham came and settled in this land where you now live.
7.5: God didn't give him any part of it, not even a square meter. But God did promise to give it to him and his family forever, even though Abraham didn't have any children.
7.8: God said to Abraham, "Every son in each family must be circumcised to show you have kept your agreement with me." So when Isaac was eight days old, Abraham circumcised him. Later, Isaac circumcised his son Jacob, and Jacob circumcised his twelve sons.
7.9: These men were our ancestors. Joseph was also one of our famous ancestors. His brothers were jealous of him and sold him as a slave to be taken to Egypt. But God was with him
7.10: and rescued him from all his troubles. God made him so wise that the Egyptian king Pharaoh thought highly of him. The king even made Joseph governor over Egypt and put him in charge of everything he owned.
7.11: Everywhere in Egypt and Canaan the grain crops failed. There was terrible suffering, and our ancestors could not find enough to eat.
7.12: But when Jacob heard there was grain in Egypt, he sent our ancestors there for the first time.
7.13: It was on their second trip that Joseph told his brothers who he was, and the king learned about Joseph's family.
7.14: Joseph sent for his father and his relatives. In all, there were 75 of them.
7.15: His father went to Egypt and died there, just as our ancestors did.
7.16: Later their bodies were taken back to Shechem and placed in the tomb that Abraham had bought from the sons of Hamor.
7.18: Another king was ruling Egypt, and he didn't know anything about Joseph.
7.19: He tricked our ancestors and was cruel to them. He even made them leave their babies outside, so they would die.
7.20: During this time Moses was born. He was a very beautiful child, and for three months his parents took care of him in their home.
7.21: Then when they were forced to leave him outside, the king's daughter found him and raised him as her own son.
7.22: Moses was given the best education in Egypt. He was a strong man and a powerful speaker.
7.23: When Moses was 40 years old, he wanted to help the Israelites because they were his own people.
7.24: One day he saw an Egyptian mistreating one of them. So he rescued the man and killed the Egyptian.
7.25: Moses thought the rest of his people would realize God was going to use him to set them free. But they didn't understand.
7.26: The next day Moses saw two of his own people fighting, and he tried to make them stop. He said, "Men, you are both Israelites. Why are you so cruel to each other?"
7.28: Are you going to kill me, just as you killed that Egyptian yesterday?"
7.29: When Moses heard this, he ran away to live in the country of Midian. His two sons were born there.
7.31: Moses was surprised by what he saw. He went closer to get a better look, and the Lord said,
7.32: "I am the God who was worshiped by your ancestors, Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob." Moses started shaking all over and didn't dare to look at the bush.
7.33: The Lord said to him, "Take off your sandals, because the place where you are standing is holy.
7.34: With my own eyes I have seen the suffering of my people in Egypt. I have heard their groans and have come down to rescue them. Now I am sending you back to Egypt."
7.35: This was the same Moses that the people rejected by saying, "Who made you our leader and judge?" God's angel had spoken to Moses from the bush. And God had even sent the angel to help Moses rescue the people and be their leader.
7.36: In Egypt and at the Red Sea and in the desert, Moses rescued the people by working miracles and wonders for 40 years.
7.37: Moses is the one who told the people of Israel, "God will choose one of your people to be a prophet, just as he chose me."
7.38: Moses brought our people together in the desert, and the angel spoke to him on Mount Sinai. There he was given these life-giving words to pass on to us.
7.39: But our ancestors refused to obey Moses. They rejected him and wanted to go back to Egypt.
7.40: The people said to Aaron, "Make some gods to lead us! Moses led us out of Egypt, but we don't know what's happened to him now."
7.41: Then they made an idol in the shape of a calf. They offered sacrifices to the idol and were pleased with what they had done.
7.43: Instead, you carried the tent where the god Molech is worshiped, and you took along the star of your god Rephan. You made those idols and worshiped them. So now I will have you carried off beyond Babylonia."
7.44: The tent where our ancestors worshiped God was with them in the desert. This was the same tent that God had commanded Moses to make. And it was made like the model that Moses had seen.
7.45: Later it was given to our ancestors, and they took it with them when they went with Joshua. They carried the tent along as they took over the land from those people that God had chased out for them. Our ancestors used this tent until the time of King David.
7.46: He pleased God and asked him if he could build a house of worship for the people of Israel.
7.47: And it was finally King Solomon who built a house for God.
7.48: But the Most High God doesn't live in houses made by humans. It is just as the prophet said, when he spoke for the Lord,
7.49: "Heaven is my throne, and the earth is my footstool. What kind of house will you build for me? In what place will I rest?
7.51: You stubborn and hardheaded people! You are always fighting against the Holy Spirit, just as your ancestors did.
7.52: Is there one prophet that your ancestors didn't mistreat? They killed the prophets who told about the coming of the One Who Obeys God. And now you have turned against him and killed him.
7.53: Angels gave you God's Law, but you still don't obey it.
7.54: When the council members heard Stephen's speech, they were angry and furious.
7.55: But Stephen was filled with the Holy Spirit. He looked toward heaven, where he saw our glorious God and Jesus standing at his right side.
7.56: Then Stephen said, "I see heaven open and the Son of Man standing at the right side of God!"
7.57: The council members shouted and covered their ears. At once they all attacked Stephen
7.58: and dragged him out of the city. Then they started throwing stones at him. The men who had brought charges against him put their coats at the feet of a young man named Saul.
7.59: As Stephen was being stoned to death, he called out, "Lord Jesus, please welcome me!"
7.60: He knelt down and shouted, "Lord, don't blame them for what they have done." Then he died.

8.3: Saul started making a lot of trouble for the church. He went from house to house, arresting men and women and putting them in jail.
8.4: The Lord's followers who had been scattered went from place to place, telling the good news.
8.5: Philip went to the city of Samaria and told the people about Christ.
8.6: They crowded around Philip because they were eager to hear what he was saying and to see him work miracles.
8.7: Many people with evil spirits were healed, and the spirits went out of them with a shout. A lot of paralyzed and lame people were also healed.
8.8: Everyone in that city was very glad because of what was happening.
8.9: For some time a man named Simon had lived there and had amazed the people of Samaria. He practiced witchcraft and claimed to be somebody great.
8.10: Everyone, rich and poor, crowded around him. They said, "This man is the power of God called 'The Great Power.'"
8.11: For a long time, Simon had used witchcraft to amaze the people, and they kept crowding around him.
8.12: But when they believed what Philip was saying about God's kingdom and about the name of Jesus Christ, they were all baptized.
8.13: Even Simon believed and was baptized. He stayed close to Philip, because he marveled at all the miracles and wonders.
8.14: The apostles in Jerusalem heard that some people in Samaria had accepted God's message, and they sent Peter and John.
8.15: When the two apostles arrived, they prayed that these people would be given the Holy Spirit.
8.16: Before this, the Holy Spirit had not been given to any of them, though some of them had been baptized in the name of the Lord Jesus.
8.17: Peter and John then placed their hands on everyone who had faith in the Lord, and they were given the Holy Spirit.
8.18: Simon noticed that the Spirit was given only when the apostles placed their hands on the people. So he brought money
8.19: and said to Peter and John, "Let me have this power too! Then anyone I place my hands on will also be given the Holy Spirit."
8.20: Peter said to him, "You and your money will both end up in hell if you think you can buy God's gift!
8.21: You don't have any part in this, and God sees that your heart isn't right.
8.22: Get rid of these evil thoughts and ask God to forgive you.
8.23: I can see that you are jealous and bound by your evil ways."
8.24: Simon said, "Please pray to the Lord, so that what you said won't happen to me."
8.25: After Peter and John had preached about the Lord, they returned to Jerusalem. On their way they told the good news in many villages of Samaria.
8.26: The Lord's angel said to Philip, "Go south along the desert road that leads from Jerusalem to Gaza."
8.27: So Philip left. An important Ethiopian official happened to be going along that road in his chariot. He was the chief treasurer for Candace, the Queen of Ethiopia. The official had gone to Jerusalem to worship
8.28: and was now on his way home. He was sitting in his chariot, reading the book of the prophet Isaiah.
8.29: The Spirit told Philip to catch up with the chariot.
8.31: The official answered, "How can I understand unless someone helps me?" He then invited Philip to come up and sit beside him.
8.32: The man was reading the passage that said, "He was led like a sheep on its way to be killed. He was silent as a lamb whose wool is being cut off, and he did not say a word.
8.33: He was treated like a nobody and did not receive a fair trial. How can he have children, if his life is snatched away?"
8.34: The official said to Philip, "Tell me, was the prophet talking about himself or about someone else?"
8.35: So Philip began at this place in the Scriptures and explained the good news about Jesus.
8.38: He ordered the chariot to stop. Then they both went down into the water, and Philip baptized him.
8.39: After they had come out of the water, the Lord's Spirit took Philip away. The official never saw him again, but he was very happy as he went on his way.
8.40: Philip later appeared in Azotus. He went from town to town, all the way to Caesarea, telling people about Jesus.

9.1: Saul kept on threatening to kill the Lord's followers. He even went to the high priest
9.2: and asked for letters to the leaders of the synagogues in Damascus. He did this because he wanted to arrest and take to Jerusalem any man or woman who had accepted the Lord's Way.
9.3: When Saul had almost reached Damascus, a bright light from heaven suddenly flashed around him.
9.4: He fell to the ground and heard a voice saying, "Saul! Saul! Why are you so cruel to me?"
9.5: "Who are you?" Saul asked. "I am Jesus," the Lord answered. "I am the one you are so cruel to.
9.6: Now get up and go into the city, where you will be told what to do."
9.7: The men with Saul stood there speechless. They had heard the voice, but they had not seen anyone.
9.8: Saul got up from the ground, and when he opened his eyes, he could not see a thing. Someone then led him by the hand to Damascus,
9.9: and for three days he was blind and did not eat or drink.
9.11: The Lord said to him, "Get up and go to the house of Judas on Straight Street. When you get there, you will find a man named Saul from the city of Tarsus. Saul is praying,
9.12: and he has seen a vision. He saw a man named Ananias coming to him and putting his hands on him, so he could see again."
9.13: Ananias replied, "Lord, a lot of people have told me about the terrible things this man has done to your followers in Jerusalem.
9.14: Now the chief priests have given him the power to come here and arrest anyone who worships in your name."
9.15: The Lord said to Ananias, "Go! I have chosen him to tell foreigners, kings, and the people of Israel about me.
9.16: I will show him how much he must suffer for worshiping in my name."
9.18: Suddenly something like fish scales fell from Saul's eyes, and he could see. He got up and was baptized.
9.19: Then he ate and felt much better. For several days Saul stayed with the Lord's followers in Damascus.
9.20: Soon he went to the synagogues and started telling people that Jesus is the Son of God.
9.21: Everyone who heard Saul was amazed and said, "Isn't this the man who caused so much trouble for those people in Jerusalem who worship in the name of Jesus? Didn't he come here to arrest them and take them to the chief priests?"
9.22: Saul preached with such power that he completely confused the Jewish people in Damascus, as he tried to show them that Jesus is the Messiah.
9.23: Later some of them made plans to kill Saul,
9.24: but he found out about it. He learned that they were guarding the gates of the city day and night in order to kill him.
9.25: Then one night his followers let him down over the city wall in a large basket.
