3.16: God is wonderful and glorious. I pray that his Spirit will make you become strong followers
3.17: and that Christ will live in your hearts because of your faith. Stand firm and be deeply rooted in his love.
3.18: I pray that you and all God's people will understand what is called wide or long or high or deep.
3.19: I want you to know all about Christ's love, although it is too wonderful to be measured. Then your lives will be filled with all that God is.

4.1: As a prisoner of the Lord, I beg you to live in a way that is worthy of the people God has chosen to be his own.
4.2: Always be humble and gentle. Patiently put up with each other and love each other.
4.3: Try your best to let God's Spirit keep your hearts united. Do this by living at peace.
4.4: All of you are part of the same body. There is only one Spirit of God, just as you were given one hope when you were chosen to be God's people.
4.5: We have only one Lord, one faith, and one baptism.
4.6: There is one God who is the Father of all people. Not only is God above all others, but he works by using all of us, and he lives in all of us.
4.7: Christ has generously divided out his gifts to us.
4.8: As the Scriptures say, "When he went up to the highest place, he led away many prisoners and gave gifts to people."
4.9: When it says, "he went up," it means that Christ had been deep in the earth.
4.10: This also means that the one who went deep into the earth is the same one who went into the highest heaven, so he would fill the whole universe.
4.11: Christ chose some of us to be apostles, prophets, missionaries, pastors, and teachers,
4.12: so his people would learn to serve and his body would grow strong.
4.13: This will continue until we are united by our faith and by our understanding of the Son of God. Then we will be mature, just as Christ is, and we will be completely like him.
4.14: We must stop acting like children. We must not let deceitful people trick us by their false teachings, which are like winds that toss us around from place to place.
4.15: Love should always make us tell the truth. Then we will grow in every way and be more like Christ, the head
4.16: of the body. Christ holds it together and makes all of its parts work perfectly, as it grows and becomes strong because of love.
4.17: As a follower of the Lord, I order you to stop living like stupid, godless people.
4.18: Their minds are in the dark, and they are stubborn and ignorant and have missed out on the life that comes from God. They no longer have any feelings about what is right,
4.19: and they are so greedy they do all kinds of indecent things.
4.22: You were told that your foolish desires will destroy you and that you must give up your old way of life with all its bad habits.
4.23: Let the Spirit change your way of thinking
4.24: and make you into a new person. You were created to be like God, and so you must please him and be truly holy.
4.25: We are part of the same body. Stop lying and start telling each other the truth.
4.26: Don't get so angry that you sin. Don't go to bed angry
4.27: and don't give the devil a chance.
4.28: If you are a thief, quit stealing. Be honest and work hard, so you will have something to give to people in need.
4.29: Stop all your dirty talk. Say the right thing at the right time and help others by what you say.
4.30: Don't make God's Spirit sad. The Spirit makes you sure that someday you will be free from your sins.
4.31: Stop being bitter and angry and mad at others. Don't yell at one another or curse each other or ever be rude.
4.32: Instead, be kind and merciful, and forgive others, just as God forgave you because of Christ.

5.1: Do as God does. After all, you are his dear children.
5.2: Let love be your guide. Christ loved us and offered his life for us as a sacrifice that pleases God.
5.3: You are God's people, so don't let it be said that any of you are immoral or indecent or greedy.
5.4: Don't use dirty or foolish or filthy words. Instead, say how thankful you are.
5.5: Being greedy, indecent, or immoral is just another way of worshiping idols. You can be sure people who behave in this way will never be part of the kingdom that belongs to Christ and to God.
5.6: Don't let anyone trick you with foolish talk. God punishes everyone who disobeys him and says foolish things.
5.7: So don't have anything to do with anyone like that.
5.8: You used to be like people living in the dark, but now you are people of the light because you belong to the Lord. So act like people of the light
5.9: and make your light shine. Be good and honest and truthful,
5.10: as you try to please the Lord.
5.11: Don't take part in doing those worthless things that are done in the dark. Instead, show how wrong they are.
5.12: It is disgusting even to talk about what is done in the dark.
5.13: But the light will show what these things are really like.
5.14: Light shows up everything, just as the Scriptures say, "Wake up from your sleep and rise from death. Then Christ will shine on you."
5.15: Act like people with good sense and not like fools.
5.16: These are evil times, so make every minute count.
5.17: Don't be stupid. Instead, find out what the Lord wants you to do.
5.18: Don't destroy yourself by getting drunk, but let the Spirit fill your life.
5.19: When you meet together, sing psalms, hymns, and spiritual songs, as you praise the Lord with all your heart.
5.20: Always use the name of our Lord Jesus Christ to thank God the Father for everything.
5.21: Honor Christ and put others first.
5.22: A wife should put her husband first, as she does the Lord.
5.23: A husband is the head of his wife, as Christ is the head and the Savior of the church, which is his own body.
5.24: Wives should always put their husbands first, as the church puts Christ first.
5.25: A husband should love his wife as much as Christ loved the church and gave his life for it.
5.26: He made the church holy by the power of his word, and he made it pure by washing it with water.
5.27: Christ did this, so he would have a glorious and holy church, without faults or spots or wrinkles or any other flaws.
5.28: In the same way, a husband should love his wife as much as he loves himself. A husband who loves his wife shows he loves himself.
5.29: None of us hate our own bodies. We provide for them and take good care of them, just as Christ does for the church,
5.30: because we are each part of his body.
5.31: As the Scriptures say, "A man leaves his father and mother to get married, and he becomes like one person with his wife."
5.32: This is a great mystery, but I understand it to mean Christ and his church.
5.33: So each husband should love his wife as much as he loves himself, and each wife should respect her husband.

6.1: Children, you belong to the Lord, and you do the right thing when you obey your parents. The first commandment with a promise says,
6.2: "Obey your father and your mother,
6.3: and you will have a long and happy life."
6.4: Parents, don't be hard on your children. Raise them properly. Teach them and instruct them about the Lord.
6.5: Slaves, you must obey your earthly masters. Show them great respect and be as loyal to them as you are to Christ.
6.6: Try to please them at all times, and not just when you think they are watching. You are slaves of Christ, so with your whole heart you must do what God wants you to do.
6.7: Gladly serve your masters, as though they were the Lord himself, and not simply people.
6.8: You know that you will be rewarded for any good things you do, whether you are slaves or free.
6.9: Slave owners, you must treat your slaves with this same respect. Don't threaten them. They have the same Master in heaven that you do, and he doesn't have favorites.
6.10: Finally, let the mighty strength of the Lord make you strong.
6.11: Put on all the armor that God gives, so you can defend yourself against the devil's tricks.
6.12: We are not fighting against humans. We are fighting against forces and authorities and against rulers of darkness and powers in the spiritual world.
6.13: So put on all the armor that God gives. Then when that evil day comes, you will be able to defend yourself. And when the battle is over, you will still be standing firm.
6.14: Be ready! Let the truth be like a belt around your waist, and let God's justice protect you like armor.
6.15: Your desire to tell the good news about peace should be like shoes on your feet.
6.16: Let your faith be like a shield, and you will be able to stop all the flaming arrows of the evil one.
6.17: Let God's saving power be like a helmet, and for a sword use God's message that comes from the Spirit.
6.18: Never stop praying, especially for others. Always pray by the power of the Spirit. Stay alert and keep praying for God's people.
6.19: Pray that I will be given the message to speak and that I may fearlessly explain the mystery about the good news.
6.20: I was sent to do this work, and this is the reason I am in jail. So pray that I will be brave and will speak as I should.
6.23: I pray that God the Father and the Lord Jesus Christ will give peace, love, and faith to every follower!
6.24: May God be kind to everyone who keeps on loving our Lord Jesus Christ.

1.1: From Paul and Timothy, servants of Christ Jesus. To all God's people who belong to Christ Jesus at Philippi and to all your bishops and deacons.
1.2: I pray that God our Father and the Lord Jesus Christ will be kind to you and will bless you with peace!
1.3: Every time I think of you, I thank my God.
1.4: And whenever I mention you in my prayers, it makes me happy.
1.5: This is because you have taken part with me in spreading the good news from the first day you heard about it.
1.6: God is the one who began this good work in you, and I am certain that he won't stop before it is complete on the day that Christ Jesus returns.
1.7: You have a special place in my heart. So it is only natural for me to feel the way I do. All of you have helped in the work God has given me, as I defend the good news and tell about it here in jail.
1.8: God himself knows how much I want to see you. He knows I care for you in the same way Christ Jesus does.
1.9: I pray that your love will keep on growing and you will fully know and understand
1.10: how to make the right choices. Then you will still be pure and innocent when Christ returns. And until that day,
1.11: Jesus Christ will keep you busy doing good deeds that bring glory and praise to God.
1.12: My dear friends, I want you to know that what has happened to me has helped to spread the good news.
1.13: The Roman guards and all the others know I am here in jail because I serve Christ.
1.14: Now most of the Lord's followers have become brave and are fearlessly telling the message.
1.15: Some are preaching about Christ because they are jealous and envious of us. Others are preaching because they want to help.
1.16: They love Christ and know I am here to defend the good news about him.
1.17: But the ones who are jealous of us are not sincere. They just want to cause trouble for me while I am in jail.
1.18: But that doesn't matter. All that matters is that people are telling about Christ, whether they are sincere or not. This is what makes me glad. I will keep on being glad,
1.19: because I know that your prayers and the help that comes from the Spirit of Christ Jesus will keep me safe.
1.20: I honestly expect and hope I will never do anything to be ashamed of. Whether I live or die, I always want to be as brave as I am now and bring honor to Christ.
1.21: If I live, it will be for Christ, and if I die, I will gain even more.
1.22: I don't know what to choose. I could keep on living and doing something useful.
1.23: It is a hard choice to make. I want to die and be with Christ, because this would be much better.
1.26: Then, when I visit you again, you will have good reason to take great pride in Christ Jesus because of me.
1.27: Above all else, you must live in a way that brings honor to the good news about Christ. Then, whether I visit you or not, I will hear that all of you think alike. I will know that you are working together and are struggling side by side to get others to believe the good news.
1.28: Be brave when you face your enemies. Your courage will show them that they are going to be destroyed, and it will show you that you will be saved. God will make all of this happen,
1.29: and he has blessed you. Not only do you have faith in Christ, but you suffer for him.
1.30: You saw me suffer, and you still hear about my troubles. Now you must suffer in the same way.

2.1: Christ encourages you, and his love comforts you. God's Spirit unites you, and you are concerned for others.
2.2: Now make me completely happy! Live in harmony by showing love for each other. Be united in what you think, as if you were only one person.
2.3: Don't be jealous or proud, but be humble and consider others more important than yourselves.
2.4: Care about them as much as you care about yourselves
2.5: and think the same way that Christ Jesus thought:
2.6: Christ was truly God. But he did not try to remain equal with God.
2.7: Instead he gave up everything and became a slave, when he became like one of us.
2.8: Christ was humble. He obeyed God and even died on a cross.
2.9: Then God gave Christ the highest place and honored his name above all others.
2.10: So at the name of Jesus everyone will bow down, those in heaven, on earth, and under the earth.
2.11: And to the glory of God the Father everyone will openly agree, "Jesus Christ is Lord!"
2.12: My dear friends, you always obeyed when I was with you. Now that I am away, you should obey even more. So work with fear and trembling to discover what it really means to be saved.
2.13: God is working in you to make you willing and able to obey him.
2.14: Do everything without grumbling or arguing.
2.15: Then you will be the pure and innocent children of God. You live among people who are crooked and evil, but you must not do anything they can say is wrong. Try to shine as lights among the people of this world,
2.16: as you hold firmly to the message that gives life. Then on the day when Christ returns, I can take pride in you. I can also know that my work and efforts were not useless.
2.17: Your faith in the Lord and your service are like a sacrifice offered to him. And my own blood may have to be poured out with the sacrifice. If this happens, I will be glad and rejoice with you.
2.18: In the same way, you should be glad and rejoice with me.
2.19: I want to be encouraged by news about you. So I hope the Lord Jesus will soon let me send Timothy to you.
2.20: I don't have anyone else who cares about you as much as he does.
2.21: The others think only about what interests them and not about what concerns Christ Jesus.
2.22: But you know what kind of person Timothy is. He has worked with me like a son in spreading the good news.
2.23: I hope to send him to you, as soon as I find out what is going to happen to me.
2.24: And I feel sure the Lord will also let me come soon.
2.25: I think I ought to send my dear friend Epaphroditus back to you. He is a follower and a worker and a soldier of the Lord, just as I am. You sent him to look after me,
2.26: but now he is eager to see you. He is worried, because you heard he was sick.
2.27: In fact, he was very sick and almost died. But God was kind to him, and also to me, and he kept me from being burdened down with sorrow.
2.28: Now I am more eager than ever to send Epaphroditus back again. You will be glad to see him, and I won't have to worry any longer.
2.29: Be sure to give him a cheerful welcome, just as people who serve the Lord deserve.
2.30: He almost died working for Christ, and he risked his own life to do for me what you could not.

3.1: Finally, my dear friends, be glad that you belong to the Lord. It doesn't bother me to write the same things to you that I have written before. In fact, it is for your own good.
3.2: Watch out for those people who behave like dogs! They are evil and want to do more than just circumcise you.
3.3: But we are the ones who are truly circumcised, because we worship by the power of God's Spirit and take pride in Christ Jesus. We don't brag about what we have done,
3.4: although I could. Others may brag about themselves, but I have more reason to brag than anyone else.
3.5: I was circumcised when I was eight days old, and I am from the nation of Israel and the tribe of Benjamin. I am a true Hebrew. As a Pharisee, I strictly obeyed the Law of Moses.
3.6: And I was so eager I even made trouble for the church. I did everything the Law demands in order to please God.
3.7: But Christ has shown me that what I once thought was valuable is worthless.
3.8: Nothing is as wonderful as knowing Christ Jesus my Lord. I have given up everything else and count it all as garbage. All I want is Christ
3.9: and to know that I belong to him. I could not make myself acceptable to God by obeying the Law of Moses. God accepted me simply because of my faith in Christ.
3.10: All I want is to know Christ and the power that raised him to life. I want to suffer and die as he did,
3.11: so that somehow I also may be raised to life.
3.12: I have not yet reached my goal, and I am not perfect. But Christ has taken hold of me. So I keep on running and struggling to take hold of the prize.
3.13: My friends, I don't feel I have already arrived. But I forget what is behind, and I struggle for what is ahead.
3.14: I run toward the goal, so I can win the prize of being called to heaven. This is the prize God offers because of what Christ Jesus has done.
3.15: All of us who are mature should think in this same way. And if any of you think differently, God will make it clear to you.
3.16: But we must keep going in the direction that we are now headed.
3.17: My friends, I want you to follow my example and learn from others who closely follow the example we set for you.
3.18: I often warned you that many people are living as enemies of the cross of Christ. And now with tears in my eyes, I warn you again
3.19: that they are headed for hell! They worship their stomachs and brag about the disgusting things they do. All they can think about are the things of this world.
3.20: But we are citizens of heaven and are eagerly waiting for our Savior to come from there. Our Lord Jesus Christ
3.21: has power over everything, and he will make these poor bodies of ours like his own glorious body.

4.1: Dear friends, I love you and long to see you. Please keep on being faithful to the Lord. You are my pride and joy.
4.2: Euodia and Syntyche, you belong to the Lord, so I beg you to stop arguing with each other.
4.3: And, my true partner, I ask you to help them. These women have worked together with me and with Clement and with the others in spreading the good news. Their names are now written in the book of life.
4.4: Always be glad because of the Lord! I will say it again: Be glad.
4.5: Always be gentle with others. The Lord will soon be here.
4.6: Don't worry about anything, but pray about everything. With thankful hearts offer up your prayers and requests to God.
4.7: Then, because you belong to Christ Jesus, God will bless you with peace that no one can completely understand. And this peace will control the way you think and feel.
4.8: Finally, my friends, keep your minds on whatever is true, pure, right, holy, friendly, and proper. Don't ever stop thinking about what is truly worthwhile and worthy of praise.
4.9: You know the teachings I gave you, and you know what you heard me say and saw me do. So follow my example. And God, who gives peace, will be with you.
4.10: The Lord has made me very grateful that at last you have thought about me once again. Actually, you were thinking about me all along, but you didn't have any chance to show it.
4.11: I am not complaining about having too little. I have learned to be satisfied with whatever I have.
4.12: I know what it is to be poor or to have plenty, and I have lived under all kinds of conditions. I know what it means to be full or to be hungry, to have too much or too little.
4.13: Christ gives me the strength to face anything.
4.14: It was good of you to help me when I was having such a hard time.
4.15: My friends at Philippi, you remember what it was like when I started preaching the good news in Macedonia. After I left there, you were the only church that became my partner by giving blessings and by receiving them in return.
4.16: Even when I was in Thessalonica, you helped me more than once.
4.17: I am not trying to get something from you, but I want you to receive the blessings that come from giving.
4.18: I have been paid back everything, and with interest. I am completely satisfied with the gifts you sent with Epaphroditus. They are like a sweet-smelling offering or like the right kind of sacrifice that pleases God.
4.19: I pray that God will take care of all your needs with the wonderful blessings that come from Christ Jesus!
4.20: May God our Father be praised forever and ever. Amen.
4.21: Give my greetings to all who are God's people because of Christ Jesus. The Lord's followers here with me send you their greetings.
4.22: All of God's people send their greetings, especially those in the service of the Emperor.
4.23: I pray that our Lord Jesus Christ will be kind to you and will bless your life!

1.1: From Paul, chosen by God to be an apostle of Christ Jesus, and from Timothy, who is also a follower.
1.2: To God's people who live in Colossae and are faithful followers of Christ. I pray that God our Father will be kind to you and will bless you with peace!
1.3: Each time we pray for you, we thank God, the Father of our Lord Jesus Christ.
1.4: We have heard of your faith in Christ and of your love for all God's people,
1.5: because what you hope for is kept safe for you in heaven. You first heard about this hope when you believed the true message, which is the good news.
1.6: The good news is spreading all over the world with great success. It has spread in this same way among you, ever since the first day you learned the truth about God's wonderful kindness
1.7: from our good friend Epaphras. He works together with us for Christ and is a faithful worker for you.
1.8: He is also the one who told us about the love that God's Spirit has given you.
1.9: We have not stopped praying for you since the first day we heard about you. In fact, we always pray that God will show you everything he wants you to do and that you may have all the wisdom and understanding his Spirit gives.
1.10: Then you will live a life that honors the Lord, and you will always please him by doing good deeds. You will come to know God even better.
1.11: His glorious power will make you patient and strong enough to endure anything, and you will be truly happy.
1.12: I pray that you will be grateful to God for letting you have part in what he has promised his people in the kingdom of light.
1.13: God rescued us from the dark power of Satan and brought us into the kingdom of his dear Son,
1.14: who forgives our sins and sets us free.
1.15: Christ is exactly like God, who cannot be seen. He is the first-born Son, superior to all creation.
1.16: Everything was created by him, everything in heaven and on earth, everything seen and unseen, including all forces and powers, and all rulers and authorities. All things were created by God's Son, and everything was made for him.
1.17: God's Son was before all else, and by him everything is held together.
1.18: He is the head of his body, which is the church. He is the very beginning, the first to be raised from death, so that he would be above all others.
1.19: God himself was pleased to live fully in his Son.
1.20: And God was pleased for him to make peace by sacrificing his blood on the cross, so that all beings in heaven and on earth would be brought back to God.
1.21: You used to be far from God. Your thoughts made you his enemies, and you did evil things.
1.22: But his Son became a human and died. So God made peace with you, and now he lets you stand in his presence as people who are holy and faultless and innocent.
1.23: But you must stay deeply rooted and firm in your faith. You must not give up the hope you received when you heard the good news. It was preached to everyone on earth, and I myself have become a servant of this message.
1.24: I am glad I can suffer for you. I am pleased also that in my own body I can continue the suffering of Christ for his body, the church.
1.25: God's plan was to make me a servant of his church and to send me to preach his complete message to you.
1.26: For ages and ages this message was kept secret from everyone, but now it has been explained to God's people.
1.27: God did this because he wanted you Gentiles to understand his wonderful and glorious mystery. And the mystery is that Christ lives in you, and he is your hope of sharing in God's glory.
1.28: We announce the message about Christ, and we use all our wisdom to warn and teach everyone, so all of Christ's followers will grow and become mature.
1.29: This is why I work so hard and use the mighty power he gives me.

2.1: I want you to know what a struggle I am going through for you, for God's people at Laodicea, and for all of those followers who have never met me.
2.2: I do it to encourage them. Then as their hearts are joined together in love, they will be wonderfully blessed with complete understanding. And they will truly know Christ. Not only is he the key to God's mystery,
2.3: but all wisdom and knowledge are hidden away in him.
2.4: I tell you these things to keep you from being fooled by fancy talk.
2.5: Even though I am not with you, I keep thinking about you. I am glad to know that you are living as you should and your faith in Christ is strong.
2.6: You have accepted Christ Jesus as your Lord. Now keep on following him.
2.7: Plant your roots in Christ and let him be the foundation for your life. Be strong in your faith, just as you were taught. And be grateful.
2.8: Don't let anyone fool you by using senseless arguments. These arguments may sound wise, but they are only human teachings. They come from the powers of this world and not from Christ.
2.9: God lives fully in Christ.
2.10: And you are fully grown because you belong to Christ, who is over every power and authority.
2.11: Christ has also taken away your selfish desires, just as circumcision removes flesh from the body.
2.12: And when you were baptized, it was the same as being buried with Christ. Then you were raised to life because you had faith in the power of God, who raised Christ from death.
2.13: You were dead, because you were sinful and were not God's people. But God let Christ make you alive, when he forgave all our sins.
2.14: God wiped out the charges that were against us for disobeying the Law of Moses. He took them away and nailed them to the cross.
2.15: There Christ defeated all powers and forces. He let the whole world see them being led away as prisoners when he celebrated his victory.
2.16: Don't let anyone tell you what you must eat or drink. Don't let them say you must celebrate the New Moon festival, the Sabbath, or any other festival.
2.17: These things are only a shadow of what was to come. But Christ is real!
2.18: Don't be cheated by people who make a show of acting humble and who worship angels. They brag about seeing visions. But it is all nonsense, because their minds are filled with selfish desires.
2.19: They are no longer part of Christ, who is the head of the whole body. Christ gives the body its strength, and he uses its joints and muscles to hold it together, as it grows by the power of God.
2.20: You died with Christ. Now the forces of the universe don't have any power over you. Why do you live as if you had to obey such rules as,
2.22: After these things are used, they are no longer good for anything. So why be bothered with the rules that humans have made up?
2.23: Obeying these rules may seem to be the smart thing to do. They appear to make you love God more and to be very humble and to have control over your body. But they don't really have any power over our desires.

3.1: You have been raised to life with Christ. Now set your heart on what is in heaven, where Christ rules at God's right side.
3.2: Think about what is up there, not about what is here on earth.
3.3: You died, which means that your life is hidden with Christ, who sits beside God.
3.4: Christ gives meaning to your life, and when he appears, you will also appear with him in glory.
3.5: Don't be controlled by your body. Kill every desire for the wrong kind of sex. Don't be immoral or indecent or have evil thoughts. Don't be greedy, which is the same as worshiping idols.
3.6: God is angry with people who disobey him by doing these things.
3.7: And this is exactly what you did, when you lived among people who behaved in this way.
3.8: But now you must stop doing such things. You must quit being angry, hateful, and evil. You must no longer say insulting or cruel things about others.
3.9: And stop lying to each other. You have given up your old way of life with its habits.
3.10: Each of you is now a new person. You are becoming more and more like your Creator, and you will understand him better.
3.11: It doesn't matter if you are a Greek or a Jew, or if you are circumcised or not. You may even be a barbarian or a Scythian, and you may be a slave or a free person. Yet Christ is all that matters, and he lives in all of us.
3.12: God loves you and has chosen you as his own special people. So be gentle, kind, humble, meek, and patient.
3.13: Put up with each other, and forgive anyone who does you wrong, just as Christ has forgiven you.
3.14: Love is more important than anything else. It is what ties everything completely together.
3.15: Each one of you is part of the body of Christ, and you were chosen to live together in peace. So let the peace that comes from Christ control your thoughts. And be grateful.
3.16: Let the message about Christ completely fill your lives, while you use all your wisdom to teach and instruct each other. With thankful hearts, sing psalms, hymns, and spiritual songs to God.
3.17: Whatever you say or do should be done in the name of the Lord Jesus, as you give thanks to God the Father because of him.
3.18: A wife must put her husband first. This is her duty as a follower of the Lord.
3.19: A husband must love his wife and not abuse her.
3.20: Children must always obey their parents. This pleases the Lord.
3.21: Parents, don't be hard on your children. If you are, they might give up.
3.22: Slaves, you must always obey your earthly masters. Try to please them at all times, and not just when you think they are watching. Honor the Lord and serve your masters with your whole heart.
3.23: Do your work willingly, as though you were serving the Lord himself, and not just your earthly master.
3.24: In fact, the Lord Christ is the one you are really serving, and you know he will reward you.
3.25: But Christ has no favorites! He will punish evil people, just as they deserve.

4.1: Slave owners, be fair and honest with your slaves. Don't forget that you have a Master in heaven.
4.2: Never give up praying. And when you pray, keep alert and be thankful.
4.3: Be sure to pray that God will make a way for us to spread his message and explain the mystery about Christ, even though I am in jail for doing this.
4.4: Please pray that I will make the message as clear as possible.
4.5: When you are with unbelievers, always make good use of the time.
4.6: Be pleasant and hold their interest when you speak the message. Choose your words carefully and be ready to give answers to anyone who asks questions.
4.7: Tychicus is the dear friend, who faithfully works and serves the Lord with us, and he will give you the news about me.
4.8: I am sending him to cheer you up by telling you how we are getting along.
4.9: Onesimus, the dear and faithful follower from your own group, is coming with him. The two of them will tell you everything that has happened here.
4.10: Aristarchus is in jail with me. He sends greetings to you, and so does Mark, the cousin of Barnabas. You have already been told to welcome Mark, if he visits you.
4.11: Jesus, who is known as Justus, sends his greetings. These three men are the only Jewish followers who have worked with me for the kingdom of God. They have given me much comfort.
4.12: Your own Epaphras, who serves Christ Jesus, sends his greetings. He always prays hard that you may fully know what the Lord wants you to do and that you may do it completely.
4.13: I have seen how much trouble he has gone through for you and for the followers in Laodicea and Hierapolis.
4.14: Our dear doctor Luke sends you his greetings, and so does Demas.
4.15: Give my greetings to the followers at Laodicea, especially to Nympha and the church that meets in her home.
4.16: After this letter has been read to your people, be sure to have it read in the church at Laodicea. And you should read the letter that I have sent to them.
4.17: Remind Archippus to do the work that the Lord has given him to do.
4.18: I am signing this letter myself: PAUL. Don't forget that I am in jail. I pray that God will be kind to you.

1.1: From Paul, a servant of God and an apostle of Jesus Christ. I encourage God's own people to have more faith and to understand the truth about religion.
1.2: Then they will have the hope of eternal life God promised long ago. And God never tells a lie!
1.3: So, at the proper time, God our Savior gave this message and told me to announce what he had said.
1.4: Titus, because of our faith, you are like a son to me. I pray that God our Father and Christ Jesus our Savior will be kind to you and will bless you with peace!
1.5: I left you in Crete to do what had been left undone and to appoint leaders for the churches in each town. As I told you,
1.6: they must have a good reputation and be faithful in marriage. Their children must be followers of the Lord and not have a reputation for being wild and disobedient.
1.7: Church officials are in charge of God's work, and so they must also have a good reputation. They must not be bossy, quick-tempered, heavy drinkers, bullies, or dishonest in business.
1.8: Instead, they must be friendly to strangers and enjoy doing good things. They must also be sensible, fair, pure, and self-controlled.
1.9: They must stick to the true message they were taught, so their good teaching can help others and correct everyone who opposes it.
1.10: There are many who don't respect authority, and they fool others by talking nonsense. This is especially true of some Jewish followers.
1.11: But you must make them be quiet. They are after money, and they upset whole families by teaching what they should not.
1.13: This surely is a true saying. And you should be hard on such people, so you can help them grow stronger in their faith.
1.14: Don't pay any attention to any of those senseless Jewish stories and human commands. These are made up by people who won't obey the truth.
1.15: Everything is pure for someone whose heart is pure. But nothing is pure for an unbeliever with a dirty mind. That person's mind and conscience are destroyed.
1.16: Such people claim to know God, but their actions prove they really don't. They are disgusting. They won't obey God, and they are too worthless to do anything good.

2.1: Titus, you must teach only what is correct.
2.2: Tell the older men to have self-control and to be serious and sensible. Their faith, love, and patience must never fail.
2.3: Tell the older women to behave as those who love the Lord should. They must not gossip about others or be slaves of wine. They must teach what is proper,
2.4: so the younger women will be loving wives and mothers.
2.5: Each of the younger women must be sensible and kind, as well as a good homemaker, who puts her own husband first. Then no one can say insulting things about God's message.
2.6: Tell the young men to have self-control in everything.
2.7: Always set a good example for others. Be sincere and serious when you teach.
2.8: Use clean language that no one can criticize. Do this, and your enemies will be too ashamed to say anything against you.
2.9: Tell slaves always to please their owners by obeying them in everything. Slaves must not talk back to their owners
2.10: or steal from them. They must be completely honest and trustworthy. Then everyone will show great respect for what is taught about God our Savior.
2.11: God has shown us undeserved grace by coming to save all people.
2.12: He taught us to give up our wicked ways and our worldly desires and to live decent and honest lives in this world.
2.13: We are filled with hope, as we wait for the glorious return of our great God and Savior Jesus Christ.
2.14: He gave himself to rescue us from everything evil and to make our hearts pure. He wanted us to be his own people and to be eager to do right.
2.15: Teach these things, as you use your full authority to encourage and correct people. Make sure you earn everyone's respect.

3.1: Remind your people to obey the rulers and authorities and not to be rebellious. They must always be ready to do something helpful
3.2: and not say cruel things or argue. They should be gentle and kind to everyone.
3.3: We used to be stupid, disobedient, and foolish, as well as slaves of all sorts of desires and pleasures. We were evil and jealous. Everyone hated us, and we hated everyone.
3.4: God our Savior showed us how good and kind he is.
3.5: He saved us because of his mercy, and not because of any good things we have done. God washed us by the power of the Holy Spirit. He gave us new birth and a fresh beginning.
3.6: God sent Jesus Christ our Savior to give us his Spirit.
3.7: Jesus treated us much better than we deserve. He made us acceptable to God and gave us the hope of eternal life.
3.8: This message is certainly true. These teachings are useful and helpful for everyone. I want you to insist that the people follow them, so that all who have faith in God will be sure to do good deeds.
3.9: But don't have anything to do with stupid arguments about ancestors. And stay away from disagreements and quarrels about the Law of Moses. Such arguments are useless and senseless.
3.10: Warn troublemakers once or twice. Then don't have anything else to do with them.
3.11: You know their minds are twisted, and their own sins show how guilty they are.
3.12: I plan to send Artemas or Tychicus to you. After he arrives, please try your best to meet me at Nicopolis. I have decided to spend the winter there.
3.13: When Zenas the lawyer and Apollos get ready to leave, help them as much as you can, so they won't have need of anything.
3.14: Our people should learn to spend their time doing something useful and worthwhile.
3.15: Greetings to you from everyone here. Greet all of our friends who share in our faith. I pray that the Lord will be kind to all of you!

1.1: From Paul, who is in jail for serving Christ Jesus, and from Timothy, who is like a brother because of our faith. Philemon, you work with us and are very dear to us. This letter is to you
1.2: and to the church that meets in your home. It is also to our dear friend Apphia and to Archippus, who serves the Lord as we do.
1.3: I pray that God our Father and our Lord Jesus Christ will be kind to you and will bless you with peace!
1.4: Philemon, each time I mention you in my prayers, I thank God.
1.5: I hear about your faith in our Lord Jesus and about your love for all God's people.
1.6: As you share your faith with others, I pray they may come to know all the blessings Christ has given us.
1.7: My friend, your love has made me happy and has greatly encouraged me. It has also cheered the hearts of God's people.
1.8: Christ gives me the courage to tell you what to do.
1.9: But I would rather ask you to do it simply because of love. Yes, as someone in jail for Christ,
1.10: I beg you to help Onesimus! He is like a son to me because I led him to Christ here in jail.
1.11: Before this, he was useless to you, but now he is useful both to you and to me.
1.12: Sending Onesimus back to you makes me very sad.
1.13: I would like to keep him here with me, where he could take your place in helping me while I am here in prison for preaching the good news.
1.14: But I won't do anything unless you agree to it first. I want your act of kindness to come from your heart, and not be something you feel forced to do.
1.15: Perhaps Onesimus was taken from you for a little while so you could have him back for good,
1.16: but not as a slave. Onesimus is much more than a slave. To me he is a dear friend, but to you he is even more, both as a person and as a follower of the Lord.
1.17: If you consider me a friend because of Christ, then welcome Onesimus as you would welcome me.
1.18: If he has cheated you or owes you anything, charge it to my account.
1.19: With my own hand I write: I, PAUL, WILL PAY YOU BACK. But don't forget you owe me your life.
1.20: My dear friend and follower of Christ our Lord, please cheer me up by doing this for me.
1.21: I am sure you will do all I have asked, and even more.
1.22: Please get a room ready for me. I hope your prayers will be answered, and I can visit you.
1.23: Epaphras is also here in jail for being a follower of Christ Jesus. He sends his greetings,
1.24: and so do Mark, Aristarchus, Demas, and Luke, who work together with me.
1.25: I pray that the Lord Jesus Christ will be kind to you!

1.1: Long ago in many ways and at many times God's prophets spoke his message to our ancestors.
1.2: But now at last, God sent his Son to bring his message to us. God created the universe by his Son, and everything will someday belong to the Son.
1.3: God's Son has all the brightness of God's own glory and is like him in every way. By his own mighty word, he holds the universe together. After the Son had washed away our sins, he sat down at the right side of the glorious God in heaven.
1.4: He had become much greater than the angels, and the name he was given is far greater than any of theirs.
1.5: God has never said to any of the angels, "You are my Son, because today I have become your Father!" Neither has God said to any of them, "I will be his Father, and he will be my Son!"
1.6: When God brings his first-born Son into the world, he commands all of his angels to worship him.
1.7: And when God speaks about the angels, he says, "I change my angels into wind and my servants into flaming fire."
1.8: But God says about his Son, "You are God, and you will rule as King forever! Your royal power brings about justice.
1.9: You loved justice and hated evil, and so I, your God, have chosen you. I appointed you and made you happier than any of your friends."
1.10: The Scriptures also say, "In the beginning, Lord, you were the one who laid the foundation of the earth and created the heavens.
1.11: They will all disappear and wear out like clothes, but you will last forever.
1.12: You will roll them up like a robe and change them like a garment. But you are always the same, and you will live forever."
1.13: God never said to any of the angels, "Sit at my right side until I make your enemies into a footstool for you!"
1.14: Angels are merely spirits sent to serve people who are going to be saved.

2.1: We must give our full attention to what we were told, so we won't drift away.
2.2: The message spoken by angels proved to be true, and all who disobeyed or rejected it were punished as they deserved.
2.3: So if we refuse this great way of being saved, how can we hope to escape? The Lord himself was the first to tell about it, and people who heard the message proved to us that it was true.
2.4: God himself showed that his message was true by working all kinds of powerful miracles and wonders. He also gave his Holy Spirit to anyone he chose to.
2.5: We know that God did not put the future world under the power of angels.
2.6: Somewhere in the Scriptures someone says to God, "What makes you care about us humans? Why are you concerned for weaklings such as we?
2.7: You made us lower than the angels for a while. Yet you have crowned us with glory and honor.
2.8: And you have put everything under our power!" God has put everything under our power and has not left anything out of our power. But we still don't see it all under our control.
2.9: What we do see is Jesus, who for a little while was made lower than the angels. Because of God's gift of undeserved grace, Jesus died for everyone. And now that Jesus has suffered and died, he is crowned with glory and honor!
2.10: Everything belongs to God, and all things were created by his power. So God did the right thing when he made Jesus perfect by suffering, as Jesus led many of God's children to be saved and to share in his glory.
2.11: Jesus and the people he makes holy all belong to the same family. This is why he isn't ashamed to call them his brothers and sisters.
2.12: He even said to God, "I will tell them your name and sing your praises when they come together to worship."
2.13: He also said, "I will trust God." Then he said, "Here I am with the children God has given me."
2.14: We are people of flesh and blood. This is why Jesus became one of us. He died to destroy the devil, who had power over death.
2.15: But he also died to rescue all of us who live each day in fear of dying.
2.16: Jesus clearly did not come to help angels, but he did come to help Abraham's descendants.
2.17: He had to be one of us, so he could serve God as our merciful and faithful high priest and sacrifice himself for the forgiveness of our sins.
2.18: And now that Jesus has suffered and was tempted, he can help anyone else who is tempted.

3.1: My friends, God has chosen you to be his holy people. So think about Jesus, the one we call our apostle and high priest!
3.2: Jesus was faithful to God, who appointed him, just as Moses was faithful in serving all God's people.
3.3: But Jesus deserves more honor than Moses, just as the builder of a house deserves more honor than the house.
3.4: Of course, every house is built by someone, and God is really the one who built everything.
3.5: Moses was a faithful servant and told God's people what would be said in the future.
3.6: But Christ is the Son in charge of God's people. And we are those people, if we keep on being brave and don't lose hope.
3.7: It is just as the Holy Spirit says, "If you hear God's voice today,
3.8: don't be stubborn! Don't rebel like those people who were tested in the desert. *
3.9: For forty years your ancestors tested God and saw the things he did.
3.10: "Then God got tired of them and said, 'You people never show good sense, and you don't understand what I want you to do.'
3.11: God became angry and told the people, 'You will never enter my place of rest!'"
3.12: My friends, watch out! Don't let evil thoughts or doubts make any of you turn from the living God.
3.13: You must encourage one another each day. And you must keep on while there is still a time that can be called "today." If you don't, then sin may fool some of you and make you stubborn.
3.14: We were sure about Christ when we first became his people. So let's hold tightly to our faith until the end.
3.15: The Scriptures say, "If you hear his voice today, don't be stubborn like those who rebelled."
3.16: Who were those people that heard God's voice and rebelled? Weren't they the same ones that came out of Egypt with Moses?
3.17: Who were the people that made God angry for 40 years? Weren't they the ones that sinned and died in the desert?
3.18: And who did God say would never enter his place of rest? Weren't they the ones that disobeyed him?
3.19: We see that those people did not enter the place of rest because they did not have faith.

4.1: The promise to enter the place of rest is still good, and we must take care that none of you miss out.
4.2: We have heard the message, just as they did. But they failed to believe what they heard, and the message did not do them any good.
4.3: Only people who have faith will enter the place of rest. It is just as the Scriptures say, "God became angry and told the people, 'You will never enter my place of rest!'" God said this, even though everything has been ready from the time of creation.
4.4: In fact, somewhere the Scriptures say that by the seventh day, God had finished his work, and so he rested.
4.5: We also read that he later said, "You people will never enter my place of rest!"
4.6: This means that the promise to enter is still good, because those who first heard about it disobeyed and did not enter.
4.7: Much later God told David to make the promise again, just as I have already said, "If you hear his voice today, don't be stubborn!"
4.8: If Joshua had really given the people rest, there would not be any need for God to talk about another day of rest.
4.9: But God has promised us a Sabbath when we will rest, even though it has not yet come.
4.10: On that day God's people will rest from their work, just as God rested from his work.
4.11: We should do our best to enter the place of rest, so none of us will disobey and miss going there, as they did.
4.12: God's word is alive and powerful! It is sharper than any double-edged sword. His word can cut through our spirits and souls and through our joints and marrow, until it discovers the desires and thoughts of our hearts.
4.13: Nothing is hidden from God! He sees through everything, and we will have to tell him the truth.
4.14: We have a great high priest, who has gone into heaven, and he is Jesus the Son of God. This is why we must hold on to what we have said about him.
4.15: Jesus understands every weakness of ours, because he was tempted in every way that we are. But he did not sin!
4.16: So whenever we are in need, we should come bravely before the throne of our merciful God. There we will be treated with undeserved grace, and we will find help.

5.1: Every high priest is appointed to help others by offering gifts and sacrifices to God because of their sins.
5.2: A high priest has weaknesses of his own, and he feels sorry for foolish and sinful people.
5.3: This is why he must offer sacrifices for his own sins and for the sins of others.
5.4: But no one can have the honor of being a high priest simply by wanting to be one. Only God can choose a priest, and God is the one who chose Aaron.
5.5: This is how it was with Christ. He became a high priest, but not just because he wanted the honor of being one. It was God who told him, "You are my Son, because today I have become your Father!"
5.6: In another place, God says, "You are a priest forever just like Melchizedek."
5.7: God had the power to save Jesus from death. And while Jesus was on earth, he begged God with loud crying and tears to save him. He truly worshiped God, and God listened to his prayers.
5.8: Jesus is God's own Son, but still he had to suffer before he could learn what it really means to obey God.
5.9: Suffering made Jesus perfect, and now he can save forever all who obey him.
5.10: This is because God chose him to be a high priest like Melchizedek.
5.11: Much more could be said about this subject. But it is hard to explain, and all of you are slow to understand.
5.12: By now you should have been teachers, but once again you need to be taught the simplest things about what God has said. You need milk instead of solid food.
5.13: People who live on milk are like babies who don't really know what is right.
5.14: Solid food is for mature people who have been trained to know right from wrong.

6.1: We must try to become mature and start thinking about more than just the basic things we were taught about Christ. We shouldn't need to keep talking about why we ought to turn from deeds that bring death and why we ought to have faith in God.
6.2: And we shouldn't need to keep teaching about baptisms or about the laying on of hands or about people being raised from death and the future judgment.
6.3: Let's grow up, if God is willing.
6.7: A field is useful to farmers, if there is enough rain to make good crops grow. In fact, God will bless such a field.
6.8: But land that produces only thornbushes is worthless. It is likely to fall under God's curse, and in the end it will be set on fire.
6.9: My friends, we are talking this way. But we are sure that you are doing those really good things people do when they are being saved.
6.10: God is always fair. He will remember how you helped his people in the past and how you are still helping them. You belong to God, and he won't forget the love you have shown his people.
6.11: We wish each of you would always be eager to show how strong and lasting your hope really is.
6.12: Then you would never be lazy. You would be following the example of those who had faith and were patient until God kept his promise to them.
6.13: No one is greater than God. So he made a promise in his own name when he said to Abraham,
6.14: "I, the Lord, will bless you with many descendants!"
6.15: Then after Abraham had been very patient, he was given what God had promised.
6.16: When anyone wants to settle an argument, they make a vow by using the name of someone or something greater than themselves.
6.17: So when God wanted to prove for certain his promise to his people could not be broken, he made a vow.
6.18: God cannot tell lies! And so his promises and vows are two things that can never be changed. We have run to God for safety. Now his promises should greatly encourage us to take hold of the hope that is right in front of us.
6.19: This hope is like a firm and steady anchor for our souls. In fact, hope reaches behind the curtain and into the most holy place.
6.20: Jesus has gone there ahead of us, and he is our high priest forever, just like Melchizedek.

7.1: Melchizedek was both king of Salem and priest of God Most High. He was the one who went out and gave Abraham his blessing, when Abraham returned from killing the kings.
7.2: Then Abraham gave him a tenth of everything he had. The meaning of the name Melchizedek is "King of Justice." But since Salem means "peace," he is also "King of Peace."
7.3: We are not told he had a father or mother or ancestors or beginning or end. He is like the Son of God and will be a priest forever.
7.4: Notice how great Melchizedek was! Our famous ancestor Abraham gave him a tenth of what he had taken from his enemies.
7.5: The Law teaches that even Abraham's descendants must give a tenth of what they possess. And they are to give this to their own relatives, who are the descendants of Levi and are priests.
7.6: Although Melchizedek wasn't a descendant of Levi, Abraham gave him a tenth of what he had. Then Melchizedek blessed Abraham, who had been given God's promise.
7.7: Everyone agrees a person who gives a blessing is greater than the one who receives the blessing.
7.8: Priests are given a tenth of what people earn. But all priests die, except Melchizedek, and the Scriptures teach that he is alive.
7.9: Levi's descendants are now the ones who receive a tenth from people. We could even say that when Abraham gave Melchizedek a tenth, Levi also gave him a tenth.
7.10: This is because Levi was born later into the family of Abraham, who gave a tenth to Melchizedek.
7.11: Even though the Law of Moses says the priests must be descendants of Levi, those priests cannot make anyone perfect. So there needs to be a priest like Melchizedek, rather than one from the priestly family of Aaron.
7.12: And when the rules for selecting a priest are changed, the Law must also be changed.
7.13: The person we are talking about is our Lord, who came from a tribe that had never had anyone to serve as a priest at the altar.
7.14: Everyone knows he came from the tribe of Judah, and Moses never said priests would come from that tribe.
7.15: All of this becomes clearer, when someone who is like Melchizedek is appointed to be a priest.
7.16: That person wasn't appointed because of his ancestors, but because his life can never end.
7.17: The Scriptures say about him, "You are a priest forever, just like Melchizedek."
7.18: In this way a weak and useless command was put aside,
7.19: because the Law cannot make anything perfect. At the same time, we are given a much better hope, and it can bring us close to God.
7.22: This means that Jesus guarantees us a better agreement with God.
7.23: There have been a lot of other priests, and all of them have died.
7.24: But Jesus will never die, and so he will be a priest forever!
7.25: He is forever able to save the people he leads to God, because he always lives to speak to God for them.
7.26: Jesus is the high priest we need. He is holy and innocent and faultless, and not at all like us sinners. Jesus is honored above all beings in heaven,
7.27: and he is better than any other high priest. Jesus doesn't need to offer sacrifices each day for his own sins and then for the sins of the people. He offered a sacrifice once for all, when he gave himself.
7.28: The Law appoints priests who have weaknesses. But God's promise, which came later than the Law, appoints his Son. And he is the perfect high priest forever.

8.1: What I mean is we have a high priest who sits at the right side of God's great throne in heaven.
8.2: He also serves as the priest in the most holy place inside the real tent there in heaven. This tent of worship was set up by the Lord, not by humans.
8.3: Since all priests must offer gifts and sacrifices, Christ also needed to have something to offer.
8.4: If he were here on earth, he would not be a priest at all, because here the Law appoints other priests to offer sacrifices.
8.5: But the tent where they serve is just a copy and a shadow of the real one in heaven. Before Moses made the tent, he was told, "Be sure to make it exactly like the pattern you were shown on the mountain!"
8.6: Now Christ has been appointed to serve as a priest in a much better way, and he has given us much assurance of a better agreement.
8.7: If the first agreement with God had been all right, there would not have been any need for another one.
8.8: But the Lord found fault with it and said, "I tell you the time will come, when I will make a new agreement with the people of Israel and the people of Judah.
8.9: It won't be like the agreement that I made with their ancestors, when I took them by the hand and led them out of Egypt. They broke their agreement with me, and I stopped caring about them!
8.10: "But now I tell the people of Israel this is my new agreement: 'The time will come when I, the Lord, will write my laws on their minds and hearts. I will be their God, and they will be my people.
8.11: Not one of them will have to teach another to know me, their Lord.' "All of them will know me, no matter who they are.
8.12: I will treat them with kindness, even though they are wicked. I will forget their sins."
8.13: When the Lord talks about a new agreement, he means that the first one is out of date. And anything that is old and useless will soon disappear.

9.1: The first promise included rules for worship and a tent for worship here on earth.
9.2: The first part of the tent was called the holy place, and a lampstand, a table, and the sacred loaves of bread were kept there.
9.3: Behind the curtain was the most holy place.
9.4: The gold altar for burning incense was in this holy place. The gold-covered sacred chest was also there, and inside it were three things. First, there was a gold jar filled with manna. Then there was Aaron's walking stick that sprouted. Finally, there were the flat stones with the Ten Commandments written on them.
9.5: On top of the chest were the glorious creatures with wings opened out above the place of mercy. Now isn't the time to go into detail about these things.
9.6: But this is how everything was when the priests went each day into the first part of the tent to do their duties.
9.7: However, only the high priest could go into the second part of the tent, and he went in only once a year. Each time he carried blood to offer for his sins and for any sins that the people had committed without meaning to.
9.8: All of this is the Holy Spirit's way of saying no one could enter the most holy place while the tent was still the place of worship.
9.9: This also has a meaning for today. It shows we cannot make our consciences clear by offering gifts and sacrifices.
9.10: These rules are merely about such things as eating and drinking and ceremonies for washing ourselves. And rules about physical things will last only until the time comes to change them for something better.
9.11: Christ came as the high priest of the good things that are now here. He also went into a much better tent that wasn't made by humans and that doesn't belong to this world.
9.12: Then Christ went once for all into the most holy place and freed us from sin forever. He did this by offering his own blood instead of the blood of goats and bulls.
9.13: According to the Law of Moses, those people who become unclean are not fit to worship God. Yet they will be considered clean, if they are sprinkled with the blood of goats and bulls and with the ashes of a sacrificed calf.
9.14: But Christ was sinless, and he offered himself as an eternal and spiritual sacrifice to God. This is why his blood is much more powerful and makes our consciences clear. Now we can serve the living God and no longer do things that lead to death.
9.15: Christ died to rescue those who had sinned and broken the old agreement. Now he brings his chosen ones a new agreement with its guarantee of God's eternal blessings!
9.16: In fact, making an agreement of this kind is like writing a will. This is because the one who makes the will must die before it is of any use.
9.17: In other words, a will doesn't go into effect as long as the one who made it is still alive.
9.18: Blood was also used to put the first agreement into effect.
9.19: Moses told the people all the Law said they must do. Then he used red wool and a hyssop plant to sprinkle the people and the book of the Law with the blood of bulls and goats and with water.
9.20: He told the people, "With this blood God makes his agreement with you."
9.21: Moses also sprinkled blood on the tent and on everything else used in worship.
9.22: The Law says that almost everything must be sprinkled with blood, and no sins can be forgiven unless blood is offered.
9.23: These things are only copies of what is in heaven, and so they had to be made holy by these ceremonies. But the real things in heaven must be made holy by something better.
9.24: This is why Christ did not go into a tent made by humans and was only a copy of the real one. Instead, he went into heaven and is now there with God to help us.
9.25: Christ did not have to offer himself many times. He wasn't like a high priest who goes into the most holy place each year to offer the blood of an animal.
9.26: If he had offered himself every year, he would have suffered many times since the creation of the world. But instead, near the end of time he offered himself once and for all, so he could be a sacrifice that does away with sin.
9.27: We die only once, and then we are judged.
9.28: So Christ died only once to take away the sins of many people. But when he comes again, it will not be to take away sin. He will come to save everyone who is waiting for him.

10.1: The Law of Moses is like a shadow of the good things to come. This shadow isn't the good things themselves, because it cannot free people from sin by the sacrifices offered year after year.
10.2: If there were worshipers who already have their sins washed away and their consciences made clear, there would not be any need to go on offering sacrifices.
10.5: When Christ came into the world, he said to God, "Sacrifices and offerings are not what you want, but you have given me my body.
10.6: No, you are not pleased with animal sacrifices and offerings for sin."
10.7: Then Christ said, "And so, my God, I have come to do what you want, as the Scriptures say."
10.8: The Law teaches that offerings and sacrifices must be made because of sin. But why did Christ mention these things and say that God did not want them?
10.9: Well, it was to do away with offerings and sacrifices and to replace them. This is what he meant by saying to God, "I have come to do what you want."
10.10: So we are made holy because Christ obeyed God and offered himself once for all.
10.11: The priests do their work each day, and they keep on offering sacrifices that can never take away sins.
10.12: But Christ offered himself as a sacrifice that is good forever. Now he is sitting at God's right side,
10.13: and he will stay there until his enemies are put under his power.
10.14: By his one sacrifice he has forever set free from sin the people he brings to God.
10.15: The Holy Spirit also speaks of this by telling us that the Lord said,
10.16: "When the time comes, I will make an agreement with them. I will write my laws on their minds and hearts.
10.17: Then I will forget about their sins and no longer remember their evil deeds."
10.18: When sins are forgiven, there is no more need to offer sacrifices.
10.19: My friends, the blood of Jesus gives us courage to enter the most holy place
10.20: by a new way that leads to life! And this way takes us through the curtain that is Christ himself.
10.21: We have a great high priest who is in charge of God's house.
10.22: So let's come near God with pure hearts and a confidence that comes from having faith. Let's keep our hearts pure, our consciences free from evil, and our bodies washed with clean water.
10.23: We must hold tightly to the hope we say is ours. After all, we can trust the one who made the agreement with us.
10.24: We should keep on encouraging each other to be thoughtful and to do helpful things.
10.25: Some people have given up the habit of meeting for worship, but we must not do that. We should keep on encouraging each other, especially since you know that the day of the Lord's coming is getting closer.
10.26: No sacrifices can be made for people who decide to sin after they find out about the truth.
10.27: They are God's enemies, and all they can look forward to is a terrible judgment and a furious fire.
10.28: If two or more witnesses accused someone of breaking the Law of Moses, that person could be put to death.
10.29: But it is much worse to dishonor God's Son and to disgrace the blood of the promise that made us holy. And it is just as bad to insult the Holy Spirit, who shows us mercy.
10.30: We know that God has said he will punish and take revenge. We also know that the Scriptures say the Lord will judge his people.
10.31: It is a terrible thing to fall into the hands of the living God!
10.32: Don't forget all the hard times you went through when you first received the light.
10.33: Sometimes you were abused and mistreated in public, and at other times you shared in the sufferings of others.
10.34: You were kind to people in jail. And you gladly let your possessions be taken away, because you knew you had something better, something that would last forever.
10.35: Keep on being brave! It will bring you great rewards.
10.36: Learn to be patient, so you will please God and be given what he has promised.
10.37: As the Scriptures say, "God is coming soon! It won't be very long.
10.38: The people God accepts will live because of their faith. But he isn't pleased with anyone who turns back."
10.39: We are not like those people who turn back and get destroyed. We will keep on having faith until we are saved.

11.1: Faith makes us sure of what we hope for and gives us proof of what we cannot see.
11.2: It was their faith that made our ancestors pleasing to God.
11.3: Because of our faith, we know that the world was made at God's command. We also know that what can be seen was made out of what cannot be seen.
11.4: Because Abel had faith, he offered God a better sacrifice than Cain did. God was pleased with him and his gift, and even though Abel is now dead, his faith still speaks for him.
11.5: Enoch had faith and did not die. He pleased God, and God took him up to heaven. This is why his body was never found.
11.6: But without faith no one can please God. We must believe that God is real and rewards everyone who searches for him.
11.7: Because Noah had faith, he was warned about something that had not yet happened. He obeyed and built a boat that saved him and his family. In this way the people of the world were judged, and Noah was given the blessings that come to everyone who pleases God.
11.8: Abraham had faith and obeyed God. He was told to go to the land that God had said would be his, and he left for a country he had never seen.
11.9: Because Abraham had faith, he lived as a stranger in the promised land. He lived there in a tent, and so did Isaac and Jacob, who were later given the same promise.
11.10: Abraham did this, because he was waiting for the eternal city God had planned and built.
11.11: Even when Sarah was too old to have children, she had faith that God would do what he had promised, and she had a son.
11.12: Her husband Abraham was almost dead, but he became the ancestor of many people. In fact, there are as many of them as there are stars in the sky or grains of sand along the seashore.
11.13: Every one of those people died. But they still had faith, even though they had not received what they had been promised. They were glad just to see these things from far away, and they agreed that they were only strangers and foreigners on this earth.
11.14: When people talk this way, it is clear they are looking for a place to call their own.
11.15: If they had been talking about the land where they had once lived, they could have gone back at any time.
11.16: But they were looking forward to a better home in heaven. This is why God wasn't ashamed for them to call him their God. He even built a city for them.
11.19: because he was sure that God could raise people to life. This was just like getting Isaac back from death.
11.20: Isaac had faith, and he promised blessings to Jacob and Esau.
11.21: Later, when Jacob was about to die, he leaned on his walking stick and worshiped. Then because of his faith he blessed each of Joseph's sons.
11.22: And right before Joseph died, he had faith that God would lead the people of Israel out of Egypt. So he told them to take his bones with them.
11.23: Because Moses' parents had faith, they kept him hidden until he was three months old. They saw that he was a beautiful child, and they were not afraid to disobey the king's orders.
11.24: Then after Moses grew up, his faith made him refuse to be called the king's grandson.
11.25: He chose to be mistreated with God's people instead of having the good time that sin could bring for a little while.
11.26: Moses knew that the treasures of Egypt were not as wonderful as what he would receive from suffering for the Messiah, and he looked forward to his reward.
11.27: Because of his faith, Moses left Egypt. Moses had seen the invisible God and wasn't afraid of the king's anger.
11.28: His faith also made him celebrate Passover. He sprinkled the blood of animals on the doorposts, so that the first-born sons of the people of Israel would not be killed by the destroying angel.
11.29: Because of their faith, the people walked through the Red Sea on dry land. But when the Egyptians tried to do it, they were drowned.
11.30: God's people had faith, and when they had walked around the city of Jericho for seven days, its walls fell down.
11.31: Rahab had been a prostitute, but she had faith and welcomed the spies. So she wasn't killed with the people who disobeyed.
11.32: What else can I say? There isn't enough time to tell about Gideon, Barak, Samson, Jephthah, David, Samuel, and the prophets.
11.33: Their faith helped them conquer kingdoms, and because they did right, God made promises to them. They closed the jaws of lions
11.34: and put out raging fires and escaped from the swords of their enemies. Although they were weak, they were given the strength and power to chase foreign armies away.
11.35: Some women received their loved ones back from death. Many of these people were tortured, but they refused to be released. They were sure they would get a better reward when the dead are raised to life.
11.36: Others were made fun of and beaten with whips, and some were chained in jail.
11.37: Still others were stoned to death or sawed in two or killed with swords. Some had nothing but sheep skins or goat skins to wear. They were poor, mistreated, and tortured.
11.38: The world did not deserve these good people, who had to wander in deserts and on mountains and had to live in caves and holes in the ground.
11.39: All of them pleased God because of their faith! But still they died without being given what had been promised.
11.40: This was because God had something better in store for us. And he did not want them to reach the goal of their faith without us.

12.1: Such a large crowd of witnesses is all around us! So we must get rid of everything that slows us down, especially the sin that just won't let go. And we must be determined to run the race that is ahead of us.
12.2: We must keep our eyes on Jesus, who leads us and makes our faith complete. He endured the shame of being nailed to a cross, because he knew later on he would be glad he did. Now he is seated at the right side of God's throne!
12.3: So keep your mind on Jesus, who put up with many insults from sinners. Then you won't get discouraged and give up.
12.4: None of you have yet been hurt in your battle against sin.
12.5: But you have forgotten that the Scriptures say to God's children, "When the Lord punishes you, don't make light of it, and when he corrects you, don't be discouraged.
12.6: The Lord corrects the people he loves and disciplines those he calls his own."
12.7: Be patient when you are being corrected! This is how God treats his children. Don't all parents correct their children?
12.8: God corrects all his children, and if he doesn't correct you, then you don't really belong to him.
12.9: Our earthly fathers correct us, and we still respect them. Isn't it even better to be given true life by letting our spiritual Father correct us?
12.10: Our human fathers correct us for a short time, and they do it as they think best. But God corrects us for our own good, because he wants us to be holy, as he is.
12.11: It is never fun to be corrected. In fact, at the time it is always painful. But if we learn to obey by being corrected, we will do right and live at peace.
12.12: Now stand up straight! Stop your knees from shaking
12.13: and walk a straight path. Then lame people will be healed, instead of getting worse.
12.14: Try to live at peace with everyone! Live a clean life. If you don't, you will never see the Lord.
12.15: Make sure no one misses out on God's wonderful kindness. Don't let anyone become bitter and cause trouble for the rest of you.
12.16: Watch out for immoral and ungodly people like Esau, who sold his future blessing for only one meal.
12.17: You know how he later wanted it back. But there was nothing he could do to change things, even though he begged his father and cried.
12.18: You have not come to a place like Mount Sinai that can be seen and touched. There is no flaming fire or dark cloud or storm
12.19: or trumpet sound. The people of Israel heard a voice speak. But they begged it to stop,
12.20: because they could not obey its commands. They were even told to kill any animal that touched the mountain.
12.21: The sight was so frightening that Moses said he shook with fear.
12.22: You have now come to Mount Zion and to the heavenly Jerusalem. This is the city of the living God, where thousands and thousands of angels have come to celebrate.
12.23: Here you will find all of God's dearest children, whose names are written in heaven. And you will find God himself, who judges everyone. Here also are the spirits of those good people who have been made perfect.
12.24: And Jesus is here! He is the one who makes God's new agreement with us, and his sprinkled blood says much better things than the blood of Abel.
12.25: Make sure you obey the one who speaks to you. The people did not escape, when they refused to obey the one who spoke to them at Mount Sinai. Do you think you can possibly escape, if you refuse to obey the one who speaks to you from heaven?
12.26: When God spoke the first time, his voice shook only the earth. This time he has promised to shake the earth once again, and heaven too.
12.27: The words "once again" mean that these created things will someday be shaken and removed. Then what cannot be shaken will last.
12.28: We should be grateful we were given a kingdom that cannot be shaken. And in this kingdom we please God by worshiping him and by showing him great honor and respect.
12.29: Our God is like a destructive fire!

13.1: Keep being concerned about each other as the Lord's followers should.
13.2: Be sure to welcome strangers into your home. By doing this, some people have welcomed angels as guests, without even knowing it.
13.3: Remember the Lord's people who are in jail and be concerned for them. Don't forget those who are suffering, but imagine you are there with them.
13.4: Have respect for marriage. Always be faithful to your partner, because God will punish anyone who is immoral or unfaithful in marriage.
13.5: Don't fall in love with money. Be satisfied with what you have. The Lord has promised that he will not leave us or desert us.
13.6: This should make you feel like saying, "The Lord helps me! Why should I be afraid of what people can do to me?"
13.7: Don't forget about your leaders who taught you God's message. Remember what kind of lives they lived and try to have faith like theirs.
13.8: Jesus Christ never changes! He is the same yesterday, today, and forever.
13.9: Don't be fooled by any kind of strange teachings. It is better to receive strength from God's gift of undeserved grace than to depend on certain foods. After all, these foods don't really help the people who eat them.
13.10: But we have an altar where even the priests who serve in the place of worship have no right to eat.
13.11: After the high priest offers the blood of animals as a sin offering, the bodies of those animals are burned outside the camp.
13.12: Jesus himself suffered outside the city gate, so his blood would make people holy.
13.13: This is why we should go outside the camp to Jesus and share in his disgrace.
13.14: On this earth we don't have a city that lasts forever, but we are waiting for such a city.
13.15: Our sacrifice is to keep offering praise to God in the name of Jesus.
13.16: But don't forget to help others and to share your possessions with them. This too is like offering a sacrifice that pleases God.
13.17: Obey your leaders and do what they say. They are watching over you, and they must answer to God. So don't make them sad as they do their work. Make them happy. Otherwise, they won't be able to help you at all.
13.18: Pray for us. Our consciences are clear, and we always try to live right.
13.19: I especially want you to pray that I can visit you again soon.
13.20: God gives peace, and he raised our Lord Jesus Christ from death. Now Jesus is like a Great Shepherd whose blood was used to make God's eternal agreement with his flock.
13.21: I pray God will make you ready to obey him and that you will always be eager to do right. May Jesus help you do what pleases God. To Jesus Christ be glory forever and ever! Amen.
13.22: My friends, I have written only a short letter to encourage you, and I beg you to pay close attention to what I have said.
13.23: By now you surely must know that our friend Timothy is out of jail. If he gets here in time, I will bring him with me when I come to visit you.
