15.2: "When the Israelites were on their way out of Egypt, the nation of Amalek attacked them. I am the LORD All-Powerful, and now I am going to make Amalek pay!
15.3: "Go and attack the Amalekites! Destroy them and all their possessions. Don't have any pity. Kill their men, women, children, and even their babies. Slaughter their cattle, sheep, camels, and donkeys."
15.4: Saul sent messengers who told every town and village to send men to join the army at Telaim. There were 210,000 troops in all, and 10,000 of these were from Judah. Saul organized them,
15.5: then led them to a valley near one of the towns in Amalek, where they got ready to make a surprise attack.
15.6: Some Kenites lived nearby, and Saul told them, "Your people were kind to our nation when we left Egypt, and I don't want you to get killed when I wipe out the Amalekites. So stay away from them." The Kenites left,
15.7: and Saul attacked the Amalekites from Havilah to Shur, which is just east of Egypt.
15.8: Every Amalekite was killed except King Agag.
15.9: Saul and his army let Agag live, and they also spared the best sheep and cattle. They didn't want to destroy anything of value, so they only killed the animals that were worthless or weak.
15.10: The LORD told Samuel,
15.11: "Saul has stopped obeying me, and I'm sorry that I made him king." Samuel was angry, and he cried out in prayer to the LORD all night.
15.12: Early the next morning he went to talk with Saul. Someone told him, "Saul went to Carmel, where he had a monument built so everyone would remember his victory. Then he left for Gilgal."
15.13: Samuel finally caught up with Saul, and Saul told him, "I hope the LORD will bless you! I have done what the LORD told me."
15.14: "Then why," Samuel asked, "do I hear sheep and cattle?"
15.15: "The army took them from the Amalekites," Saul explained. "They kept the best sheep and cattle, so they could sacrifice them to the LORD your God. But we destroyed everything else."
15.16: "Stop!" Samuel said. "Let me tell you what the LORD told me last night." "All right," Saul answered.
15.18: When the LORD sent you on this mission, he told you to wipe out those worthless Amalekites.
15.19: Why didn't you listen to the LORD? Why did you keep the animals and make him angry?"
15.21: All the animals were going to be destroyed anyway. That's why the army brought the best sheep and cattle to Gilgal as sacrifices to the LORD your God."
15.22: "Tell me," Samuel said. "Does the LORD really want sacrifices and offerings? No! He doesn't want your sacrifices. He wants you to obey him.
15.23: Rebelling against God or disobeying him because you are proud is just as bad as worshiping idols or asking them for advice. You refused to do what God told you, so God has decided that you can no longer be king."
15.24: "I have sinned," Saul admitted. "I disobeyed both you and the LORD. I was afraid of the army, and I listened to them instead.
15.25: Please forgive me and come back with me so I can worship the LORD."
15.26: "No!" Samuel replied, "You disobeyed the LORD, and I won't go back with you. Now the LORD has said that you can't be king of Israel any longer."
15.27: As Samuel turned to go, Saul grabbed the edge of Samuel's robe. It tore!
15.28: Samuel said, "The LORD has torn the kingdom of Israel away from you today, and he will give it to someone who is better than you.
15.29: Besides, the eternal God of Israel isn't a human being. He doesn't tell lies or change his mind."
15.30: Saul said, "I did sin, but please honor me in front of the leaders of the army and the people of Israel. Come back with me, so I can worship the LORD your God."
15.31: Samuel followed Saul back, and Saul worshiped the LORD.
15.34: Samuel went home to Ramah, and Saul returned to his home in Gibeah.
15.35: Even though Samuel felt sad about Saul, Samuel never saw him again. The LORD was sorry he had made Saul the king of Israel.

16.1: One day he said, "Samuel, I've rejected Saul, and I refuse to let him be king any longer. Stop feeling sad about him. Put some olive oil in a small container and go visit a man named Jesse, who lives in Bethlehem. I've chosen one of his sons to be my king."
16.2: Samuel answered, "If I do that, Saul will find out and have me killed." "Take a calf with you," the LORD replied. "Tell everyone that you've come to offer it as a sacrifice to me,
16.3: then invite Jesse to the sacrifice. When I show you which one of his sons I have chosen, pour the olive oil on his head."
16.5: "Yes, it is!" Samuel answered. "I've come to offer a sacrifice to the LORD. Get yourselves ready to take part in the sacrifice and come with me." Samuel also invited Jesse and his sons to come to the sacrifice, and he got them ready to take part.
16.6: When Jesse and his sons arrived, Samuel noticed Jesse's oldest son, Eliab. "He has to be the one the LORD has chosen," Samuel said to himself.
16.8: Jesse told his son Abinadab to go over to Samuel, but Samuel said, "No, the LORD hasn't chosen him."
16.9: Next, Jesse sent his son Shammah to him, and Samuel said, "The LORD hasn't chosen him either."
16.10: One by one, Jesse told all seven of his sons to go over to Samuel. Finally, Samuel said, "Jesse, the LORD hasn't chosen any of these young men.
16.13: Samuel poured the oil on David's head while his brothers watched. At that moment, the Spirit of the LORD took control of David and stayed with him from then on. Samuel returned home to Ramah.
16.14: The Spirit of the LORD had left Saul, and an evil spirit from the LORD was terrifying him.
16.15: "It's an evil spirit from God that's frightening you," Saul's officials told him.
16.16: "Your Majesty, let us go and look for someone who is good at playing the harp. He can play for you whenever the evil spirit from God bothers you, and you'll feel better."
16.18: "A man named Jesse who lives in Bethlehem has a son who can play the harp," one official said. "He's a brave warrior, he's good-looking, he can speak well, and the LORD is with him."
16.19: Saul sent a message to Jesse: "Tell your son David to leave your sheep and come here to me."
16.20: Jesse loaded a donkey with bread and a goatskin full of wine, then he told David to take the donkey and a young goat to Saul.
16.21: David went to Saul and started working for him. Saul liked him so much that he put David in charge of carrying his weapons.
16.22: Not long after this, Saul sent another message to Jesse: "I really like David. Please let him stay with me."
16.23: Whenever the evil spirit from God bothered Saul, David would play his harp. Saul would relax and feel better, and the evil spirit would go away.

17.1: The Philistines got ready for war and brought their troops together to attack the town of Socoh in Judah. They set up camp at Ephes-Dammim, between Socoh and Azekah.
17.4: The Philistine army had a hero named Goliath who was from the town of Gath and was about three meters tall.
17.7: and his spear was so big that the iron spearhead alone weighed about seven kilograms. A soldier always walked in front of Goliath to carry his shield.
17.8: Goliath went out and shouted to the army of Israel: Why are you lining up for battle? I'm the best soldier in our army, and all of you are in Saul's army. Choose your best soldier to come out and fight me!
17.9: If he can kill me, our people will be your slaves. But if I kill him, your people will be our slaves.
17.10: Here and now I challenge Israel's whole army! Choose someone to fight me!
17.11: Saul and his men heard what Goliath said, but they were so frightened of Goliath that they couldn't do a thing.
17.12: David's father Jesse was an old man, who belonged to the Ephrath clan and lived in Bethlehem in Judah. Jesse had eight sons:
17.15: He took care of his father's sheep, and he went back and forth between Bethlehem and Saul's camp.
17.16: Goliath came out and gave his challenge every morning and every evening for 40 days.
17.17: One day, Jesse told David, "Hurry and take this sack of roasted grain and these ten loaves of bread to your brothers at the army camp.
17.18: And here are ten large chunks of cheese to take to their commanding officer. Find out how your brothers are doing and bring back something that shows that they're all right.
17.19: They're with Saul's army, fighting the Philistines in Elah Valley."
17.20: David obeyed his father. He got up early the next morning and left someone else in charge of the sheep; then he loaded the supplies and started off. He reached the army camp just as the soldiers were taking their places and shouting the battle cry.
17.21: The army of Israel and the Philistine army stood there facing each other.
17.22: David left his things with the man in charge of supplies and ran up to the battle line to ask his brothers if they were well.
17.23: While David was talking with them, Goliath came out from the line of Philistines and started boasting as usual. David heard him.
17.24: When the Israelite soldiers saw Goliath, they were scared and ran off.
17.26: David asked some soldiers standing nearby, "What will a man get for killing this Philistine and stopping him from insulting our people? Who does that worthless Philistine think he is? He's making fun of the army of the living God!"
17.27: The soldiers told David what the king would give the man who killed Goliath.
17.28: David's oldest brother Eliab heard him talking with the soldiers. Eliab was angry with him and said, "What are you doing here, anyway? Who's taking care of your little flock of sheep out in the desert? You spoiled brat! You came here just to watch the fighting, didn't you?"
17.29: "Now what have I done?" David answered. "Can't I even ask a question?"
17.30: Then he turned and asked another soldier the same thing he had asked the others, and he got the same answer.
17.31: Some soldiers overheard David talking, so they told Saul what David had said. Saul sent for David, and David came.
17.32: "Your Majesty," he said, "this Philistine shouldn't turn us into cowards. I'll go out and fight him myself!"
17.33: "You don't have a chance against him," Saul replied. "You're only a boy, and he's been a soldier all his life."
17.34: But David told him: Your Majesty, I take care of my father's sheep. And when one of them is dragged off by a lion or a bear,
17.35: I go after it and beat the wild animal until it lets the sheep go. If the wild animal turns and attacks me, I grab it by the throat and kill it.
17.36: Sir, I have killed lions and bears that way, and I can kill this worthless Philistine. He shouldn't have made fun of the army of the living God!
17.37: The LORD has rescued me from the claws of lions and bears, and he will keep me safe from the hands of this Philistine. "All right," Saul answered, "go ahead and fight him. And I hope the LORD will help you."
17.38: Saul had his own military clothes and armor put on David, and he gave David a bronze helmet to wear.
17.39: David strapped on a sword and tried to walk around, but he was not used to wearing those things. "I can't move with all this stuff on," David said. "I'm just not used to it." David took off the armor
17.40: and picked up his shepherd's stick. He went out to a stream and picked up five smooth rocks and put them in his leather bag. Then with his sling in his hand, he went straight toward Goliath.
17.41: Goliath came toward David, walking behind the soldier who was carrying his shield.
17.42: When Goliath saw that David was just a healthy, good-looking boy, he made fun of him.
17.45: David answered: You've come out to fight me with a sword and a spear and a dagger. But I've come out to fight you in the name of the LORD All-Powerful. He is the God of Israel's army, and you have insulted him too!
17.46: Today the LORD will help me defeat you. I'll knock you down and cut off your head, and I'll feed the bodies of the other Philistine soldiers to the birds and wild animals. Then the whole world will know that Israel has a real God.
17.47: Everybody here will see that the LORD doesn't need swords or spears to save his people. The LORD always wins his battles, and he will help us defeat you.
17.48: When Goliath started forward, David ran toward him.
17.49: He put a rock in his sling and swung the sling around by its straps. When he let go of one strap, the rock flew out and hit Goliath on the forehead. It cracked his skull, and he fell facedown on the ground.
17.50: David defeated Goliath with a sling and a rock. He killed him without even using a sword.
17.51: David ran over and pulled out Goliath's sword. Then he used it to cut off Goliath's head. When the Philistines saw what had happened to their hero, they started running away.
17.52: But the soldiers of Israel and Judah let out a battle cry and went after them as far as Gath and Ekron. The bodies of the Philistines were scattered all along the road from Shaaraim to Gath and Ekron.
17.53: When the Israelite army returned from chasing the Philistines, they took what they wanted from the enemy camp.
17.54: David took Goliath's head to Jerusalem, but he kept Goliath's weapons in his own tent.
17.57: When David came back from fighting Goliath, he was still carrying Goliath's head. Abner took David to Saul,
17.58: and Saul asked, "Who are you?" "I am David the son of Jesse, a loyal Israelite from Bethlehem."

18.1: David and Saul finished talking, and soon David and Jonathan became best friends. Jonathan thought as much of David as he did of himself.
18.2: From that time on, Saul kept David in his service and would not let David go back to his own family.
18.3: Jonathan liked David so much that they promised to always be loyal friends.
18.4: Jonathan took off the robe that he was wearing and gave it to David. He also gave him his military clothes, his sword, his bow and arrows, and his belt.
18.5: David was a success in everything that Saul sent him to do, and Saul made him a high officer in his army. That pleased everyone, including Saul's other officers.
18.6: David had killed Goliath, the battle was over, and the Israelite army set out for home. As the army went along, women came out of each Israelite town to welcome King Saul. They were celebrating by singing songs and dancing to the music of tambourines and harps.
18.7: They sang: Saul has killed a thousand enemies; David has killed ten thousand!
18.10: The next day the LORD let an evil spirit take control of Saul, and he began acting like a crazy man inside his house. David came to play the harp for Saul as usual, but this time Saul had a spear in his hand.
18.11: Saul thought, "I'll pin David to the wall." He threw the spear at David twice, but David dodged and got away both times.
18.12: Saul was afraid of David, because the LORD was helping David and was no longer helping him.
18.13: Saul put David in charge of 1,000 soldiers and sent him out to fight.
18.14: The LORD helped David, and he and his soldiers always won their battles.
18.15: This made Saul even more afraid of David.
18.16: But everyone else in Judah and Israel was loyal to David, because he led the army in battle.
18.17: One day, Saul told David, "If you'll be brave and fight the LORD's battles for me, I'll let you marry my oldest daughter Merab." But Saul was really thinking, "I don't want to kill David myself, so I'll let the Philistines do it for me."
18.18: David answered, "How could I possibly marry your daughter? I'm not very important, and neither is my family."
18.19: But when the time came for David to marry Saul's daughter Merab, Saul told her to marry Adriel from the town of Meholah.
18.20: Saul had another daughter. Her name was Michal, and Saul found out that she was in love with David. This made Saul happy,
18.21: and he thought, "I'll tell David he can marry Michal, but I'll set it up so that the Philistines will kill him." He told David, "I'm going to give you a second chance to marry one of my daughters."
18.24: The officials went back to Saul and told him exactly what David had said.
18.25: Saul was hoping that the Philistines would kill David, and he told his officials to tell David, "The king doesn't want any silver or gold. He only wants to get even with his enemies. All you have to do is to bring back proof that you have killed 100 Philistines!"
18.26: The officials told David, and David wanted to marry the princess. King Saul had set a time limit, and before it ran out,
18.27: David and his men left and killed 200 Philistines. David brought back the proof that Saul had demanded and showed it to him, so he could marry Michal. Saul agreed to let David marry Michal.
18.28: King Saul knew that she loved David, and he also realized that the LORD was helping David.
18.29: But knowing those things made Saul even more afraid of David, and he was David's enemy for the rest of his life.
18.30: The Philistine rulers kept coming to fight Israel, but whenever David fought them, he won. He was famous because he won more battles against the Philistines than any of Saul's other officers.

19.1: One day, Saul told his son Jonathan and his officers to kill David. But Jonathan and David were best friends,
19.7: Jonathan went to David and told him what Saul had said. Then he brought David to Saul, and David served in Saul's army just as he had done before.
19.8: The next time there was a war with the Philistines, David fought hard and forced them to retreat.
19.11: Saul sent guards to watch David's house all night and then to kill him in the morning. Michal, David's wife, told him, "If you don't escape tonight, they'll kill you tomorrow!"
19.12: She helped David leave through a window and climb down to the ground. As David ran off,
19.13: Michal put a statue in his bed. She put goat hair on its head and dressed it in some of David's clothes.
19.14: The next morning, Saul sent guards to arrest David. But Michal told them, "David is sick."
19.16: When the guards went in, all they found in the bed was the statue with the goat hair on its head.
19.17: "Why have you tricked me this way?" Saul asked Michal. "You helped my enemy get away!" She answered, "He said he would kill me if I didn't help him escape!"
19.18: Meanwhile, David went to Samuel at Ramah and told him what Saul had done. Then Samuel and David went to Prophets Village and stayed there.
19.20: Saul sent a few soldiers to bring David back. They went to Ramah and found Samuel in charge of a group of prophets who were all prophesying. Then the Spirit of God took control of the soldiers and they started prophesying too.
19.21: When Saul heard what had happened, he sent some more soldiers, but they prophesied just like the first group. He sent a third group of soldiers, but the same thing happened to them.
19.23: Saul left for Ramah. But as he walked along, the Spirit of God took control of him, and he started prophesying. Then, when he reached Prophets Village,
19.24: he stripped off his clothes and prophesied in front of Samuel. He dropped to the ground and lay there naked all that day and night. That's how the saying started, "Is Saul now a prophet?"

20.1: David escaped from Prophets Village. Then he ran to see Jonathan and asked, "Why does your father Saul want to kill me? What have I done wrong?"
20.2: "My father can't be trying to kill you! He never does anything without telling me about it. Why would he hide this from me? It can't be true!"
20.4: Then Jonathan said, "Tell me what to do, and I'll do it."
20.5: David answered: Tomorrow is the New Moon Festival, and I'm supposed to eat dinner with your father. But instead, I'll hide in a field until the evening of the next day.
20.7: If your father says it's all right, then I'm safe. But if he gets angry, you'll know he wants to harm me.
20.8: Be kind to me. After all, it was your idea to promise the LORD that we would always be loyal friends. If I've done anything wrong, kill me yourself, but don't hand me over to your father.
20.9: "Don't worry," Jonathan said. "If I find out that my father wants to kill you, I'll certainly let you know."
20.10: "How will you do that?" David asked.
20.12: Jonathan said: I swear by the LORD God of Israel, that two days from now I'll know what my father is planning. Of course I'll let you know if he's friendly toward you.
20.13: But if he wants to harm you, I promise to tell you and help you escape. And I ask the LORD to punish me severely if I don't keep my promise. I pray that the LORD will bless you, just as he used to bless my father.
20.16: Jonathan and David made an agreement that even David's descendants would have to keep. Then Jonathan said, "I pray that the LORD will take revenge on your descendants if they break our promise."
20.17: Jonathan thought as much of David as he did of himself, so he asked David to promise once more that he would be a loyal friend.
20.18: After this Jonathan said: Tomorrow is the New Moon Festival, and people will wonder where you are, because your place at the table will be empty.
20.19: By the day after tomorrow, everyone will think you've been gone a long time. Then go to the place where you hid before and stay beside Going-Away Rock.
20.20: I'll shoot three arrows at a target off to the side of the rock,
20.23: But he will always watch us to make sure that we keep the promise we made to each other.
20.24: So David hid there in the field. During the New Moon Festival, Saul sat down to eat
20.25: by the wall, just as he always did. Jonathan sat across from him, and Abner sat next to him. But David's place was empty.
20.26: Saul didn't say anything that day, because he was thinking, "Something must have happened to make David unfit to be at the Festival. Yes, something must have happened."
20.27: The day after the New Moon Festival, when David's place was still empty, Saul asked Jonathan, "Why hasn't that son of Jesse come to eat with us? He wasn't here yesterday, and he still isn't here today!"
20.30: Saul was furious with Jonathan and yelled, "You're no son of mine, you traitor! I know you've chosen to be loyal to that son of Jesse. You should be ashamed of yourself! And your own mother should be ashamed that you were ever born.
20.31: You'll never be safe, and your kingdom will be in danger as long as that son of Jesse is alive. Turn him over to me now! He deserves to die!"
20.32: "Why do you want to kill David?" Jonathan asked. "What has he done?"
20.33: Saul threw his spear at Jonathan and tried to kill him. Then Jonathan was sure that his father really did want to kill David.
20.34: Jonathan was angry and hurt that his father had insulted David so terribly. He got up, left the table, and didn't eat anything all that day.
20.35: In the morning, Jonathan went out to the field to meet David. He took a servant boy along
20.36: and told him, "When I shoot the arrows, you run and find them for me." The boy started running, and Jonathan shot an arrow so that it would go beyond him.
20.37: When the boy got near the place where the arrow had landed, Jonathan shouted, "Isn't the arrow on past you?"
20.38: Jonathan shouted to him again, "Hurry up! Don't stop!" The boy picked up the arrows and brought them back to Jonathan,
20.39: but he had no idea about what was going on. Only Jonathan and David knew.
20.40: Jonathan gave his weapons to the boy and told him, "Take these back into town."
20.41: After the boy had gone, David got up from beside the mound and bowed very low three times. Then he and Jonathan kissed each other and cried, but David cried louder.
20.42: Jonathan said, "Take care of yourself. And remember, we each have asked the LORD to watch and make sure that we and our descendants keep our promise forever." David left and Jonathan went back to town.

21.1: David went to see Ahimelech, a priest who lived in the town of Nob. Ahimelech was trembling with fear as he came out to meet David. "Why are you alone?" Ahimelech asked. "Why isn't anyone else with you?"
21.2: "I'm on a mission for King Saul," David answered. "He ordered me not to tell anyone what the mission is all about, so I ordered my soldiers to stay somewhere else.
21.3: Do you have any food you can give me? Could you spare five loaves of bread?"
21.4: "The only bread I have is the sacred bread," the priest told David. "You can have it if your soldiers didn't sleep with women last night."
21.5: "Of course we didn't sleep with women," David answered. "I never let my men do that when we're on a mission. They have to be acceptable to worship God even when we're on a regular mission, and today we're on a special mission."
21.6: The only bread the priest had was the sacred bread that he had taken from the place of worship after putting out the fresh loaves. So he gave it to David.
21.7: It so happened that one of Saul's officers was there, worshiping the LORD that day. His name was Doeg the Edomite, and he was the strongest of Saul's shepherds.
21.9: The priest answered, "The only sword here is the one that belonged to Goliath the Philistine. You were the one who killed him in Elah Valley, and so you can take his sword if you want to. It's wrapped in a cloth behind the statue." "It's the best sword there is," David said. "I'll take it!"
21.10: David kept on running from Saul that day until he came to Gath, where he met with King Achish.
21.11: The officers of King Achish were also there, and they asked Achish, "Isn't David a king back in his own country? Don't the Israelites dance and sing, 'Saul has killed a thousand enemies; David has killed ten thousand'?"
21.12: David thought about what they were saying, and it made him afraid of Achish.
21.13: So right there in front of everyone, he pretended to be insane. He acted confused and started making scratches on the doors of the town gate, while drooling in his beard.
21.14: "Look at him!" Achish said to his officers. "You can see he's crazy. Why did you bring him to me?
21.15: I have enough crazy people without your bringing another one here. Keep him away from my palace!"

22.1: When David escaped from the town of Gath, he went to Adullam Cave. His brothers and the rest of his family found out where he was, and they followed him there.
22.2: A lot of other people joined him too. Some were in trouble, others were angry or in debt, and David was soon the leader of 400 men.
22.3: David left Adullam Cave and went to the town of Mizpeh in Moab, where he talked with the king of Moab. "Please," David said, "let my father and mother stay with you until I find out what God will do with me."
22.4: So he brought his parents to the king of Moab, and they stayed with him while David was in hiding.
22.6: Saul was sitting under a small tree on top of the hill at Gibeah when he heard that David and his men had been located. Saul was holding his spear, and his officers were standing in front of him.
22.7: He told them: Listen to me! You belong to the Benjamin tribe, so if that son of Jesse ever becomes king, he won't give you fields or vineyards. He won't make you officers in charge of thousands or hundreds as I have done.
22.8: But you're all plotting against me! Not one of you told me that my own son Jonathan had made an agreement with him. Not one of you cared enough to tell me that Jonathan had helped one of my officers rebel. Now that son of Jesse is trying to ambush me.
22.9: Doeg the Edomite was standing with the other officers and spoke up, "When I was in the town of Nob, I saw that son of Jesse. He was visiting the priest Ahimelech the son of Ahitub.
22.10: Ahimelech talked to the LORD for him, then gave him food and the sword that had belonged to Goliath the Philistine."
22.11: Saul sent a message to Ahimelech and his whole family of priests at Nob, ordering them to come to him. When they came,
22.12: Saul told them, "Listen to me, you son of Ahitub." "Certainly, Your Majesty," Ahimelech answered.
22.13: Saul demanded, "Why did you plot against me with that son of Jesse? You helped him rebel against me by giving him food and a sword, and by talking with God for him. Now he's trying to ambush me!"
22.14: "Your Majesty, none of your officers is more loyal than David!" Ahimelech replied. "He's your son-in-law and the captain of your bodyguard. Everyone in your family respects him.
22.15: This isn't the first time I've talked with God for David, and it's never made you angry before! Please don't accuse me or my family like this. I have no idea what's going on!"
22.16: "Ahimelech," Saul said, "you and your whole family are going to die."
22.17: Saul shouted to his bodyguards, "These priests of the LORD helped David! They knew he was running away, but they didn't tell me. Kill them!" But the king's officers would not attack the priests of the LORD.
22.18: Saul turned to Doeg, who was from Edom, and said, "Kill the priests!" On that same day, Doeg killed 85 priests.
22.19: Then he attacked the town of Nob, where the priests had lived, and he killed everyone there--men, women, children, and babies. He even killed their cattle, donkeys, and sheep.
22.20: Ahimelech's son Abiathar was the only one who escaped. He ran to David
22.21: and told him, "Saul has murdered the LORD's priests at Nob!"
22.22: David answered, "That day when I saw Doeg, I knew he would tell Saul! Your family died because of me.
22.23: Stay here. Isn't the same person trying to kill both of us? Don't worry! You'll be safe here with me."

23.1: One day some people told David, "The Philistines keep attacking the town of Keilah and stealing grain from the threshing place."
23.2: David asked the LORD, "Should I attack these Philistines?" "Yes," the LORD answered. "Attack them and rescue Keilah."
23.3: But David's men said, "Look, even here in Judah we're afraid of the Philistines. We will be terrified if we try to fight them at Keilah!"
23.4: David asked the LORD about it again. "Leave at once," the LORD answered. "I will give you victory over the Philistines at Keilah."
23.5: David and his men went there and fiercely attacked the Philistines. They killed many of them, then led away their cattle, and rescued the people of Keilah.
23.10: David prayed, "LORD God of Israel, I was told that Saul is planning to come here. What should I do? Suppose he threatens to destroy the town because of me.

13.29: The old prophet picked up the body, put it on his own donkey, and took it back to Bethel, so he could bury it and mourn for the prophet from Judah.
13.31: He said to his sons, "When I die, bury my body next to this prophet.
13.32: I'm sure that everything he said about the altar in Bethel and the shrines in Samaria will happen."
13.33: But Jeroboam kept on doing evil things. He appointed men to be priests at the local shrines, even if they were not Levites. In fact, anyone who wanted to be a priest could be one.
13.34: This sinful thing led to the downfall of his kingdom.

14.1: About the same time, Abijah son of Jeroboam got sick.
14.4: She got ready and left for Ahijah's house in Shiloh. Ahijah was now old and blind,
14.5: but the LORD told him, "Jeroboam's wife is coming to ask about her son. I will tell you what to say to her." Jeroboam's wife came to Ahijah's house, pretending to be someone else.
14.7: Give your husband this message from the LORD God of Israel: "Jeroboam, you know that I, the LORD, chose you over anyone else to be the leader of my people Israel.
14.8: I even took David's kingdom away from his family and gave it to you. But you are not like my servant David. He always obeyed me and did what was right.
14.9: "You have made me very angry by rejecting me and making idols out of gold. Jeroboam, you have done more evil things than any king before you.
14.10: "Because of this, I will destroy your family by killing every man and boy in it, whether slave or free. I will wipe out your family, just as fire burns up trash.
14.11: Dogs will eat the bodies of your relatives who die in town, and vultures will eat the bodies of those who die in the country. I, the LORD, have spoken and will not change my mind!"
14.12: That's the LORD's message to your husband. As for you, go back home, and right after you get there, your son will die.
14.13: Everyone in Israel will mourn at his funeral. But he will be the last one from Jeroboam's family to receive a proper burial, because he's the only one the LORD God of Israel is pleased with.
14.14: The LORD will soon choose a new king of Israel, who will destroy Jeroboam's family. And I mean very soon.
14.15: The people of Israel have made the LORD angry by setting up sacred poles for worshiping the goddess Asherah. So the LORD will punish them until they shake like grass in a stream. He will take them out of the land he gave to their ancestors, then scatter them as far away as the Euphrates River.
14.16: Jeroboam sinned and caused the Israelites to sin. Now the LORD will desert Israel.
14.17: Jeroboam's wife left and went back home to the town of Tirzah. As soon as she set foot in her house, her son died.
14.18: Everyone in Israel came and mourned at his funeral, just as the LORD's servant Ahijah had said.
14.19: Everything else Jeroboam did while he was king, including the battles he won, is written in The History of the Kings of Israel.
14.20: He was king of Israel for 22 years, then he died, and his son Nadab became king.
14.21: Rehoboam son of Solomon was 41 years old when he became king of Judah, and he ruled 17 years from Jerusalem, the city where the LORD had chosen to be worshiped. His mother Naamah was from Ammon.
14.22: The people of Judah disobeyed the LORD and made him even angrier than their ancestors had.
14.23: They also built their own local shrines and stone images of foreign gods, and they set up sacred poles for worshiping the goddess Asherah on every hill and in the shade of large trees.
14.24: Even worse, they allowed prostitutes at the shrines, and followed the disgusting customs of the foreign nations that the LORD had forced out of Canaan.
14.25: After Rehoboam had been king for four years, King Shishak of Egypt attacked Jerusalem.
14.26: He took everything of value from the temple and the palace, including Solomon's gold shields.
14.27: Rehoboam had bronze shields made to replace the gold ones, and he ordered the guards at the city gates to keep them safe.
14.28: Whenever Rehoboam went to the LORD's temple, the guards carried the shields. But they always took them back to the guardroom as soon as he was finished.
14.29: Everything else Rehoboam did while he was king is written in The History of the Kings of Judah.
14.30: He and Jeroboam were constantly at war.
14.31: Rehoboam's mother Naamah was from Ammon, but when Rehoboam died, he was buried beside his ancestors in Jerusalem. His son Abijam then became king.

15.1: Abijam became king of Judah in Jeroboam's eighteenth year as king of Israel,
15.2: and he ruled from Jerusalem for three years. His mother was Maacah the daughter of Abishalom.
15.3: Abijam did not truly obey the LORD his God as his ancestor David had done. Instead, he was sinful just like his father Rehoboam.
15.8: Abijam died and was buried in Jerusalem, and his son Asa became king.
15.9: Asa became king of Judah in the twentieth year of Jeroboam's rule in Israel,
15.10: and he ruled 41 years from Jerusalem. His grandmother was Maacah the daughter of Abishalom.
15.11: Asa obeyed the LORD, as David had done.
15.12: He forced the prostitutes at the shrines to leave the country, and he got rid of the idols his ancestors had made.
15.13: His own grandmother Maacah had made an idol of Asherah, and Asa took it and burned it in Kidron Valley. Then he removed Maacah from her position as queen mother.
15.14: As long as Asa lived, he was completely faithful to the LORD, even though he did not destroy the local shrines.
15.15: He placed in the temple all the silver and gold objects that he and his father had dedicated to the LORD.
15.16: Asa was always at war with King Baasha of Israel.
15.17: One time, Baasha invaded Judah and captured the town of Ramah. He started making the town stronger, so he could put troops there to stop people from going in and out of Judah.
15.18: When Asa heard about this, he took the silver and gold from his palace and from the LORD's temple. He gave it to some of his officials and sent them to Damascus with this message for King Benhadad of Syria:
15.19: "Our fathers signed a peace treaty. Why don't we do the same thing? This silver and gold is a present for you. So, would you please break your treaty with Baasha and force him to leave my country?"
15.20: Benhadad did what Asa asked and sent the Syrian army into Israel. They captured the towns of Ijon, Dan, and Abel-Bethmaacah, and the territories of Chinneroth and Naphtali.
15.21: When Baasha heard about it, he left Ramah and went back to Tirzah.
15.22: Asa ordered everyone in Judah to carry away the stones and wood Baasha had used to strengthen the town of Ramah. Then he used these same stones and wood to fortify the town of Geba in the territory of Benjamin and the town of Mizpah.
15.23: Everything else Asa did while he was king, including his victories and the towns he rebuilt, is written in The History of the Kings of Judah. When he got older, he had a foot disease.
15.24: Asa died and was buried in the tomb of his ancestors in Jerusalem. His son Jehoshaphat then became king.
15.25: Nadab son of Jeroboam became king of Israel in Asa's second year as king of Judah, and he ruled two years.
15.26: Nadab disobeyed the LORD by following the evil example of his father, who had caused the Israelites to sin.
15.29: The LORD's prophet Ahijah had earlier said, "Not one man or boy in Jeroboam's family will be left alive." And, as soon as Baasha became king, he killed everyone in Jeroboam's family,
15.30: because Jeroboam had made the LORD God of Israel angry by sinning and causing the Israelites to sin.
15.31: Everything else Nadab did while he was king is written in The History of the Kings of Israel.
15.32: King Asa of Judah and King Baasha of Israel were always at war.
15.33: Baasha son of Ahijah became king of Israel in Asa's third year as king of Judah, and he ruled 24 years from Tirzah.
15.34: Baasha also disobeyed the LORD by acting like Jeroboam, who had caused the Israelites to sin.

16.1: The LORD sent Jehu son of Hanani to say to Baasha:
16.2: Nobody knew who you were until I, the LORD, chose you to be the leader of my people Israel. And now you're acting exactly like Jeroboam by causing the Israelites to sin. What you've done has made me so angry
16.3: that I will destroy you and your family, just as I did the family of Jeroboam.
16.4: Dogs will eat the bodies of your relatives who die in town, and vultures will eat the bodies of those who die in the country.
16.8: Elah son of Baasha became king of Israel after Asa had been king of Judah for 25 years, and he ruled from Tirzah for two years.
16.9: Zimri commanded half of Elah's chariots, and he made plans to kill Elah. One day, Elah was in Tirzah, getting drunk at the home of Arza, his prime minister,
16.10: when Zimri went there and killed Elah. So Zimri became king in the twenty-seventh year of Asa's rule in Judah.
16.11: As soon as Zimri became king, he killed everyone in Baasha's family. Not one man or boy in his family was left alive--even his close friends were killed.
16.12: Baasha's family was completely wiped out, just as the LORD's prophet Jehu had warned.
16.13: Baasha and Elah sinned and caused the Israelites to sin, and they made the LORD angry by worshiping idols.
16.14: Everything else Elah did while he was king is written in The History of the Kings of Israel.
16.17: At once, Omri and his army marched to Tirzah and attacked.
16.18: When Zimri saw that the town was captured, he ran into the strongest part of the palace and killed himself by setting it on fire.
16.19: Zimri had disobeyed the LORD by following the evil example of Jeroboam, who had caused the Israelites to sin.
16.20: Everything else Zimri did while he was king, including his rebellion against Elah, is written in The History of the Kings of Israel.
16.21: After Zimri died, some of the Israelites wanted Tibni son of Ginath to be king, but others wanted Omri.
16.22: Omri's followers were stronger than Tibni's, so Tibni was killed, and Omri became king of Israel
16.23: in the thirty-first year of Asa's rule in Judah. Omri ruled Israel for twelve years. The first six years he ruled from Tirzah,
16.24: then he bought the hill of Samaria from Shemer for 6,000 pieces of silver. He built a town there and named it Samaria, after Shemer who had owned the hill.
16.25: Omri did more evil things than any king before him.
16.26: He acted just like Jeroboam and made the LORD God of Israel angry by causing the Israelites to sin and to worship idols.
16.27: Everything else Omri did while he was king, including his brave deeds, is written in The History of the Kings of Israel.
16.28: Omri died and was buried in Samaria, and his son Ahab became king.
16.29: Ahab son of Omri became king of Israel in the thirty-eighth year of Asa's rule in Judah, and he ruled 22 years from Samaria.
16.30: Ahab did more things to disobey the LORD than any king before him.
16.31: He acted just like Jeroboam. Even worse, he married Jezebel the daughter of King Ethbaal of Sidon and started worshiping Baal.
16.32: Ahab built an altar and temple for Baal in Samaria
16.33: and set up a sacred pole for worshiping the goddess Asherah. Ahab did more to make the LORD God of Israel angry than any king of Israel before him.
16.34: While Ahab was king, a man from Bethel named Hiel rebuilt the town of Jericho. But while Hiel was laying the foundation for the town wall, his oldest son Abiram died. And while he was finishing the gates, his youngest son Segub died. This happened just as the LORD had told Joshua to say many years ago.

17.2: Later, the LORD said to Elijah,
17.3: "Leave and go across the Jordan River so you can hide near Cherith Creek.
17.4: You can drink water from the creek, and eat the food I've told the ravens to bring you."
17.5: Elijah obeyed the LORD and went to live near Cherith Creek.
17.6: Ravens brought him bread and meat twice a day, and he drank water from the creek.
17.7: But after a while, it dried up because there was no rain.
17.8: The LORD told Elijah,
17.9: "Go to the town of Zarephath in Sidon and live there. I've told a widow in that town to give you food."
17.10: When Elijah came near the town gate of Zarephath, he saw a widow gathering sticks for a fire. "Would you please bring me a cup of water?" he asked.
17.11: As she left to get it, he asked, "Would you also please bring me a piece of bread?"
17.14: The LORD God of Israel has promised that your jar of flour won't run out and your bottle of oil won't dry up before he sends rain for the crops."
17.15: The widow went home and did exactly what Elijah had told her. She and Elijah and her family had enough food for a long time.
17.16: The LORD kept the promise that his prophet Elijah had made, and she did not run out of flour or oil.
17.17: Several days later, the son of the woman who owned the house got sick, and he kept getting worse, until finally he died.
17.18: The woman shouted at Elijah, "What have I done to you? I thought you were God's prophet. Did you come here to cause the death of my son as a reminder that I've sinned against God?"
17.19: "Bring me your son," Elijah said. Then he took the boy from her arms and carried him upstairs to the room where he was staying. Elijah laid the boy on his bed
17.20: and prayed, "LORD God, why did you do such a terrible thing to this woman? She's letting me stay here, and now you've let her son die."
17.21: Elijah stretched himself out over the boy three times, while praying, "LORD God, bring this boy back to life!"
17.22: The LORD answered Elijah's prayer, and the boy started breathing again.
17.23: Elijah picked him up and carried him downstairs. He gave the boy to his mother and said, "Look, your son is alive."
17.24: "You are God's prophet!" the woman replied. "Now I know that you really do speak for the LORD."

18.5: and said, "We have to find something for our horses and mules to eat. If we don't, we will have to kill them. Let's look around every creek and spring in the country for some grass.
18.6: You go one way, and I'll go the other." Then they left in separate directions.
18.7: As Obadiah was walking along, he met Elijah. Obadiah recognized him, bowed down, and asked, "Elijah, is it really you?"
18.9: Obadiah replied: King Ahab would kill me if I told him that. And I haven't even done anything wrong.
18.10: I swear to you in the name of the living LORD your God that the king has looked everywhere for you. He sent people to look in every country, and when they couldn't find you, he made the leader of each country swear that you were not in that country.
18.12: What if the LORD's Spirit takes you away as soon as I leave? When Ahab comes to get you, he won't find you. Then he will surely kill me. I have worshiped the LORD since I was a boy.
18.13: I even hid 100 of the LORD's prophets in caves when Jezebel was trying to kill them. I also gave them food and water.
18.16: Obadiah left and told Ahab where to find Elijah. Ahab went to meet Elijah,
18.17: and when he saw him, Ahab shouted, "There you are, the biggest troublemaker in Israel!"
18.18: Elijah answered: You're the troublemaker--not me! You and your family have disobeyed the LORD's commands by worshiping Baal.
18.19: Call together everyone from Israel to meet me on Mount Carmel. Be sure to bring along the 450 prophets of Baal and the 400 prophets of Asherah who eat at Jezebel's table.
18.20: Ahab got everyone together, then they went to meet Elijah on Mount Carmel.
18.21: Elijah stood in front of them and said, "How much longer will you try to have things both ways? If the LORD is God, worship him! But if Baal is God, worship him!" The people did not say a word.
18.22: Then Elijah continued: I am the LORD's only prophet, but Baal has 450 prophets.
18.23: Bring us two bulls. Baal's prophets can take one of them, kill it, and cut it into pieces. Then they can put the meat on the wood without lighting the fire. I will do the same thing with the other bull, and I won't light a fire under it either.
18.24: The prophets of Baal will pray to their god, and I will pray to the LORD. The one who answers by starting the fire is God. "That's a good idea," everyone agreed.
18.27: At noon, Elijah began making fun of them. "Pray louder!" he said. "Baal must be a god. Maybe he's daydreaming or using the toilet or traveling somewhere. Or maybe he's asleep, and you have to wake him up."
18.28: The prophets kept shouting louder and louder, and they cut themselves with swords and knives until they were bleeding. This was the way they worshiped,
18.29: and they kept it up until time for the evening sacrifice. But there was no answer of any kind.
18.35: until finally, the water ran down the altar and filled the ditch.
18.36: When it was time for the evening sacrifice, Elijah prayed: Our LORD, you are the God of Abraham, Isaac, and Israel. Now, prove that you are the God of this nation, and that I, your servant, have done this at your command.
18.37: Please answer me, so these people will know that you are the LORD God, and that you will turn their hearts back to you.
18.38: The LORD immediately sent fire, and it burned up the sacrifice, the wood, and the stones. It scorched the ground everywhere around the altar and dried up every drop of water in the ditch.
18.39: When the crowd saw what had happened, they all bowed down and shouted, "The LORD is God! The LORD is God!"
18.40: Just then, Elijah said, "Grab the prophets of Baal! Don't let any of them get away." So the people captured the prophets and took them to Kishon River, where Elijah killed every one of them.
18.41: Elijah told Ahab, "Get something to eat and drink. I hear a heavy rain coming."
18.42: Ahab left, but Elijah climbed back to the top of Mount Carmel. Then he stooped down with his face almost to the ground
18.43: and said to his servant, "Look toward the sea." The servant left. And when he came back, he said, "I looked, but I didn't see anything." Elijah told him to look seven more times.

19.1: Ahab told his wife Jezebel what Elijah had done and that he had killed the prophets.
19.2: She sent a message to Elijah: "You killed my prophets. Now I'm going to kill you! I pray that the gods will punish me even more severely if I don't do it by this time tomorrow."
19.3: Elijah was afraid when he got her message, and he ran to the town of Beersheba in Judah. He left his servant there,
19.4: then walked another whole day into the desert. Finally, he came to a large bush and sat down in its shade. He begged the LORD, "I've had enough. Just let me die! I'm no better off than my ancestors."
19.5: Then he lay down in the shade and fell asleep. Suddenly an angel woke him up and said, "Get up and eat."
19.6: Elijah looked around, and by his head was a jar of water and some baked bread. He sat up, ate and drank, then lay down and went back to sleep.
19.7: Soon the LORD's angel woke him again and said, "Get up and eat, or else you'll get too tired to travel."
19.8: So Elijah sat up and ate and drank. The food and water made him strong enough to walk 40 more days. At last, he reached Mount Sinai, the mountain of God,
19.9: and he spent the night there in a cave. While Elijah was on Mount Sinai, the LORD asked, "Elijah, why are you here?"
19.10: He answered, "LORD God All-Powerful, I've always done my best to obey you. But your people have broken their solemn promise to you. They have torn down your altars and killed all your prophets, except me. And now they are even trying to kill me!"
19.11: "Go out and stand on the mountain," the LORD replied. "I want you to be there when I pass by." All at once, a strong wind shook the mountain and shattered the rocks. But the LORD was not in the wind. Next, there was an earthquake, but the LORD was not in the earthquake.
19.12: Then there was a fire, but the LORD was not in the fire. Finally, there was a gentle breeze,
19.13: and when Elijah heard it, he covered his face with his coat. He went out and stood at the entrance to the cave. A voice asked, "Elijah, why are you here?"
19.14: Elijah answered, "LORD God All-Powerful, I've always done my best to obey you. But your people have broken their solemn promise to you. They have torn down your altars and killed all your prophets, except me. And now they are even trying to kill me!"
19.15: The LORD said: Elijah, you can go back to the desert near Damascus. And when you get there, appoint Hazael to be king of Syria.
19.16: Then appoint Jehu son of Nimshi to be king of Israel, and Elisha son of Shaphat to take your place as my prophet.
19.17: Hazael will start killing the people who worship Baal. Jehu will kill those who escape from Hazael, and Elisha will kill those who escape from Jehu.
19.18: But 7,000 Israelites have refused to worship Baal, and they will live.
19.19: Elijah left and found Elisha plowing a field with a pair of oxen. There were eleven other men in front of him, and each one was also plowing with a pair of oxen. Elijah went over and put his own coat on Elisha.
19.21: Elisha left and took his oxen with him. He killed them and boiled them over a fire he had made with the wood from his plow. He gave the meat to the people who were with him, and they ate it. Then he left with Elijah and became his assistant.

20.1: King Benhadad of Syria called his army together. He was joined by 32 other kings with their horses and chariots, and together they marched to Samaria and attacked.
20.2: Benhadad sent a messenger to tell King Ahab of Israel,
20.3: "Ahab, give me your silver and gold, your wives, and your strongest sons!"
20.4: "Your Majesty," Ahab replied, "everything I have is yours, including me."
20.5: Later, Benhadad sent another messenger to say to Ahab, "I already told you to give me your silver and gold, your wives, and your children.
20.6: But tomorrow at this time, I will send my officials into your city to search your palace and the houses of your officials. They will take everything else that you own."
20.7: Ahab called a meeting with the leaders of Israel and said, "Benhadad is causing real trouble. He told me to give him my wives and children, as well as my silver and gold. And I agreed."
20.10: he replied, "I'll completely destroy Samaria! There won't even be enough of it left for my soldiers to carry back in their hands. If I don't do it, I pray that the gods will punish me terribly."
20.11: Ahab then answered, "Benhadad, don't brag before the fighting even begins. Wait and see if you live through it."
20.12: Meanwhile, Benhadad and the other kings had been drinking in their tents. But when Ahab's reply came, he ordered his soldiers to prepare to attack Samaria, and they all got ready.
20.15: So Ahab called together the 232 young soldiers and the 7,000 troops in Israel's army, and he got them ready to fight the Syrians.
20.18: "Take them alive!" Benhadad ordered. "I don't care if they have come out to fight or to surrender."
20.19: The young soldiers led Israel's troops into battle,
20.20: and each of them attacked and killed an enemy soldier. The rest of the Syrian army turned and ran, and the Israelites went after them. Benhadad and some others escaped on horses,
20.21: but Ahab and his soldiers followed them and captured their horses and chariots. Ahab and Israel's army crushed the Syrians.
20.22: Later, the prophet went back and warned Ahab, "Benhadad will attack you again next spring. Build up your troops and make sure you have some good plans."
20.23: Meanwhile, Benhadad's officials went to him and explained: Israel's gods are mountain gods. We fought Israel's army in the hills, and that's why they defeated us. But if we fight them on flat land, there's no way we can lose.
20.24: Here's what you should do. First, get rid of those 32 kings and put army commanders in their places.
20.25: Then get more soldiers, horses, and chariots, so your army will be as strong as it was before. We'll fight Israel's army on flat land and wipe them out. Benhadad agreed and did what they suggested.
20.26: In the spring, Benhadad got his army together, and they marched to the town of Aphek to attack Israel.
20.27: The Israelites also prepared to fight. They marched out to meet the Syrians, and the two armies camped across from each other. The Syrians covered the whole area, but the Israelites looked like two little flocks of goats.
20.29: For seven days the two armies stayed in their camps, facing each other. Then on the seventh day the fighting broke out, and before sunset the Israelites had killed 100,000 Syrian troops.
20.30: The rest of the Syrian army ran back to Aphek, but the town wall fell and crushed 27,000 of them. Benhadad also escaped to Aphek and hid in the back room of a house.
20.32: They dressed in sackcloth and put ropes on their heads, then they went to Ahab and said, "Your servant Benhadad asks you to let him live." "Is he still alive?" Ahab asked. "Benhadad is like a brother to me."
20.33: Benhadad's officials were trying to figure out what Ahab was thinking, and when he said "brother," they quickly replied, "You're right! You and Benhadad are like brothers." "Go get him," Ahab said. When Benhadad came out, Ahab had him climb up into his chariot.
20.34: Benhadad said, "I'll give back the towns my father took from your father. And you can have shops in Damascus, just as my father had in Samaria." Ahab replied, "If you do these things, I'll let you go free." Then they signed a peace treaty, and Ahab let Benhadad go.
20.35: About this time the LORD commanded a prophet to say to a friend, "Hit me!" But the friend refused,
20.37: The prophet found someone else and said, "Hit me!" So this man beat him up.
20.38: The prophet left and put a bandage over his face to disguise himself. Then he went and stood beside the road, waiting for Ahab to pass by.
20.39: When Ahab went by, the prophet shouted, "Your Majesty, right in the heat of battle, someone brought a prisoner to me and told me to guard him. He said if the prisoner got away, I would either be killed or forced to pay 3,000 pieces of silver.
20.40: But I got busy doing other things, and the prisoner escaped." Ahab answered, "You will be punished just as you have said."
20.41: The man quickly tore the bandage off his face, and Ahab saw that he was one of the prophets.
20.43: Ahab went back to Samaria, angry and depressed.

21.1: Naboth owned a vineyard in Jezreel near King Ahab's palace.
21.2: One day, Ahab said, "Naboth, your vineyard is near my palace. Give it to me so I can turn it into a vegetable garden. I'll give you a better vineyard or pay whatever you want for yours."
21.3: Naboth answered, "This vineyard has always been in my family. I won't let you have it."
21.4: So Ahab went home, angry and depressed because of what Naboth had told him. He lay on his bed, just staring at the wall and refusing to eat a thing.
21.5: Jezebel his wife came in and asked, "What's wrong? Why won't you eat?"
21.7: "Aren't you the king of Israel?" Jezebel asked. "Get out of bed and eat something! Don't worry, I'll get Naboth's vineyard for you."
21.11: After receiving her letters, they did exactly what she had asked.
21.12: They told the people that it was a day to go without eating, and when they all came together, they seated Naboth at the front.
21.13: The two liars came in and sat across from Naboth. Then they accused him of cursing God and the king, so the people dragged Naboth outside and stoned him to death.
21.14: The leaders of Jezreel sent a message back to Jezebel that said, "Naboth is dead."
21.15: As soon as Jezebel got their message, she told Ahab, "Now you can have the vineyard Naboth refused to sell. He's dead."
21.16: Ahab got up and went to take over the vineyard.
21.17: The LORD said to Elijah the prophet,
21.18: "King Ahab of Israel is in Naboth's vineyard right now, taking it over.
21.19: Go tell him that I say, 'Ahab, you murdered Naboth and took his property. And so, in the very spot where dogs licked up Naboth's blood, they will lick up your blood.'" When Elijah found him,
21.20: Ahab said, "So, my enemy, you found me at last." Elijah answered: Yes, I did! Ahab, you have managed to do everything the LORD hates.
21.21: Now you will be punished. You and every man and boy in your family will die, whether slave or free.
21.22: Your whole family will be wiped out, just like the families of King Jeroboam and King Baasha. You've made the LORD very angry by sinning and causing the Israelites to sin.
21.24: Dogs will also eat the bodies of your relatives who die in town, and vultures will eat the bodies of those who die in the country.

22.1: For the next three years there was peace between Israel and Syria.
22.2: During the third year King Jehoshaphat of Judah went to visit King Ahab of Israel.
22.4: Then he asked Jehoshaphat, "Would you go to Ramoth with me and attack the Syrians?" "Just tell me what to do," Jehoshaphat answered. "My army and horses are at your command.
22.6: Ahab sent for about 400 prophets and asked, "Should I attack the Syrians at Ramoth?" "Yes!" the prophets answered. "The Lord will help you defeat them."
22.7: But Jehoshaphat said, "Just to make sure, is there another of the LORD's prophets we can ask?"
22.8: "We could ask Micaiah son of Imlah," Ahab said. "But I hate Micaiah. He always has bad news for me." "Don't say that!" Jehoshaphat replied.

22.17: He answered, "In a vision I saw Israelite soldiers walking around in the hills like sheep without a shepherd to guide them. The LORD said, 'This army has no leader. They should go home and not fight.'"
22.19: Micaiah replied: Listen to this! I also saw the LORD seated on his throne with every creature in heaven gathered around him.

22.21: then finally a spirit came forward and said to the LORD, "I can trick Ahab." "How?" the LORD asked.
22.22: "I'll make Ahab's prophets lie to him." "Good!" the LORD replied. "Now go and do it."
22.23: This is exactly what has happened, Ahab. The LORD made all your prophets lie to you, and he knows you will soon be destroyed.
22.24: Zedekiah walked up to Micaiah and slapped him on the face. Then he asked, "Do you really think the LORD would speak to you and not to me?"
22.25: Micaiah answered, "You'll find out on the day you have to hide in the back room of some house."
22.26: Ahab shouted, "Arrest Micaiah! Take him to Prince Joash and Governor Amon of Samaria.
22.27: Tell them to put him in prison and to give him nothing but bread and water until I come back safely."
22.28: Micaiah said, "If you do come back, I was wrong about what the LORD wanted me to say." Then he told the crowd, "Don't forget what I said!"
22.29: Ahab and Jehoshaphat led their armies to Ramoth in Gilead.
22.30: Before they went into battle, Ahab said, "Jehoshaphat, I'll disguise myself, but you wear your royal robe." Then Ahab disguised himself and went into battle.
22.32: So when they saw Jehoshaphat in his robe, they thought he was Ahab and started to attack him. But when Jehoshaphat shouted out to them,
22.33: they realized he wasn't Ahab, and they left him alone.

22.35: The fighting lasted all day, with Ahab propped up in his chariot so he could see the Syrian troops. He bled so much that the bottom of the chariot was covered with blood, and by evening he was dead.
22.37: Ahab's body was taken to Samaria and buried there.
22.38: Some workers washed his chariot near a spring in Samaria, and prostitutes washed themselves in his blood. Dogs licked Ahab's blood off the ground, just as the LORD had warned.
22.39: Everything else Ahab did while he was king, including the towns he strengthened and the palace he built and furnished with ivory, is written in The History of the Kings of Israel.
22.40: Ahab died, and his son Ahaziah became king.
22.41: Jehoshaphat son of Asa became king of Judah in Ahab's fourth year as king of Israel.
22.42: Jehoshaphat was 35 years old when he became king, and he ruled from Jerusalem for 25 years. His mother was Azubah daughter of Shilhi.
22.47: The country of Edom had no king at the time, so a lower official ruled the land.
22.48: Jehoshaphat had seagoing ships built to sail to Ophir for gold. But they were wrecked at Ezion-Geber and never sailed.
22.49: Ahaziah son of Ahab offered to let his sailors go with Jehoshaphat's sailors, but Jehoshaphat refused.
22.50: Jehoshaphat died and was buried beside his ancestors in Jerusalem, and his son Jehoram became king.
22.51: Ahaziah son of Ahab became king of Israel in the seventeenth year of Jehoshaphat's rule in Judah, and he ruled two years from Samaria.
22.52: Ahaziah disobeyed the LORD, just as his father, his mother, and Jeroboam had done. They all led Israel to sin.
22.53: Ahaziah worshiped Baal and made the LORD God of Israel very angry, just as his father had done.

1.3: About the same time, an angel from the LORD sent Elijah the prophet from Tishbe to say to the king's messengers, "Ahaziah has rejected Israel's own God by sending you to ask Baalzebub about his injury.

1.5: When the messengers returned to Ahaziah, he asked, "Why are you back so soon?"
1.7: "What did the man look like?" Ahaziah asked.

1.10: "If I am a man of God," Elijah answered, "God will send down fire on you and your 50 soldiers." Fire immediately came down from heaven and burned up the officer and his men.
1.12: "If I am a man of God," Elijah answered, "fire will destroy you and your 50 soldiers." And God sent down fire from heaven on the officer and his men.
1.13: Ahaziah sent a third army officer and 50 more soldiers. This officer went up to Elijah, then he got down on his knees and begged, "Man of God, please be kind to me and these 50 servants of yours. Let us live!

2.13: Elijah's coat had fallen off, so Elisha picked it up and walked back to the Jordan River.
2.14: He struck the water with the coat and wondered, "Will the LORD perform miracles for me as he did for Elijah?" As soon as Elisha did this, a dry path opened up through the water, and he walked across.
2.15: When the prophets from Jericho saw what happened, they said to each other, "Elisha now has Elijah's power." They walked over to him, bowed down,

2.21: and he carried it to the spring. He threw the salt into the water and said, "The LORD has made this water pure again. From now on you'll be able to grow crops, and no one will starve."

2.23: Elisha left and headed toward Bethel. Along the way some boys started making fun of him by shouting, "Go away, baldy! Get out of here!"
2.24: Elisha turned around and stared at the boys. Then he cursed them in the name of the LORD. At once two bears ran out of the woods and ripped to pieces 42 of the boys.

3.1: Joram son of Ahab became king of Israel in Jehoshaphat's eighteenth year as king of Judah. Joram ruled twelve years from Samaria
3.2: and disobeyed the LORD by doing wrong. He tore down the stone image his father had made to honor Baal, and so he wasn't as sinful as his parents.
3.3: But he kept doing the sinful things that Jeroboam son of Nebat had led Israel to do.
3.4: For many years the country of Moab had been controlled by Israel and was forced to pay taxes to the kings of Israel. King Mesha of Moab raised sheep, so he paid the king of Israel 100,000 lambs and the wool from 100,000 rams.
3.5: But soon after the death of Ahab, Mesha rebelled against Israel.
3.6: One day, Joram left Samaria and called together Israel's army.
3.7: He sent this message to King Jehoshaphat of Judah, "The king of Moab has rebelled. Will you go with me to attack him?" "Yes, I will," Jehoshaphat answered. "I'm on your side, and my soldiers and horses are at your command.
3.8: But which way should we go?" "We will march through Edom Desert," Joram replied.
3.9: So Joram, Jehoshaphat, and the king of Edom led their troops out. But seven days later, there was no drinking water left for them or their animals.
3.10: Joram cried out, "This is terrible! The LORD must have led us out here to be captured by Moab's army."
3.12: Jehoshaphat replied, "He can give us the LORD's message." The three kings went over to Elisha,
3.13: and he asked Joram, "Why did you come to me? Go talk to the prophets of the foreign gods your parents worshiped." "No," Joram answered. "It was the LORD who led us out here, so that Moab's army could capture us."
3.15: Then Elisha said, "Send for someone who can play the harp." The harpist began playing, and the LORD gave Elisha this message for Joram:
3.16: The LORD says that this dry riverbed will be filled with water.
3.17: You won't feel any wind or see any rain, but there will be plenty of water for you and your animals.
3.18: That simple thing isn't all the LORD is going to do. He will also help you defeat Moab's army.
3.19: You will capture all their walled cities and important towns. You will chop down every good tree and stop up every spring of water, then ruin their fertile fields by covering them with rocks.
3.20: The next morning, while the sacrifice was being offered, water suddenly started flowing from the direction of Edom, and it flooded the land.
3.21: Meanwhile, the people of Moab had heard that the three kings were coming to attack them. They had called together all of their fighting men, from the youngest to the oldest, and these troops were now standing at their border, ready for battle.
3.22: When they got up that morning, the sun was shining across the water, making it look red. The Moabite troops took one look
3.23: and shouted, "Look at that blood! The armies of those kings must have fought and killed each other. Come on, let's go take what's left in their camp."
3.24: But when they arrived at Israel's camp, the Israelite soldiers came out and attacked them, until they turned and ran away. Israel's army chased them all the way back to Moab, and even there they kept up the attack.
3.25: The Israelites destroyed the Moabite towns. They chopped down the good trees and stopped up the springs of water, then covered the fertile fields with rocks. Finally, the only city left standing was Kir-Hareseth, but soldiers armed with slings surrounded and attacked it.
3.26: King Mesha of Moab saw that he was about to be defeated. So he took along 700 soldiers with swords and tried to break through the front line where the Edomite troops were positioned. But he failed.
3.27: He then grabbed his oldest son who was to be the next king and sacrificed him as an offering on the city wall. The Israelite troops were so horrified that they left the city and went back home.

4.1: One day the widow of one of the LORD's prophets said to Elisha, "You know that before my husband died, he was a follower of yours and a worshiper of the LORD. But he owed a man some money, and now that man is on his way to take my two sons as his slaves."
4.2: "Maybe there's something I can do to help," Elisha said. "What do you have in your house?" "Sir, I have nothing but a small bottle of olive oil."
4.3: Elisha told her, "Ask your neighbors for their empty jars. And after you've borrowed as many as you can,
4.4: go home and shut the door behind you and your sons. Then begin filling the jars with oil and set each one aside as you fill it."
4.5: The woman left. Later, when she and her sons were back inside their house, the two sons brought her the jars, and she began filling them.
4.7: After she told Elisha what had happened, he said, "Sell the oil and use part of the money to pay what you owe the man. You and your sons can live on what is left."
4.8: Once, while Elisha was in the town of Shunem, he met a rich woman who invited him to her home for dinner. After that, whenever he was in Shunem, he would have a meal there with her and her husband.
4.9: Some time later the woman said to her husband, "I'm sure the man who comes here so often is a prophet of God.
4.10: Why don't we build him a small room on the flat roof of our house? We can put a bed, a table and chair, and an oil lamp in it. Then whenever he comes, he can stay with us."
4.11: The next time Elisha was in Shunem, he stopped at their house and went up to his room to rest.
4.14: "Then what can we do for her?" Elisha asked Gehazi. Gehazi replied, "I do know that her husband is old, and that she doesn't have a son."
4.17: But a few months later, the woman got pregnant. She gave birth to a son, just as Elisha had promised.
4.18: One day while the boy was still young, he was out in the fields with his father, where the workers were harvesting the crops.
4.20: The servant picked up the boy and carried him to his mother. The boy lay on her lap all morning, and by noon he was dead.
4.21: She carried him upstairs to Elisha's room and laid him across the bed. Then she walked out and shut the door behind her.
4.22: The woman called to her husband, "I need to see the prophet. Let me use one of the donkeys. Send a servant along with me, and let me leave now, so I can get back quickly."
4.23: "Why do you need to see him today?" her husband asked. "It's not the Sabbath or time for the New Moon Festival." "That's all right," she answered.
4.24: She saddled the donkey and said to her servant, "Let's go. And don't slow down unless I tell you to."
4.25: She left at once for Mount Carmel to talk with Elisha. When Elisha saw her coming, he said, "Gehazi, look! It's the woman from Shunem.
4.27: But as soon as she got to the top of the mountain, she went over and grabbed Elisha by the feet. Gehazi started toward her to push her away, when Elisha said, "Leave her alone! Don't you see how sad she is? But the LORD hasn't told me why."
4.29: "Gehazi, get ready and go to her house," Elisha said. "Take along my walking stick, and when you get there, lay it on the boy's face. Don't stop to talk to anyone, even if they try to talk to you."
4.31: Gehazi ran on ahead and laid Elisha's walking stick on the boy's face, but the boy didn't move or make a sound. Gehazi ran back to Elisha and said, "The boy didn't wake up."
4.32: Elisha arrived at the woman's house and went straight to his room, where he saw the boy's body on his bed.
4.33: He walked in, shut the door, and prayed to the LORD.
4.34: Then he got on the bed and stretched out over the dead body, with his mouth on the boy's mouth, his eyes on his eyes, and his hand on his hands. As he lay there, the boy's body became warm.
4.35: Elisha got up and walked back and forth in the room, then he went back and leaned over the boy's body. The boy sneezed seven times and opened his eyes.
4.37: She came in and bowed down at Elisha's feet. Then she picked up her son and left.
4.38: Later, Elisha went back to Gilgal, where there was almost nothing to eat, because the crops had failed. One day while the prophets who lived there were meeting with Elisha, he said to his servant, "Prepare a big pot of stew for these prophets."
4.39: One of them went out into the woods to gather some herbs. He found a wild vine and picked as much of its fruit as he could carry, but he didn't know that the fruit was very sour. When he got back, he cut up the fruit and put it in the stew.
4.40: The stew was served, and when the prophets started eating it, they shouted, "Elisha, this stew tastes terrible! We can't eat it."
4.41: "Bring me some flour," Elisha said. He sprinkled the flour in the stew and said, "Now serve it to them." And the stew tasted fine.
4.42: A man from the town of Baal-Shalishah brought Elisha some freshly cut grain and 20 loaves of bread made from the first barley that was harvested. Elisha said, "Give it to the people so they can eat."
4.43: "There's not enough here for 100 people," his servant said. "Just give it to them," Elisha replied. "The LORD has promised there will be more than enough."
4.44: So the servant served the bread and grain to the people. They ate and still had some left over, just as the LORD had promised.

5.1: Naaman was the commander of the Syrian army. The LORD had helped him and his troops defeat their enemies, so the king of Syria respected Naaman very much. Naaman was a brave soldier, but he had leprosy.
5.2: One day while the Syrian troops were raiding Israel, they captured a girl, and she became a servant of Naaman's wife.
5.3: Some time later the girl said, "If your husband Naaman would go to the prophet in Samaria, he would be cured of his leprosy."
5.4: When Naaman told the king what the girl had said,
5.5: the king replied, "Go ahead! I will give you a letter to take to the king of Israel." Naaman left and took along 30,000 pieces of silver, 6,000 pieces of gold, and 10 new outfits.
5.6: He also carried the letter to the king of Israel. It said, "I am sending my servant Naaman to you. Would you cure him of his leprosy?"
5.8: As soon as Elisha the prophet heard what had happened, he sent the Israelite king this message: "Why are you so afraid? Send the man to me, so that he will know there is a prophet in Israel."
5.9: Naaman left with his horses and chariots and stopped at the door of Elisha's house.
5.10: Elisha sent someone outside to say to him, "Go wash seven times in the Jordan River. Then you'll be completely cured."
5.11: But Naaman stormed off, grumbling, "Why couldn't he come out and talk to me? I thought for sure he would stand in front of me and pray to the LORD his God, then wave his hand over my skin and cure me.
5.12: What about the Abana River or the Pharpar River? Those rivers in Damascus are just as good as any river in Israel. I could have washed in them and been cured."
5.13: His servants went over to him and said, "Sir, if the prophet had told you to do something difficult, you would have done it. So why don't you do what he said? Go wash and be cured."
5.14: Naaman walked down to the Jordan; he waded out into the water and stooped down in it seven times, just as Elisha had told him. At once, he was cured, and his skin became as smooth as a child's.
5.15: Naaman and his officials went back to Elisha. Naaman stood in front of him and announced, "Now I know that the God of Israel is the only God in the whole world. Sir, would you please accept a gift from me?"
5.17: Finally Naaman said, "If you won't accept a gift, then please let me take home as much soil as two mules can pull in a wagon. Sir, from now on I will offer sacrifices only to the LORD.
5.18: But I pray that the LORD will forgive me when I go into the temple of the god Rimmon and bow down there with the king of Syria."
5.19: "Go on home, and don't worry about that," Elisha replied. Then Naaman left. After Naaman had gone only a short distance,
5.20: Gehazi said to himself, "Elisha let that Syrian off too easy. He should have taken Naaman's gift. I swear by the living LORD that I will talk to Naaman myself and get something from him."
5.21: So he hurried after Naaman. When Naaman saw Gehazi running after him, he got out of his chariot to meet him. Naaman asked, "Is everything all right?"
5.24: When they reached the hill where Gehazi lived, he took the bags from the servants and placed them in his house, then sent the men away. After they had gone,
5.25: Gehazi went in and stood in front of Elisha, who asked, "Gehazi, where have you been?" "Nowhere, sir," Gehazi answered.
5.26: Elisha asked, "Don't you know that my spirit was there when Naaman got out of his chariot to talk with you? Gehazi, you have no right to accept money or clothes, olive orchards or vineyards, sheep or cattle, or servants.
5.27: Because of what you've done, Naaman's leprosy will now be on you and your descendants forever!" Suddenly, Gehazi's skin became white with leprosy, and he left.

6.1: One day the prophets said to Elisha, "The place where we meet with you is too small.
6.2: Why don't we build a new meeting place near the Jordan River? Each of us could get some wood, then we could build it." "That's a good idea," Elisha replied, "get started."
6.3: "Aren't you going with us?" one of the prophets asked. "Yes, I'll go," Elisha answered,
6.4: and he left with them. They went to the Jordan River and began chopping down trees.
6.5: While one of the prophets was working, his ax head fell off and dropped into the water. "Oh!" he shouted. "Sir, I borrowed this ax."
6.6: "Where did it fall in?" Elisha asked. The prophet pointed to the place, and Elisha cut a stick and threw it into the water at that spot. The ax head floated to the top of the water.
6.7: "Now get it," Elisha told him. And the prophet reached in and grabbed it.
6.8: Time after time, when the king of Syria was at war against the Israelites, he met with his officers and announced, "I've decided where we will set up camp."
6.10: So the king would warn the Israelite troops in that place to be on guard.
6.11: The king of Syria was furious when he found out what was happening. He called in his officers and asked, "Which one of you has been telling the king of Israel our plans?"
6.12: "None of us, Your Majesty," one of them answered. "It's an Israelite named Elisha. He's a prophet, so he can tell his king everything--even what you say in your own room."
6.14: He ordered his best troops to go there with horses and chariots. They marched out during the night and surrounded the town.
6.15: When Elisha's servant got up the next morning, he saw that Syrian troops had the town surrounded. "Sir, what are we going to do?" he asked.
6.17: Then he prayed, "LORD, please help him to see." And the LORD let the servant see that the hill was covered with fiery horses and flaming chariots all around Elisha.
6.18: As the Syrian army came closer, Elisha prayed, "LORD, make those soldiers blind!" And the LORD blinded them with a bright light.
6.19: Elisha told the enemy troops, "You've taken the wrong road and are in the wrong town. Follow me. I'll lead you to the man you're looking for." Elisha led them straight to the capital city of Samaria.
