9.1: Everyone in Israel was listed in the official family records that were included in the history of Israel's kings. The people of Judah were taken to Babylonia as prisoners because they sinned against the LORD.
9.2: And the first people to return to their towns included priests, Levites, temple workers, and other Israelites.
9.3: People from the tribes of Judah, Benjamin, Ephraim, and Manasseh settled in Jerusalem.
9.13: There was a total of 1,760 priests, all of them family leaders in their clan and trained in the work at the temple.
9.17: Shallum, Akkub, Talmon, Ahiman, and their relatives were the guards at the temple gates. Shallum was the leader of this clan,
9.18: and for a long time they had been the guards at the King's Gate on the east side of the city. Before that, their ancestors guarded the entrance to the Levite camp.
9.19: Shallum son of Kore, as well as the other men in the Korahite clan, guarded the entrance to the temple, just as their ancestors had guarded the entrance to the sacred tent.
9.20: Phinehas son of Eleazar had supervised their work because the LORD was with him.
9.21: Zechariah son of Meshelemiah was also one of the guards at the temple.
9.22: There was a total of 212 guards, all of them listed in the family records in their towns. Their ancestors had been chosen by King David and by Samuel the prophet to be responsible for this work,
9.23: and now they guarded the temple gates.
9.24: There was one full-time guard appointed to each of the four sides of the temple.
9.25: Their assistants lived in the villages outside the city, and every seven days a group of them would come into the city and take their turn at guard duty.
9.26: The four full-time guards were Levites, and they supervised the other guards and were responsible for the rooms in the temple and the supplies kept there.
9.27: They guarded the temple day and night and opened its doors every morning.
9.28: Some of the Levites were responsible for the equipment used in worship at the temple, and they had to count everything before and after it was used.
9.29: Others were responsible for the temple furnishings and its sacred objects, as well as the flour, wine, olive oil, incense, and spices.
9.30: But only the priests could mix the spices.
9.31: Mattithiah, Shallum's oldest son, was a member of the Levite clan of Korah, and he was in charge of baking the bread used for offerings.
9.32: The Levites from the Kohath clan were in charge of baking the sacred loaves of bread for each Sabbath.
9.33: The Levite family leaders who were the musicians also lived at the temple. They had no other responsibilities, because they were on duty day and night.
9.34: All of these men were family leaders in the Levi tribe and were listed that way in their family records. They lived in Jerusalem.
9.35: Jeiel had settled the town of Gibeon, where he and his wife Maacah lived.
9.36: They had ten sons, who were born in the following order: Abdon, Zur, Kish, Baal, Ner, Nadab,
9.38: the father of Shimeam. Some of them went to live in Jerusalem near their relatives.
9.39: Ner was the father of Kish and the grandfather of King Saul. Saul had four sons: Jonathan, Malchishua, Abinadab, and Eshbaal.

10.1: The Philistines fought against Israel in a battle at Mount Gilboa. Israel's soldiers ran from the Philistines, and many of them were killed.
10.2: The Philistines closed in on Saul and his sons and killed three of them: Jonathan, Abinadab, and Malchishua.
10.3: The fighting was fierce around Saul, and he was badly wounded by enemy arrows.
10.5: When the soldier realized that Saul was dead, he killed himself in the same way.
10.6: Saul, three of his sons, and all his male relatives were dead.
10.7: The Israelites who lived in Jezreel Valley learned that their army had run away and that Saul and his sons were dead. They ran away too, and the Philistines moved into the towns the Israelites left behind.
10.8: The next day the Philistines came back to the battlefield to carry away the weapons of the dead Israelite soldiers. When they found the bodies of Saul and his sons on Mount Gilboa,
10.9: they took Saul's weapons, pulled off his armor, and cut off his head. Then they sent messengers everywhere in Philistia to spread the news among their people and to thank the idols of their gods.
10.10: They put Saul's armor in the temple of their gods and hung his head in the temple of their god Dagon.
10.11: When the people who lived in Jabesh in Gilead heard what the Philistines had done to Saul,
10.12: some brave men went to get his body and the bodies of his three sons. The men brought the bodies back to Jabesh, where they buried them under an oak tree. Then for seven days, they went without eating to show their sorrow.
10.13: Saul died because he was unfaithful and disobeyed the LORD. He even asked advice from a woman who talked to spirits of the dead,
10.14: instead of asking the LORD. So the LORD had Saul killed and gave his kingdom to David, the son of Jesse.

11.1: Israel's leaders met with David at Hebron and said, "We are your relatives,
11.2: and we know that you have led our army into battle, even when Saul was still our king. The LORD God has promised that you would rule our country and take care of us like a shepherd.
11.3: So we have come to crown you king of Israel." David made an agreement with the leaders and asked the LORD to be their witness. Then the leaders poured olive oil on David's head to show that he was now king of Israel. This happened just as the LORD's prophet Samuel had said.
11.4: Jerusalem was called Jebus at the time, and David led Israel's army to attack the town.
11.5: The Jebusites said, "You won't be able to get in here!" But David captured the fortress of Mount Zion, which is now called the City of David.
11.6: David had told his troops, "The first soldier to kill a Jebusite will become my army commander." And since Joab son of Zeruiah attacked first, he became commander.
11.7: Later, David moved to the fortress--that's why it's called the City of David.
11.8: He had the city rebuilt, starting at the landfill on the east side. Meanwhile, Joab supervised the repairs to the rest of the city.
11.9: David became a great and strong ruler, because the LORD All-Powerful was on his side.
11.10: The LORD had promised that David would become king, and so everyone in Israel gave David their support. Certain warriors also helped keep his kingdom strong.
11.11: The first of these warriors was Jashobeam the son of Hachmoni, the leader of the Three Warriors. In one battle he killed 300 men with his spear.
11.12: Another one of the Three Warriors was Eleazar son of Dodo the Ahohite.
11.13: During a battle against the Philistines at Pas-Dammim, all the Israelite soldiers ran away,
11.14: except Eleazar, who stayed with David. They took their positions in a nearby barley field and defeated the Philistines! The LORD gave Israel a great victory that day.
11.15: One time the Three Warriors went to meet David among the rocks at Adullam Cave. The Philistine army had set up camp in Rephaim Valley
11.16: and had taken over Bethlehem. David was in a fortress,
11.17: and he said, "I'm very thirsty. I wish I had a drink of water from the well by the gate to Bethlehem."
11.18: The Three Warriors sneaked through the Philistine camp and got some water from the well near Bethlehem's gate. They took it back to David, but he refused to drink it. Instead, he poured out the water as a sacrifice to the LORD
11.19: and said, "Drinking this water would be like drinking the blood of these men who risked their lives to get it for me." The Three Warriors did these brave deeds.
11.20: Joab's brother Abishai was the leader of the Thirty Warriors, and in one battle he killed 300 men with his spear. He was just as famous as the Three Warriors
11.21: and was more famous than the rest of the Thirty Warriors. He was their commander, but he never became one of the Three Warriors.
11.22: Benaiah the son of Jehoiada was a brave man from Kabzeel who did some amazing things. One time he killed two of Moab's best fighters, and one snowy day he went into a pit and killed a lion.
11.23: Another time he killed an Egyptian who was over two meters tall and was armed with a spear. Benaiah only had a club, so he grabbed the spear from the Egyptian and killed him with it.
11.24: Benaiah did things like that; he was just as brave as the Three Warriors,
11.25: even though he never became one of them. And he was certainly as famous as the rest of the Thirty Warriors. So David made him the leader of his own bodyguard.

12.1: Some time earlier, David had gone to live in the town of Ziklag to escape from King Saul. While David was there, several brave warriors joined him to help fight his battles.
12.2: Several of these warriors were from King Saul's own tribe of Benjamin. They were experts at using a bow and arrows, and they could shoot an arrow or sling a stone with either hand.
12.8: Men from the tribe of Gad also joined David at his fortress in the desert and served as his warriors. They were also brave soldiers--fierce as lions and quick as gazelles. They were always prepared to fight with shields and spears.
12.14: All these men were army officers; some were high-ranking officers over a thousand troops, and others were officers over a hundred troops.
12.15: Earlier, they had crossed the Jordan River when it flooded, and they chased out the people who lived in the valleys on each side of the river.
12.16: One time a group of men from the tribes of Benjamin and Judah went to the fortress where David was staying.
12.17: David met them outside and said, "If you are coming as friends to fight on my side, then stay and join us. But if you try to turn me over to my enemies, the God our ancestors worshiped will punish you, because I have done nothing wrong."
12.18: Amasai, who later became the leader of the Thirty Warriors, was one of these men who went to David. God's Spirit took control of him, and he said, "We will join you, David son of Jesse! You and your followers will always be successful, because God fights on your side." So David agreed to let them stay, and he even put them in charge of his soldiers who raided enemy villages.
12.19: Some of the warriors who joined David were from the tribe of Manasseh. They had earlier gone with David when he agreed to fight on the side of the Philistines against King Saul. But as soon as the Philistine rulers realized that David might turn against them and rejoin Saul, they sent David away to the town of Ziklag.
12.20: That's when the following men from Manasseh joined him: Adnah, Jozabad, Jediael, Michael, Jozabad, Elihu, and Zillethai. They had all been commanders in Saul's army
12.21: and brave soldiers, and so David made them officers in his army. They fought on his side when enemy troops attacked.
12.22: Day after day, new men came to join David, and soon he had a large, powerful army.
12.38: All of these soldiers voluntarily came to Hebron because they wanted David to become king of Israel. In fact, everyone in Israel wanted the same thing.
12.39: The soldiers stayed in Hebron three days, eating and drinking what their relatives had prepared for them.
12.40: Other Israelites from as far away as the territories of Issachar, Zebulun, and Naphtali brought cattle and sheep to slaughter for food. They also brought donkeys, camels, mules, and oxen that were loaded down with flour, dried figs and raisins, wine, and olive oil. Everyone in Israel was very happy.

13.8: while David and the crowd danced and sang praises to the LORD with all their might. They played music on small harps and other stringed instruments, and on tambourines, cymbals, and trumpets.

13.11: David then got angry with God for killing Uzzah. So he named that place "Attack on Uzzah," and it's been called that ever since.
13.12: David was afraid what the LORD might do to him, and he asked himself, "Should I really be the one to take care of the sacred chest?"
13.13: So instead of taking it to Jerusalem, David decided to take it to the home of Obed-Edom, who lived in the town of Gath.
13.14: The chest stayed there for three months, and the LORD blessed Obed-Edom, his family, and everything he owned.

14.1: King Hiram of Tyre sent some officials to David. They brought along carpenters and stone workers, and enough cedar logs to build David a palace.
14.2: David now knew that the LORD had made him a powerful king of Israel for the good of his people.
14.3: After David moved to Jerusalem, he married more women and had more sons and daughters.
14.8: When the Philistines heard that David had become king of Israel, they came to capture him. But David heard about their plan and marched out to meet them in battle.
14.9: The Philistines had already camped in Rephaim Valley and were raiding the nearby villages.
14.10: David asked God, "Should I attack the Philistines? Will you help me win?" The LORD told David, "Yes, attack them! I will give you victory."
14.11: David and his army marched to Baal-Perazim, where they attacked and defeated the Philistines. He said, "I defeated my enemies because God broke through them like a mighty flood." So he named the place "The Lord Broke Through."
14.12: Then David ordered his troops to burn the idols that the Philistines had left behind.
14.13: Some time later, the Philistines came back into the hill country and camped in Rephaim Valley.
14.15: Wait there until you hear the treetops making the sound of marching troops. That sound will mean I have marched out ahead of you to fight the Philistine army. So you must then attack quickly!"
14.16: David obeyed God and he defeated the Philistines. He even chased them all the way from Gibeon to the entrance to Gezer.
14.17: From then on, David became even more famous, and the LORD made all the nations afraid of him.

15.1: David had several buildings built in Jerusalem, and he had a tent set up where the sacred chest would be kept.
15.2: He said, "Only Levites will be allowed to carry the chest, because the LORD has chosen them to do that work and to serve him forever."
15.3: Next, David invited everyone to come to Jerusalem and watch the sacred chest being carried to the place he had set up for it.
15.4: He also sent for Aaron's descendants and for the Levites. The Levites that came were:
15.5: Uriel, the leader of the Kohath clan, and 120 of his relatives;
15.6: Asaiah, the leader of the Merari clan, and 220 of his relatives;
15.7: Joel, the leader of the Gershon clan, and 130 of his relatives;
15.8: Shemaiah, the leader of the Elizaphan clan, and 200 of his relatives;
15.9: Eliel, the leader of the Hebron clan, and 80 of his relatives; and
15.10: Amminadab, the leader of the Uzziel clan, with 112 of his relatives.
15.11: David called together these six Levites and the two priests, Zadok and Abiathar.
15.12: He said to them, "You are the leaders of the clans in the Levi tribe. You and your relatives must first go through the ceremony to make yourselves clean and acceptable to the LORD. Then you may carry the sacred chest that belongs to the LORD God of Israel and bring it to the place I have prepared for it.
15.13: The first time we tried to bring the chest to Jerusalem, we didn't ask the LORD what he wanted us to do. He was angry with us, because you Levites weren't there to carry the chest."
15.14: The priests and the Levites made themselves clean. They were now ready to carry the sacred chest
15.15: on poles that rested on their shoulders, just as the LORD had told Moses to do.
15.16: David then told the leaders to choose some Levites to sing and play music on small harps, other stringed instruments, and cymbals.
15.22: Chenaniah was chosen to be the music director, because he was a skilled musician.
15.25: David, the leaders of Israel, and the army commanders were very happy as they went to Obed-Edom's house to get the sacred chest.
15.26: God gave the Levites the strength they needed to carry the chest, and so they sacrificed seven bulls and seven rams.
15.27: David, the Levites, Chenaniah the music director, and all the musicians were wearing linen robes, and David was also wearing a linen cloth.
15.28: While the sacred chest was being carried into Jerusalem, everyone was celebrating by shouting and playing music on horns, trumpets, cymbals, harps, and other stringed instruments.
15.29: Saul's daughter Michal looked out her window and watched the chest being brought into David's City. But when she saw David jumping and dancing in honor of the LORD, she was disgusted.

16.1: They put the sacred chest inside the tent that David had set up for it, then they offered sacrifices to please the LORD and sacrifices to ask his blessing.
16.2: After David had finished, he blessed the people in the name of the LORD
16.3: and gave every person in the crowd a small loaf of bread, some meat, and a handful of raisins.
16.4: David appointed some of the Levites to serve at the sacred chest; they were to play music and sing praises to the LORD God of Israel.
16.5: Asaph was their leader, and Zechariah was his assistant. Jeiel, Shemiramoth, Jehiel, Mattithiah, Eliab, Benaiah, Obed-Edom, and another man named Jeiel were appointed to play small harps and stringed instruments. Asaph himself played the cymbals,
16.6: and the two priests Benaiah and Jahaziel were to blow trumpets every day in front of the sacred chest.
16.7: That same day, David instructed Asaph and his relatives for the first time to sing these praises to the LORD:
16.8: Praise the LORD and pray in his name! Tell everyone what he has done.
16.9: Sing praises to the LORD! Tell about his miracles.
16.10: Celebrate and worship his holy name with all your heart.
16.11: Trust the LORD and his mighty power. Worship him always.
16.12: Remember his miracles and all his wonders and his fair decisions.
16.13: You belong to the family of Israel, his servant; you are his chosen ones, the descendants of Jacob.
16.14: The LORD is our God, bringing justice everywhere on earth.
16.15: We must never forget his agreement and his promises, not in thousands of years. *
16.18: when he said, "I'll give you the land of Canaan."
16.19: At the time there were only a few of us, and we were homeless.
16.20: We wandered from nation to nation, from one country to another.
16.21: God did not let anyone mistreat our people. Instead he protected us by punishing rulers
16.23: Everyone on this earth, sing praises to the LORD. Day after day announce, "The LORD has saved us!"
16.24: Tell every nation on earth, "The LORD is wonderful and does marvelous things!
16.25: The LORD is great and deserves our greatest praise! He is the only God worthy of our worship.
16.26: Other nations worship idols, but the LORD created the heavens.
16.27: Give honor and praise to the LORD, whose power and beauty fill his holy temple."
16.28: Tell everyone of every nation, "Praise the glorious power of the LORD.
16.29: He is wonderful! Praise him and bring an offering into his temple. Worship the LORD, majestic and holy.
16.30: Everyone on earth, now tremble!" The world stands firm, never to be shaken.
16.31: Tell the heavens and the earth to be glad and celebrate! And announce to the nations, "The LORD is King!"
16.32: Command the ocean to roar with all of its creatures and the fields to rejoice with all of their crops.

16.34: Praise the LORD because he is good to us, and his love never fails.
16.35: Say to him, "Save us, LORD God! Bring us back from among the nations. Let us celebrate and shout in praise of your holy name.
16.37: David chose Asaph and the Levites in his clan to be in charge of the daily worship at the place where the sacred chest was kept.
16.38: Obed-Edom and 68 of his relatives were their assistants, and Hosah and Obed-Edom the son of Jeduthun were the guards.
16.39: David also chose Zadok the priest and his relatives who were priests to serve at the LORD's sacred tent at Gibeon.
16.40: They were to offer sacrifices on the altar every morning and evening, just as the LORD had commanded in the Law he gave Israel.
16.41: Heman and Jeduthun were their assistants, as well as the other men who had been chosen to praise the LORD for his never-ending love.
16.42: Heman and Jeduthun were also responsible for blowing the trumpets, and for playing the cymbals and other instruments during worship at the tent. The Levites in Jeduthun's clan were the guards at Gibeon.
16.43: After that, everyone went home, and David went home to his family.

17.1: Soon after David moved into his new palace, he said to Nathan the prophet, "Look around! I live in a palace made of cedar, but the sacred chest is kept in a tent."
17.3: That night, the LORD told Nathan
17.4: to go to David and tell him: David, you are my servant, so listen carefully: You are not the one to build a temple for me.
17.5: I didn't live in a temple when I brought my people out of Egypt, and I don't live in one now. A tent has always been my home wherever I have gone with them.
17.6: I chose special leaders and told them to be like shepherds for my people Israel. But did I ever say anything to even one of them about building a cedar temple for me?
17.7: David, this is what I, the LORD All-Powerful, say to you. I brought you in from the fields where you took care of sheep, and I made you the leader of my people.
17.8: Wherever you went, I helped you and destroyed your enemies right in front of your eyes. I have made you one of the most famous people in the world.
17.9: I have given my people Israel a land of their own where they can live in peace. They will no longer have to tremble with fear--evil nations won't bother them, as they did
17.10: when I let judges rule my people, and I will keep your enemies from attacking you. Now I promise that like you, your descendants will be kings.
17.11: I'll choose one of your sons to be king when you reach the end of your life and are buried beside your ancestors. I'll make him a strong ruler,
17.12: and no one will be able to take his kingdom away from him. He will be the one to build a temple for me.
17.13: I will be like a father to him, and he will be like a son to me. I will never put an end to my agreement with him, as I put an end to my agreement with Saul, who was king before you.
17.14: I will make sure that your son and his descendants will rule my people and my kingdom forever.
17.15: Nathan told David exactly what the LORD had said.
17.16: David went into the tent he had set up for the sacred chest. He sat there and prayed: LORD God, my family and I don't deserve what you have already done for us,
17.17: and yet you have promised to do even more for my descendants. You are treating me as if I am a very important person.
17.18: I am your servant, and you know my thoughts. What else can I say, except that you have honored me?
17.19: It was your choice to do these wonderful things for me and to make these promises.
17.20: No other god is like you, LORD--you alone are God. Everything we have heard about you is true.
17.21: And there is no other nation on earth like Israel, the nation you rescued from slavery in Egypt to be your own. You became famous by using great and wonderful miracles to force other nations and their gods out of your land, so that your people could live here.
17.22: You have chosen Israel to be your people forever, and you have become their God.
17.23: LORD God, please do what you promised me and my descendants.
17.24: Then you will be famous forever, and everyone will say, "The LORD All-Powerful rules Israel and is their God." My kingdom will be strong,
17.25: because you are my God, and you have promised that my descendants will be kings. That's why I have the courage to pray to you like this, even though I am only your servant.
17.26: You are the LORD God, and you have made this good promise to me.
17.27: Now please bless my descendants forever, and let them always be your chosen kings. You have already blessed my family, and I know you will bless us forever.

18.1: Later, David attacked and defeated the Philistines. He captured their town of Gath and the nearby villages.
18.2: David also defeated the Moabites, and so they had to accept him as their ruler and pay taxes to him.
18.3: While King Hadadezer of Zobah was trying to gain control of the territory near the Euphrates River, David met him in battle at Hamath and defeated him.
18.4: David captured 1,000 chariots, 7,000 chariot drivers, and 20,000 soldiers. And he crippled all but 100 of the horses.
18.5: When troops from the Syrian kingdom of Damascus came to help Hadadezer, David killed 22,000 of them.
18.6: Then David stationed some of his troops in Damascus, and the people there had to accept David as their ruler and pay taxes to him. Everywhere David went, the LORD helped him win battles.
18.7: Hadadezer's officers had carried gold shields, but David took these shields and brought them back to Jerusalem.
18.8: He also took a lot of bronze from the cities of Tibhath and Cun, which had belonged to Hadadezer. Later, Solomon used this bronze to make the large bowl called the Sea, and to make the pillars and other furnishings for the temple.
18.11: David gave these gifts to the LORD, just as he had done with the silver and gold he had captured from Edom, Moab, Ammon, Philistia, and Amalek.
18.12: Abishai the son of Zeruiah defeated the Edomite army in Salt Valley and killed 18,000 of their troops.
18.13: Then he stationed troops in Edom, and the people there had to accept David as their ruler. Everywhere David went, the LORD gave him victory in war.
18.14: David ruled all Israel with fairness and justice.
18.15: Joab the son of Zeruiah was the commander in chief of the army. Jehoshaphat the son of Ahilud kept the government records.
18.16: Zadok the son of Ahitub and Ahimelech the son of Abiathar were the priests. Shavsha was the secretary.
18.17: Benaiah the son of Jehoiada was the commander of David's bodyguard. David's sons were his highest-ranking officials.

19.1: Some time later, King Nahash of Ammon died, and his son Hanun became king.
19.2: David said, "Nahash was kind to me, so I will be kind to his son." He sent some officials to Ammon to tell Hanun how sorry he was that his father had died. But when David's officials arrived at Ammon,
19.4: Hanun arrested David's officials and had their beards shaved off and their robes cut off just below the waist, and then he sent them away.
19.5: They were terribly ashamed. When David found out what had happened to his officials, he sent a message that told them, "Stay in Jericho until your beards grow back. Then you can come home."
19.6: The Ammonites realized they had made David furious. So they paid 34 tons of silver to hire chariot troops from Mesopotamia and from the Syrian kingdoms of Maacah and Zobah.
19.7: Thirty-two thousand troops, as well as the king of Maacah and his army, came and camped near Medeba. The Ammonite troops also left their towns and came to prepare for battle.
19.8: David heard what was happening, and he sent out Joab with his army.
19.9: The Ammonite troops marched to the entrance of the city and prepared for battle, while the Syrian troops took their positions in the open fields.
19.10: Joab saw that the enemy troops were lined up on both sides of him. So he picked some of the best Israelite soldiers to fight the Syrians.
19.11: Then he put his brother Abishai in command of the rest of the army and told them to fight against the Ammonites.
19.12: Joab told his brother, "If the Syrians are too much for me to handle, come and help me. And if the Ammonites are too strong for you, I'll come and help you.
19.13: Be brave and fight hard to protect our people and the towns of our LORD God. I pray he will do whatever pleases him."
19.14: Joab and his soldiers attacked the Syrians, and the Syrians ran from them.
19.15: When the Ammonite troops saw that the Syrians had run away, they ran from Abishai's soldiers and went back into their own city. Joab then returned to Jerusalem.
19.16: As soon as the Syrians realized they had been defeated, they sent for their troops that were stationed on the other side of the Euphrates River. Shophach, the commander of Hadadezer's army, led these troops to Ammon.
19.17: David found out what the Syrians were doing, and he brought Israel's entire army together. They crossed the Jordan River, and he commanded them to take their positions facing the Syrian troops. Soon after the fighting began,
19.18: the Syrians ran from Israel. David killed 7,000 chariot troops and 40,000 regular soldiers. He also killed Shophach, their commander.
19.19: When the kings who had been under Hadadezer's rule saw that Israel had defeated them, they made peace with David and accepted him as their new ruler. The Syrians never helped the Ammonites again.

20.1: The next spring, the time when kings go to war, Joab marched out in command of the Israelite army and destroyed towns all over the country of Ammon. He attacked the capital city of Rabbah and left it in ruins. But David stayed in Jerusalem.
20.2: Later, David himself went to Rabbah, where he took the crown from the statue of their god Milcom. The crown was made of about 34 kilograms of gold, and there was a valuable jewel on it. David put the jewel on his crown, then carried off everything else of value.
20.3: He forced the people of Rabbah to work with saws, iron picks, and axes. He also did the same thing with the people in all the other Ammonite towns. David then led Israel's army back to Jerusalem.
20.4: Some time later, Israel fought a battle against the Philistines at Gezer. During this battle, Sibbecai from Hushah killed Sippai, a descendant of the Rephaim, and the Philistines were defeated.
20.5: In another battle against the Philistines, Elhanan the son of Jair killed Lahmi the brother of Goliath from Gath, whose spear shaft was like a weaver's beam.
20.6: Another one of the Philistine soldiers who was a descendant of the Rephaim was as big as a giant and had six fingers on each hand and six toes on each foot. During a battle at Gath,
20.7: he made fun of Israel, so David's nephew Jonathan killed him.
20.8: David and his soldiers killed these three men from Gath who were descendants of the Rephaim.

21.1: Satan decided to cause trouble for Israel by making David think it was a good idea to find out how many people there were in Israel and Judah.
21.2: David told Joab and the army commanders, "Count everyone in Israel, from the town of Beersheba in the south all the way north to Dan. Then I will know how many people can serve in my army."
21.3: Joab answered, "Your Majesty, even if the LORD made your kingdom a hundred times larger, you would still rule everyone in it. Why do you need to know how many soldiers there are? Don't you think that would make the whole nation angry?"
21.4: But David would not change his mind. And so Joab went everywhere in Israel and Judah and counted the people. He returned to Jerusalem
21.5: and told David that the total number of men who could serve in the army was 1,100,000 in Israel and 470,000 in Judah.
21.6: Joab refused to include anyone from the tribes of Levi and Benjamin, because he still disagreed with David's orders.
21.7: David's order to count the people made God angry, and he punished Israel.
21.8: David prayed, "I am your servant. But what I did was stupid and terribly wrong. Please forgive me."
21.9: The LORD said to Gad, one of David's prophets,
21.10: "Tell David that I will punish him in one of three ways. But he will have to choose which one it will be."
21.11: Gad went to David and told him: You must choose how the LORD will punish you:
21.12: Will there be three years when the land won't grow enough food for its people? Or will your enemies constantly defeat you for three months? Or will the LORD send a horrible disease to strike your land for three days? Think about it and decide, because I have to give your answer to God who sent me.
21.13: David was miserable and said, "It's a terrible choice to make! But the LORD is kind, and I'd rather be punished by him than by anyone else."
21.14: So the LORD sent a horrible disease on Israel, and 70,000 Israelites died.
21.16: David saw the LORD's angel in the air, holding a sword over Jerusalem. He and the leaders of Israel, who were all wearing sackcloth, bowed with their faces to the ground,
21.17: and David prayed, "It's my fault! I sinned by ordering the people to be counted. They have done nothing wrong--they are innocent sheep. LORD God, please punish me and my family. Don't let the disease wipe out your people."
21.18: The LORD's angel told the prophet Gad to tell David that he must go to Araunah's threshing place and build an altar in honor of the LORD.
21.20: Araunah and his four sons were threshing wheat at the time, and when they saw the angel, the four sons ran to hide.
21.21: Just then, David arrived, and when Araunah saw him, he stopped his work and bowed down.
21.22: David said, "Would you sell me your threshing place, so I can build an altar on it to the LORD? Then this disease will stop killing the people. I'm willing to pay whatever you say it's worth."
21.23: Araunah answered, "Take it, Your Majesty, and do whatever you want with it. I'll even give you the oxen for the sacrifice and the wheat for the grain sacrifice. And you can use the threshing-boards for the fire. It's all yours!"
21.24: But David replied, "No! I want to pay you what they're worth. I can't just take something from you and then offer the LORD a sacrifice that cost me nothing."
21.25: So David paid Araunah 600 gold coins for his threshing place.
21.26: David built an altar and offered sacrifices to please the LORD and sacrifices to ask his blessing. David prayed, and the LORD answered him by sending fire down on the altar.
21.27: Then the LORD commanded the angel to put the sword away.
21.28: When David saw that the LORD had answered his prayer, he offered more sacrifices there at the threshing place,

22.1: David said, "The temple of the LORD God must be built right here at this threshing place. And the altar for offering sacrifices will also be here."
22.2: David ordered the foreigners living in Israel to come to Jerusalem. Then he assigned some to cut blocks of stone for building the temple.
22.3: He got a large supply of iron to make into nails and hinges for the doors, and he provided so much bronze that it could not be weighed.
22.4: He also brought an endless supply of cedar logs from the cities of Sidon and Tyre.
22.5: He said, "The temple for the LORD must be great, so that everyone in the world will know about it. But since my son Solomon is young and has no experience, I will make sure that everything is ready for the temple to be built." That's why David did all these things before he died.
22.6: David sent for his son Solomon and told him to build a temple for the LORD God of Israel.
22.7: He said: My son, I wanted to build a temple where the LORD my God would be worshiped.
22.8: But some time ago, he told me, "David, you have killed too many people and have fought too many battles. That's why you are not the one to build my temple.
22.9: But when your son becomes king, I will give him peace throughout his kingdom. His name will be Solomon, because during his rule I will keep Israel safe and peaceful.
22.10: Solomon will build my temple. He will be like a son to me, and I will be like a father to him. In fact, one of his descendants will always rule in Israel."
22.11: Solomon, my son, I now pray that the LORD your God will be with you and keep his promise to help you build a temple for him.
22.12: May he give you wisdom and knowledge, so that you can rule Israel according to his Law.
22.13: If you obey the laws and teachings that the LORD gave Moses, you will be successful. Be strong and brave and don't get discouraged or be afraid of anything.
22.14: I have all the supplies you'll need to build the temple: You have more than 3,000 tons of gold and over 34,000 tons of silver. There's also plenty of wood, stone, and more bronze and iron than I could weigh. Ask for anything else you need.
22.15: I have also assigned men who will cut and lay the stone. And there are carpenters and people who are experts in working with
22.16: gold, silver, bronze, and iron. You have plenty of workers to do the job. Now get started, and I pray that the LORD will be with you in your work.
22.17: David then gave orders for the leaders of Israel to help Solomon.
22.18: David said: The LORD our God has helped me defeat all the people who lived here before us, and he has given you peace from all your enemies. Now this land belongs to the LORD and his people.
22.19: Obey the LORD your God with your heart and soul. Begin work on the temple to honor him, so that the sacred chest and the things used for worship can be kept there.

23.1: David was old when he chose his son Solomon to be king of Israel.
23.2: Some time later, David called together all of Israel's leaders, priests, and Levites.
23.3: He then counted the Levite men who were at least 30 years old, and the total was 38,000.
23.4: He said, "Twenty-four thousand of the Levites will be in charge of the temple, 6,000 will be temple officials and judges,
23.5: 4,000 will be guards at the temple, and 4,000 will praise the LORD by playing the musical instruments I have given them."
23.6: David then divided the Levites into three groups according to the clans of Levi's sons, Gershon, Kohath, and Merari.
23.7: Gershon had two sons: Ladan and Shimei.
23.8: Ladan was the father of Jehiel, Zetham, and Joel.
23.9: They were all family leaders among their father's descendants. Shimei was the father of Shelomoth, Haziel, and Haran.
23.12: Kohath had four sons: Amram, Izhar, Hebron, and Uzziel.
23.13: Amram was the father of Aaron and Moses. Aaron and his descendants were chosen to be in charge of all the sacred things. They served the LORD by offering sacrifices to him and by blessing the people in his name.
23.17: Rehabiah, who was Eliezer's only son, had many children.
23.18: The second son born to Kohath was Izhar, and his oldest son was Shelomith.
23.19: Hebron, the third son of Kohath, was the father of Jeriah, Amariah, Jahaziel, and Jekameam.
23.20: Kohath's youngest son, Uzziel, was the father of Micah and Isshiah.
23.21: Merari had two sons: Mahli and Mushi. Mahli was the father of Eleazar and Kish.
23.22: Eleazar had no sons, only daughters, and they married their uncle's sons.
23.23: Mushi the second son of Merari, was the father of Mahli, Eder, and Jeremoth.
23.24: These were the clans and families of the tribe of Levi. Those who were 20 years and older were assigned to work at the LORD's temple.
23.25: David said: The LORD God of Israel has given his people peace, and he will live in Jerusalem forever.
23.26: And so, the Levites won't need to move the sacred tent and the things used for worship from place to place.
23.27: From now on, all Levites at least 20 years old
23.28: will serve the LORD by helping Aaron's descendants do their work at the temple, by keeping the courtyards and rooms of the temple clean, and by making sure that everything used in worship stays pure.
23.29: They will also be in charge of the sacred loaves of bread, the flour for the grain sacrifices, the thin wafers, any offerings to be baked, and the flour mixed with olive oil. These Levites will weigh and measure these offerings.
23.30: Every morning and evening, the Levites are to give thanks to the LORD and sing praises to him.
23.31: They must also give thanks and sing praises when sacrifices are offered on each Sabbath, as well as during New Moon Festivals and other religious feasts. There must always be enough Levites on duty at the temple to do everything that needs to be done.
23.32: They were once in charge of taking care of the sacred tent; now they are responsible for the temple and for helping Aaron's descendants.

24.1: Aaron's descendants were then divided into work groups. Aaron had four sons: Nadab, Abihu, Eleazar, and Ithamar.
24.2: But Nadab and Abihu died long before their father, without having any sons. That's why Eleazar and Ithamar served as priests.
24.3: David divided Aaron's descendants into groups, according to their assigned work. Zadok, one of Eleazar's descendants, and Ahimelech, one of Ithamar's descendants, helped David.
24.4: Eleazar's descendants were divided into 16 groups, and Ithamar's were divided into eight groups, because Eleazar's family included more family leaders.
24.5: However, both families included temple officials and priests, and so to make sure the work was divided fairly, David asked God what to do.
24.6: As each group was assigned their duties, Shemaiah the son of Nethanel the Levite wrote down the name of the family leader in charge of that group. The witnesses were David and his officials, as well as Zadok the priest, Ahimelech the son of Abiathar, and the family leaders from the clans of the priests and the Levites.
24.19: These men were assigned their duties at the temple, just as the LORD God of Israel had commanded their ancestor Aaron.
24.20: Here is a list of the other descendants of Levi: Amram was the ancestor of Shubael and Jehdeiah.
24.21: Rehabiah was the ancestor of Isshiah, the oldest son in his family.
24.22: Izhar was the father of Shelomoth and the grandfather of Jahath.
24.23: Hebron had four sons, in the following order: Jeriah, Amariah, Jahaziel, and Jekameam.
24.24: Uzziel was the father of Micah and the grandfather of Shamir.
24.25: Isshiah, Micah's brother, was the father of Zechariah.
24.26: Merari was the father of Mahli, Mushi, and Jaaziah.
24.27: Jaaziah had three sons: Shoham, Zaccur, and Ibri.
24.30: Mushi had three sons: Mahli, Eder, and Jerimoth. These were the descendants of Levi, according to their clans.
24.31: Each one was assigned his duties in the same way that their relatives the priests had been assigned their duties. David, Zadok, Ahimelech, and the family leaders of the priests and Levites were the witnesses.

25.1: David and the temple officials chose the descendants of Asaph, Heman, and Jeduthun to be in charge of music. They were to praise the LORD by playing cymbals, harps and other stringed instruments. Here is a list of the musicians and their duties:
25.2: Asaph's four sons, Zaccur, Joseph, Nethaniah, and Asarelah, were under the direction of their father and played music whenever the king told them to.
25.3: Jeduthun's six sons, Gedaliah, Zeri, Jeshaiah, Shimei, Hashabiah, and Mattithiah, were under the direction of their father and played harps and sang praises to the LORD.
25.4: Heman had 14 sons: Bukkiah, Mattaniah, Uzziel, Shebuel, Jerimoth, Hananiah, Hanani, Eliathah, Giddalti, Romamtiezer, Joshbekashah, Mallothi, Hothir, Mahazioth.
25.5: Heman was one of the king's prophets, and God honored Heman by giving him 14 sons and 3 daughters.
25.6: His sons were under his direction and played cymbals, harps, and other stringed instruments during times of worship at the temple. Asaph, Jeduthun, and Heman took their orders directly from the king.
25.7: There were 288 of these men, and all of them were skilled musicians.
25.8: David assigned them their duties by asking the LORD what he wanted. Everyone was responsible for something, whether young or old, teacher or student.

26.1: The temple guards were also divided into groups according to clans. Meshelemiah son of Kore was from the Korah clan and was a descendant of Asaph.
26.2: He had seven sons, who were born in the following order: Zechariah, Jediael, Zebadiah, Jathniel,
26.8: There were 62 descendants of Obed-Edom who were strong enough to be guards at the temple.
26.9: Eighteen descendants of Meshelemiah were chosen for this work.
26.12: The guards were divided into groups, according to their family leaders, and they were assigned duties at the temple, just like the other Levites.
26.13: Each group, no matter how large or small, was assigned a gate to guard, and they let the LORD show them what he wanted done.
26.14: Shelemiah was chosen to guard the East Gate. Zechariah his son was a wise man and was chosen to guard the North Gate.
26.15: Obed-Edom was then chosen to guard the South Gate, and his sons were chosen to guard the storerooms.
26.16: Shuppim and Hosah were chosen to guard the West Gate and the Shallecheth Gate on the upper road. The guards were assigned the following work schedule:
26.17: Each day six guards were on duty on the east side of the temple, four were on duty on the north side, and four were on duty on the south side. Two guards were stationed at each of the two storerooms,
26.18: four were stationed along the road leading to the west courtyard, and two guards stayed in the court itself.
26.19: These were the guard duties assigned to the men from the clans of Korah and Merari.
26.20: The Levites who were relatives of the Korahites and the Merarites were in charge of guarding the temple treasury and the gifts that had been dedicated to God.
26.21: Ladan was from the Gershon clan and was the father of Jehieli. Many of his other descendants were family leaders in the clan.
26.22: Jehieli was the father of Zetham and Joel, and they were responsible for guarding the treasury.
26.23: Other guards at the treasury were from the Kohathite clans of Amram, Izhar, Hebron, and Uzziel.
26.24: Shebuel was a descendant of Gershom the son of Moses. He was the chief official in charge of the temple treasury.
26.25: The descendants of Gershom's brother Eliezer included Rehabiah, Jeshaiah, Joram, Zichri, and Shelomoth.
26.26: Shelomoth and his relatives were in charge of all the gifts that were dedicated to the LORD. These included the gifts that King David had dedicated, as well as those dedicated by the family leaders, army officers, and army commanders.
26.27: And whenever valuable things were captured in battle, these men brought back some of them to make repairs to the temple.
26.28: Shelomoth and his relatives were responsible for any gifts that had been given to the temple, including those from Samuel the prophet, King Saul the son of Kish, Abner the son of Ner, and Joab the son of Zeruiah.
26.29: Chenaniah from the Izhar clan and his sons were government officials and judges. They did not work at the temple.
26.30: Hashabiah from the Hebron clan and 1,700 of his skilled relatives were the officials in charge of all religious and government business in the Israelite territories west of the Jordan River.

27.1: Each month a group of 24,000 men served as soldiers in Israel's army. These men, which included the family leaders, army commanders, and officials of the king, were under the command of the following men, arranged by the month of their service:
27.2: In the first month, Jashobeam the son of Zabdiel,
27.4: in the second month, Dodai the Ahohite, whose assistant was Mikloth;
27.5: in the third month, Benaiah the son of Jehoiada the priest,
27.6: who was the leader of the Thirty Warriors, and whose son Ammizabad was also an army commander;
27.7: in the fourth month, Asahel the brother of Joab, whose son Zebadiah took over command after him;
27.8: in the fifth month, Shamhuth from the Izrah clan;
27.9: in the sixth month, Ira the son of Ikkesh from Tekoa;
27.10: in the seventh month, Helez from Pelon in the territory of Ephraim;
27.11: in the eighth month, Sibbecai from Hushah of the Zerah clan;
27.12: in the ninth month, Abiezer from Anathoth in the territory of Benjamin;
27.13: in the tenth month, Maharai from Netophah of the Zerah clan;
27.14: in the eleventh month, Benaiah from Pirathon in the territory of Ephraim;
27.15: in the twelfth month, Heldai from Netophah, who was a descendant of Othniel.
27.23: When David decided to count the people of Israel, he gave orders not to count anyone under 20 years of age, because the LORD had promised long ago that Israel would have as many people as there are stars in the sky.
27.24: Joab the son of Zeruiah had begun to count the people, but he stopped when the LORD began punishing Israel. So the total number was never included in David's official records.
27.25: Azmaveth the son of Adiel was in charge of the king's personal storage rooms. Jonathan the son of Uzziah was in charge of the king's other storerooms that were in the towns, the villages, and the defense towers in Israel.
27.26: Ezri the son of Chelub was in charge of the workers who farmed the king's land.
27.27: Shimei from Ramah was in charge of the vineyards, and Zabdi from Shepham was in charge of storing the wine.
27.28: Baal Hanan from Geder was in charge of the olive and sycamore trees in the western foothills, and Joash was in charge of storing the olive oil.
27.29: Shitrai from Sharon was responsible for the cattle that were kept in Sharon Plain, and Shaphat son of Adlai was responsible for those kept in the valleys.
27.30: Obil the Ishmaelite was in charge of the camels, Jehdeiah from Meronoth was in charge of the donkeys, and Jaziz the Hagrite was in charge of the sheep and goats.
27.31: These were the men in charge of David's royal property.
27.32: David's uncle Jonathan was a wise and intelligent advisor. He and Jehiel the son of Hachmoni taught David's sons.
27.33: Ahithophel and Hushai the Archite were two of David's advisors.
27.34: Jehoiada the son of Benaiah was the king's advisor after Ahithophel, and later, Abiathar was his advisor. Joab was commander of Israel's army.

28.1: David called a meeting in Jerusalem for all of Israel's leaders, including the tribal leaders, the government officials, the army commanders, the officials in charge of the royal property and livestock, the palace officials, and the brave warriors.
28.2: After everyone was there, David stood up and said: Listen to me, my people. I wanted to build a place where the sacred chest would be kept, so we could go there and worship the LORD our God. I have prepared all the supplies for building a temple,
28.3: but the LORD has refused to let me build it, because he said I have killed too many people in battle.
28.4: The LORD God chose Judah to be the leading tribe in Israel. Then from Judah, he chose my father's family, and from that family, he chose me to be the king of Israel, and he promised that my descendants will also rule as kings.
28.5: The LORD has blessed me with many sons, but he chose my son Solomon to be the next king of Israel.
28.6: The LORD said to me, "Your son Solomon will build my temple, and it will honor me. Solomon will be like a son to me, and I will be like a father to him.
28.7: If he continues to obey my laws and commands, his kingdom will never end."
28.8: My friends, you are the LORD's people. And now, with God as your witness, I want you to promise that you will do your best to obey everything the LORD God has commanded us. Then this land will always belong to you and your descendants.
28.10: The LORD has chosen you to build a temple for worshiping him. Be confident and do the work you have been assigned.
28.11: After David finished speaking, he gave Solomon the plans for building the main rooms of the temple, including the porch, the storerooms, the rooms upstairs and downstairs, as well as the most holy place.
28.12: He gave Solomon his plans for the courtyards and the open areas around the temple, and for the rooms to store the temple treasures and gifts that had been dedicated to God.
28.13: David also gave Solomon his plans for dividing the priests and the Levites into groups, as well as for the work that needed to be done at the temple and for taking care of the objects used for worship.
28.14: He told Solomon how much gold and silver was to be used in making the sacred objects,
28.16: the gold table which held the sacred loaves of bread, the tables made of silver,
28.17: the meat forks, the bowls and cups,
28.18: the gold incense altar, and the gold statue of a chariot for the winged creatures which were on the lid of the sacred chest.
28.21: The priests and Levites have been assigned their duties, and all the skilled workers are prepared to do their work. The people and their leaders will do anything you tell them.

29.1: David told the crowd: God chose my son Solomon to build the temple, but Solomon is young and has no experience. This is not just any building--this is the temple for the LORD God!
29.2: That's why I have done my best to get everything Solomon will need to build it--gold, silver, bronze, iron, wood, onyx, turquoise, colored gems, all kinds of precious stones, and marble.
29.3: Besides doing all that, I have promised to give part of my own gold and silver as a way of showing my love for God's temple.
29.4: More than 100 tons of my finest gold and almost 240 tons of my silver will be used to decorate its walls
29.5: and to make the gold and silver objects. Now, who else will show their dedication to the LORD by giving gifts for building his temple?
29.6: After David finished speaking, the family leaders, the tribal leaders, the army commanders, and the government officials voluntarily gave gifts
29.7: for the temple. These gifts included more than 170 tons of gold, over 340 tons of silver, 620 tons of bronze, and more than 3,400 tons of iron.
29.8: Everyone who owned precious stones also donated them to the temple treasury, where Jehiel from the Levite clan of Gershon guarded them.
29.9: David and the people were very happy that so much had been given to the LORD, and they all celebrated.

29.21: The next day, the Israelites slaughtered 1,000 bulls, 1,000 rams, and 1,000 lambs, and they offered them as sacrifices to please the LORD, along with offerings of wine.

The people celebrated and poured olive oil on Solomon's head to show that he would be their next king. They also poured oil on Zadok's head to show that he was their priest.
29.23: So Solomon became king after David his father. Solomon was successful, and everyone in Israel obeyed him.
29.24: Every official and every soldier, as well as all of David's other sons, were loyal to him.
29.25: The LORD made Solomon a great king, and the whole nation was amazed at how famous he was. In fact, no other king of Israel was as great as Solomon.
29.26: David the son of Jesse was king of Israel
29.27: for 40 years. He ruled from Hebron for 7 years and from Jerusalem for 33 years.
29.28: David was rich and respected and lived to be an old man. Then he died, and his son Solomon became king.

1.6: and there at the bronze altar, Solomon offered a thousand animals as sacrifices to please the LORD.

1.10: and make me wise. Give me the knowledge I'll need to be the king of this great nation of yours.

2.1: Solomon decided to build a temple where the LORD would be worshiped, and also to build a palace for himself.

2.3: Solomon sent the following message to King Hiram of Tyre: Years ago, when my father David was building his palace, you supplied him with cedar logs. Now will you send me supplies?
2.4: I am building a temple where the LORD my God will be worshiped. Sweet-smelling incense will be burned there, and sacred bread will be offered to him. Worshipers will offer sacrifices to the LORD every morning and evening, every Sabbath, and on the first day of each month, as well as during all our religious festivals. These things will be done for all time, just as the LORD has commanded.
2.5: This will be a great temple, because our God is greater than all other gods.
2.6: No one can ever build a temple large enough for God--even the heavens are too small a place for him to live in! All I can do is build a place where we can offer sacrifices to him.
2.7: Send me a worker who can not only carve, but who can work with gold, silver, bronze, and iron, as well as make brightly colored cloth. The person you send will work here in Judah and Jerusalem with the skilled workers that my father has already hired.
2.8: I know that you have workers who are experts at cutting lumber in Lebanon. So would you please send me some cedar, pine, and juniper logs? My workers will be there to help them,
2.9: because I'll need a lot of lumber to build such a large and glorious temple.
2.10: I will pay your woodcutters 2,000 tons of wheat, the same amount of barley, 400,000 liters of wine, and that same amount of olive oil.
2.12: Praise the LORD God of Israel who made heaven and earth! He has given David a son who isn't only wise and smart, but who has the knowledge to build a temple for the LORD and a palace for himself.

Not only is Huram an expert at working with gold, silver, bronze, iron, stone, and wood, but he can also make colored cloth and fine linen. 2.15: Go ahead and send the wheat, barley, olive oil, and wine you promised to pay my workers.

2.18: He assigned 70,000 of them to carry building supplies and 80,000 of them to cut stone from the hills. He chose 3,600 others to supervise the workers and to make sure the work was completed.

3.3: The inside of the temple was 27 meters long and 9 meters wide, according to the older standards.

3.7: to decorate the ceiling beams, the doors, the door frames, and the walls. Solomon also told the workers to carve designs of winged creatures into the walls.

3.17: Solomon had one of the columns placed on the south side of the temple's entrance; it was called Jachin. The other one was placed on the north side of the entrance; it was called Boaz.

4.1: Solomon had a bronze altar made that was nine meters square and four and a half meters high.
4.2: He also gave orders to make a large metal bowl called the Sea. It was 4.5 meters across, just over two meters deep, and 13.5 meters around.
4.3: Its outer edge was decorated with two rows of carvings of bulls, ten bulls to about every 45 centimeters, all made from the same piece of metal as the bowl.
4.4: The bowl itself sat on top of twelve bronze bulls, with three bulls facing outward in each of four directions.
4.5: The sides of the bowl were 75 millimeters thick, and its rim was in the shape of a cup that curved outward like flower petals. The bowl held about 60,000 liters.
4.6: He also made ten small bowls and put five on each side of the large bowl. The small bowls were used to wash the animals that were burned on the altar as sacrifices, and the priests used the water in the large bowl to wash their hands.
4.7: Ten gold lampstands were also made according to the plans. Solomon placed these lampstands inside the temple, five on each side of the main room.
4.8: He also made ten tables and placed them in the main room, five on each side. And he made 100 small gold sprinkling bowls.
4.9: Solomon gave orders to build two courtyards: a smaller one that only priests could use and a larger one. The doors to these courtyards were covered with bronze.
4.10: The large bowl called the Sea was placed near the southeast corner of the temple.
4.11: Huram made shovels, sprinkling bowls, and pans for hot ashes. Here is a list of the other furnishings he made for God's temple:
4.12: two columns, two bowl-shaped caps for the tops of these columns, two chain designs on the caps,
4.13: 400 pomegranates in two rows for the chain designs,
4.14: the stands and the small bowls,
4.15: the large bowl and the twelve bulls that held it up,
4.16: pans for hot ashes, as well as shovels and meat forks. Huram made all these things out of polished bronze
4.17: by pouring melted bronze into the clay molds he had set up near the Jordan River, between Succoth and Zeredah.
4.18: There were so many bronze furnishings that no one ever knew how much bronze it took to make them.
4.19: Solomon also gave orders to make the following temple furnishings out of gold: the altar, the tables that held the sacred loaves of bread,
4.20: the lampstands and the lamps that burned in front of the most holy place,
4.21: flower designs, lamps and tongs,
4.22: lamp snuffers, small sprinkling bowls, ladles, fire pans, and the doors to the most holy place and the main room of the temple.

5.1: After the LORD's temple was finished, Solomon put in its storage rooms everything that his father David had dedicated to the LORD, including the gold and silver, and the objects used in worship.
5.6: Solomon and a crowd of people stood in front of the chest and sacrificed more sheep and cattle than could be counted.

5.8: whose wings covered both the chest and the poles used for carrying it.
5.9: The poles were so long that they could be seen from just outside the most holy place, but not from anywhere else. And they stayed there from then on.

5.14: The LORD's glory was in that cloud, and the light from it was so bright that the priests could not stay inside to do their work.

6.19: But I ask you to answer my prayer.

6.40: LORD God, hear us when we pray in this temple.

7.1: As soon as Solomon finished praying, fire came down from heaven and burned up the offerings. The LORD's dazzling glory then filled the temple,
7.2: and the priests could not go in.
7.3: When the crowd of people saw the fire and the LORD's glory, they knelt down and worshiped the LORD. They prayed: "The LORD is good, and his love never ends."
7.6: Everybody stood up during the ceremony. The priests were in their assigned places, blowing their trumpets. And the Levites faced them, playing the musical instruments that David had made for them to use when they praised the LORD for his never-ending love.
7.7: On that same day, Solomon dedicated the courtyard in front of the temple and got it ready to be used for worship. The bronze altar he had made was too small, so he used the courtyard to offer sacrifices to please the LORD and grain sacrifices, and also to send up in smoke the fat from the other offerings.
7.8: For 7 days, Solomon and the crowd celebrated the Festival of Shelters, and people came from as far away as the Egyptian Gorge in the south and Lebo-Hamath in the north.
7.9: Then on the next day, everyone came together for worship. They had celebrated a total of 14 days, 7 days for the dedication of the altar and 7 more days for the festival.
7.10: Then on the twenty-third day of the seventh month, Solomon sent everyone home. They left very happy because of all the good things the LORD had done for David and Solomon, and for his people Israel.
7.11: The LORD's temple and Solomon's palace were now finished. In fact, everything Solomon had planned to do was completed.
7.12: Some time later, the LORD appeared to Solomon in a dream and said: I heard your prayer, and I have chosen this temple as the place where sacrifices will be offered to me.
7.13: Suppose I hold back the rain or send locusts to eat the crops or make my people suffer with deadly diseases.
7.14: If my own people will humbly pray and turn back to me and stop sinning, then I will answer them from heaven. I will forgive them and make their land fertile once again.
7.15: I will hear the prayers made in this temple,
7.16: because it belongs to me, and this is where I will be worshiped forever. I will never stop watching over it.
7.18: and I will keep my solemn promise to him that someone from your family will always be king of Israel.
7.20: I will pull you out of this land I gave you. I will desert this temple where I said I would be worshiped, so that people everywhere will think it is only a joke and will make fun of it.
7.21: This temple is now magnificent. But when these things happen, everyone who walks by it will be shocked and will ask, "Why did the LORD do such a terrible thing to his people and to this temple?"

8.1: It took 20 years for the LORD's temple and Solomon's palace to be built.
8.2: After that, Solomon had his workers rebuild the towns that Hiram had given him. Then Solomon sent Israelites to live in those towns.

8.4: He ordered his workers to build the town of Tadmor in the desert and some towns in Hamath where he could keep his supplies.
8.5: He strengthened Upper Beth-Horon and Lower Beth-Horon by adding walls and gates that could be locked.
8.6: He did the same thing to the town of Baalath and to the cities where he kept supplies, chariots, and horses. Solomon ordered his workers to build whatever he wanted in Jerusalem, Lebanon, and anywhere else in his kingdom.
8.10: Solomon appointed 250 officers to be in charge of his workers.
8.11: Solomon's wife, the daughter of the king of Egypt, moved from the part of Jerusalem called David's City to her new palace that Solomon had built. The sacred chest had been kept in David's City, which made his palace sacred, and so Solomon's wife could no longer live there.
8.12: Solomon offered sacrifices to the LORD on the altar he had built in front of the temple porch.
8.13: He followed the requirements that Moses had given for sacrifices offered on the Sabbath, on the first day of each month, the Festival of Thin Bread, the Harvest Festival, and the Festival of Shelters.
8.14: Solomon then assigned the priests and the Levites their duties at the temple, and he followed the instructions that his father, the man of God, had given him. Some of the Levites were to lead music and help the priests in their duties, and others were to guard the temple gates
8.15: and the storage rooms. The priests and Levites followed these instructions exactly.
8.16: Everything Solomon had planned to do was now finished--from the laying of the temple's foundation to its completion.
8.17: Solomon went to Ezion-Geber and Eloth, two Edomite towns on the Red Sea.
8.18: Hiram sent him ships and some of his experienced sailors. They went with Solomon's own sailors to the country of Ophir and brought back more than 15 tons of gold for Solomon.

9.1: The Queen of Sheba heard how famous Solomon was, so she went to Jerusalem to test him with difficult questions. She took along several of her officials, and she loaded her camels with gifts of spices, jewels, and gold. When she arrived, she and Solomon talked about everything she could think of.
9.2: He answered every question, no matter how difficult it was.
9.5: She said: Solomon, in my own country I had heard about your wisdom and all you've done.
9.6: But I didn't believe it until I saw it with my own eyes! And there's so much I didn't hear about. You are greater than I was told.
9.7: Your people and officials are lucky to be here where they can listen to the wise things you say.
9.8: I praise the LORD your God. He is pleased with you and has made you king of Israel. God loves the people of this country and will never desert them, so he has given them a king who will rule fairly and honestly.
9.9: The Queen of Sheba gave Solomon more than four tons of gold, a large amount of jewels, and the best spices anyone had ever seen.
9.13: Solomon received almost 23 tons of gold each year,
9.14: not counting what the merchants and traders brought him. The kings of Arabia and the leaders of Israel also gave him gold and silver.
9.15: Solomon made 200 gold shields that weighed over three kilograms each.
9.16: He also made 300 smaller gold shields that weighed almost two kilograms, and he put these shields in his palace in Forest Hall.
9.17: His throne was made of ivory and covered with pure gold.
9.18: It had a gold footstool attached to it and armrests on each side. There was a statue of a lion on each side of the throne,
9.19: and there were two lion statues on each of the six steps leading up to the throne. No other throne in the world was like Solomon's.
9.20: Solomon's cups and dishes in Forest Hall were made of pure gold, because silver was almost worthless in those days.

9.22: Solomon was the richest and wisest king in the world.
9.25: Solomon had 4,000 stalls for his horses and chariots, and he owned 12,000 horses that he kept in Jerusalem and other towns.

9.27: While Solomon was king, there was silver everywhere in Jerusalem, and cedar was as common as the sycamore trees in the western foothills.

9.29: Everything else Solomon did while he was king is written in the records of Nathan the prophet, Ahijah the prophet from Shiloh, and Iddo the prophet who wrote about Jeroboam son of Nebat.
9.30: After Solomon had ruled 40 years from Jerusalem,
9.31: he died and was buried in the city of his father David. His son Rehoboam then became king.

10.1: Rehoboam went to Shechem where everyone was waiting to crown him king.
10.2: Jeroboam son of Nebat heard what was happening, and he returned from Egypt, where he had gone to hide from Solomon.
10.3: The people from the northern tribes of Israel sent for him. Then together they went to Rehoboam and said,
10.4: "Your father Solomon forced us to work very hard. But if you make our work easier, we will serve you and do whatever you ask."
10.5: Rehoboam replied, "Come back in three days for my answer." So the people left.
10.6: Rehoboam went to some leaders who had been his father's senior officials, and he asked them, "What should I tell these people?"
10.7: They answered, "If you want them to serve and obey you, then you should be kind and promise to make their work easier."
10.8: But Rehoboam refused their advice and went to the younger men who had grown up with him and were now his officials.
10.9: He asked, "What do you think I should say to these people who asked me to make their work easier?"
10.10: His younger advisors said: Here's what we think you should say to them: "Compared to me, my father was weak.
10.11: He made you work hard, but I'll make you work even harder. He punished you with whips, but I'll use whips with pieces of sharp metal!"
10.12: Three days later, Jeroboam and the others came back.
10.13: Rehoboam ignored the advice of the older advisors. He spoke bluntly
10.14: and told them exactly what his own advisors had suggested. He said: "My father made you work hard, but I'll make you work even harder. He punished you with whips, but I'll use whips with pieces of sharp metal!"

11.1: After Rehoboam returned to Jerusalem, he decided to attack Israel and regain control of the whole country. So he called together 180,000 soldiers from the tribes of Judah and Benjamin.

11.3: to tell Rehoboam and everyone from Judah and Benjamin,

11.22: so he chose their oldest son Abijah to be the next king.

12.1: Soon after Rehoboam had control of his kingdom, he and everyone in Judah stopped obeying the LORD.
12.2: So in the fifth year of Rehoboam's rule, the LORD punished them for their unfaithfulness and allowed King Shishak of Egypt to invade Judah.
12.3: Shishak attacked with his army of 1,200 chariots and 60,000 cavalry troops, as well as countless Egyptian soldiers from Libya, Sukkoth, and Ethiopia.
12.4: He captured every one of the fortified cities in Judah and then marched to Jerusalem.
12.5: Rehoboam and the leaders of Judah had gone to Jerusalem to escape Shishak's invasion. And while they were there, Shemaiah the prophet told them, "The LORD says that because you have disobeyed him, he has now abandoned you. The LORD will not help you against Shishak!"
12.6: Rehoboam and the leaders were sorry for what they had done and admitted, "The LORD is right. We have deserted him."
12.7: When the LORD heard this, he told Shemaiah: The people of Judah are truly sorry for their sins, and so I won't let Shishak completely destroy them. But because I am still angry,
12.8: he will conquer and rule them. Then my people will know what it's like to serve a foreign king instead of serving me.
12.9: Shishak attacked Jerusalem and took all the valuable things from the temple and from the palace, including Solomon's gold shields.
12.10: Rehoboam had bronze shields made to replace the gold ones, and he ordered the guards at the city gates to keep them safe.
12.11: Whenever Rehoboam went to the LORD's temple, the guards carried the shields. But they always took them back to the guardroom as soon as he had finished worshiping.
12.12: Rehoboam turned back to the LORD, and so the LORD did not let Judah be completely destroyed, and Judah was prosperous again.
12.13: Rehoboam was 41 years old when he became king, and he ruled 17 years from Jerusalem, the city where the LORD had chosen to be worshiped. His mother Naamah was from Ammon. Rehoboam was a powerful king,
12.14: but he still did wrong and refused to obey the LORD.
12.15: Everything else Rehoboam did while he was king, including a history of his family, is written in the records of the two prophets, Shemaiah and Iddo. During Rehoboam's rule, he and King Jeroboam of Israel were constantly at war.
12.16: When Rehoboam died, he was buried beside his ancestors in Jerusalem, and his son Abijah became king.

13.1: Abijah became king of Judah in Jeroboam's eighteenth year as king of Israel,
13.2: and he ruled from Jerusalem for three years. His mother was Micaiah the daughter of Uriel from Gibeah. Some time later, Abijah and King Jeroboam of Israel went to war against each other.
13.3: Abijah's army had 400,000 troops, and Jeroboam met him in battle with 800,000 troops.
13.4: Abijah went to the top of Mount Zemaraim in the hills of Ephraim and shouted: Listen, Jeroboam and all you Israelites!
13.5: The LORD God of Israel has made a solemn promise that every king of Israel will be from David's family.
13.6: But Jeroboam, you were King Solomon's official, and you rebelled.
13.7: Then right after Rehoboam became king, you and your bunch of worthless followers challenged Rehoboam, who was too young to know how to stop you.
13.9: You don't even have descendants of Aaron on your side, because you forced out the LORD's priests and Levites. In their place, you appoint ordinary people to be priests, just as the foreign nations do. In fact, anyone who brings a bull and seven rams to the altar can become a priest of your so-called gods.
13.11: Two times every day they offer sacrifices and burn incense to the LORD. They set out the sacred loaves of bread on a table that has been purified, and they light the lamps in the gold lampstand every day at sunset. We follow the commands of the LORD our God--you have rejected him!
13.12: That's why God is on our side and will lead us into battle when the priests sound the signal on the trumpets. It's no use, Israelites. You might as well give up. There's no way you can defeat the LORD, the God your ancestors worshiped.
13.13: But while Abijah was talking, Jeroboam had sent some of his troops to attack Judah's army from behind, while the rest attacked from the front.
13.14: Judah's army realized they were trapped, and so they prayed to the LORD. The priests blew the signal on the trumpet,
13.15: and the troops let out a battle cry. Then with Abijah leading them into battle, God defeated Jeroboam and Israel's army.
13.16: The Israelites ran away, and God helped Judah's soldiers slaughter
13.17: 500,000 enemy troops.
13.18: Judah's army won because they had trusted the LORD God of their ancestors.
13.19: Abijah kept up his attack on Jeroboam's army and captured the Israelite towns of Bethel, Jeshanah, and Ephron, as well as the villages around them.
13.20: Jeroboam never regained his power during the rest of Abijah's rule. The LORD punished Jeroboam, and he died, but Abijah became more powerful.
13.21: Abijah had a total of 14 wives, 22 sons, and 16 daughters.
13.22: Everything Abijah said and did while he was king is written in the records of Iddo the prophet.

14.1: Abijah died and was buried in Jerusalem. Then his son Asa became king, and Judah had ten years of peace.
14.2: Asa obeyed the LORD his God and did right.
14.3: He destroyed the local shrines and the altars to foreign gods. He smashed the stone images of gods and cut down the sacred poles used in worshiping the goddess Asherah.
14.4: Then he told everyone in Judah to worship the LORD God, just as their ancestors had done, and to obey his laws and teachings.
14.5: He destroyed every local shrine and incense altar in Judah.
14.6: The LORD blessed Judah with peace while Asa was king, and so during that time, Asa fortified many of the towns.
14.7: He said to the people, "Let's build walls and defense towers for these towns, and put in gates that can be locked with bars. This land still belongs to us, because we have obeyed the LORD our God. He has given us peace from all our enemies." The people did everything Asa had suggested.
14.8: Asa had a large army of brave soldiers: 300,000 of them were from the tribe of Judah and were armed with shields and spears; 280,000 were from Benjamin and were armed with shields and bows.
14.9: Zerah from Ethiopia led an army of 1,000,000 soldiers and 300 chariots to the town of Mareshah in Judah.
14.10: Asa met him there, and the two armies prepared for battle in Zephathah Valley.
14.11: Asa prayed: LORD God, only you can help a powerless army defeat a stronger one. So we depend on you to help us. We will fight against this powerful army to honor your name, and we know that you won't be defeated. You are the LORD our God.
14.12: The LORD helped Asa and his army defeat the Ethiopians. The enemy soldiers ran away,
14.13: but Asa and his troops chased them as far as Gerar. It was a total defeat--the Ethiopians could not even fight back! The soldiers from Judah took everything that had belonged to the Ethiopians.
14.14: The people who lived in the villages around Gerar learned what had happened and were afraid of the LORD. So Judah's army easily defeated them and carried off everything of value that they wanted from these towns.
14.15: They also attacked the camps where the shepherds lived and took a lot of sheep, goats, and camels. Then they went back to Jerusalem.

15.1: Some time later, God spoke to Azariah son of Oded.
15.2: At once, Azariah went to Asa and said: Listen to me, King Asa and you people of Judah and Benjamin. The LORD will be with you and help you, as long as you obey and worship him. But if you disobey him, he will desert you.
15.3: For a long time, the people of Israel did not worship the true God or listen to priests who could teach them about God. They refused to obey God's Law.
15.4: But whenever trouble came, Israel turned back to the LORD their God and worshiped him.
15.5: There was so much confusion in those days that it wasn't safe to go anywhere in Israel.
15.6: Nations were destroying each other, and cities were wiping out other cities, because God was causing trouble and unrest everywhere.
15.7: So you must be brave. Don't give up! God will honor you for obeying him.
15.8: As soon as Asa heard what Azariah the prophet said, he gave orders for all the idols in Judah and Benjamin to be destroyed, including those in the towns he had captured in the territory of Ephraim. He also repaired the LORD's altar that was in front of the temple porch.
15.9: Asa called together the people from Judah and Benjamin, as well as the people from the territories of Ephraim, West Manasseh, and Simeon who were living in Judah. Many of these people were now loyal to Asa, because they had seen that the LORD was with him.
15.10: In the third month of the fifteenth year of Asa's rule, they all met in Jerusalem.
15.11: That same day, they took 700 bulls and 7,000 sheep and goats from what they had brought back from Gerar and sacrificed them as offerings to the LORD.
15.12: They made a solemn promise to faithfully worship the LORD God their ancestors had worshiped,
15.13: and to put to death anyone who refused to obey him.
15.14: The crowd solemnly agreed to keep their promise to the LORD, then they celebrated by shouting and blowing trumpets and horns.
15.15: Everyone was happy because they had made this solemn promise, and in return, the LORD blessed them with peace from all their enemies.
15.16: Asa's grandmother Maacah had made a disgusting idol of the goddess Asherah, so he cut it down, crushed it, and burned it in Kidron Valley. Then he removed Maacah from her position as queen mother.
15.17: As long as Asa lived, he was faithful to the LORD, even though he did not destroy the local shrines in Israel.
15.18: He placed in the temple all the silver and gold objects that he and his father had dedicated to God.
